webTitle: Dalglish set to leave post at Celtic

fields.headline: Dalglish set to leave post at Celtic
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish is likely to quit as Celtic's director of football after it was confirmed that the club's chief executive Allan MacDonald had talked with him about a severance deal.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish is likely to quit as Celtic's director of football after it was confirmed that the club's chief executive Allan MacDonald had talked with him about a severance deal.

Appointed to the post when John Barnes arrived last summer, Dalglish has been imperilled ever since the club embarked on their quest to find a new manager. Martin O'Neill arrived at Parkhead last week saying he wanted "full control of all football matters".

Dalglish, who earns £600,000 a year from Celtic, had been said to be on a seven-year contract, but this has proved to be fanciful. His pay-out, if the parting occurs, may be for as little as half that amount.

Even before O'Neill's arrival, relations between Dalglish and Celtic had become frosty. He took charge of the team in the wake of Barnes's sacking in February and they won only eight out of 16 games.

At a club bent on improving their image, a series of Dalglish-inspired PR disasters incensed the Parkhead directors. The most notable was his decision to hold pre-match press conferences in Glasgow pubs. These and other tensions led to Dalglish's last weeks of the season being marked by acrimony.

O'Neill did not rule out working with Dalglish, but if he does stay Celtic have been urging him to accept reduced terms to reflect his changed role. Dalglish has resisted taking a drop in salary and the upshot, it appeared yesterday, was inevitable separation.

"Kenny has been a good servant to Celtic and has the club at heart, but things have changed radically since last summer," said a Celtic director. "Whatever happens we want these things to be handled with dignity. The club, we hope, will make an announcement soon."

Even if Dalglish leaves his present post it is unlikely to be the end of his long association with the club, whom he joined at 16 and graced for a decade, becoming one of their most revered players, before moving to Liverpool in 1977. Celtic said they would like Dalglish to take on "an ambassadorial role" in Scotland or England, attracting youngsters to the club's planned youth academy.

webTitle: Net loss for Shearer but Keegan stands by his man

fields.headline: Net loss for Shearer but Keegan stands by his man
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has made it clear that Alan Shearer will start for England in the Euro 2000 finals despite the captain's problems with the net and on the Net.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has made it clear that Alan Shearer will start for England in the Euro 2000 finals despite the captain's problems with the net and on the Net.

Some 72% of 15,000 respondents in a poll conducted on a website felt that Shearer should no longer be a first-choice England striker. He last scored seven games ago.

However, Keegan is not only sticking doggedly by the Newcastle striker but says he knows his starting XI for England's Group A opener against Portugal on Monday.

"I know my team," he confirmed yesterday. "If everyone is fit - and they are at the moment - I know the 11 players who will start against Portugal. I've had it in my head for a long time, my ideal team.

"I do favour 4-4-2. But I've looked at everything, especially in these last three matches. I've looked at systems and players.

"But I will not be naming any team publicly or formation until just before each kick-off. This is a major tournament and I can't give anything away."

The only name he will give away is that of Shearer, who will retire from international football after Euro 2000. "Nothing that I've seen in these last three matches has influenced my opinion about him," said the coach. "I'm not naming my team, but if Alan Shearer is fit he will be the captain and centre-forward.

"He's lived with criticism and people questioning him for so long. It doesn't affect him. The people who respect him most are those closest to him. He's a great player and a key player."

Defending Shearer has become as familiar for Keegan as talking up his team's chances and his own belief in them. Far from panicking after the unimpressive outing against Malta, the England coach says he returned home to find himself in the rare position of falling asleep in his chair. This was not while watching a replay of England's scrappy 2-1 win but because, he says, he feels so relaxed heading into the tournament.

"In the dressing room I said to the players: 'I'm not going to start throwing teacups and shouting at you.' One of them said: 'It's just that we're ready for the tournament.' I said: 'That's where we'll end it, then. That's a good point to end on.'

"We were ready for the championships after Ukraine. The players are ready, I'm ready, the country is ready and we want to get going."

 The Premier League will not be forced into adopting a midwinter break even though it forms an integral part of a unified season which was formally backed by Fifa in Zurich yesterday. There is sufficient flexibility in the calendar to allow the current English fixture list. At the meeting Fifa agreed that the ill-conceived World Club Championship will be retained on a biennial basis.

fields.headline: Just don't call us Slovakia
fields.standfirst: Its footballers are aiming to put Slovenia on the map, writes  Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: Its footballers are aiming to put Slovenia on the map, writes Rory Carroll.
fields.body:
Marooned and ignored in a patch of central Europe since a dramatic birth nine years ago, Slovenia sails into the European Championship astonished that football is about to alert the world to its existence.

A squad of no-hopers playing an unfamiliar sport are poised to banish anonymity and succeed where a war of independence and earnest nation-building failed. Starting with its national anthem and teamsheet, the world will discover that between Austria and Croatia lies a country the size of Wales which feared it was forever fated to be confused with Slovakia.

Not known for being excitable, Slovenes are turning positively giddy. From the Julian Alps to the capital Ljubljana, flags are unfurling and optimism blooming.

The architects of it all, the footballers, have zoomed from near-zeros to heroes. Kicking a ball around a field, or watching others do so, has never held much joy or beauty for their 1.9m countrymen. Skiing, ice hockey, hiking and basketball is where the action is. Or was, until against all the odds a fairytale unfolded.

Finishing eight points behind Norway in a weak group, Slovenia staggered into a play-off expecting to receive the coup de grace from Ukraine. Instead about 9,000 fans inside the Ljubljana ground witnessed the substitute Milenko Acimovic intercept a pass six minutes from time and score with a lob from near the halfway line. A 2-1 victory.

"I have never scored a goal like that before and I still can't believe I did it," gasped Acimovic. His epiphany was replayed endlessly.

Miracle No2 arrived in Kiev in the away leg when Slovenia held Ukraine to a 1-1 draw in a blizzard. The team returned home at 2am to 5,000 freezing, delirious fans. President Milan Kucan hailed them as the best Slovenian athletes on snow.

"This is brilliant. We've had a lot of clubs and people asking about the country, the history, everything," said Angela Rennie, of the Slovenian tourist office in London. "They only know Slovenia as the one which started it all." It, in this case, is the break-up of Yugoslavia. Alarmed at the 1991 crackdown in Kosovo by the Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic, Slovenia stockpiled weapons and after a 10-day war with federal troops became the first of the Yugoslav republics to gain independence.

Joining the United Nations, being visited by Prince Charles and initiating daily flights from Heathrow failed to raise its profile. That is what happens when you become a stable liberal democracy rather than an ethnic conflagration. "It stayed out of the news, you see," explained Rennie.

For the past two weeks all attention has turned to the training base in Brdo, 15 miles north of Ljubljana. A bullish mood is growing. The squad and the coach Srecko Katanec have discounted bookmakers' odds of 80-1 against winning the championship. "Of course we are the underdogs," Katanec said. "This is normal. But things do happen in football so there could be a surprise."

His team came close to a major upset in a friendly at the Stade de France in April, racing to a 2-0 lead against the world champions before losing 3-2 in injury-time. After Saturday's 2-0 win at home to Saudi Arabia Katanec said: "I think we will be a big problem for all our opponents if we play as we did today."

Inevitably Zlatko Zahovic, Slovenia's inspiration, got the first goal against the Saudis. A playmaker and goalscorer, he is free to roam across the otherwise rigid 3-5-2 system.

The Olympiakos player, once of Porto, is short of match practice after first going on strike - claiming the Greek league was full of "jealous, lazy and unprofessional" players - and then being suspended for two months by his club for swearing at the coach, but he has been working with a personal trainer. Of the 15 goals the team scored to reach these finals, the 29-year-old got 10.

"People look at me as the star," said the man known as ZZ Top, "but it is the team that is the star. That is how we have come so far: by teamwork."

Katanec, a former Sampdoria and Yugoslavia player, has imposed a rigorous work ethic. Asked if his players had been dope-tested yet, he replied: "No, but we will be soon because we have been training so hard no one will believe us."

That the first match next Tuesday should be against Yugoslavia has galvanised the team and nation. "Whatever else happens we will not lose that one," growled a spokesman for the national football association.

Two of the Slovenia squad played for Yugoslavia before independence. But for Acimovic the game carries particular resonance. Not only does he play for Red Star Belgrade but his sister is married to the Lazio and Yugoslavia midfielder Dejan Stankovic. "I play in Yugoslavia. I know how they play and it's possible to beat them," Acimovic said. "I do believe that." Spain and Norway follow.

Whatever happens, Slovenia reckons Euro 2000 will secure its place in the public consciousness. Possibly as a winner, more likely as a loser, but definitely as a player.

webTitle: Lib Dem voting rebuff for Kennedy

fields.headline: Lib Dem voting rebuff for Kennedy
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy's plans to move to one member one vote democracy inside the Liberal Democrats have been blocked by his own executive.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy's plans to move to one member one vote democracy inside the Liberal Democrats have been blocked by his own executive.

In a sign that Mr Kennedy has yet to get a full grip on his party's organisation, an emergency meeting of the party's executive overturned a previous decision to hold a referendum on one member one vote for the party's key committees.

The federal executive had voted a fortnight ago to hold a referendum of the party's 90,000 membership on whether future elections to the party executive and policy committee should be held by one member one vote. The move had been promoted on the executive by MP Lembit Opik.

At present, the two senior party committees are elected by conference delegates.

Protests over the referendum decision and the speed with which it had been taken, led to the calling of a special executive meeting on Monday night, which overturned its own previous decision. Senior Liberal Democrat officials admitted that Mr Kennedy had been defeated on the issue.

Critics claimed the referendum was being held before a proper party debate. Some also baulked at the £22,000 cost, and the subsequent £50,000 a year to hold annual elections. The executive has now agreed that the issue will be first discussed at the party conference before holding a further discussion within the party. One executive member, who led opposition to "the shotgun referendum" on the executive, said "a small group of people were intent on putting a spanner in the works just when we are gathering some momentum after the Romsey byelection. The one thing we do not need now in an divisive internal debate."

Donnachadh McCarthy, a critic of co-operation with Labour, claimed direct election for key party bodies would end political accountability in the party.

fields.headline: A word to the wise
fields.standfirst:
The way we work Richard Reeves

www.workunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: The way we work Richard Reeves: If ignorance is bliss, we are in trouble.
fields.body:
If ignorance is bliss, we are in trouble. Knowledge is suddenly everywhere, tripping off the tongues of politicians and business leaders - as a necessary prefix to "economy", "industry", "worker" - spawning new breeds of consultants and creating whole industries. The hot corporate job is now CKO - not, as I thought, a trendy scent but Chief Knowledge Officer. Organisations are rushing to build knowledge management systems and the "knowledge economy" is said to be our only hope for the future.

There is something paradoxical about this elevation of knowledge just at the point in history at which it can be more easily acquired than ever before. In the days when it took hours in a dusty library to discover the outcome of the battle of Gettysburg, the Latin term for sunflower, or the details of Wade v Roe, having that knowledge in your head really meant something. Now you can just Ask Jeeves. Internet search engines and CD-roms have taken the kudos out of knowledge. Knowledge might once have been power - now it is just a click away.

Maybe we actually need less knowledge, not more. New ailments are springing up: "information overload" and "burnout". Even before we get to our desks and turn on our PCs, we have been drenched in knowledge - there is more information in the newspaper you are holding than a typical person was exposed to during their entire lifetime 300 years ago.

With this glut of information and easily-accessed knowledge, we should be striving for the ability to contemplate creatively, to distinguish between informational gold and garbage. It is wisdom we should be seeking, not knowledge. We proudly acknowledge our desire to be healthy and wealthy - whatever happened to wise?

Forget MBAs and NVQs. Turn instead to philosophy and a warning from Montaigne about early signs of knowledge-mania in 16th-century France. "The absurdity of our education: its end has not been to make us good and wise, but learned. It has not taught us to seek virtue and to embrace wisdom. We ought to find out not who understands most but who understands best." A wise economy might be less frantic than the dot.com-driven knowledge one, might contribute less to gross domestic product, but it would be more humane, longer-lasting, less panicky and more fun.

A greater emphasis on wisdom could also have a profound impact on the way older workers are treated. Most of us get wiser as the years pass. If wisdom and experience were properly valued, employees over 50 would be seen as critical to the success of an organisation, rather than as a burden.

How, then, to become wiser? Given that the entire workforce cannot decamp to the Sorbonne, the opportunity to gather wisdom on the job is vital. It would be wonderful indeed if work could be a place where we endeavour to create, together, something of value to the world and where we deepen our understanding of that world and our place within it.

Sadly, 21st-century work - constructed under the shadow of the shareholder - leaves most of us none the wiser. Not enough has changed since the Indian chief Smohalla voiced his views on the nine to five. "My young men shall never work. Men who work cannot dream, and wisdom comes in dreams."

Who asked you?

One of the favoured reasons macho managers give for not consulting with colleagues and staff is that decisions have to be made too quickly for any mucking about of that commie nature. If you are one of those who believes fast decisions need strong, individualistic leaders, Norm Bowie, Dixon's Professor of Business Ethics at the London Business School, has bad news for you. In a study of decisions taken by the crews of commercial airliners in crisis situations, it turns out that, even if there were only 10 seconds in which to take corrective action, the quality of the decision taken improved if there was some consultation between the captain and first officer. As Bowie said in a talk last week: "Sure, there are some decisions that need to be taken quickly in business. But how many are taken that quickly?"

Bowie had a stern warning, too, for companies who think gimmicks can substitute for a progressive approach to staff relations. A major US manufacturing firm hung a neon sign flashing "Quality counts" above its factory floor and introduced a Quality Cat mascot to boost spirits. A disgruntled employee described the workers' considered response: "We heaved beer cans at the sign and kicked the crap out of the cat."

Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

fields.headline: Up, up and, er ...
fields.standfirst: Diary of a dream
fields.trailText: For years, Tony Blair had his heart set on being PM. Now he's made it, he admits he's wondering what to do next. Sally Weale examines the aftermath of ambition
fields.body:
You've got a good job, you're doing well, you're climbing the career ladder as fast as you can. But have you ever stopped to think what will happen when you reach the top rung? Is it possible to be too successful, too young?

The prime minister touches on this very issue this week in an interview in the Blairs' favourite women's magazine, Prima. In an illuminating aside, he pauses to consider what life will hold for him once he leaves office. "I don't know whether I believe in a mid-life crisis," Blair says enigmatically. "But there is a point where you think back and wonder, what were the ambitions I started with, what am I going to do for the rest of my life and what will I do when I have fulfilled my ambitions."

He still has a lot he wants to achieve as prime minister, he says - but it's what he will do afterwards that is more troubling. Having done the most important job in the country, having fulfilled his greatest ambitions, what can possibly lie ahead? What happens when you've done it all - and you're still not even 50? It is a predicament that reflects a growing trend in society. People are achieving their goals, realising their ambitions and making their fortunes at a younger age than ever before.

Traditionally, in business and in politics, it might take decades to work one's way to the top; even the most talented had to "do their time", fortunes were accrued slowly but surely and highfliers often did not peak until their late 50s. Today, you can be prime minister at 44, a chief executive in your 30s and an e-millionaire before you've left home.

American internet tycoon Mark Cuban was just 41 when he sold his company for $6b. He had always known he would be wealthy - he worked hard to make his company, broadcast.com, a success. After selling up to Yahoo, he celebrated in Las Vegas and the Bahamas, then came home to face the rest of his life. His ambition had always been to make a fortune - having made it so early in life, what came next? "His plan to get rich had never included a plan to be rich," as one American journalist pointed out.

But Cuban, it seems, is coping very well with the problem of being young and rich. First he bought himself all the usual billionaire's trappings - a $13m Dallas chateau, a $40m jet. Then he realised another lifelong ambition and bought a basketball team, for $280m. The Dallas Mavericks are one of the worst teams in the league, making Cuban's next challenge to turn around their fortunes and start making more money.

For people like Cuban and Blair, the drive and ambition that have brought them such extraordinary success so early in life is simply redirected into something else. "This phenomenon is more prevalent than ever before," says Cary Cooper, professor of occupational psychology at Manchester University. "People are getting to senior positions much younger. Twenty years ago, a chief executive of a company would have been about 55. Now they are between 35 and 40, and they are looking around and saying: 'Now what am I going to do?' I don't call it a mid-life crisis, I call it a mid-career crisis."

Nevertheless, Cooper believes such people will find something to do. "They all do. Quite a lot of senior executives in industry go through a period of uncertainty after they've become an entrepreneur, built up a company - you've done that, you've been there, what do you do now? What these people should say to themselves is: 'I've achieved everything I wanted to achieve, what use can I make of the experience I have?' It frees you up to achieve something you really care about, something you almost certainly could not achieve when you were in office."

This was certainly the case for Jimmy Carter. Chased out of the White House at the age of 56 after a disastrous term as US president, he went on to become a freelance global diplomat of enormous influence. "I'm one of the youngest survivors of the White House," he said, "and I've been able to utilise the experience and knowledge and prestige and access to leaders, and to complete some of the things I was not able to complete in the White House."

More often, deposed politicians set up their foundations, write their memoirs, then sit on the sidelines reminiscing about their time in office. For loss of power is not the only blow to the highly successful: loss of visibility also hurts.

"In a role like prime minister or chief executive of a company, you are in the public eye all the time," Cooper points out. "It may have a cost in terms of your private life, it may constrain a whole range of activities you'd like to do but can't - but lots of people miss that visibility. Being in the public eye makes you feel important and when you leave office, you don't have the reinforcement of your role by the media." As Carter said of leaving the White House and returning to his failing peanut farm in his home town: "Nobody was begging for my presence."

So what do those thrusting entrepreneurs who have set up thriving businesses and made millions in their 20s dream about for the future? Are they worried that they're doing it all too young and there will be little left to strive for?

Jason Drummond certainly isn't losing any sleep over it. Just 30, he is the founder of Virtual Internet and is worth an estimated £40m. "There's no doubt the world of work has changed," he says. "You know how you used to have to do your time, no matter how good you were? That's certainly all gone. What will come out at the other end, I've no idea. Probably people will aspire to different things, not only in business but in other aspects of their life, too. I've got two young children and they are probably the thing I'm most proud of."

As for his own future, Drummond says: "Since I was 16, my ambition was to build a successful business. We are now a fully listed, fully quoted PLC and that's quite a good achievement. But there are always new challenges. Now I'm excited about going up from a medium-sized to a large business." Then what? "Even larger."

Entrepreneurs like Drummond will always find alternative goals. They don't just set up one business and make it successful, they do it again and again. Others develop a philanthropic impulse - 51-year-old computer millionaire Peter Ogden last year donated £25m to fund talented children from modest backgrounds to attend top fee-paying schools.

"Human beings are very resilient," Cooper concludes. "Yes, there are people who never recover, who never come to terms with losing their influence and their visibility. But the majority ultimately find another niche, another role."

fields.headline: Unilever clinches Bestfoods deal
fields.trailText: Unilever announced a $20.3bn (£13.5bn) agreed takeover of Bestfoods, the US food group, yesterday in a deal that marks the Anglo-Dutch consumer group's largest purchase yet.
fields.body:
Unilever announced a $20.3bn (£13.5bn) agreed takeover of Bestfoods, the US food group, yesterday in a deal that marks the Anglo-Dutch consumer group's largest purchase yet.

The takeover was announced after a month-long pursuit of its target. Bestfoods, which sells products such as Hellmann's mayonnaise and Knorr soup in 110 countries, initially rejected a Unilever offer of $66 a share.

It succumbed to a $73 a share offer, a premium more than 40% on its share price just before Unilever revealed its interest just over a month ago. Unilever's investors supported the bid even though the company effectively bid against itself in trying to win board acceptance of its offer.

Shares in Unilever were up almost 1% immediately after the deal was announced in New York. Shares in Bestfoods had risen 10% to more than $69 just before the deal was announced, after the board attended a meeting last night.

John Macmillan, food analyst at Prudential Securities, said the deal marked the beginning of more consolidation in the global food industry.

He added that it made strategic sense for both sides and the Bestfoods management team had extracted a good price from Unilever.

He described the company's reported talks with several takeover targets including Campbell's Soup of the US as "smoke and mirrors". Unilever said it would employ an "all-star team approach" to selecting which managers should stay with the combined group.

Niall Fitzgerald, Unilever co-chairman, predicted savings of £750m before 2003. "We were quite determined to be patient and deliberate about it as we wanted Bestfood's management to come in willingly."

webTitle: FSA to open financial store for best deals

fields.headline: FSA to open financial store for best deals
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The financial services authority is to set up a call centre to give buyers of mortgages, pensions and investments a list of the best products to take out in a move that has sent shockwaves through Britain's independent financial advisers.
fields.body:
The financial services authority is to set up a call centre to give buyers of mortgages, pensions and investments a list of the best products to take out in a move that has sent shockwaves through Britain's independent financial advisers.

Buyers will also be able to consult league tables on the FSA's website allowing them to select products according to criteria such as price, charges and flexibility - although not including past performance, which the financial watchdog says is a poor indicator of future success.

The database will come into operation next year and fulfils a pledge made in the 1999 Budget by the chancellor to give consumers league tables that will "guarantee a better deal and avoid the mis-selling of the past". The move is a radical shift for the watchdog, which until now has focused on regulating the selling process and has avoided top 10-style lists.

One FSA insider likened the league tables to a financial supermarket in which consumers will be able to choose products although the checkouts will be run by the product providers. The FSA will not sell any products or give individual product advice.

But investment advisers immediately warned consumers not to attempt do-it-yourself financial buying. Paul Smee, head of the Association of Independent Financial Advisers, said: "This will only give you basic product information and no guidance on whether the product is right for you.

Product providers also warned that consumers might wrongly select products because, for example, they did not know the difference between life insurance and critical illness insurance.

But privately they admit that the database will eliminate "commission bias" in which sales staff steer buyers into products which pay the highest commission.

fields.headline: House prices have peaked - Halifax
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Housing price rises have passed their peak, according to Britain's biggest mortgage lender, which said yesterday that property prices fell 0.4% in May - the third monthly decline in four months.
fields.body:
Housing price rises have passed their peak, according to Britain's biggest mortgage lender, which said yesterday that property prices fell 0.4% in May - the third monthly decline in four months.

The data from the Halifax reveals that the average home fell in value by £365 to £84,290 last month. This caused the annual rate of house price inflation to fall to 11.2% from 14.2% in April. In January annual price growth was running at 16%.

The figures are the latest in a series of sets of data which show the property market as slowing down following the exceptional surges of the last 18 months, during which time prices have risen at their fastest rate since 1989. The Halifax, and Nationwide building society, the two leading commentators on house prices, frequently disagree over the state of the property market, but for once both are in agreement that prices fell 0.4% last month.

The new figures will strengthen the case for leaving interest rates unchanged when the Bank of England's monetary policy committee makes its monthly decision today.

Three price falls in four months could be said to represent a partial "correction" following the sharp rises in prices late last year and early this year, said the Halifax

It believes the slowdown is largely in response to the four mortgage rate rises since last September and the abolition of mortgage interest tax relief in April, which between them have added nearly £750 to the annual mortgage bill of a typical borrower with a £60,000 home loan.

The Halifax said a rapid slowdown was unlikely - it predicts that annual house price growth will stabilise at around its current level over the coming months, and will end the year at 12%.

There was further good news for the MPC in a survey showing that retail prices fell for the second month a row in May, according to the Confederation of British Industry. The CBI found that sales were at a three-month peak but that retailers had cut prices to move their goods.

Halifax house price index
Nationwide house price index
Land Registry house price index

fields.headline: Elizabeth and Essex
fields.standfirst: Philharmonia/ Richard Hickox Royal Festival Hall ****
fields.trailText: Philharmonia/ Richard Hickox Royal Festival Hall ****
fields.body:
"One of the great disasters of operatic history," was how the 1953 opening night of Britten's Gloriana was described at the time - and that was by one of the composer's friends. It's not hard to see why the opera didn't initially catch on. The audience of New Elizabethan grandees at the Covent Garden premiere, six days after the coronation, must have been expecting something unambiguously celebratory of their new young queen. Instead they got Gloriana, a series of tableaux involving an elderly, sometimes selfish, undignified Elizabeth I and her relationship with the Earl of Essex. Richard Hickox, however, put together a convincing case for the work with this performance, part of the Philharmonia's Britten Series.

The score isn't easy to pace - each of the earlier scenes closes with an orchestral climax, while the later ones mostly fade out. Hickox kept something in reserve in his orchestra, so that the effect when they did let rip was thrilling. The six extra trumpets presented their opening fanfares with a rousing swagger; elsewhere the brass blended mellifluously, and the strings negotiated plucked passages at breakneck speed with remarkable clarity. On this occasion the Philharmonia really was an orchestra of virtuosos working together as a team.

Hickox assembled a top-notch cast for this concert performance, with singers including Janice Watson, Catherine Wyn Rogers and Roderick Williams in supporting roles. Tenor Thomas Randle really performed as Essex, projecting the essence of the insolent yet vulnerable courtier every moment he was on the stage. This sense of involvement was lacking in Christine Brewer's performance of the title role. Her singing itself was imperious, but she remained visually detached. However, although much of the burden of the score falls to Elizabeth and Essex, this Gloriana was a team effort, and even the most fleeting solos, from Gail Pearson and James Gilchrist, were sung very strongly.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Voting blueprint for pension funds
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The National Association of Pension Funds is to start advising pension funds on how to exercise their votes at the annual meetings of companies in which they own shares.
fields.body:
The National Association of Pension Funds is to start advising pension funds on how to exercise their votes at the annual meetings of companies in which they own shares.

Next week the NAPF will issue a template of recommended responses for pension funds - up to 50% of which still do not vote at agms - on corporate governance issues such as board structure and executives' pay.

The long-expected move follows government calls for greater shareholder pressure on boardrooms. If members follow the NAPF recommendations that would affect 25% of shareholdings.

The NAPF's policy document, Towards Better Corporate Governance, is being posted to pension fund managers and trustees. In some instances it takes a tougher stance than the "combined code" which listed companies must adhere to.

The voting recommendations will vary from company to company but it appears that the NAPF will not permit the roles of chairman and chief executive to be combined or allow share options to be re-priced when a company share price has underperformed.

For regulatory reasons, the NAPF's voting issues service, headed by John Rogers, will not be able to recommend how shareholders vote on takeovers or acquisitions. However, Mr Rogers said, in the case of the 400 biggest British companies it would make recommendations on resolutions put to agms.

The template, which is expected to cover 14 potentially controversial corporate governance issues, will be available for all agm resolutions from July 3 and in addition to being made available to pension fund trustees will appear on the NAPF's eVote system, which allows shareholders to register votes electronically.

In the foreword to the document, Alan Rubenstein, chairman of the NAPF investment committee, said: "It is our ardent hope that the introduction of clear policy positions, agreed by the NAPF, together with templates to assist voting, will go a long way towards helping pension funds achieve a higher level of active participation in the governance of UK companies, to their and the whole economy's benefit."

While the NAPF template will give pension fund trustees less excuse not to vote, they will also be able to over-rule any recommendations made by the body. Pension funds will soon have to make statements about how they vote.

The move will also increase the competition between the NAPF and Pirc, the pensions investment research company.

fields.headline: A ham, sandwiched
fields.standfirst: Robert Clark Henry Moore Foundation Studio, Halifax ***
fields.trailText: Robert Clark Henry Moore Foundation Studio, Halifax ***
fields.body:
The critic Michael Fried, attacking the new American artists of the 60s, accused them of "theatricality". Since then, artists have joyfully trodden on this anti-theatrical prejudice, and installation has become the dominant form of art. The Henry Moore Foundation Studio at Dean Clough, with its stone vaults and iron pillars, is the perfect stage for Robert Clark's Plans for the Real World Parts 1-12, an installation that is also a potted history of the genre.

Clark is also a critic - one who contributes to this paper, infact - and it shows in this sequence of 12 chambers containing calf-skin gloves, scorched paintings, scrawled letters, even an art encyclopaedia. There are invocations of Joseph Beuys and Anselm Kiefer, and an overall chaos that says, in red smeared letters, Julian Schnabel. None of these artists are the kind Michael Fried would have in his modernist club. On the contrary they are preening, bombastic, stagy types, and Clark - almost wistfully - emulates their grand manner of performance.

A white lobby has a wall text that makes the theatrical game explicit: "The space, a temporary set-up. The protagonists, not all there. The audience, unknown." Inside you study props, costumes, bits of script. Bits of black lace, phallic elephant's tusk, shower curtain and saucy snapshots tell us this is a self-exposing male sexual confession.

Desire is a will-o'-the-wisp and so is the content of this installation. The best bit is only visible through a glass window as you look down the length of Clark's wooden structure to see the spine of iron columns concealed by his painted rooms. The spookiness of this sealed space drew attention to the fussiness of the rooms. As he seems to be aware, this artist is a bit of a ham.

Until June 17. Details: 0113-246 7467.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Clark is also a critic - one who contributes to this paper, infact - and it shows in this sequence of 12 chambers containing calf-skin gloves, scorched paintings, scrawled letters, even an art encyclopaedia. There are invocations of Joseph Beuys and Anselm Kiefer, and an overall chaos that says, in red smeared letters, Julian Schnabel. None of these artists are the kind Michael Fried would have in his modernist club. On the contrary they are preening, bombastic, stagy types, and Clark - almost wistfully - emulates their grand manner of performance. A white lobby has a wall text that makes the theatrical game explicit: "The space, a temporary set-up. The protagonists, not all there. The audience, unknown." Inside you study props, costumes, bits of script. Bits of black lace, phallic elephant's tusk, shower curtain and saucy snapshots tell us this is a self-exposing male sexual confession. Desire is a will-o'-the-wisp and so is the content of this installation. The best bit is only visible through a glass window as you look down the length of Clark's wooden structure to see the spine of iron columns concealed by his painted rooms. The spookiness of this sealed space drew attention to the fussiness of the rooms. As he seems to be aware, this artist is a bit of a ham. Until June 17. Details: 0113-246 7467. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Bamboozled by tables? You might still be

fields.headline: Bamboozled by tables? You might still be
fields.standfirst:
FSA gets down to the ABCs
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Notebook FSA gets down to the ABCs
fields.body:
Want to find the best mobile phone deal? The telecoms regulator is about the last place you would try. Looking for the best train fare? The strategic rail authority will not help out. But from next spring the financial services authority will go further than any other watchdog in telling consumers what to buy.

Yesterday the FSA fleshed out the promise made by the chancellor in the 1999 Budget to give consumers product league tables to avoid a repeat of the mis-selling scandals that have plagued the industry. Initially the FSA, more used to regulating the selling process rather than offering best-buy tables, backpedalled hard and convinced the Treasury to accept alphabetically listed tables rather than price-ranked ones.

But it has now gone further than Gordon Brown could have hoped, and will send callers to the FSA bespoke tables of products depending on what they are interested in buying, the amount of money they have and their age. It is the biggest step yet towards DIY financial advice, and comes with a government stamp of approval.

Predictably, financial advisers have dismissed this invasion of their manor as full of risks, with dim-witted consumers taking the wrong product off the FSA supermarket shelf. Others will decry market interference by nanny-state regulators and the end of caveat emptor .

Few consumers will agree. Caveat emptor works when you can test-drive a car, but not with financial products - you cannot test-drive a pension. You find out you bought a dud 30 years later.

The best financial advice is still the preserve of high income individuals who can afford a fee-based adviser rather than one swayed by commission. What the FSA tables will do is empower middle market purchasers who are too easily bamboozled by laptop-waving salesmen or by glossy brochures at high-charging banks.

The product providers will attempt to lure buyers with add-on features that enable them to increase charges. But the existence of the tables will exert even greater downward pressure on charges that CAT standards are already bringing to stakeholder pensions and unit trusts.

One mild concern remains. With alphabetical listing, can it be long before Aardvark Insurance launches and goes straight to the top of the table? And Zurich Insurance may rue the day it dropped the Allied tag.

BA's big ticket

We are witnessing what appears to be one of the most exciting developments in the airline business, the takeover of one flag carrier by another. In this case, one of those involved is our own national service, British Airways, which is likely to announce today that the Dutch line, KLM, has coyly agreed to step into bed.

While the industry is rife with rumours that the Swiss are about to do a deal with the Belgians, and the French and the Spanish are closely eyeing each other up, BA and KLM seem to be ahead of the pack.

The deal comes at a time when BA has quietly started to reduce business fares across the North Atlantic. For years, it has been using its unassailable position at Heathrow to charge exorbitantly on these high yield routes. Possibly because of its potential link with KLM it has reconsidered its position. It needs to keep premium business, as it managed this week when it announced a 10% increase in business travel in one month.

Bloated prices on North American routes will not please KLM. Its comparable charges to the US can be around half those of BA. And if Sir Michael Bishop of British Midland gets a toehold in the US, then prices will have to be even more competitive.

Congratulations then to BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington, who rightly accepts that BA cannot go on trading on past glory.

BASF rings in

This afternoon BASF chairman Jürgen Strube will be ringing the opening bell on the New York stock exchange to mark his company's Wall Street debut. But will he one day be wringing his hands?

BASF sees plenty of advantages in bringing its shares to the market. It should raise BASF's profile in a key area and it will provide an acquisition currency which may well come in handy. It will also set BASF directly alongside its US peers in the eyes of the investment community, and the company can certainly promote itself as an underpriced share in an underpriced currency.

But it remains a conglomerate in days when focus is thought to count. It has the basis for steady long term growth - but since when did that cut much ice on Wall Street?

BASF's share price could do with a tow. If US listing does not provide it, Mr Strube may find he has raised the profile in places he would rather not have done. Wall Street is not short of merger and acquisition specialists.

webTitle: BA in merger talks KLM announcement today

fields.headline: BA in merger talks KLM announcement today
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: British Airways and the Dutch airline KLM are expected to confirm today that they are to proceed with merger talks.
fields.body:
British Airways and the Dutch airline KLM are expected to confirm today that they are to proceed with merger talks.

Industry sources last night said that an announcement was imminent and could be made in the next 24 hours. They said that BA had already appointed investment bankers to advise it in talks on what amounts to a friendly takeover by BA of the Dutch airline.

Speculation in the market yesterday suggested that BA had appointed a number of investment banks to advise it on the deal. Among those mentioned was UBS Warburg.

If the takeover goes ahead, it will be regarded as a triumph for BA's newly appointed chief executive, Rod Eddington, brought in to succeed the sacked Bob Ayling. Mr Eddington has already indicated that he believes the company's future should involve forging greater links in Europe.

BA staff were last night excited at the prospect of a merger with an airline which they say is very much like their own - they say KLM is seen as reliable and professional, with a good reputation both at home and abroad.

The terms of the potential deal remain unclear, but the goal is a full merger of the two carriers. If the deal is completed, it would be one of the first cases of one airline acquiring a majority stake in a foreign carrier.

These deals are complicated because the bilateral treaties permitting airlines to fly to foreign countries specify an airline's country of ownership.

So if BA were to buy KLM, some countries might say that KLM was no longer a national carrier, forcing Holland to renegotiate its air service agreements.

Up to now, airlines have avoided this situation by buying minority shares and establishing international alliances like Star Alliance, founded by United Airlines and Lufthansa. Industry sources said that BA and KLM would not be going ahead with their deal if they felt they had not faced the issue.

The deal will turn BA and KLM into the largest airline in Europe, providing them with the two important hubs at Heathrow and Schiphol.

The deal would lead to the end of the airlines' two low cost carriers, Go, owned by BA, and Buzz, owned by KLM. A newly strengthened "Buzzgo," with its base at Stansted, and more routes, would pose a threat to other low cost carriers in the market.

fields.headline: Going under ground
fields.standfirst: The Tunnel Clyde Tunnel, Glasgow **
fields.trailText: The Tunnel Clyde Tunnel, Glasgow **
fields.body:
Like London, Glasgow is fiercely divided into north and south. Some residents go a whole life without crossing the divide, but many of those who do use the Clyde Tunnel, an unprepossessing subterranean half-mile that was recently the setting for Roddy Buchanan's award-winning video, Gobstoppers.

Enter one Stephen Skrynka into the cycle and pedestrian tunnel to create a site-specific sound installation. Sixty-four speakers transmit furtively recorded sounds from the city, plus sounds made using the graffiti text found on the tunnel's walls. Transcribed by the artist and then whispered, chanted and shouted through speakers that line the route, this invisible wave of words -some filthy, much sectarian, some just crackers - travels at different speeds. So far, so good. The tunnel has been spookily lit, so it looks like the kind of place that haunts uneasy dreams.

The limitation of the project comes from a clash between the found space and concept. Not only did the tunnel already emphatically embody all the life, contradictions and dangers the intervention seeks to highlight - none of which are amplified by the installation, ironically - but Skrynka has taken it upon himself to whitewash over the graffiti after copying it all down. There are some photographs of it visible through peepholes he has installed and there will be a book of the text he has covered up.

This act of appropriation nags. What gives an artist - anyone - the right to do this, not just the painting over but the transferring into book form? For three weeks, the tunnel is made clean, safe and well lit. Afterwards, the artist and the invigilators will leave and it will turn back into the kind of place you might not want to walk through alone, another place some of us can choose to avoid. So who is the vandal now?

Until June 18. Details: 0141-576 7956.

fields.headline: Armenian dynamism
fields.standfirst: Night Ark Pizza Express, London ****
fields.trailText: Night Ark Pizza Express, London ****
fields.body:
World jazz may be the big hope of every major record label with a jazz department, but Night Ark, the quartet that mixes jazz, electronics and Armenian folk music, is no convenient slice of ethnic tourism. Its members are Ara Dinkjian, who specialises in the oud, an Arabic stringed instrument; dynamic percussionist/singer Arto Tuncboyaciyan; American jazzers Jim Beard (keys) and Tim Lefebvre (bass). The band represents one of the best blends of rootsy materials and hard-nosed jazz improvisation to have emerged in recent years.

A freewheeling looseness is part of the band's secret. Somebody dropped a fork during the hushed and spacious electronic opening to the evening, and though the band didn't drop a stitch musically, they all unconcernedly cracked up. Tuncboyaciyan's singing then entered - a clear, insistent chanting, flickering with microtonal yodellings, gradually reinforced by his own drumming.

Those who thought that Night Ark were the kind of world jazz ensemble in which the jazz was a splash of opportunistic colouring on a canvas of formal ethnic set-pieces were soon put right. Out of a faster, dance-like theme in which Beard's keyboards resembled a marimba and Dinkjian's jaunty oud lines were resolved in the bustle of Lefebvre's bass phrasing, an almost McCoy Tyner-like jazz piano group emerged. Tuncboyaciyan also indicated that the distance between his culture and Latin America's was narrower than might be expected, as he appled dynamic hand-drumming and a kind of whispering Armenian scat to a samba-like vibe. Front-runners in an overcrowded world music market.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: British Airways confirms merger talks with KLM

fields.headline: British Airways confirms merger talks with KLM
fields.standfirst: BA to announce merger talks
fields.trailText: British Airways confirmed today that it has entered talks with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines about a possible merger.
fields.body:
British Airways confirmed today that it has entered talks with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines about a possible merger.

If successful, an alliance would create the world's third largest airline, behind United Airlines and American Airlines.

The combined airline would be valued at more than £5bn with a fleet of almost 600 aircraft.

A deal could, however, face significant regulatory hurdles in Europe and the United States. British Airways said in a statement that it would be making no further public comment "until there is anything material to say". British Airways cautioned that the talks were at a preliminary stage and might not "result in any transaction between the parties".

Speculation about a deal between British Airways and KLM began after KLM called off a joint venture with Alitalia SpA in late April. On Monday, KLM confirmed that it wanted to find a new partner within a year.

British Airways and KLM last attempted to merge in 1992, but the deal broke down over the issue of valuations. Analysts had been expecting pairings in the airline industry to intensify after the recent announcement that UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, has agreed to acquire US Airways for $4.3bn (£2.8bn).

webTitle: Carphone Warehouse defies jittery market to press on with £1bn float

fields.headline: Carphone Warehouse defies jittery market to press on with £1bn float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse is planning to announce its much anticipated stock market flotation in the next few days, producing a company valuation of between £800m and £1bn.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse is planning to announce its much anticipated stock market flotation in the next few days, producing a company valuation of between £800m and £1bn.

The firm is pressing ahead in the face of recent market turmoil that has caused a series of hi-tech float cancellations. The retailer has awarded the mandate to investment banks Credit Suisse First Boston and UBS Warburg.

The mobile phone company has made 35-year-old founder Charles Dunstone one of the best-known businessmen in Britain, and its flotation will make him one of the richest.

Share options are also expected to be awarded to virtually the entire UK staff, leaving Mr Dunstone with roughly 50% of the group and chief executive David Ross holding around a third. Post flotation, some 25% of the company is expected to be on the market.

Carphone Warehouse has long resisted flotation, with Mr Dunstone being said to be suspicious of the City and fearful of its effect on the firm's culture. Carphone Warehouse denied reports as recently as March that it was drawing up plans to go to market.

Mr Dunstone is understood to have been convinced by the need for financial flexibility ahead of mobile phone sales being driven to new heights by wireless internet. Third generation services with high speed web access and video capability are expected to launch in Britain during 2002.

Carphone Warehouse has also been actively expanding in Europe, and is likely to use its shares as currency for further acquisitions.

Sales last year were £350m and are expected to reach £600m this year.

But Carphone Warehouse has not had everything its own way in the UK. The retail business has come under increasing pressure from new entrants such as supermarket chains and from the four networks building their own high street presence. Vodafone, BT Cellnet, Orange and One2One have been expanding aggressively, buying up independent chains in order to cut the commission paid to middlemen.

Sir Richard Branson's Virgin group has also started selling its own mobile phone service direct to consumers.

Mr Dunstone and Mr Ross founded Carphone Warehouse in 1989 with just £6,000.

The company harbours ambitions beyond the retail sector and in January launched a £30m fund to invest in wireless technology and internet ventures. Carphone has also launched a mobile phone service under the Value Telecom brand, buying airtime wholesale from the One2One network. Mr Dunstone was not available for comment.

fields.headline: Exchange merger revolt
fields.standfirst:
Top German companies fear London listings will kill their index
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Frankfurt stock exchange is facing the prospect of a revolt by some of Germany's top companies against its plans for a merger with London.
fields.body:
The Frankfurt stock exchange is facing the prospect of a revolt by some of Germany's top companies against its plans for a merger with London.

Senior executives at a number of companies from the Dax index, made up of the shares in Germany's top 30 companies, are worried they may be forced to list in London after the merger and are also unsettled by speculation that the Dax index could be abandoned, according to Max Dietrich Kley, deputy chairman of German chemicals group BASF.

Unless their concerns are addressed they may consider action which might include switching to another German exchange or setting up an alternative index to the Dax.

The companies have already set up a working party to consider the implications of the merger and possible responses, and Mr Kley - who is in New York for BASF's Wall Street debut - is to seek an urgent meeting with the Deutsche Börse's chief executive, Werner Seifert, when he returns to Germany.

The Anglo-German alliance is designed as a crucial step in moves towards pan-European equity trading but has come under fire in both countries. Under the terms of the deal agreed between the boards of the two exchanges, but not yet approved by the London stock exchange's members or Deutsche Börse shareholders, London would be the administrative centre for the merged exchange and the centre for blue chip shares - including the Dax stocks.

Frankfurt would provide the trading platform and be the centre for high growth stocks.

Mr Kley, who is also president of the German Institute for Share Promotion, said yesterday that a merger between London and Frankfurt, as a first step towards greater stock market integration in Europe and in the much longer term at a global level, was in "the right corridor" but, he said, the companies for whom the exchange provided a service should have been consulted.

"We are the people who are necessary to the stock exchange because it is our shares that are traded. They should have asked us about the implications [of the merger] but no-one has been in touch."

"We have been reading in the newspapers that the Dax shares will be traded in London, that we might have to list again in London, that the legal regime and the corporate governance will be London's."

Such issues could pose significant problems for German companies, which have two tier board structures - a supervisory and an executive board - rather than the single board used by UK companies.

He added: "There has been speculation that the importance of the Dax could go down after the merger, that there could be another index.

"The Dax is important to German investors.

"If there were a new index you could not exclude they would sell some of their shares. It could happen that you would get a certain pressure on [some] German shares as a result of this."

Asked what the companies could do if the exchange did not take their concerns on board, Mr Kley warned: "We have some alternatives. The regional stock exchanges in Germany are linked to the Xetra [trading platform]. Dax shares could be traded through Xetra from Dusseldorf or Stuttgart."

Mr Kley delivered a strong hint that the companies could set up a replacement if Frankfurt scrapped the Dax. "The Dax is a trademark of the Deutsche Börse, but people can be innovative."
fields.bodyText: The Frankfurt stock exchange is facing the prospect of a revolt by some of Germany's top companies against its plans for a merger with London. Senior executives at a number of companies from the Dax index, made up of the shares in Germany's top 30 companies, are worried they may be forced to list in London after the merger and are also unsettled by speculation that the Dax index could be abandoned, according to Max Dietrich Kley, deputy chairman of German chemicals group BASF. Unless their concerns are addressed they may consider action which might include switching to another German exchange or setting up an alternative index to the Dax. The companies have already set up a working party to consider the implications of the merger and possible responses, and Mr Kley - who is in New York for BASF's Wall Street debut - is to seek an urgent meeting with the Deutsche Börse's chief executive, Werner Seifert, when he returns to Germany. The Anglo-German alliance is designed as a crucial step in moves towards pan-European equity trading but has come under fire in both countries. Under the terms of the deal agreed between the boards of the two exchanges, but not yet approved by the London stock exchange's members or Deutsche Börse shareholders, London would be the administrative centre for the merged exchange and the centre for blue chip shares - including the Dax stocks. Frankfurt would provide the trading platform and be the centre for high growth stocks. Mr Kley, who is also president of the German Institute for Share Promotion, said yesterday that a merger between London and Frankfurt, as a first step towards greater stock market integration in Europe and in the much longer term at a global level, was in "the right corridor" but, he said, the companies for whom the exchange provided a service should have been consulted. "We are the people who are necessary to the stock exchange because it is our shares that are traded. They should have asked us about the implications [of the merger] but no-one has been in touch." "We have been reading in the newspapers that the Dax shares will be traded in London, that we might have to list again in London, that the legal regime and the corporate governance will be London's." Such issues could pose significant problems for German companies, which have two tier board structures - a supervisory and an executive board - rather than the single board used by UK companies. He added: "There has been speculation that the importance of the Dax could go down after the merger, that there could be another index. "The Dax is important to German investors. "If there were a new index you could not exclude they would sell some of their shares. It could happen that you would get a certain pressure on [some] German shares as a result of this." Asked what the companies could do if the exchange did not take their concerns on board, Mr Kley warned: "We have some alternatives. The regional stock exchanges in Germany are linked to the Xetra [trading platform]. Dax shares could be traded through Xetra from Dusseldorf or Stuttgart." Mr Kley delivered a strong hint that the companies could set up a replacement if Frankfurt scrapped the Dax. "The Dax is a trademark of the Deutsche Börse, but people can be innovative."

fields.headline: Blatter urges England game switch
fields.trailText: Euro 2000 organisers insisted yesterday that England's match with Germany will go ahead in Charleroi on June 17, even though the Fifa general secretary had added his voice to those calling for the game to be switched to another venue.
fields.body:
Euro 2000 organisers insisted yesterday that England's match with Germany will go ahead in Charleroi on June 17, even though the Fifa general secretary had added his voice to those calling for the game to be switched to another venue.

"I don't know the stadium. But I do know that the Belgium government has expressed its concerns to [the European governing body] Uefa," Sepp Blatter told Die Welt, a German newspaper.

"Playing the game in another stadium should be considered. I am absolutely convinced that this is being thought about."

However, the joint Dutch-Belgian organisers were quick to rule out any change. "Everything remains the same - nothing will change," a Euro spokesman retorted. "If it was going to be moved, it would have been done long before now. It has not been discussed at all and with less than two weeks before the game there will not be a change."

Fifa has no jurisdiction over Euro 2000, which is a Uefa tournament, and Blatter's comments less than a week before the opening game will not have been welcomed.

Concerns about the suitability of the stadium at Charleroi arose as soon as the draw was made. The ground is hemmed in by other buildings, so the extra seating needed to bring the capacity up to 30,000 was installed at a particularly steep angle.

Last month the Belgian parliament's home affairs committee visited the ground and expressed its concern about the implications for safety. "We fear for the worst," said Pieter de Crem, a member of the committee.

Blatter, meanwhile, has spoken of his desire to keep thugs away from the tournament. "We must try to block their entry," he said. "In England the various hooligan organisations are known.

"However, they could still travel with their European passports. There are so many ways to travel nowadays. We cannot control everyone."

Prosecutors in both host countries have argued that they have neither the staff nor the resources to ensure that plans for speedy prosecutions of offenders can be carried out.

"Quick justice for Euro 2000 is not going to be that easy because of the availability of manpower and means," said Brussels' general prosecutor, Benoit Dejemeppe.

"It all depends on the means. In Antwerp, for example, we can only apply it during working days, not on weekends," added Bart van Lijsebeth, the city's general prosecutor.

England play Germany on Saturday week.

Scotland, Wales and the Republic of Ireland will next month discuss the possibility of a joint bid to host Euro 2008. The Wales FA general secretary David Collins pointed to the successful joint hosting of the rugby union world cup and said: "At chief executive and president level there have been talks although these have not been held formally yet." The Scottish FA chief executive David Taylor confirmed that Ireland had already broached the subject.

webTitle: Hosts face up to ticket traumas

fields.headline: Hosts face up to ticket traumas
fields.standfirst: Tournament organisers admit their plans are impossible to implement
fields.trailText: Tournament organisers admit their plans are impossible to implement.
fields.body:
The organisers of Euro 2000 admitted yesterday that their supposedly watertight security policy of allowing into grounds only fans who are carrying tickets bearing their names is already showing worrying signs of leakage.

And, with thousands of fans set to converge on Belgium and the Netherlands this week, the ambitious plan appears to be impossible to implement given the congestion expected in and around stadiums.

"Perhaps our threat to turn away fans who are carrying tickets which do not bear their names has not been properly thought out," said the Euro 2000 spokesman Michel van Schie. "We will not have the resources to implement this policy. There is no way that we will be able to check every fan that is going into a ground."

Euro 2000 organisers, like their predecessors at France '98, had hoped that the names-on-tickets policy might deter supporters from buying them on the black market. But, as in France, those who have bought a ticket through a third party, assuming they behave reasonably, are unlikely to have a problem gaining admission to a ground.

All tickets for Euro 2000 will carry a name. Those that are purchased through national football associations will bear the name of the relevant organisation, while those that have been purchased independently will carry the name of the person who bought them.

Tournament organisers concede that their sales policy was designed to ensure that all tickets are traceable to somebody. All national football associations have had to provide a list of fans who have purchased tickets from them while a large number of tickets, almost 30% of the total allocation of 1.2m, have been sold over the internet.

Fans buying tickets over the counter in Holland and Belgium have had to produce proof of identification and declare their address. "We know the names of everybody who has bought tickets and our sales policy is connected to the security of stadiums," said Van Schie. "One way or another, we will be able to trace who has bought tickets."

But, while all tickets have been sold directly by Euro 2000, the tournament's organising body, officials admit that there is little they can do if a fan in England sells on a ticket to another supporter who is then arrested for causing trouble at a match.

"Technically the person whose name is on the ticket is responsible for that ticket," he added. "They can be held accountable if it finds its way into somebody else's hands. But there is little we can do. We have to rely on authorities in England to take action."

Tournament organisers concede that officials in the 16 countries taking part are unlikely to have the time or resources to track down origi nal purchasers of tickets who may have sold them on.

The problem highlights one of the grey areas in Euro 2000's ticketing strategy, although football fans groups and national associations are satisfied that, for once, genuine supporters have been put before commercial interests in the allocation of tickets.

"It's a very decent allocation," said a Football Association source. "We have sold all of our tickets and have provided a list of who has purchased them to organisers."

Euro 2000 worked closely with the governments of Belgium and Holland in drawing up their ticketing policy. Initially they wanted fans to be able to buy a maximum of four tickets each so that families could attend matches but this was revised to a maximum of two tickets per person to ensure that large groups could not gather in grounds.

Once initial requests for tickets had been received, the applicants' names were checked against lists of known hooligans supplied by police forces across the continent. As a result, around 200 people were refused tickets.

Special laws have also been introduced in Belgium and Holland to outlaw black market sales and a number of companies in both countries are to face prosecution for offering tickets, although little can be done against firms outside the Low Countries.

Furthermore, organisers have warned that fans will be subject to spot checks, particularly at games where there is the potential for trouble. All those attending games will have to carry some form of identification.

"Everyone runs the risk of being checked," added Van Schie. "If the police see fans misbehaving or trying to enter a part of the ground set aside for opposition fans, they will have the right to turn them away."

Ticket distribution

The breakdown of the 1.2m tickets made available for Euro 2000 was as follows:

General public: 39% (or 470,000 tickets)

Participating associations: 36% (430,000)

Commercial partners: 12% (144,000)

Press and media: 6% (72,000)

Hospitality: 5% (60,000)

Uefa and Fifa: 2% (24,000)

webTitle: Kitchen sink drama means no fire in Spanish bellies

fields.headline: Kitchen sink drama means no fire in Spanish bellies
fields.trailText: Spain's forwards are expected to do some damage to European defences at Euro 2000 but they are not half as dangerous as the team's cooks - at least not in the eyes of the Dutch, who have ruled the Spanish catering operation unsafe.
fields.body:
Spain's forwards are expected to do some damage to European defences at Euro 2000 but they are not half as dangerous as the team's cooks - at least not in the eyes of the Dutch, who have ruled the Spanish catering operation unsafe.

The team's five cooks were planning to prepare food in three tents for the squad at the Spanish team's base at Tegelen in eastern Netherlands but the fire brigade have ruled the roofs are too low and the risk of a fire is too great. The cooks have had to resort to using a local catering firm's facilities.

"We will be cooking until 11 in the morning," the Dutch news agency ANP quoted the catering firm's manager as saying. "Then we'll hand over to the Spaniards until two. They'll take a siesta until five and be back at the stoves after that."

The Spanish play their first match against Norway on June 13 in Rotterdam.

Dozens of Benfica fans gathered outside the Stadium of Light in Lisbon yesterday to protest against the club's decision to cut short the contract of the team captain Joao Pinto.

Pinto had four years of a seven-year contract to run. "I'm unemployed," the 28-year-old forward said, adding that he was open to offers from other clubs.

Spain's Real Sociedad said yesterday that they had verbally agreed to sign the Turkey midfielder Arif Erdem from Galatasaray.

webTitle: Guardian woman elected to Luton board

fields.headline: Guardian woman elected to Luton board
fields.trailText: Yvonne Fletcher, the Guardian's sports desk manager, will be unveiled as Luton Town's first female director today.
fields.body:
Yvonne Fletcher, the Guardian's sports desk manager, will be unveiled as Luton Town's first female director today.

The Luton-born fan takes the post of the elected supporters' representative and will be invited to take a seat in the boardroom by the new septuagenarian owner Mike Watson-Challis.

Watson-Challis had asked a committee member of the Fans of Luton Action Group (Flag) to join the board in recognition of the work it did in helping to save the Second Division club, who went into receivership in March 1999.

Fletcher saw off the challenge of two other supporters to be elected as one of Luton's five directors. She will be on an equal footing with the other four, unlike the "Fan on the Board" at Manchester City under Francis Lee. "People say 'You'll be there to deal with the season-ticket prices, the pies and the toilets', but it's a directors' position like anyone else's, so I will be involved in all areas," she said.

Fletcher, who has spent 30 years watching Luton, will renew her season-ticket for next season and divide her time at home games between the directors' box and her usual seat, spending 45 minutes in each.

"I hope for better communication," she said, "so the board understand what the supporters want and value, and the supporters understand better the decisions by the board.

"A lot of animosity is down to lack of knowledge and information. I would like to set up monthly surgeries at which fans can talk to directors and ask questions."

Luton are the second club with an elected supporters' representative on their board, after Northampton Town.

fields.headline: Gascoigne plans foreign finale
fields.trailText: Paul Gascoigne says he will play out the final chapter of his turbulent career abroad but hopes to remain at Middlesbrough until the end of next season.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne says he will play out the final chapter of his turbulent career abroad but hopes to remain at Middlesbrough until the end of next season.

The 33-year-old midfielder, who was linked with a move to Joondalup City in Perth last month, admitted that he has had offers from clubs in Australia and the United States. He has not played a competitive game for Middlesbrough since breaking his arm against Aston Villa in February.

"I will definitely go abroad but I just don't know where or when," Gascoigne said. "It could be America or Australia. I haven't decided yet.

"I have been offered jobs in both of those countries, so I will have to think seriously about my future. I'm going to see what happens at the end of the season and talk to the manager Bryan Robson but I definitely want to play football as long as I can."

Dave Jones, whose position as Southampton's manager was put on hold in January, will face the club at a Premier League management arbitration tribunal in 15 days' time over his claim that he is owed £300,000 from the remainder of his contract.

Southampton placed Jones, who will answer 17 child abuse charges in November, on 12 months' paid leave to allow him to prepare for his court case but the former Stockport manager claims that he was sacked and is owed money for the 2 years that were left on his contract when he was replaced by Glenn Hoddle.

Jones will be supported at the tribunal by the League Managers Association chief executive John Barnwell.

webTitle: Now every goalkeeper wants to be a clown

fields.headline: Now every goalkeeper wants to be a clown
fields.trailText: Over the past couple of decades the notion of the crazy goalkeeper has been re-inforced by the endless propaganda put out by Bob Wilson.
fields.body:
After England's faltering display in Malta Kevin Keegan said: "Maybe it's good we've got a performance like that out of our system." Plainly the England boss was echoing some Anfield boot-room legend that a team can produce only a finite number of hapless performances. This is a comforting notion but it is also untrue. Otherwise Luxembourg would be surfing on a sparkling wave of victories until well into the next millennium. In football, however, mythology shapes past, present and future.

Another example came last week, when Manchester United signed Fabien Barthez. Clearly there are some attributes a goalkeeper needs: agility, quick reflexes and the ability in dire emergencies to, in the words of Big Ron, "make himself big" rather after the manner of an inflatable life raft. More important than this, however, the custodian must also satisfy the myth by being mentally unhinged.

Barthez is a top-class professional and has plainly been working on the psychological side of his game. He has shaved his head, grown a goatee and now numbers swimming with the dolphins at his local marina among his hobbies. At his first press conference the Frenchman summed up his philosophy of life: "I start from the principle that the more you shout at each other the better it is."

While Fabien is unlikely to get a job as a counsellor with Relate, he is clearly top-class modern goalkeeping material. I say modern because I suspect the notion of the eccentric between the posts is of recent provenance. Certainly there were goalkeepers in the distant past who were wild and wacky but surely not so many as there are today.

A few years ago football was branded "the new rock 'n' roll". Later in some eyes comedy became "the new rock 'n' roll", presumably leaving football as the new skiffle. I do not hold with this development. To my mind football is still the new rock 'n' roll and goalkeepers are the drummers. They are men who have to behave in an outlandish manner in order to draw attention to themselves - because, just as no one fancies the drummer, likewise it is a sad child indeed who dons a replica goalkeeper's jersey.

Over the past couple of decades this notion of the crazy goalkeeper has been re-inforced by the endless propaganda put out by Bob Wilson. Though many of the ITV frontman's contemporaries, Pat Jennings and Ray Clemence for instance, were such slaves to dull rationality that they make Delia Smith look like Don King, the Arsenal old boy rarely misses an opportunity to remind us of the sheer lunacy of the netminding fraternity.

Possibly this is because Bob himself was very much the Keith Moon of his profession. The Who drummer infamously drove his Rolls Royce into an LA swimming pool.

The Arsenal goalkeeper, meanwhile, is reported to have once steered his Rover 2000 in through the out gate of a car park in Hatfield. Like many of the wilder celebrity stories, though, this may be apocryphal.

Ever since Wilson began his campaign more and more mad goalkeepers have appeared - mad, I should say, in a footballing sense. Jorge Campos wears flamboyant outfits but he does not sit at the back of the team coach rambling about space monkeys. Ed de Goey may look like the eponymous anti-hero of some straight-to-video stalk-and-slash movie but he does not march around the West End wearing a sandwich board predicting armageddon unless we all stop eating peanuts this minute.

Some types of weirdness would probably not be encouraged even by Bob Wilson. But Sweden's defence in the 1994 World Cup was doubtless strengthened by the presence of wild-eyed Tomas Ravelli. It would surely increase the concentration of any centre-half to know the man standing behind him looked as if he would have been happier chasing Shelley Duvall around the Overlook Hotel with an axe than picking the ball out of the net.

Wilson's tireless campaign has had an impact on football thinking. Nowadays one suspects that, just as coaches look for pace in strikers, they are also actively seeking delirium in potential keepers.
