Ever since Wilson began his campaign more and more mad goalkeepers have appeared - mad, I should say, in a footballing sense. Jorge Campos wears flamboyant outfits but he does not sit at the back of the team coach rambling about space monkeys. Ed de Goey may look like the eponymous anti-hero of some straight-to-video stalk-and-slash movie but he does not march around the West End wearing a sandwich board predicting armageddon unless we all stop eating peanuts this minute. Some types of weirdness would probably not be encouraged even by Bob Wilson. But Sweden's defence in the 1994 World Cup was doubtless strengthened by the presence of wild-eyed Tomas Ravelli. It would surely increase the concentration of any centre-half to know the man standing behind him looked as if he would have been happier chasing Shelley Duvall around the Overlook Hotel with an axe than picking the ball out of the net. Wilson's tireless campaign has had an impact on football thinking. Nowadays one suspects that, just as coaches look for pace in strikers, they are also actively seeking delirium in potential keepers.

fields.headline: England draw no comfort
fields.standfirst:
England 374 & 147
Zimbabwe 285-4 dec & 25-1
Match drawn
fields.trailText: Of all the test sides, surely only England have the capacity to win a series and yet generate such a feeling of utter gloom. The draw they extracted yesterday from the rain-ruined second Test ensured that they clung on to a lead gained at Lord's, an event accompanied then by such euphoria that street parties and a thanksgiving service in Westminster Abbey would not have been out of the question.
fields.body:
Of all the test sides, surely only England have the capacity to win a series and yet generate such a feeling of utter gloom. The draw they extracted yesterday from the rain-ruined second Test ensured that they clung on to a lead gained at Lord's, an event accompanied then by such euphoria that street parties and a thanksgiving service in Westminster Abbey would not have been out of the question.

In this match, though, they have been reminded in the strongest terms possible that they are a side of such violent mood swings that they could do with counselling as much as coaching. England held on to win the series with all the style, panache and lightness of touch of Fatty Arbuckle tapdancing.

For two days, first as Murray Goodwin scored his memorable century and then yesterday as the Zimbabwe bowlers worked their way with embarrassing ease through the England top order, they have been outplayed and, until the overs began to run out, it was they who were floundering.

If this match had been billed in some quarters as England's chance to generate a feelgood factor to take into the forthcoming West Indies series then it is Zimbabwe instead, pride restored, who will carry the good vibrations into the triangular series while the resurgent West Indies, who will have been watching with interest, will scarcely be quaking. England are capable of good things but they remain vulnerable.

It could have been the dullest of last days. Instead, Zimbabwe's declaration, albeit 75 minutes before play - they would have bowled at England on the fourth evening had bad light not intervened - appeared to catch England on the hop. Mark Ramprakash, Nasser Hussain and Nick Knight, opening in place of Mike Atherton whose absence from the field on Sunday meant he was unable to bat until the fifth wicket fell, all departed to the new ball, the first two to the teenage debutant Mluleke Nkala, bringing his match haul to a creditable five. By lunch Alec Stewart had followed.

At the start of the penultimate over before tea, with the score 113 for seven and a lead of 202, there was still an outside chance if Zimbabwe could finish the innings off quickly that there would be time to have a dart at pulling off a remarkable win. Perhaps the match was destined to finish with Andy Caddick and Darren Gough bowling two feet wide of the stumps and the Zimbabwean coach Andy Pycroft saying they flippin' murdered 'em.

Instead Atherton, playing the only responsible innings of the day, struck three successive boundaries off Brian Murphy's leg spin to rubber-stamp, just about, England's escape.

Atherton was superbly caught at backward point for 34 shortly after tea and England were finally all out for 147, their lowest total against Zimbabwe, leaving the visitors with a maximum of 13 overs to face.

In the five overs used before the draw was agreed there was time for Grant Flower to be caught at second slip in Caddick's first over. It was Ramprakash who brought things to a conclusion with an over of passable impressions of the great fast bowlers. He might profitably try doing Viv Richards with the bat.

The presentations brought a man-of-the-match award to Goodwin for his unbeaten 148 and man-of-the-series awards to Atherton for England and Heath Streak for Zimbabwe.

At a time when England have been looking to consolidate, there have been more questions raised than answered. None of the top-order batsmen distinguished themselves yesterday, with Ramprakash edging the first of Andy Flower's five catches, Hussain lbw to something from Nkala that might have been going over the top of the stumps and Knight, short of footwork, comprehensively yorked by Streak.

Later, Stewart was caught behind attempting to withdraw his bat from a short ball and Andy Flintoff and Graeme Hick also fell to the wicketkeeper.

Hick had played solidly enough for 2 hours for his 30. But the last 75 minutes of his stay, after lunch, contained no boundaries and brought just 10 runs with his inelegant swish at a wide ball from the newly shaven-headed Neil Johnson either the stroke of a man desperate to get a move on or one who believed the job to have been completed already.

The most disappointing innings, though, was from Flintoff, who some had ear marked prematurely for full-time promotion up the order. Atherton's stomach ailment on Sunday gave him the chance at six yesterday and he failed to grasp it.

Flintoff is a mighty hitter of the ball but test cricket involves rather more than that, demanding intelligence and technique as well. The bare statistics tell a tale: 62 deliveries faced with 16 runs scored, including a six biffed over long-off and a four. Six runs, in other words, from the remaining 60 balls. Flintoff's power demands that the field sits deeper, but no attempt was made to milk the singles that were on offer as a consequence.

His technique against the moving ball needs tightening too and left Graham Gooch, for one, shaking his head as Streak worked him over and then dismissed him.

webTitle: Atherton seeks his own cure as England display old ills

fields.headline: Atherton seeks his own cure as England display old ills
fields.standfirst: The series is won but West Indies bring on that queasy feeling
fields.trailText: The series is won but West Indies bring on that queasy feeling once again, reports David Hopps
fields.body:
If England's relapse into bad habits of old became increasingly hard to stomach over the final two days at Nottingham, that was particularly so in the case of Michael Atherton. He will see a gastro-enterologist this week about the recurring intestinal problems that dogged him throughout the second test.

Had Atherton been unwell yesterday, and been unable to bat at No7, then England might have been faced with explaining away a calamitous defeat and a drawn Test series against a Zimbabwe side that had been widely derided as test also-rans after their innings defeat at Lord's only a fortnight earlier.

Remove Atherton's 2 hours at the crease and Zimbabwe's run chase, while still demanding, would have been within the realms of possibility. After his first-innings century, which was good enough for him to be named as England's man of the series, it should not have been necessary to extricate them from a mess of their own making.

Atherton is likely to skip Lancashire's championship match against Hampshire, which begins at Liverpool today. "He has had this gastric trouble a couple of times in the past, so he is going to see a specialist to check it out," said his captain Nasser Hussain.

His overriding concern will be that his stomach ailment is linked both to his long-standing back problem and the painkillers and anti-inflammatory drugs that he has regularly taken to alleviate the condition.

As Hussain is painfully aware, any captain trying to analyse England's form on a weekly basis would assuredly send himself insane. England.com would rank as the most wildly fluctuating share in a volatile market. At Lord's they were the hottest stock around; by the time they pulled stumps in Nottingham they were not worth a hill of beans. Not that Atherton, in his current state, would be wise to add to his diet.

The bookmakers have observed all England's inconsistencies, recalled the West Indies dreadful recent record outside the Caribbean and installed England as slight favourites for the forthcoming five-Test series.

Neither Hussain, nor Zimbabwe's captain Andy Flower, agreed with the bookies' contention. Flower suggested: "England can beat the West Indies but statistically I don't think they deserve to be favourites."

Those statistics are daunting: West Indies have won 10 of the last 13 series between the teams, with three drawn, winning 35 tests and losing only six. Hussain responded: "If one team hasn't beaten another for 31 years, it is hard to see how they can be favourites. If we play well, we can beat the West Indies but we will have to play a lot better than we did here."

It would be difficult to complete a series victory less convincingly. Nick Knight, opening in place of Atherton, and Andrew Flintoff both again manifested known technical defects and Chris Schofield's retreat towards square leg against bowlers of moderate pace will have been savoured by the West Indian quicks.

But it was Mark Ramprakash's testy response to his dismissal, which brought England most regret and which indicated that, however much lip service is paid to his more relaxed state of mind, Ramprakash plus poor dismissal will always equal irascibility.

Ramprakash's crime was to poke his bat in the direction of a roving Sky TV cameraman, who intruded a little too closely upon his private grief as he entered the pavilion.

The match referee, Graham Dowling from New Zealand, was unperturbed but, if Ramprakash had wanted to attack one of Sky's 32 cameras, a most popular choice would have been the movable eye introduced on the boundary edge which has whizzed perkily up and down a track throughout the series like some higher life form from a Spielberg movie.

webTitle: Favourite to succeed Wigley launches bid

fields.headline: Favourite to succeed Wigley launches bid
fields.trailText: June 6 2000: Ieuan Wyn Jones, the odds on favourite to succeed Dafydd Wigley as leader of Plaid Cymru, yesterday declared his hand.
fields.body:
Ieuan Wyn Jones, the odds on favourite to succeed Dafydd Wigley as leader of Plaid Cymru, yesterday declared his hand.

At his campaign launch in Cardiff Bay Mr Jones, the MP and Assembly Member for Ynys Mon (Anglesey), said Plaid Cymru, which stunned Labour by capturing the Rhondda and Islwyn in last year's assembly election, must reach out to new supporters in urban and city areas and "build on the support from non-Welsh speakers".

He would be putting forward a "positive programme" outlining how to achieve Plaid's immediate objective of full law making powers for the national assembly while maintaining a belief in eventual "full national status" within the EU. Mr Wigley announced last week that he is to stand down as head of the party on medical grounds after almost a decade as president. Mr Jones, 51, who will relinquish his Westminster seat at the general election, favours splitting the roles of president of the party and assembly leader but is putting his name forward for both so the party as a whole can decide who the leader in the assembly should be.

Two other potential candidates for the leadership, the MEP Jill Evans, and Helen Mary Jones, who chairs the Plaid Cymru group in the assembly, are expected to make their intentions known later this week. Nominations close on June 30 and voting will take place on a one member one vote basis at branch meetings in July.

webTitle: High flyers heading for a fall

fields.headline: High flyers heading for a fall
fields.standfirst: It's not clever to spend your rock 'n' roll years swotting for Oxbridge | Fashion's silliest fad Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: It's not clever to spend your rock 'n' roll years swotting for Oxbridge | Fashion's silliest fad
fields.body:
One of the cleverest people I know - a redbrick university lecturer whose first book is a well-received treatise on postmodernity - would not conform to Blair and Brown's definition of a high achiever. As a fan of anarcho punk band Crass and opposer of "authority", he flunked his A-levels at 18 with a view to proving to "them" that his resistance to being graded - as if for market - was a sign of intellectual independence.

When "they" failed to log this gesture, my friend upped the ante by refusing to retake, telling his vicar father that he didn't have time for any of that bollocks. Declaring his intention to continue with his "music" rather than apply for university, he left the parental home to squat in south-east London with the drummer out of Flowers in the Dustbin and a dog called Moroccan Black.

Loath as I am to add my tuppenceworth to the ongoing Laura Spence debate, there is something people are missing. All this talk of making Oxford and Cambridge more accessible to lower-class "high flyers" rests on the presumption that "high flyers" are, by definition, people who spend their teenage years OD-ing on Brodie's Notes. Exactly why this group of oddballs necessarily comprises an "elite" is as hard to account for as the fact that neither side of this argument is prepared to address the ridiculous and pernicious notion that early academic achievement is what separates the "best and the brightest" from demotivated losers like my intellectual friend and myself. Anyone who thinks this has committed the cardinal error of mistaking swottiness for ability and "all must win prizes" obsession for genuine commitment and drive.

In order to acquire her 10 A-starred O-levels Laura Spence must have worked her arse off. Night after night, when friends were getting up to teenage mischief, she would have climbed the stairs to her bedroom with a full litre bottle of Evian, an alarm clock and a sheaf of past papers. Now, as then, we've no way of telling how clever she is. She may well be one of those students with a blotting-paper brain for facts. On the other hand, many averagely intelligent people can overcome considerable hurdles with the right combination of cramming and parental pressure.

As long as they are willing to sacrifice all semblance of a life, a swotty B-type student is (I would hazard) more likely than a better-rounded A-type one to bring home the A-type grades. Who, after all, would choose to pass their rock 'n' roll years writing up science experiments? Isn't there a case for saying that the "best and the brightest" may well have been otherwise occupied - guerrilla gardening, perhaps, or snogging - when their course work assessments were due?

Certainly, at my sixth form college, the people who applied for Oxbridge were, to a girl and boy, spooky, teacher-pleasing swots. People who had anything about them would not have been caught dead in the after-hours master classes run for the "elite" few. Their resistance to an institution that represented intellectual conformity would not have been reversed by any more stringent efforts to increase the state school intake. None of these students lacked confidence. They had made an informed decision to avoid the establishment "fast track" because they wanted more from education than that patina of intellectual fluency that makes the Oxbridge graduate so easy to spot at parties.

Sounds pretty bright to me. Blair and Brown would doubtless say they'd failed to "unlock their potential", whereas I would contend that, of all university applicants, intelligent Oxbridge refusniks are the cream of our state-school stock. Indeed, it could be argued that far from being home to an elite, the beleaguered institutions they opt out of are little more than enclaves for a maniac fringe of bug-eyed overachievers who never had the time to develop the kind of mental tools that distinguish the smart from the merely well read.

People I know who have taught there all complain about a soporific atmosphere. Students are keen and compliant but there's little sign of critical life behind their "teach me" eyes. Which isn't to say they won't do splendidly from a system whose primary purpose is to groom them for the "top jobs" they will canter into.

And so the cycle continues. Your Oxbridge grad gets the "top job" not because he's necessarily the person who would do it best but because the the people who would don't want to. If you have to be slightly mad to get a million starred As at A-level, you'd have to be barking to think that a "top job" is really a sign of success as a human being. Yet believe it they do, turning up for their 18-hour days with the same dogged single-mindedness they once applied to their studies.

Given that the price of a "top job" is any semblance of a civilised life, the system naturally favours those with the least to lose. Far from being a meritocracy, the way our "elites" are selected benefits those who are underdeveloped as human beings.

The old cliché that a healthy society is one in which a binman's daughter could grow up to be the prime minister ignores the fact that only the truly weird would nurse this aspiration. In common with most other "top jobs", the person in the driving seat got there because the best driver was busy hanging curtains with his Mrs, or, was in Tony Blair's case, not smiley enough. It makes sense, given his position, that Gordon Brown should leap to Laura Spence's defence. The pity is, he didn't knock the idea that ability is always congruent with achievement.

Cut-offs are the wrong trousers
Long before the unsettled weather showed signs of beginning to break, this summer's silliest fashion fad was gaining a dreadful momentum. As far back as April, it became nigh on impossible to find a pair of "normal" jeans that hadn't been docked from the bottom. Now, everybody is wearing them. Capri pants have always looked to me like underachieving trousers - there is less to them than there should be and their deficiency has never been charming for the simple reason that mid-calf is a bad place to stop. Higher and they'd show the whole shape of the leg, lower and they'd let you guess it.

These truncated abominations reveal too much for the ankle to be sexy and too little to attract the eye elsewhere. As for what they do to your figure - just walk down any high street and you'll see the full range of body shapes insulted by this garment . Fat women look fatter in them. Thin women look fatter in them. Loose, they look like tropical prisoner's trousers, tight they look like catalogue offcuts.

No one who goes out in them should expect anything but derision. At least last year's ubiquitous combats didn't require a Vogue style guide to determine the right kind of shoes. Pumps, they say, are preferable. But everyone wears them with mules.

As long as they are willing to sacrifice all semblance of a life, a swotty B-type student is (I would hazard) more likely than a better-rounded A-type one to bring home the A-type grades. Who, after all, would choose to pass their rock 'n' roll years writing up science experiments? Isn't there a case for saying that the "best and the brightest" may well have been otherwise occupied - guerrilla gardening, perhaps, or snogging - when their course work assessments were due? Certainly, at my sixth form college, the people who applied for Oxbridge were, to a girl and boy, spooky, teacher-pleasing swots. People who had anything about them would not have been caught dead in the after-hours master classes run for the "elite" few. Their resistance to an institution that represented intellectual conformity would not have been reversed by any more stringent efforts to increase the state school intake. None of these students lacked confidence. They had made an informed decision to avoid the establishment "fast track" because they wanted more from education than that patina of intellectual fluency that makes the Oxbridge graduate so easy to spot at parties. Sounds pretty bright to me. Blair and Brown would doubtless say they'd failed to "unlock their potential", whereas I would contend that, of all university applicants, intelligent Oxbridge refusniks are the cream of our state-school stock. Indeed, it could be argued that far from being home to an elite, the beleaguered institutions they opt out of are little more than enclaves for a maniac fringe of bug-eyed overachievers who never had the time to develop the kind of mental tools that distinguish the smart from the merely well read. People I know who have taught there all complain about a soporific atmosphere. Students are keen and compliant but there's little sign of critical life behind their "teach me" eyes. Which isn't to say they won't do splendidly from a system whose primary purpose is to groom them for the "top jobs" they will canter into. And so the cycle continues. Your Oxbridge grad gets the "top job" not because he's necessarily the person who would do it best but because the the people who would don't want to. If you have to be slightly mad to get a million starred As at A-level, you'd have to be barking to think that a "top job" is really a sign of success as a human being. Yet believe it they do, turning up for their 18-hour days with the same dogged single-mindedness they once applied to their studies. Given that the price of a "top job" is any semblance of a civilised life, the system naturally favours those with the least to lose. Far from being a meritocracy, the way our "elites" are selected benefits those who are underdeveloped as human beings. The old cliché that a healthy society is one in which a binman's daughter could grow up to be the prime minister ignores the fact that only the truly weird would nurse this aspiration. In common with most other "top jobs", the person in the driving seat got there because the best driver was busy hanging curtains with his Mrs, or, was in Tony Blair's case, not smiley enough. It makes sense, given his position, that Gordon Brown should leap to Laura Spence's defence. The pity is, he didn't knock the idea that ability is always congruent with achievement. Cut-offs are the wrong trousers Long before the unsettled weather showed signs of beginning to break, this summer's silliest fashion fad was gaining a dreadful momentum. As far back as April, it became nigh on impossible to find a pair of "normal" jeans that hadn't been docked from the bottom. Now, everybody is wearing them. Capri pants have always looked to me like underachieving trousers - there is less to them than there should be and their deficiency has never been charming for the simple reason that mid-calf is a bad place to stop. Higher and they'd show the whole shape of the leg, lower and they'd let you guess it. These truncated abominations reveal too much for the ankle to be sexy and too little to attract the eye elsewhere. As for what they do to your figure - just walk down any high street and you'll see the full range of body shapes insulted by this garment . Fat women look fatter in them. Thin women look fatter in them. Loose, they look like tropical prisoner's trousers, tight they look like catalogue offcuts. No one who goes out in them should expect anything but derision. At least last year's ubiquitous combats didn't require a Vogue style guide to determine the right kind of shoes. Pumps, they say, are preferable. But everyone wears them with mules.

fields.headline: Cross current
fields.standfirst: Has Laura Spence unwittingly unleashed a student brain drain to better-endowed US universities?
fields.trailText: Has Laura Spence unwittingly unleashed a student brain drain to better-endowed US universities?
fields.body:
Top American universities are opening their arms to students from the UK, urging them to apply for places for the next academic year. The lure of state-of-the-art sports facilities, multi-million pound libraries, large scholarships and admissions procedures which bend over backwards to judge applicants on potential not privilege could trigger a stampede to campuses across the Atlantic.

This threatens to be the unintended consequence of Chancellor Gordon Brown's attack on Oxford University for being elitist after one of its colleges rejected Laura Spence, the Tyneside comprehensive sixth-former with 10 A-starred GCSEs. She later secured a place and a £65,000 scholarship at Harvard.

Now the government's attempts to strike a populist note before the next election look like backfiring among other school-leavers. Many are now being tempted to follow in Spence's footsteps. Only they are unlikely to bother applying to Oxbridge or other UK universities in the first place.

Professor David Blanchflower, head of economics at Dartmouth College, urges more UK students to apply to his college - which along with Harvard, Princeton and Yale is one of the prestigious Ivy League institutions in the north-eastern US: "The college would be interested in receiving a limited number of talented students' applications from the UK."

Harvard, meanwhile, has reported an increase in applications from UK students in the past year. But Sally Baker, head of admissions, stressed that UK students still make up only a tiny proportion of undergraduates - only 16 out of 6,500 students enrolled last year were from the UK. These few benefit from the university's huge endowment reserves, estimated at $15bn (£10bn). Last year the university raised an extra $200m (£134m) from almumni and private donations for student financial aid in particular - an extra $2,000 (£1,340) a year for students on scholarships.

Even US institutions with smaller reserves put our richest universities to shame. Dartmouth College and Oxford have roughly the same financial reserves (£1.5bn) and similar student intakes (4,000 undergraduates a year). Dartmouth recently spent £67m updating its library; its sports facilities include a 20,000 seater stadium. Oxford's facilities are small scale by comparison. The local professional football team, Oxford United, let alone the university, would envy Dartmouth's all-seater stadium.

Reports suggest, though, that it is Harvard's transformation from "a finishing school for elites" into an institution open to talent from all backgrounds, colours and classes that has inspired Brown in his summer breaks in the US. Nearly a quarter of Dartmouth's students are from minority backgrounds, against 6% at Oxford.

Many government advisers behind the scenes at Numbers 10 and 11 Downing Street also experienced at first hand the Ivy League's meritocratic admissions system. New Labour's inner circle won exclusive scholarships to study in the US after Oxbridge. Brown's right-hand man Ed Balls, for instance, went to Oxford then Harvard. The head of the prime minister's policy unit, David Miliband, went to MIT.

The government plans to announce measures to widen access in universities when Whitehall's spending review ends next month. This will include money for Harvard-style recruiters to trawl state schools in search of talent.

Yet the US universities employ radical measures to enrol gifted students. Needs-blind admissions systems ensure students' financial backgrounds are only probed after they have been accepted. Recommendations from high-school peers and aptitude tests are taken into account. And institutions recruit as many valedictorians - students coming top of their high school - as possible. In the UK this would mean that coming top at a local comp with good A-levels would give you a better chance at Oxbridge entrance than coming 57th at Eton.

But all this comes at a price. US institutions are free to charge their own tuition fees. And economists will tell UK university heads this week that unless they embrace a similar commercial stance, they will be unable to stem the brain drain of academic talent leaving for US universities.

Why money matters

Dartmouth College is a private university based in New Hampshire in the US. It is one of eight prestigious academic institutions, including Harvard, Princeton and Yale, all in the north-eastern US, known as the Ivy League - which began as an amateur intercollegiate football league in the 1930s. Dartmouth has an endowment fund approaching $2bn (£1.33bn) and has 4,200 undergraduates and around 500 graduate students.

Fees: Many US universities charge fees for tuition and board in excess of $30,000 (£20,000), even those outside the Ivy League that do not have large endowments. At Dartmouth, tuition and fees for 1998/9 were approx $24,000 (£16,000).

Scholarships: Dartmouth spent $26.2m (£17.5m) on needs-blind scholarships in 1997-98. Students are only asked about their financial needs after being accepted. Two-fifths of students received financial aid at an average of $15,058 (£10,000) per year.

Scholarships at Dartmouth are skewed heavily to minority groups. In 1996-97, 89% of African-American students received on average $18,300 (£12,200) a year; 80% of Native American students received on average $18,581 (£12,400) a year; 69% of Latino students re ceived on average $17,639 (£11,750) a year; 46% of Asian-American students received on average $15,435 (£10,300) a year; two-thirds of international students received on average $24,000 (£16,000) a year.

Social diversity: Dartmouth's class of 2001 included 5% African-American, 12% Asian-American, 5% Hispanic, and 2% Native American students.

School intake: 31% of students are from private schools at Dartmouth. But 28% of students are valedictorians (first in their high-school class) and 9% salutatorians (second).

Graduate debts: $50,000 (£33,330) isn't unusual and much more than this for graduates of medical, law or business schools.

University resources: Harvard spent $67m (£44.7m) in 1998/9 on its library - with 991 staff. Dartmouth is about to spend $100m (£66.65m) improving its library.

Student facilities at Dartmouth include: a golf course, ski area, five gyms, two swimming pools, a 20,000-seater stadium, indoor and outdoor tracks and a range of sports and social facilities.

Lecturers' pay: At Dartmouth, assistant profs - equivalent to junior lecturers in the UK - are paid $51,800 (£34,500). Full professors are paid $88,700 (£59,100).

With assets accrued over 800 years, Oxford University's 36 colleges are thought to have £1.58bn in endowment capital. Their joint endowments generate £63m every year. In 1997-98, the university enrolled 4,023 undergraduates. Oxford is autonomous but fees are largely paid by the state. The vice-chancellor is one of 19 university heads which make up the Russell Group, named after the London hotel they meet in. This week the group will consider a report by economists on moves to a US-type funding system of fees and scholarships.

Fees: Full-time undergraduates whose family income exceeds £28,000 have to contribute the maximum £1,025 flat-rate tuition fee. The government estimates that a third of students in universities pay the full fee, a third pay a contribution and the rest pay nothing.

Scholarships/loans: The government has scrapped its maintenance grant for living costs. Student loans are replacing this grant, with a maximum of £4,480 available in London, and £3,635 outside London for the academic year 1999/2000. There are no scholarships for undergraduates, although University College plans to award two or three bursaries in a scheme to fund students from state schools with no tradition of Oxford applicants. There are some university and college grants for travel, hardship and books. The government provides £654,311 Access Funds. The university also has Hardship Funds administered by the Committee on Student Hardship.

Social diversity: According to the latest figures from the Higher Education Statistics Agency, 6.24% of Oxford students were from ethnic minority backgrounds in 1997-98.

School intake: According to the Higher Education Funding Council for England, 47% of Oxford's student intake came from state schools and colleges, 53% from private schools (which make up 7% of UK schools).

Graduate debts: students graduating in 1999 faced on average £5,286 debt, up 17.5% on the previous year. These are the last students to graduate without paying fees.

University resources: In 1998-99 Oxford spent £18.36m on central library and information services. This does not include college libraries - every college has its own. Oxford is building a new swimming pool and increasing its sporting facilities. Colleges have (or share) a boat house, tennis, football and cricket facilities. Some colleges also have gyms.

Lecturers' pay: In old universities, a young lecturer earns on average £19,396, a professor £42,836.

A tale of two students

Personal recommendations from fellow high school pupils are among a raft of measures used by Dartmouth College to make sure students are selected in the fairest possible way, according to Jesse Cook-Dubin, a third year Dartmouth undergraduate.

The application process for Ivy League institutions is a long and arduous task - lasting over a year - with students assessed on high-school grades, aptitude tests, interviews and peer reviews. Only when students are finally accepted are they probed for financial details.

Like many students, Cook-Dubin is only able to study at Dartmouth because of the scholarship offered by the college. "I come from a family who live in a very average rural community," he says. "There would have been no way that the family could pay for me to go to an institution such as Dartmouth."

Cook-Dubin's parents invested a small amount of money when he was born, and this fund now pays for the costs not covered by the Dartmouth scholarship. Fees for tuition and board are $33,000 (£22,000) a year. And like most US degrees, his American and English literature course will last four years.

There was a day when Dartmouth was known as an all-white all Christian school. But now the onus is placed on opportunity for all. And the student intake at Dartmouth has become increasingly diverse. "We all have the same opportunities for education - this has been drummed into us since school," he says. "We are raised to believe that anyone can grow up to be president." A small minority complain that scholarships benefit those from families who have not worked as hard as others, but he says so many students are on financial aid that it is not big issue.

Oxford's colleges must do much more to improve links with inner city schools and under-represented groups in universities if they want to broaden their student intake, says Oxford graduate Rosna Mortuza. Even with top A-level grades, most school students from poor or ethnic minority backgrounds still perceive Oxbridge as an enclave for the privileged white middle classes. A bigger barrier can be the preconceptions of teachers, who see Oxford and Cambridge as off-bounds for their pupils.

"I don't think the colleges and university are doing enough to promote themselves to show that they are serious about taking on more able students from inner city state schools and ethnic backgrounds," she says.

During sixth form, Mortuza was lucky enough to meet a black Oxford undergraduate, who helped her to overcome the "absurdity of perceptions of Oxford as a place only for white, public school boys". She eventually graduated from Oxford with a degree in politics, philosophy and economics. During the degree, she became involved in the Oxford University Access Scheme and the Target Schools programme, both student-led and student-run schemes to encourage applicants to Oxbridge from "non-traditional" backgrounds.

The Oxford Access Scheme encourages youngsters from inner-city and ethnic minority backgrounds to apply to Oxford by using undergraduates from similar backgrounds to challenge perceptions and raise aspirations. "Although some colleges are beginning to be proactive," says Mortuza, "there is much colleges can learn from the Access Scheme."

While at Mansfield College, Rosna Mortuza was elected to be the college's first black and Muslim JCR president.

fields.headline: Winning smiles
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers introduces the Teaching Awards 2000 while Jerome Monahan and Phil Revell speak to last year's successes
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers introduces the Teaching Awards 2000 while Jerome Monahan and Phil Revell speak to last year's successes
fields.body:
The regional ceremonies for the Teaching Awards 2000 will kick off this week, in the final countdown to this year's glittering climax of the first national scheme to formally recognise and celebrate the achievements of the country's most outstanding teachers.

Up to 168 category winners will be honoured at 12 awards events across England, Northern Ireland and Wales over the next four weeks in the presence of their heads, fellow teachers, pupils, families, local education authority chiefs and MPs.

The first presentation takes place in Winchester today, with further events in Bath tomorrow, Plymouth on Thursday and Cardiff on Friday. The last regional event will take place in Norwich on June 27. As last year, each ceremony will be professionally staged and hosted by a senior BBC news anchor such as Mike Embley, Andrew Harvey or Nick Owen. The 168 area winners will pick up cheques for up to £3,500 for their schools, but the other 672 finalists will also be rewarded with £500 each.

The UK judging panel will then have the unenviable task of selecting the final 14 national winners of the coveted Plato trophies, which have this year been redesigned to make a stunning asset for any mantelpiece or a school cabinet. Each national winner will receive their award - plus cheques for a £20,000 for their schools - at a televised ceremony at the Dome Skyscape in Greenwich, south-east London. Last year the gala event was televised live on BBC1 in a one-hour special and viewed by an estimated 4m people.

The organisers were left wondering how to beat the final awards ceremony last July, when some of the more memorable moments of the months of hard work included Tony Blair making a surprise appearance in Norma Machell's classroom in Scarcroft primary school near York, to present her with the award of primary teacher of the year. We are promised plenty more surprises this year, which will make the final ceremony an event not to be missed.

Inevitably, many lessons were learned from the inaugural year of the scheme, which has led to numerous improvements being made this time around. Schools were given more time to submit their applications, for example, because of the need for the involvement of governing bodies. And as well as widening the geographical net to include Northern Ireland and Wales, a new category to recognise the achievements of classroom assistants has been created.

And the clear evidence of exceptional talent and enthusiasm among teachers new to the classroom triggered support for a further category of Outstanding New Teacher. In a further new development, the 14 winning teachers will be invited to take part in "best practice" workshops in London in October to provide opportunities to network and share ideas. Winners of awards in the leadership categories will also be offered the chance to go on courses run by the Leadership Trust based in Ross-on-Wye, which aims to enhance and influence leadership development in all aspects of society.

The awards were the brainchild of the Oscar-winning film producer David (Lord) Puttnam, who is now well established as a key figure in education as the chairman of the fledgling General Teaching Council and a member of many government education committees. He used the skills he had learned in the film business to bang heads together and drum up financial support.

The Teaching Awards Trust that now administers the awards was set up in 1998 as a registered charity to promote and encourage high standards in teaching and education, at the same time raising the profile and morale of the profession.

The scheme is now funded exclusively by corporate sponsorship and donations - the bulk coming from the main sponsor, Lloyds TSB. The Guardian is involved for the second year running, this year sponsoring the Teacher of the Year award. Watch this space - we will will be running detailed reports of the regional events over the next three weeks as well as a full-colour supplement on the national winners in the autumn.

Flo Witcombe

It's 2.00pm on a half-term Saturday and Flo Witcombe, winner of the Dorling Kindersley award for best new primary teacher, is in her classroom at Inverteign Junior School in Teignmouth. She has been at work creating a hanging display, Our Art Gallery. "Anything that comes into range tends to get laminated," she explains. "I wanted to get this done earlier on in the week but I went down with flu. It's classic - the immune system knows there's a chance of a rest and it tells the bugs 'come and get me'."

Her thoughts return to the awards ceremony last July. "When I realised I had won I felt sick with shock. The BBC had filmed me teaching but the crew said they were doing the same for all the finalists. Apparently, when it was announced on TV a yell went up from the houses near the school - someone said it sounded like England scoring a World Cup goal."

Flo's nomination had been popular among parents. "I grew up on an estate like the one many of our children come from and this definitely helped me relate to the parents. I also tried not to be too stiff. Just asking people to call me by my first name helped diffuse some of the tension at my first parents' evening."

Flo was pleased to see the money she won benefiting pupils. The £8,000 went on a minibus. "It was provided by Leyland Daf at about half price - my winning definitely raised the profile of the school and helped us attract sponsorship."

Her advice to anyone nominated for the 2000 award in her category is "Go for it - it has been entirely positive for the school. It was also a huge pleasure for me being able to thank colleagues publicly for helping me during my first teaching years. You will have a lot of attention from the press and that can be hard to fit in. I was on the front page of the local newspaper for about four weeks running. But then they sorted out their news priorities and got back to other top stories, like children losing toys on the beach, so it didn't go to my head."

webTitle: a) frying pan or b) fire?

fields.headline: a) frying pan or b) fire?
fields.standfirst: Suddenly Britain's politicians are in love with America's Sat, the multiple-choice university entrance test. Careful, says  Sonja D Lewis, it favours affluent white males
fields.trailText: Suddenly Britain's politicians are in love with America's Sat, the multiple-choice university entrance test. Careful, says Sonja D Lewis, it favours affluent white males
fields.body:
Education ministers are exploring new - and potentially fairer - ways of assessing university applicants to ensure that potential gets recognised whatever a student's race, class or income.

To make sure that the best and brightest do get university places, Britain's politicians feel there are lessons to be learnt from America, to which an increasing number of top-notch British students are likely to look for a fairer deal. And they have eyes set on the Sat, the oldest, most widely used college entrance exam in the US.

In the Sat they see precisely the world-class university admissions system they are seeking. After all, it is time tested - in use since 1926 - and is a fair academic measure which is blind to socio-economic factors and other barriers used to alienate certain students.

Not so fast, warns Bob Schaeffer, public education director at the National Center for Fair and Open Testing (FairTest), a US advocacy organisation working to end the abuses, misuses and flaws of standardised testing. In spite of its exquisite facade, he says the Sat has long been flawed for what it is and how it is used.

He likens it to "a fast-paced game with a premium on strategic guessing, which systematically screens out African Americans and other minorities" - such as bilingual individuals and those from low-income families.

It also effectively discriminates against females. So if UK authorities really want to put all potential college students on a level playing field, they should do plenty of homework before considering a system "that might not only fail to add value, but also distort university admissions".

The College Board, a private organisation, contracts the Educational Testing Service (ETS) to produce and administer the Sat. The exam is in two parts, verbal and maths, each scored on a 200- to 800-point scale, and claims to offer colleges and universities a fair and impartial way to compare students from different school situations.

It is also certified as a predictor of first-year college grades. Each year more than a million 16- to 17-year-old students sit the largely multiple choice, 138-question exam. Only ten of the questions, which relate to maths, require them to write in answers. And in three hours it is over.

The test does not require extensive essay writing or sustained reasoning. In fact, there is very little writing involved. Students simply need the knack of solving problems quickly to prove their worth to 82% of America's universities (other universities no longer use standardised admission exams).

Make no mistake, the Sat is intense, if only because you have to do it so so fast. There is immense pressure to score high - some universities, particularly the top ones, have cut-off scores and won't consider applicants unless they meet minimum requirements, not even if they have excellent high school records.

Schaeffer and colleagues believe this is a flagrant misuse of the Sat, since they say the test reflects "test-taking aptitude" not academic potential. There are no consistent relations between Sat scores and academic careers. The College Board's literature says the Sat is not an intelligence test; indeed it changed the title of the exam from Scholastic Aptitude Test to Sat I - Reasoning Test, thus distancing itself from the original meaning of the acronyn.

Meanwhile, the students scoring highest on the Sat are white, although females lag behind males by at least 40 points. Why? Possibly because males are most comfortable with the Sat's emphasis on speed. The College Board reports that female test-takers come from families with lower incomes and have parents with less education. And yet female college records are consistently better - challenging the test as a predictor of first-year college grades.

White students' closest competitors are Asian students, who sometimes outperform them. Schaeffer attributes this to the high pressure cultures from which these students hail. But more recent Asian immigrants such as Filipinos and Vietnamese, who may still have trouble with the English language, show lower test scores. The language barrier also presents major burdens for Hispanic students.

The lowest scores come from African-Americans and low-income minorities. College Board literature says both groups lag in academic achievement - grades, class rank and graduation rates - long before they take the Sat, since parents with higher incomes can buy better educations for their children.

The College Board does consistently address superficial barriers such as questions that might culturally discriminate, but Schaeffer says problems lie in the speedy nature of the test, and how it is used.

Studies show that African-Americans and lower-income minorities don't excel on these types of test. Many don't even finish them. Coaching devices can improve scores by 100 points, but some cost $700 or more. FairTest literature says this also "skews scores in favour of higher-income test-takers".

Schaeffer applauds colleges that don't rely on the Sat and says the rest should make the test optional, and also use other measures such as high-school grades, class rank, leadership skills and non-academic factors such as community service to avoid distorting admissions. He also maintains that the Sat should never be used alone - if it is, "College Board should enforce the user guidelines and stop making the test scores available to them".

It is only America's top 100, extremely competitive universities that are most likely to be misusing the Sat. But even they have former students who broke the mould and did not achieve a top Sat score.

One of them will be the next president of the US. Both candidates - George W Bush and Al Gore - had mid-range scores and average academic records, but no doubt because of their elite family status were not held back. Very few students can sidestep this kind of discrimination, especially if they are poor or come from minority backgrounds.

"There is no point in the UK pursuing a dead-end route," Schaeffer points out. "A test such as the Sat will be biased towards those who grew up speaking English, and will put immigrants at a disadvantage." Not to mention that it will exclude low-income students and minorities, the very groups the ministers say they want to include.

Try your hand at some real Sat questions.

College Board replies

In spite of the harsh criticism heaped upon the Sat, Janice Gams, associate public affairs director for the College Board, believes the test is as good as it gets but says: "No test is going to produce equal results for all."

Education ministers should keep that in mind when reviewing university admissions reform.

Gams insists that the Sat is not only fair, but that it adds an element of fairness to the admissions process. High-school grades vary from teacher to teacher and school to school, and in rare cases may "give a false impression". The Sat, she says, offers colleges a fair assessment to balance other factors.

To ensure fairness, the test is constantly reviewed. Each question goes through eight rigorous steps before being put into practice. Test makers ETS follow detailed guidelines to ensure cultural and racial-ethnic diversity. Gams admits the test is fast paced, so some students don't finish, but says this isn't necessarily reflected in their scores. She points out that students will need speed throughout their academic life, especially in their final exams.

She believes the Sat is the scapegoat for the enduring problem of unequal educational opportunities. The groups that score low on the Sat - African-Americans and low-income students - have lower high-school grades and class ranks: "This is not new. Human performance is linked to family education, income, parenting skills and many other factors."

Gams says Sat scores reflect students' readiness for the test rather than a problem with the test. "The students that score higher in any group have taken appropriate courses and prepared for university."

She says the board averages scores from different groups of students (ethnic, family income and gender) and there are exceptions in all groups. The board distinguishes between preparation and coaching. To help test takers prepare, they give them a booklet and encourage them to take a strict programme of courses and practice tests, and read widely.

"Sat scores rise through learning [about 50 points per high school year]," she says. But research shows that commercial coaching accounts for an increase of about 26 points a year, which probably doesn't have a bearing on admissions.

Gams says the Sat should not be the number one or sole criterion, and its research confirms that it is not. The board advises universities to also take account of grades and class rank. Taken together, these help predict readiness for college: "The Sat measures verbal and mathematical reasoning skills. It is not an intelligence test. It covers reading comprehension, grammar, vocabulary, math and science" - all basic skills needed at college.

fields.trailText: William Hague will today launch his latest attempt to seize the populist agenda with an assault on "the liberal elite which has brought our education system to its knees", pledging to hand heads and governors "complete freedom" to set discipline standards.
fields.body:
William Hague will today launch his latest attempt to seize the populist agenda with an assault on "the liberal elite which has brought our education system to its knees", pledging to hand heads and governors "complete freedom" to set discipline standards.

His promise to restore headteachers' right to exclude unruly pupils at will was condemned last night by the government as incoherent, uncosted and unworkable.

Government moves to cut exclusions by setting schools maximum targets for the number of pupils expelled would be reversed under a Conservative government, the Tory leader will say during a school visit in south London today, heralding moves to make school discipline a "key plank" of education policy for the next general election.

But the education secretary, David Blunkett, will point to the threefold rise in exclusions during the 1990s under the last Tory government, arguing that the Conservatives left excluded youngsters "on the streets to cause crime and mayhem". He will also emphasise that heads have the right to exclude violent or severely disruptive pupils immediately, amid efforts to reduce exclusions overall.

Mr Hague's references to the "elitism" of the New Labour government as "the real enemy of good education in Britain" are intended to hit back at the government over its claims to be seeking greater fairness in education with attacks on Oxbridge "elitist" selection systems.

The Tory leader, whose education team has frequently stated party opposition to current government policy on exclusion, will also use his speech to condemn what he calls the "politically correct nonsense" of the liberal elite, including moves to abolish section 28 and recent criticism of the game of musical chairs as unfair to children who lose.

But teaching unions are certain to despair that day-to-day classroom concerns have become the latest political football to be kicked between the parties, just as the complexities of university selection were lost amid the row over the refusal of an Oxford place to the Tyneside teenager Laura Spence.

Teachers have protested strongly at heavy-handed government efforts to bring down exclusions, which peaked at 12,700 a year shortly before Labour's election and have since fallen to 10,400.

webTitle: The bomber who tried to unleash a race war

fields.headline: The bomber who tried to unleash a race war
fields.standfirst:
London nail bombs: special report
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The nail bomber who killed three people and injured dozens of others in a terrifying campaign last spring told police he was a homophobic Nazi, and that he hoped the explosions would "set fire to the country and stir up a racial war", the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The nail bomber who killed three people and injured dozens of others in a terrifying campaign last spring told police he was a homophobic Nazi, and that he hoped the explosions would "set fire to the country and stir up a racial war", the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

David Copeland, 24, claimed he planted the first two bombs in Brixton, south London, and Brick Lane, east London, because he knew they were areas where many black and Asian people lived.

Acting alone after studying bomb-making guides on the internet, Copeland targeted the communities for "political" reasons. He intended to cause "murder, mayhem, chaos and damage" and "to spread fear, resentment and hatred throughout the country", the jury heard.

His third bomb, left at the bar of the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho, central London, on April 30 last year, was not, however, a political statement, said Nigel Sweeney, QC, prosecuting. "It was personal. The defendant told police that he was very homophobic. He hated gay men and he said his hatred stemmed from the way his parents had treated him as a child. He regarded gay men as perverted degenerates who were no use to society and should be put to death."

Andrea Dykes, 27, who was pregnant, John Light, 32, and Nick Moore, 31, were killed by the blast. They were having a drink before a night out in the West End. Seventy-nine others were seriously hurt in what Mr Sweeney called a "devastating" explosion.

After planting the bomb, Copeland, of Cove, Hampshire, watched the carnage he had caused on TV at a nearby hotel before going home.

He told police he would have continued bombing ethnic minority communities if he had not been caught. Southall in west London was his next target.

Three months ago Copeland admitted three charges of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility, but the prosecution refused to accept the guilty pleas.

In his opening speech to the jury on the first day of the trial, Mr Sweeney said: "We say that this defendant murdered each of the three victims. He obviously intended to kill or to cause really serious bodily harm."

Copeland, wearing a crumpled blue shirt, sat expressionless in the dock of court one as Mr Sweeney described how events unfolded in 13 days last April.

Behind Copeland in the public gallery were many of his victims, including one man who lost a leg.

Copeland, an engineer's assistant working on the Jubilee extension line, had been planning the bombing campaign for several months, the court heard. He came up with the idea when a bomb went off in Centennial park during the Olympic Games in Atlanta four years ago.

"He told police that the Notting Hill carnival was on at about the same time," said Mr Sweeney. "He began to wish that someone would blow up the Notting Hill carnival. To start off with he treated the thought as a joke, but he could not get it out of his head. The thought became stronger. He woke up one day and decided he was going to do it."

Copeland wanted to make "proper bombs". In April, 1997, he downloaded a manual called the Terrorists' Handbook at a cyber cafe in Victoria, central London. But he found it difficult to follow the instructions for making one of the chemical ingredients and gave up.

One night in 1998 when he was bored, he looked at the manual again and saw instructions for making a "pipe bomb", which was less sophisticated. Referring to another guide on the internet, How to Make Bombs part 2, he set about collecting the materials.

Copeland bought £1,500 of fireworks from two stores in Farnborough, Hants, and ignition devices from a firm in Dorset. He used old-fashioned alarm clocks as his timers. He packed up to 1,500 nails in each completed device, which he taped into sports holdalls.

Before heading to Brixton for the first attack, he experimented with different mixtures of "flash powder" to get the biggest explosion, blowing up small lengths of pipe at a common near the bedsit he rented from a local vicar.

With the bomb, primed to go off at 5.30pm, in a bag slung over his shoulder, Copeland took a train to London on Saturday, April 17, last year, and then a taxi to Brixton, which he believed to be the heart of London's black community.

He told detectives he was surprised to find so many white people shopping there. "He did not care about hurting them," Mr Sweeney told the court. "He told the police: 'If they want to live there, that's up to them'."

After scouting the area, Copeland decided to leave the bag next to a bus stop outside the busy Iceland store on the corner of Electric Avenue.

But before it detonated, an unlicensed street trader picked it up. Another man took the bomb out of the bag and put it on a stack of wooden pallets at the side of the Iceland shop.

The jury was shown CCTV pictures of the scene just before the explosion. The bomb was clearly visible and a security guard from the store was trying to usher people away from it, though nobody was taking him seriously. Police officers arrived at the shop and were walking towards the device when it went off at 5.25pm.

There were gasps from the public gallery as silent images of men and women being thrown sideways in the violent blast appeared on TV screens mounted in court.

Mr Sweeney said it was a miracle that nobody had been killed. Forty people were injured, including two who lost an eye and a 23-month-old child who had a nail embedded in his skull.

A week later, Copeland went to Brick Lane, which he believed to be the centre of London's Asian community. He wanted to plant a bomb in the middle of the busy market, but discovered he was a day early.

Mr Sweeney said Copeland dumped the bag, but a passerby, Gerrard Lynch, spotted it and tried to hand it in to a local police office, which was closed. Mr Lynch put the bag in the boot of his car and was walking towards a local police station to report lost property, when the device exploded.

"The car was destroyed by the force of the blast," said Mr Sweeney. "Fortunately, relatively few people were hurt. Ten suffered minor injuries."

Copeland intended to strike again the following Saturday, but brought his plans forward when, during a reconnaissance mission in Soho, he heard on the radio that the police had released CCTV photos of him taken while he was in Brixton.

He went home to Hampshire, was relieved that the police had not found him, and returned to London with the materials he needed to make another bomb, the court heard.

Copeland checked into a hotel in Victoria under a false name on Thursday, April 29, and assembled his bomb in another hotel the following morning. He set it to go off at 6.30pm.

"He went to the Admiral Duncan at 5.30pm. He put the bag by the bar and talked to one of the customers, pretending to be waiting for a gay friend. He left the Admiral Duncan at 6.05. Nobody noticed he had left the bag. It was still there when the three victims arrived shortly before it exploded."

Mr Sweeney added: "There were at least 70 people in the bar. The effect of an explosion in such a confined space was devastating. Nick Moore and Andrea Dykes were killed at the scene. John Light died from his injuries the next day. A number of other victims suffered dreadful injuries."

Four people lost one or both of their lower limbs, another lost an arm.

By the time Copeland returned home, the police were on his trail. A work colleague, Paul Mifsud, had telephone the police to say he recognised Copeland as the Brixton bomber.

Mr Sweeney said Copeland immediately admitted to the officers who arrested him that he was responsible.

They found two swastika flags on the walls of his room, bomb-making equipment and a membership card of a far-right group he had joined, the National Socialist Movement.

"He told them he was a Nazi who believed in a white master race," said Mr Sweeney. "He did not like black people or Asian people and wanted them out of the country. He thought the British people had a right to ethnic cleansing, like the Serbs. He thought the bombs would be the spark to start a fire in this country, stirring up a racial war that would cause white people to vote for the British National Party."

During interviews with detectives, Copeland said his campaign was "a top story" and that "every nutter out there, if he wants to get on the news, will have to blow something up."

His hatred of gay men, not gay women, could only be gauged by the comments he made to the police, Mr Sweeney said. "He said they were perverted degenerates that should be put to death. Even as a racist, he said he would prefer the company of a black or Asian man rather than a gay man."

Copeland told them he acted entirely on his own and told nobody of his plans. He described Combat 18, an extremist group which claimed responsibility for the blasts, as a "bunch of yobs."

Copeland was dismissive of another group, the White Wolves, which also claimed responsibility.

He told detectives he had never heard of the group and thought it was "trying to take my glory."

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Met's £1m hate campaign payout
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard agreed yesterday to pay a compensation package worth an estimated £1m to a female officer subjected to a barrage of sexual and racial discrimination that left her suicidal.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard agreed yesterday to pay a compensation package worth an estimated £1m to a female officer subjected to a barrage of sexual and racial discrimination that left her suicidal.

The settlement came the day before the start of a high court case brought against the Metropolitan police by Sarah Locker, who is of Turkish origin.

She was suing the force for breach of contract and negligence, claiming that it broke a back-to-work agreement made after Scotland Yard settled an employment tribunal case for sex and race discrimination that she had brought in 1993.

Scotland Yard made a public apology and paid her £32,500 after Ms Locker's first case and agreed she would receive fair treatment at work. Ms Locker said their promises were empty. She was appointed detective constable and promised a job as a financial investigator in an elite squad, but claims it turned out to be little more than a desk job.

The hate campaign had started again, including obscene phone calls. Within weeks she took sick leave and left the force after 16 years.

The high court case, due to start today, would have seen a senior Scotland Yard officer questioned under oath.

Lawyers for Ms Locker had called John Grieve, now head of the racial and violent crimes taskforce, to give evidence.

On her return Mr Grieve was her boss and Ms Locker alleges that he mismanaged her return to work.

Ms Locker, 38, will receive £215,000 in cash. On top of that she is entitled to a pension and police injury award worth around £20,000 a year for life.

Her original tribunal case followed her being subjected to hardcore pornographic material and abuse about her Turkish origins.

One leaflet sent to her was a spoof application form for a training course purporting to have been written by her. It read: "A few of them courses is right up the street of a third world effnic girl like me... I'm finking that a couple of weeks at that Brands Hatch beauty centre might help me hairy legs and low-slung bum.

"I could really go for that rape and serious sexual offences bit - if they got some nice greasy Mediterrean boys there wiv all the right bits cut off their fings - the practice might come in handy.

"And wots more me mum is into magic, seeing into the future and that one word from me and the curse will be flying about faster than a pork chop in a mosque."

After yesterday's settlement was announced, Ms Locker said: "My colleagues shunned me. It was a kind of torture. I began to realise that the agreement was all show. I had no real work to do and no one to talk to. I cracked up and left with a nervous breakdown. So I brought these proceedings.

"My life's ambition was to be a professional police officer. I gave 16 years of my life to the police and they have torn it apart.

"They ruined me as they have hurt so many other women and black officers.

"They have had to pay so much money that I now hope they have learned their lessons."

Her solicitor, Jane Deighton, said the Met's failure to admit liability despite the large payout was arrogant.

"There are two things Sarah Locker has not achieved. First, an apology. The police refuse to admit responsibility. Why pay out so much unless they know they were likely to lose in court?

"Second, the public and police have no guarantee that despite the commissioner throwing money at this disaster, another one is not around the corner. The police are saying they have changed. If they had changed they would have apologised."

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "The MPS settled this case without an admission of liability. We considered we had a good case but felt it was not in the interests of either Sarah Locker or the MPS to have a lengthy and expensive trial in the high court on this matter.

"The claim refers to issues which occurred six years ago and the organisation has moved forward since that time. The MPS felt it was in no one's interest, particularly Sarah Locker, to protract the situation any further."

webTitle: Cook aims to stop rebels diamond trade

fields.headline: Cook aims to stop rebels diamond trade
fields.trailText: Foreign secretary Robin Cook said today that Britain is pressing for a UN resolution to prevent the Sierra Leone rebels selling diamonds on the international market.
fields.body:
Foreign secretary Robin Cook said today that Britain is pressing for a UN resolution to prevent the Sierra Leone rebels selling diamonds on the international market.

Under the foreign secretary's plans only diamonds certified by the Sierra Leone government will be eligible for sale abroad.

Mr Cook said that diamonds had allowed the rebels to buy vast quantities of arms while the people of Sierra Leone had become among the poorest in the world. The ultimate aim is for the government of Sierra Leone to take control of the diamond-mining areas.

The foreign secretary will also visit Sierra Leone on Thursday to discuss with the country's president Ahmed Tejan Kabbah what further help Britain can provide.

Shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude called for a full inquiry into why British troops had needed to be deployed in Sierra Leone. He added that the inquiry should look into what role the Foreign Office played in pressuring the Sierra Leone government into committing the "fatal error" of admitting rebel leader Foday Sankoh into the government.

Britain remains on course to withdraw its troops from Sierra Lone by mid-June when the UN force is expected to reach 11,000.

fields.headline: Football hooligans put on notice
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 800 known or suspected English football hooligans could be prevented from attending the Euro 2000 football tournament this summer, after British police passed their names to authorities in Belgium and Holland.
fields.body:
More than 800 known or suspected English football hooligans could be prevented from attending the Euro 2000 football tournament this summer, after British police passed their names to authorities in Belgium and Holland.

The list includes more than 500 hooligans with domestic or international banning orders against them, plus 300 people suspected of football violence whom police believe are intent on causing violent disorder.

Both Holland and Belgium, the tournament's co-hosts, have laws permitting preventative detention of undesirables, and have made it clear that they will refuse entry to anyone they believe may cause trouble.

Last month Jack Straw, home secretary, turned down the opportunity to introduce legislation allowing the passports of known hooligans to be confiscated, as it would not be passed before the four-week tournament begins this Saturday.

After a meeting with Dutch, Belgian and British police and Football Association representatives yesterday, Mr Straw blamed "Conservative mavericks" and "a pusillanimous Tory front bench" for failing to support the legislation when it was introduced last year.

Rejecting the criticism, Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, said Mr Straw had abdicated responsibility by leaving it up to the host countries to turn hooligans away at their borders. "Why don't we stop them at ours?"

Mr Straw said he was confident that the authorities in the host countries and British police had done everything within their power to prevent violence.

"The preparations for this tournament have been far more intensive than they were for the World Cup in France in 1998, and we have built on that experience," he said. "In the end it is down to the Dutch and Belgian authorities."

English hooligans were widely condemned after rioting in Marseille during the World Cup.

Tension has been heightened recently by disturbances abroad involving English supporters. Two Leeds fans were killed in Istanbul after travelling to see their club play Galatasaray, and there were running battles between Arsenal and Galatasaray fans in Copenhagen last month.

Detective Superintendent Brian Drew, head of the football unit of the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS), said: "Dutch and Belgian police have attended every one of England's qualifying matches in the run-up to the tournament, and they have seen how English fans behave both at home and away.

"They were also present in Copenhagen, and I am confident that they have the power to stop that sort of thing taking place."

At yesterday's meeting Dutch and Belgian authorities assured Mr Straw that they would charge and convict English supporters involved in violence - rather than deporting troublemakers, as the Danes did last month - allowing the British courts to issue orders banning them from travelling to future matches abroad.

The National Federation of Football Supporters' Clubs insisted that, despite intelligence provided to the Dutch and Belgians by the NCIS, not enough had been done to prevent hooligans from travelling to the competition.

"It is inevitable that there will be trouble at Euro 2000," said Ian Todd, the federation's chairman. "The government is struggling to recover from a situation they made for themselves when they chickened out of introducing that legislation."

England's first match, against Portugal, is in Eindhoven, Holland, next Monday, followed five days later by one against Germany in the small Belgian town of Charleroi, which many believe will be a flashpoint for serious trouble.
