fields.trailText: PELE WHIPS UP A STORM
fields.body:
PELE WHIPS UP A STORM

Earlier today, when Edson Arantes do Nascimento skipped out of his Rio beach house in his skimpy Koogan-style briefs, he was greeted by a thunderous downpour - which was strange because it hadn't rained in nearly a decade. But while the sight was greeted by gasps of amazement by Brazilian weathermen, and sighs of bewilderment from the children in the barrios, there was one person who just shrugged her head and thought: "Here we go again."

That person was Mrs Pele, wife of Brazilian legend Pele, who'd heard him cheerfully predict sunny times ahead just the night before. But that setback didn't stop the great man turning his gaze to the low countries and picking Steve McManaman and Henrik Larsson as the men who will stand out in Euro 2000. "Four years ago when England were the hosts, McManaman was one of the players who impressed me most in the tournament," claimed Pele, who'd obviously been watching on radio. "He had great pace and skill and wasn't afraid to take defenders on and beat them," the great man continued. "I don't know what happened to McManaman in the last few years, but I see he is back where he should be - as one of the finest players in Europe."

And because Pele's state-of-the-art satellite system also picks up the finest Swedish TV (it's for the football, Mrs Pele), he also felt qualified to talk about Henrik Larsson. "He had the injury, but if I were the coach I might take the risk," Pele told the Daily Record. "You have 22 players and you can take a risk with one - otherwise after only three matches it might be too late. I think that coaches sometimes need to show more courage." Just the kind of stirring words to get our Kelvin and Swedish coach Tommy Svensson talking up their Euro 2000 prospects - at least until they realise that Pele also predicted that Colombia would win the World Cup in 1994 and an African nation would win it by 2000. Do we hear thunder?

WE'RE NOT TOO PROUD TO BEG

The latest Euro can be found here and there'll be another along at 9am tomorrow morning. If you haven't subscribed yet, go and do it now. Oh go on. Pleeeeeeeeeease.

ADVERTISEMENT

http://www.theaa.co.uk/euro2000 Free one-stop information shop for fans travelling to Euro 2000. An inclusive AA service offering routes, traffic reports, practical advice and lots more.

DIE-GO!

Short of breath? Troubled by cold sweats? Plagued by a chronic need to indulge in ginormous amounts of hard drugs? Chances are you're suffering from Diegorrhea, an excessive amount of sympathy for the plight of poor old stumpy Argentine cheat Diego Maradona. Help is at hand however, as Diego himself appears to be making a miraculous recovery from his recent 'heart difficulties'.

"After a spectacular improvement he has reached a plateau and now the advance will come bit by bit. I think we will succeed," said Diego's personal doctor Alfredo Cahe this week. Dr Cahe, who has treated Maradona since he was 16 - and what sterling work he's done - went on to explain just how successful the treatment has been. "Diego has achieved abstinence from drugs," he said. "He has achieved an understanding of abstinence." Er, right. The Fiver has an understanding of abstinence too, but that doesn't stop us from indulging in all-night sex orgies with glamour models.

Oh, alright, it does, but you get our point. Anyway, the wonderful Dr Cahe believes that, as long as Diego stays in Cuba, he'll be well again by the end of the year. And as far as Diego is concerned his heart is now 60% fit, up 30% from his last professional self-assessment. Which should explain why he has reportedly spent the last week indulging in endless barbecues with his Argentine mates whilst diving into swimming pools fully clothed screaming "Gooooooool!". "In Cuba, I am happy. I love Cuba," he said this week. Sounds like.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I may look different, but everyone knows that inside I am the same player and same person. And that is what is important" - Especially when it comes to playing against England. Portugal's Abel Xavier on his new (and Thomas Castaignède's old) haircut.

ROBBO GOES INTERGALACTIC

Why is the Fiver's favourite plant pot, which has been precariously perched on top of that large pedestal over there, rocking so violently? It's almost as if it's being used as a medium of communication by somebody trapped in a parallel universe. [rock rock] Blimey, it's Bryan Robson. What on earth are you up to? [rock rock] You're in a parallel universe because you reckon Middlesbrough stand a better chance of signing world-class players there? Good grief.

[rock rock] You've offered Barcelona £12m for out-of-favour striker Dani? [rock rock] You're prepared to offload £3m-rated Hamilton Ricard in order to fund the bid? [rock rock] Shouldn't you set your sights a bit lower? Haven't you learnt anything after failing in your ridiculous bid for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink? [rock rock] But you haven't actually signed Real Madrid's Christian Karambeu yet, so that proves nothing.

[rock rock] You're close to signing Fiorentina's Paul Okon as well? [rock rock] The captain of the Australian national team has told reporters that he's "interested in Middlesbrough and I've made up my mind to leave Italy. I'd be lying if I said the Premiership didn't appeal to me"? [rock rock] Don't get too excited - he may just be angling for a move to another Premiership club. [rock rock] You could always buy Phil Babb. Apparently Dunfermline aren't interested in him any more. [rock rock smash] Hmm, the plant pot seems to have fallen off its pedestal.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Unconfirmed reports suggest that representatives from Lazio have arrived in London today to discuss the £15m transfer of Marc Overmars from Arsenal. The Dutch winger has been linked with a move abroad for some time.

Another Arsenal player expected to leave the club this summer, Emmanuel Petit, appears to have committed himself to the club. "I have two years left on my contract", he told London's Evening Standard. "As far as I am concerned, I will be at Arsenal next season."

The latest candidate for Manchester United's problem centre-back position is Aston Villa and England's Gareth Barry. The Manchester Evening News reports that the Imperial Lord Ferg will make a "name your price" offer to John Gregory this week.

Everton are believed to be ready to accept offers in the region of £3m for Don Hutchison. The Scotland international is at the top of Sunderland's summer shopping list.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS) are to hand the names of 1,000 English hooligans to the Dutch and Belgian police, with orders that they should be turned back at the borders.

Blackburn Rovers owner Jack Walker is undergoing treatment in hospital for an unknown condition. A statement released by the Trustees of the Jack Walker 1987 Settlement read: "Mr Walker appreciates the many genuine enquiries about his health, but asks that both his and his family's privacy is respected at this time."

Kevin Phillips has been named as the Carling Premier League player of the year. A spokesman for the Carling awards panel said: "Kevin Phillips has made the transition from First Division to the Carling Premiership without a problem. "

Rangers have dropped their interest in Real Mallorca striker Diego Tristan. Chairman David Murray was willing to pay the £10m asking price but pulled out when the Spanish club started "messing him around".

Gheorghe Hagi has been asked to take over as manager of Euro-Vase winners Galatasaray. His appointment is expected to be made next week.

The Football Association of Wales will allow Mark Hughes to carry on playing for Everton until the summer of 2002 later this week when his revised contract is rubber-stamped at a committee meeting.

Hibernian have signed Danish defender Ulrik Laursen from OB Odense.

Stockport are expected to complete the signing of Clyde winger Brian Carrigan in a £250,000 deal tomorrow.

Walsall are holding talks to bring in Tony Dorigo as their player-coach. The 34-year-old former England international is available on a free transfer after being released by Derby at the end of the season.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Three Lions (10.45pm)

The history of the England team. Let's hope Skinner and Baddiel aren't getting any royalties for the title.

Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (6.30pm)

Or 'La World Football Show' as they say in France.

International Football - Live (12.30am)

The US play in the US Cup. Not at all insular, that.

British Eurosport: Football Dream Team (7pm)

It's not that 'Dream Team', so no bad acting to be found here.

Football - Live (7.30pm)

France v Morocco or, looking at it another way, Arsenal v Coventry/Southampton. Who'll win that, then?

fields.headline: No 1: David Trezeguet
fields.trailText: Appearance: Don't tell me. He's the moody French striker with plenty of pace, isn't he? The one who plays for Real Madrid.
fields.body:
Appearance: Don't tell me. He's the moody French striker with plenty of pace, isn't he? The one who plays for Real Madrid.

No. That's Nicholas Anelka, but you're not far away. Because Trezeguet is also French, fast and very moody. But I bet he hasn't been demanding a transfer all season a la Nic?

Oh yes he has - and with the same brashness too "I have had some great contacts from Italy and England," Trezza says modestly. "Milan is my first choice and I had several positive contacts with Mr Braida, the number three of the club. Anyway, wherever I go, even as a World Champion, I shall prove myself and win my place."

Confident lad isn't he? Well yes.

So I bet he gets on like a house on fire with young Nicolas? Are you trying to be funny? Relations between the two men are frosty, to put it mildly. "Nicholas played two good games and scored twice" Trezeguet opined recently. "On TV they talk about him as the centre forward of Les Bleus. Me I played 30 matches and scored a lot, but obviously, it doesn't have the same impact."

And I suppose Thierry Henry gets the same treatment? Surprisingly not - both players came up through the ranks at AS Monaco and are firm friends. Indeed Henry reckons: "David is a tenacious lad who never loses his self belief. His positional sense is unbelievable. The ball always comes back to him like an old friend."

Sounds like he can he playIndeed. Italy's veteran international defender Alessandro Costacurta claimed (after they played against each other in France 98) that Trezeguet had the potential to be the best striker in the world after Ronaldo. And this season he's been the second top scorer in Le Championnat.

Any trivia that we can expect Motty to bore us stupid with? One 'interesting' fact is that Trezeguet was raised in Argentina, and is the son of an Argentine who played for France. Trezeguet the younger started his career as a trainee at Platense in Argentina (playing one match in the top division) before returning to France aged 18 where he signed for Monaco and manager Jean Tigana.

So the rumours linking him to Fulham are true? Don't be silly.

But he is Bleu through and through? Mmm. Trezeguet starred for France at the 1997 World Youth Cup - it was only after Argentina decided not to select him.

Not to be confused with: Nicholas Anelka, Thierry Henry, Reggie Miller.

webTitle: Thomson buys Primark to challenge information leaders

fields.headline: Thomson buys Primark to challenge information leaders
fields.trailText: Thomson Corporation, the family-owned Canadian business, confirmed its move out of newspapers and into the world of electronic information publishing yesterday with a $842m (£558m) cash offer for Primark, a leading US financial data group.
fields.body:
Thomson Corporation, the family-owned Canadian business, confirmed its move out of newspapers and into the world of electronic information publishing yesterday with a $842m (£558m) cash offer for Primark, a leading US financial data group.

Yesterday's acquisition, which adds up to more than $1bn once the target's $235m in debt is assumed, caps a spending spree by the Canadian group which started earlier this year when it announced a decision to sell all 130 newspapers except the Globe & Mail in Toronto.

In the first quarter alone, Thomson has spent $1.1bn on three acquisitions in the field of online information. With the deal, Thomson, a 64-year-old company still 73% owned by the founding family, is to become the leading provider of financial forecasting in the US. Its assets already include First Call/Thomson Financial, which provides such information to professional investors.

Thomson's president and chief executive,Richard J Harrington, said: "With the acquisition of Primark, Thomson is taking another significant step to strengthen its global information offerings, in particular, the content and software applications we provide to the financial services market."

Primark's global presence - it operates in 61 countries - was a key part of its attraction for Thomson. Following the acquisition, 20% of revenues at Thomson Financial, the group's second largest business unit, will come from outside North America, compared with 9% today.

Primark is particularly strong in Europe; in Britain it owns MarketEye. Under the terms of the agreed bid, Thomson will pay $38 per share for Primark, which provides a range of information to the financial community. The price represents a 31% premium to company's closing price on Friday.

Primark shares rose $85/16 to $375/16 yesterday morning.

Primark, which employs 3,458 people, competes with Reuters and Bloomberg in providing financial information to fund managers and investment banks.

Primark recently agreed to sell the Yankee Group, its hi-tech research unit, to Reuters for $72.5m. Thomson said it expects the acquisition to dilute earnings per share this year and next. Primark reported revenues of $495m last year. The deal is expected to be completed during the second half of this year.

Earlier this year, Thomson bought the Prometric testing division of Sylvan Learning Systems, Wave Technologies and the online business of Dialog.

fields.body:
She arrived in early March, the plane landing at Katunayake airport before the dawn. They had raced it ever since coming over the west coast of India, so that now passengers stepped onto the tarmac in the dark.

By the time she was out of the terminal the sun had risen. In the West she'd read, The dawn comes up like thunder, and she knew she was the only one in the classroom to recognize the phrase physically. Though it was never abrupt thunder to her. It was first of all the noise of chickens and carts and modest morning rain or a man squeakily cleaning the windows with newspaper in another part of the house.

As soon as her passport with the light-blue UN bar was processed, a young official approached and moved alongside her. She struggled with her suitcases but he offered no help.

'How long has it been? You were born here, no?'

'Fifteen years.'

'You still speak Sinhala?'

'A little. Look, do you mind if I don't talk in the car on the way into Colombo - I'm jet-lagged. I just want to look. Maybe drink some toddy before it gets too late. Is Gabriel's Saloon still there for head massages?'

'In Kollupitiya, yes. I knew his father.'

'My father knew his father too.'

Without touching a single suitcase he organized the loading of the bags into the car. 'Toddy!' He laughed, continuing his conversation. 'First thing after fifteen years. The return of the prodigal.'

'I'm not a prodigal.'

An hour later he shook hands energetically with her at the door of the small house they had rented for her.

'There's a meeting tomorrow with Mr. Diyasena.'

'Thank you.'

'You have friends here, no?'

'Not really.'

Anil was glad to be alone. There was a scattering of relatives in Colombo, but she had not contacted them to let them know she was returning. She unearthed a sleeping pill from her purse, turned on the fan, chose a sarong and climbed into bed. The thing she had missed most of all were the fans. After she had left Sri Lanka at eighteen, her only real connection was the new sarong her parents sent her every Christmas (which she dutifully wore), and news clippings of swim meets. Anil had been an exceptional swimmer as a teenager, and the family never got over it; the talent was locked to her for life. As far as Sri Lankan families were concerned, if you were a well-known cricketer you could breeze into a career in business on the strength of your spin bowling or one famous inning at the Royal-Thomian match. Anil at sixteen had won the two-mile swim race that was held by the Mount Lavinia Hotel.

Each year a hundred people ran into the sea, swam out to a buoy a mile away and swam back to the same beach, the fastest male and the fastest female feted in the sports pages for a day or so. There was a photograph of her walking out of the surf that January morning - which The Observer had used with the headline 'Anil Wins It!' and which her father kept in his office. It had been studied by every distant member of the family (those in Australia, Malaysia and England, as well as those on the island), not so much because of her success but for her possible good looks now and in the future. Did she look too large in the hips?

The photographer had caught Anil's tired smile in the photograph, her right arm bent up to tear off her rubber swimming cap, some out-of-focus stragglers (she had once known who they were). The black-and-white picture had remained an icon in the family for too long.

She pushed the sheet down to the foot of the bed and lay there in the darkened room, facing the waves of air. The island no longer held her by the past. She'd spent the fifteen years since ignoring that early celebrity. Anil had read documents and news reports, full of tragedy, and she had now lived abroad long enough to interpret Sri Lanka with a long-distance gaze. But here it was a more complicated world morally. The streets were still streets, the citizens remained citizens. They shopped, changed jobs, laughed. Yet the darkest Greek tragedies were innocent compared with what was happening here. Heads on stakes. Skeletons dug out of a cocoa pit in Matale. At university Anil had translated lines from Archilochus - In the hospitality of war we left them their dead to remember us by. But here there was no such gesture to the families of the dead, not even the information of who the enemy was.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: A colleague sends me something from the internet - the summary of a research paper by Professor Giovanni Andrea Fava, editor of that popular top shelf publication Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics.
fields.body:
Tuesday
A colleague sends me something from the internet - the summary of a research paper by Professor Giovanni Andrea Fava, editor of that popular top shelf publication Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics. "Hypochondriasis can be treated, but is nurtured by medical information," is the title. Even if this makes Prof Fava sounds like ante-post favourite for editorship of Bleeding Obvious Monthly, I suppose there may be something in his "explanatory theory". However, I feel much too sinusy to examine the matter today.

Wednesday
I awake, as always, feeling thick-headed and with a face that aches from the forehead to the cheekbones that lie buried beneath so much fat. More and more I regret cancelling the submuchosal resection on my significantly deviated septum, because my breathing is worse than ever. I am even thinking about a homeopath recommended by a friend with chronic cystitis - a practitioner more likely to improve my quality of life, it occurs to me, than Prof Fava of the University of Bologna.

Thursday
I still cannot read the hypochondriasis paper, as I tell Rebecca while she is juicing some mouldy mangos - a diet-related activity which, in her hands, takes on an unsettlingly Freudian air. "You don't want to read it in case it's helpful," she says, grabbing a particularly withered piece of fruit. "You're terrified of being cured. If you lost your hypochondria, you'd lose the crutch on which you limp through life." Somehow the pedantic mid-sentence placement of the preposition irritates me even more than the sentiment, but I respond maturely by saying "yaiss, yaiss, very wise, oh yaiss", while nodding my head in savagely ironic agreement, until a familiar tinkling sends me scurrying for dustpan and brush.

Friday
"Hypochondriasis (the conviction of being seriously ill despite no objective medical evidence) is often regarded as a chronic and disabling condition, refractory to treatment," writes Prof Fava. "A randomized controlled trial performed at the University of Bologna would suggest this is not the case." The finding, if this isn't too technical, seems to be that patients whose doctors explain why they can't possibly have the illnesses they fear tend to worry less than those whose doctors don't. And all those years I thought Italian medicine began and ended with prescribing suppositories.

Saturday
Over the years, I reflect while browsing through the vitamins at the Pestle and Mortar chemist, I have enjoyed a fair amount of "explanatory therapy" from my physician Sarah Jarvis, of the "You do not have colon cancer because you do not have any symptoms" variety, and from my wife. And yet the hypochondriasis is, if anything, worse than in 1991, the year I first entered Room 19 at the Grove surgery and later became shackled by the bonds of holy wedlock.

Sunday
After lunch, we put explanatory theory into practice when I complain vigorously of pain in my left thumb and elbow. I diagnose the onset of motor neurone disease, but Rebecca, taking the role of Prof Fava, dissents. "Can you think of any activity that might explain it?" she asks pleasantly, allowing the good cop half of her routine an early outing in the tacit understanding that the bad cop was not too far away. "Nothing," I reply, "nothing at all." "What were you doing until 2.30am with your friend Giles?" "Playing FIFA 2000 football on the Playstation." "Show me how you hold the thing when you play." Reluctantly I mime. My elbow is held at an artificially raised angle, while the thumb is extended and at full pressure to the button. I take her point. Perhaps there is something in explanatory theory after all.

Monday
I awake feeling nervy and distressed, having passed a very troubled night. In this dream, I am lying on the mortuary slab while Dr Jarvis and Rebecca discuss what they should put down as cause of death. "Well, literally, it was the colono-rectal cancer," says the doctor. "Yes," says my widow, "but every time he complained of passing blood, I pointed to all the empty jars of beetroot and told him not to be so silly. If he'd been treated sooner, he might have been all right." "Perhaps," says Dr Jarvis, "but at least you cured him of his hypochondriasis." Taking a fountain pen to the death certificate, the doctor writes "explanatory theory" under cause of death, and pausing only to laugh at the irony, the two women leave me to eternity.

webTitle: Secrets of the healthiest nation on the planet

fields.headline: Secrets of the healthiest nation on the planet
fields.standfirst: Raw fish, green tea, seaweed and very little fat... just some of the reasons why the Japanese stay fit and healthy for years longer than the rest of us.  Jonathan Watts  reports from Tokyo
fields.trailText: Raw fish, green tea, seaweed and very little fat... just some of the reasons why the Japanese stay fit and healthy for years longer than the rest of us. Jonathan Watts reports from Tokyo
fields.body:
At first glance, the news that Japan is the world's healthiest nation is something of a surprise. This, after all, is a country with notoriously high levels of pollution and one of the worst suicide rates on the planet.

Walk into a coffee shop and the smog confirms that Japan is a smoker's paradise - more than half the male population light up regularly. Or take a midnight walk around the neon-lit entertainment districts of Shinjuku or Namba and it's clear from the crumpled figures on the pavement that this is also a land of heroic drinking - and a growing alcohol problem. Yet for all this, the 126 million Japanese can expect to live longer and more active lives than anyone else, according to a new report from the World Health Organisation. The average healthy life expectancy in Japan is now 74.5 years, comfortably ahead of France, in second place with 73.2 years, and leagues ahead of Britain, in 14th spot with 71.7 years.

The most commonly cited and convincing explanation is Japan's traditional low-fat and varied diet. Raw fish, green tea, seaweed and pickled plums (so sour that they make your eyes water) are all believed to contribute to some of the lowest rates of cancer and heart disease in the world.

Take the Abe family, a fairly typical household living on the outskirts of Tokyo. Steelworker Hideo Abe is a smoker and a drinker but he expects to live past 70. The reason, he says, is that his grandparents and great grandparents all lived well into their 90s on a diet that was very similar to his own.

The Abes start the day with a bowl of miso and tofu soup, white rice and a few strips of nori (laver seaweed). As a breakfast, it might not sound as tasty as a British fry-up, but it wins hands down in terms of calories and good nutrition.

For lunch, Mr Abe orders a "bento", a boxed meal that contains at least 10 different - all neatly compartmentalised - types of food ranging from pickles and salad to fish and the staple white rice. Mothers send their children off to school with similar bentos, which ensure a far more balanced diet than the usual British fare of sandwiches or meat and two-veg. Mr Abe also makes sure he has a piece of fruit.

For the evening meal, Mrs Abe prepares numerous small dishes. Fish is usually the main one - more than half of the Japanese intake of protein comes from the sea. On the occasions when the Abes do have red meat, they prefer it as "shabu shabu": wafer thin slices of meat that are boiled for just a few seconds.

The Abes wash these meals down with green tea. Although it's made from the same leaves as the black tea popular in the west, it is not fermented, which means it retains more polyphenols, antioxidants that are believed to fight cancer. It is also drunk without milk or sugar, which ensures less fat and fewer calories.

The Abes enjoy alcohol, but like many Japanese, they have recently cut down on beer and sake, and started drinking more red wine. Underlining the health-consciousness of the country, imports of Burgundy have more than tripled since researchers found that red wine may reduce the risk of heart disease.

Such a diet helps to explain why Japanese waistlines are less likely to bulge. Obesity is three times lower than in America and, as a result, there is a less risk of a heart attack or diabetes.

But food alone cannot explain why the country is so healthy. The state has also played a key role, not only as a nanny, but as a nurse, policeman and personal trainer. To keep the nation in trim, the state-run NHK channel broadcasts music and instructions for calisthenic exercises at the crack of dawn each day. More importantly - and unlike the US, which was 24th on the WHO list - Japan is a truly egalitarian society. Once described as the only successful example of socialism, Japan has an average wage of £22,000 and high standards of health care that are within reach of almost everyone.

Change, though, is on the way, with western food and habits gradually catching on. Fat intakes are on the up and fitness levels are declining. Even Mr Abe acknowledges that he may not live as long as his ancestors. "Our generation is different. We've probably had it too good to be really healthy."

webTitle: When the doctors didn't know best

fields.headline: When the doctors didn't know best
fields.standfirst: It began with an itch and ended with a campaign to prevent babies dying in the womb.  Helen Falconer reports on one mother's fight against a condition called obstetric cholestasis
fields.trailText: It began with an itch and ended with a campaign to prevent babies dying in the womb. Helen Falconer reports on one mother's fight against a condition called obstetric cholestasis
fields.body:
Thirty weeks into her first pregnancy, Jenny Chambers' limbs began to itch. She was told not to worry: at that time doctors and consultants were taught that itching during pregnancy was unimportant. But shortly before she was due to give birth, her daughter, Victoria, died in the womb. It was classed as an "unexplained still birth". These things happen, she was told, and it wouldn't happen next time.

In 1988, pregnant for the second time, the itching began at 28 weeks. This time Chambers broke her kneecap in a fall and was admitted to hospital. Confined to her bed and constantly monitored, her baby was induced at 38 weeks. The little boy, Alex, was fine.

In 1990 she was pregnant again with her daughter Olivia, and this time she became unbearably itchy after 27 weeks - hands, feet, arms, legs - "an army of ants was marching under my skin". She couldn't sleep. She scratched until she bled.

Convinced there must be a link between the itching and the loss of the first baby, she and her husband begged the hospital to induce this one by 38 weeks, but they were repeatedly told they were worrying unnecessarily. "No one was listening," Chambers says. Eventually, the doctors announced they would induce her at 39 weeks.

Two days before the date set a hand-held heart monitor showed the baby - little Olivia - alive and well. Yet within six hours the baby was dead. After a short labour, Jenny held her in her arms. "What amazed me was, she was so warm. So perfect. I didn't want to give her away. I wanted to get off the bed and run out of the hospital with her."

The maternity unit called it another unexplained still birth, but Chambers was certain there was an explanation. A senior registrar suggested she talk to a different obstetrician called Judith Weaver in the same hospital. Chambers went to see her and asked: "Do you know why my babies died?" Weaver replied: "Yes. I know exactly why they died."

Weaver told her about obstetric cholestastis, an under-reported and under-diagnosed condition of pregnancy which for some reason can cause stillbirth in pregnancies. Weaver explained that certain blood tests Jenny had during pregnancy had showed a disorder of her liver function - her bile production wasn't flowing normally, and bile had built up in her blood. This hadn't been picked up because her doctors had been taught it didn't matter as she wasn't jaundiced. But what they'd been taught was wrong. Weaver told Jenny that if her baby had been delivered by 38 weeks, "she would have been alive today".

Grieving and shocked, Jenny and her husband considered suing the hospital. But instead they "decided it was better to make sure it never happened again, to anyone else". She threw herself into researching the disease. A friend - a GP who, like most, had never heard of obstetric cholestasis - downloaded articles from the internet. It was clear that if a woman itched in pregnancy, and her liver function tests proved abnormal, the chances were that she had OC, and the solution was simple - delivery by 37 or 38 weeks could prevent nearly every still birth caused by the disease.

Chambers realised that just because a few top doctors had heard of the condition, it didn't mean the message had got into the system. So she began her intensive campaign to raise the OC profile. Through the helpline she set up, she met other women who had lost babies, and encouraged them to join her fight to spread the word.

She never went back to her building society job. Instead she became a phlebotomist - someone trained to take blood - as a way into the NHS. Once inside the system, she spoke to people in labs working in clinical chemistry. She linked up with doctors who were starting research projects in Birmingham and London, and travelled the country lecturing to members of the medical profession.

She sat on the board of a government inquiry into perinatal mortality and, at her insistence, the board included checks for liver function and bile acid in its battery of tests. Results showed that nearly 5% of unexplained still births were probably related to OC. This meant one baby a week in Britain was dying an easily preventable death.

It was solely down to Jenny Chambers that during my latest pregnancy I reported itching to my consultant at Whipps Cross hospital in London. None of the (up-to-date) pregnancy books I'd bought mentioned OC in the index, but I'd read one of the paragraphs Chambers had placed in a baby magazine, and also the entry in the NHS pregnancy guide. My consultant referred me to a colleague, Catherine Nelson-Piercy, who diagnosed OC, a condition currently being researched at Whipps Cross. I was monitored daily, and induced just before 37 weeks. (Twins Imogen and Seán are doing well).

I was amazed how much respect Chambers, a lay person, had among medical professionals. Nelson-Piercy refers to her as her "very good friend" and credits her with the fact that a lot more people know about the disease now than did eight years ago. Andrew Shennan, a senior lecturer at St Thomas's hospital in London, who leads London-based research into the prevalence of OC, also considers Chambers to be "hugely instrumental" in raising understanding of the condition. He refers to her single-handed campaign as "unique".

Current studies are far from complete. The prevalence research only began last August and relies for funding on the perinatal charity Tommy's Campaign. No one is yet sure how many pregnant women get OC (the guess is around 1% to 2% in this country), or how many of those pregnancies are likely to end in still birth if they go to term (possibly 2%). Nobody yet knows why there is a connection between OC and still birth - only that the connection exists. It is very much the case that most women who itch in pregnancy will suffer no ill effects. But there is no need to take chances, because the diagnosis is simple, as is the solution.

Thanks to Chambers, most hospital consultants today are aware that itching is not necessarily benign and will investigate further. Nelson-Piercy agrees, however, that many GPs and midwives are still behind the times. Her message for pregnant women is: "If you itch, don't just request a medical opinion - ask firmly to be given a liver function test."

As for Jenny Chambers, after Olivia's death she vowed never to try for another child. But later, with Weaver as her consultant, she went on to have another son. Baby Tim was induced for everyone's peace of mind at 35 weeks, after another horribly itchy OC pregnancy.

Now 42 years old, Chambers is sad she's never had another daughter, but she cannot regret the two she had. "My work can't bring back my girls," she says, "but it can make sure they didn't die in vain. I feel their deaths have achieved so much."

For more information, call the Obstetric Cholestasis Support Group on: 0121-353 0699

This time Chambers broke her kneecap in a fall and was admitted to hospital. Confined to her bed and constantly monitored, her baby was induced at 38 weeks. The little boy, Alex, was fine. In 1990 she was pregnant again with her daughter Olivia, and this time she became unbearably itchy after 27 weeks - hands, feet, arms, legs - "an army of ants was marching under my skin". She couldn't sleep. She scratched until she bled. Convinced there must be a link between the itching and the loss of the first baby, she and her husband begged the hospital to induce this one by 38 weeks, but they were repeatedly told they were worrying unnecessarily. "No one was listening," Chambers says. Eventually, the doctors announced they would induce her at 39 weeks. Two days before the date set a hand-held heart monitor showed the baby - little Olivia - alive and well. Yet within six hours the baby was dead. After a short labour, Jenny held her in her arms. "What amazed me was, she was so warm. So perfect. I didn't want to give her away. I wanted to get off the bed and run out of the hospital with her." The maternity unit called it another unexplained still birth, but Chambers was certain there was an explanation. A senior registrar suggested she talk to a different obstetrician called Judith Weaver in the same hospital. Chambers went to see her and asked: "Do you know why my babies died?" Weaver replied: "Yes. I know exactly why they died." Weaver told her about obstetric cholestastis, an under-reported and under-diagnosed condition of pregnancy which for some reason can cause stillbirth in pregnancies. Weaver explained that certain blood tests Jenny had during pregnancy had showed a disorder of her liver function - her bile production wasn't flowing normally, and bile had built up in her blood. This hadn't been picked up because her doctors had been taught it didn't matter as she wasn't jaundiced. But what they'd been taught was wrong. Weaver told Jenny that if her baby had been delivered by 38 weeks, "she would have been alive today". Grieving and shocked, Jenny and her husband considered suing the hospital. But instead they "decided it was better to make sure it never happened again, to anyone else". She threw herself into researching the disease. A friend - a GP who, like most, had never heard of obstetric cholestasis - downloaded articles from the internet. It was clear that if a woman itched in pregnancy, and her liver function tests proved abnormal, the chances were that she had OC, and the solution was simple - delivery by 37 or 38 weeks could prevent nearly every still birth caused by the disease. Chambers realised that just because a few top doctors had heard of the condition, it didn't mean the message had got into the system. So she began her intensive campaign to raise the OC profile. Through the helpline she set up, she met other women who had lost babies, and encouraged them to join her fight to spread the word. She never went back to her building society job. Instead she became a phlebotomist - someone trained to take blood - as a way into the NHS. Once inside the system, she spoke to people in labs working in clinical chemistry. She linked up with doctors who were starting research projects in Birmingham and London, and travelled the country lecturing to members of the medical profession. She sat on the board of a government inquiry into perinatal mortality and, at her insistence, the board included checks for liver function and bile acid in its battery of tests. Results showed that nearly 5% of unexplained still births were probably related to OC. This meant one baby a week in Britain was dying an easily preventable death. It was solely down to Jenny Chambers that during my latest pregnancy I reported itching to my consultant at Whipps Cross hospital in London. None of the (up-to-date) pregnancy books I'd bought mentioned OC in the index, but I'd read one of the paragraphs Chambers had placed in a baby magazine, and also the entry in the NHS pregnancy guide. My consultant referred me to a colleague, Catherine Nelson-Piercy, who diagnosed OC, a condition currently being researched at Whipps Cross. I was monitored daily, and induced just before 37 weeks. (Twins Imogen and Seán are doing well). I was amazed how much respect Chambers, a lay person, had among medical professionals. Nelson-Piercy refers to her as her "very good friend" and credits her with the fact that a lot more people know about the disease now than did eight years ago. Andrew Shennan, a senior lecturer at St Thomas's hospital in London, who leads London-based research into the prevalence of OC, also considers Chambers to be "hugely instrumental" in raising understanding of the condition. He refers to her single-handed campaign as "unique". Current studies are far from complete. The prevalence research only began last August and relies for funding on the perinatal charity Tommy's Campaign. No one is yet sure how many pregnant women get OC (the guess is around 1% to 2% in this country), or how many of those pregnancies are likely to end in still birth if they go to term (possibly 2%). Nobody yet knows why there is a connection between OC and still birth - only that the connection exists. It is very much the case that most women who itch in pregnancy will suffer no ill effects. But there is no need to take chances, because the diagnosis is simple, as is the solution. Thanks to Chambers, most hospital consultants today are aware that itching is not necessarily benign and will investigate further. Nelson-Piercy agrees, however, that many GPs and midwives are still behind the times. Her message for pregnant women is: "If you itch, don't just request a medical opinion - ask firmly to be given a liver function test." As for Jenny Chambers, after Olivia's death she vowed never to try for another child. But later, with Weaver as her consultant, she went on to have another son. Baby Tim was induced for everyone's peace of mind at 35 weeks, after another horribly itchy OC pregnancy. Now 42 years old, Chambers is sad she's never had another daughter, but she cannot regret the two she had. "My work can't bring back my girls," she says, "but it can make sure they didn't die in vain. I feel their deaths have achieved so much." For more information, call the Obstetric Cholestasis Support Group on: 0121-353 0699

fields.headline: Is laser eye surgery safe?
fields.standfirst: In just a matter of minutes - with almost no pain - you could have perfect eyesight. But little is known about the long-term effects of some treatments, says  Esther Addley
fields.trailText: In just a matter of minutes - with almost no pain - you could have perfect eyesight. But little is known about the long-term effects of some treatments, says Esther Addley
fields.body:
Spice girl Mel G has done it. So has Richard Branson. Actress Courteney Cox says it's saved her career. It's not a wonder slimming drug or a new tantric meditation technique, but a relatively straightforward and relatively new laser treatment to correct short sight. A gaggle of celebs are queueing up to rave about Lasik laser surgery, each in terms more breathless than the last. "It's a miracle, I feel I've been given a new life," Cox says. Before she had the surgery, she could not read cue cards or an autoprompt, and even had difficulty telling her Friends co-stars Lisa Kudrow and Jennifer Aniston apart (one is blonde, the other a brunette). Cox's eyesight was so bad that she qualified as legally blind. Now, she says, "every day is a new experience of vibrant images".

It may sound too good to be true, but Lasik surgery (Lasik stands for "laser in situ kertatomileusis") does promise something little short of miraculous. An almost entirely painless technique to correct chronically poor eyesight, with immediate improvement in vision, the technique takes only 10 minutes for each eye. You can even have it done the day you walk into a surgery, so long as you have £3,000 in your pocket.

Tempted by a while-you-wait one-stop eyesight shop, 12,000 myopic patients in the UK and close to 1m in the US are signing up for it each year. It's now the most common form of elective surgery in America and accounts for 90% of all laser eye operations each year in this country. "People walk into a surgery and 20 minutes later they throw away their glasses," says a spokesman for the Moorfields eye hospital.

It is six years since Lasik treatment was first offered in the UK and five years since it was licensed in the US, but the long-term safety of the procedure is far from proven. In 1998 the Home Office suggested that police forces reject any candidates who had undergone any form of laser eye surgery as its efficacy was unproven. Now some eye experts are questioning its safety, in particular whether it can lead to long-term vision deterioration or even disintegration of the eyeballs.

The procedure, in which the surgeon lifts a sliver of the cornea with a knife, removes some tissue beneath it with a laser and replaces the sliver, is known as "flap and zap" because of its supposed speed and ease. But, warn experts, if the surgery goes awry it can lead to the cornea bulging, or parts of it becoming dislodged. In extreme cases some patients may even need a complete corneal transplant.

John Marshall, professor of ophthalmology at St Thomas's hospital in London and the country's leading expert on laser eye surgery, has this week expressed reservations about the long-term safety of the Lasik technique. He was involved in the development of Lasik's more conservative predecessor, the photo-refractive keratectomy (PRK) treatment, in which microscopic amounts of tis sue are removed from the surface of the cornea with an ultraviolet beam of light. It can take some months for the eyes to heal, during which time there can be some pain and clouding.

"If you are offered two types of surgery, one of which is painless, the other of which involves some pain, there is virtually no doubt that you will go for the former," says Marshall. "If I said in the second operation I will remove less than 5% of the wall of your eye, whereas in the other I'll cut into a third of your eyeball, you might think again. And if I said that in the case of PRK I have 10 years of follow-up data, but in the second I don't know if it will be stable, your decision might be very different.

"I'm not saying that one is bad and the other isn't. It is just that Lasik is a much more aggressive procedure and we don't have a lot of information about the long-term effects."

Certainly Lasik treatment galloped into use in the US, passed by the Food and Drug Administration after only two years. Marshall says he is concerned "because before doing such huge numbers it would have been nice to have had more long-term follow-up."

Those worried about the potential scale of the problem should look to the US, where a support group called Surgical Eyes exists for people whose laser treatment has gone wrong. Executive director Ron Link says it is difficult to measure the scale of the problem, but that he knows of 1,000 people who have suffered long-term eye damage, with another 4,000 potential cases waiting to be assessed.

I'm not saying that Lasik is a bad procedure, but it is not being used appropriately," he says. "Secondly, people do not realise that if they have a bad result, there is no Plan B. The impression is that you can go back into glasses and contact lenses, and nothing is further from the truth." If the surgery goes wrong, you may need reconstructive surgery - or end up almost blind.

Marshall agrees that the key is being as informed as possible before paying for surgery. The treatment is not appropriate, for instance, for those with vision worse than -12 diaopters (extreme short sight). If a private clinic tells you otherwise, be suspicious, and walk away if they offer to do the procedure on the same day as the first consultation. The Royal College of Ophthalmologists publishes guidelines for practitioners and potential patients. The only way the latter will know whether their surgeon follows these guidelines, says a spokeswoman, is to make sure they are well-informed themselves.

"The fact remains that with a 95% success rate, this procedure has one of the highest success rates of any operation," says Marshall. It is just that when it goes wrong, it goes very wrong - and no one knows the real risks. "I'm not saying that it is going to ruin your eyes, but I just want people to be aware that there are potential risks. You have no idea of what will happen in four or five years' time."

webTitle: Regrets, politicians have had a few

fields.headline: Regrets, politicians have had a few
fields.standfirst: Apologising for the wrongs done to people by previous governments may make leading political figures look good but Derek Brown asks if it really means anything to the victims
fields.trailText: Apologising for the wrongs done to people by previous governments may make leading political figures look good but Derek Brown asks if it really means anything to the victims.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's apology to the Guildford Four, who were wrongly locked away for 15 years for the Guildford pub bombings of 1974, is the latest spillage of crocodile tears by a politician who feels obliged, every so often, to say sorry for things he hasn't done.

The prime minister is in august company. The Pope has apologised for Catholics being beastly to Jews. The prime minister of Japan has mumbled his regrets for the unpleasantness in the Pacific from 1941 to 1945. The Queen has politely implied her sorrow about the appalling events in Amritsar in 1919.

Blair has a record of public sorrow over Irish events, having most notably apologised for the potato famine of the 1840s. A public expression of regret for the Strongbow expedition to Leinster in 1169 cannot, surely, be long delayed.

Such apologies seem to be woven into the fabric of modern statesmanship. They are easily mocked, but there is a serious aspect to them: that is, their very shallowness and irrelevance.

The details of Blair's new apology will be fully disclosed tonight on the BBC Northern Ireland programme, Spotlight, which follows the fortunes of Paul Hill, one of the Guildford Four.

Hill's wife is Courtney Kennedy, daughter of the murdered US Attorney General Robert Kennedy. It was to her, not Mr Hill, that the celebrity-conscious prime minister directed his thoughts.

"There were miscarriages of justice in your husband's case, and the cases of those convicted with him," he wrote, and who can argue with that? But then he went on: "I am very sorry indeed that this should have happened."

That is no doubt very decent of him, but it hardly passes the 'so what' test. Mr Hill, for one, won't lose much sleep over the prime minister's sorrow. He is more concerned with his claim to be adequately compensated for being wrongly imprisoned for 15 years.

He and countless others whose lives have been blighted by more than 30 years of conflict in Northern Ireland want more than cheap gestures.

However, if our public men insist on apology as a substitute for action, it would be good to hear a more balanced range of regrets. Maybe The Reverend Ian Paisley could say sorry for his bellowing intransigence, Gerry Adams could admit that, just possibly, his opponents occasionally have a point, and the British army could apologise for some of its more bone-headed actions.

Who knows, even the IRA could apologise for the couple of thousand lives it has snuffed out, including the dead of Guildford.

But that is too absurd. Sorry.

fields.headline: Don't be afraid
fields.trailText: Within the next month, possibly within the next few days, the sequencing of the human genome will be effectively complete. This is a scientific, technical and cultural prize which ranks among the highest of our achievements as human beings, having deciphered a secret as old as ourselves. Simply put, it will revolutionise human biology: it has the potential to bring huge benefits to all of us.
fields.body:
Within the next month, possibly within the next few days, the sequencing of the human genome will be effectively complete. This is a scientific, technical and cultural prize which ranks among the highest of our achievements as human beings, having deciphered a secret as old as ourselves. Simply put, it will revolutionise human biology: it has the potential to bring huge benefits to all of us.

Sadly, for many people the news will only stimulate uneasiness, even fear, conditioned by the current atmosphere of ignorance and mistrust of science. Why is it that in Britain there is such a strong anti-scientific bias, especially among opinion formers and commentators? Why do most people feel unsure that they could accurately judge the merits of the use of scientific knowledge but easily fall prey to scare-mongering about GM food? The reasons are many and some are easy to identify - the paucity of scientific training among Britain's politicians, mandarins and media gurus, the English upper-class loathing of getting one's hands dirty, and our awful school science education.

This fear and loathing of science, engineering and technology, damages both British society and our chances of meeting the challenges ahead. "Northern chemists" are sneered at by the Oxbridge literateurs and in the City greed and gambling for short-term gain have edged out prudent, long-term investment in research and development. British commerce and industry spend only £130 per head of population on research and development, whereas in the United States it is six times as much. The only truly vibrant research-led British industry is the pharmaceutical industry (the developing electronics industry of the 70s having been effectively killed by Tories), but even this is under great threat.

Jan Leschly and Richard Sykes, bosses of soon to be merged SmithKline Beecham/Glaxo Wellcome, recently told the House of Commons science and technology committee that Britain is in danger of becoming a poor place to run a science-based industry. This is partly because of public hostility, but also because of the lack of government investment in science and technology in universities, which is now only 85% of what it was in 1995. Leschly and Sykes's veiled threat is probably serious. In the 70s the hysterical reactions of green activists against the bio-manufacture of medicines forced German pharmaceutical companies to relocate manufacturing and R&D in Ireland and the US. Germany is only now catching up.

What can be done about the current situation? Of course scientists must bear some responsibility. We must engage and be open minded, and eschew the arrogance we so often hide behind. We must be careful to prove that while being pro-science we are against its misuse - where it can be genuinely shown. But we must also stand up for ourselves and our community in stop ping the headlong rush towards unreason. Wherever possible, working scientists should point out the difference between hazard (a potential for harm) and risk (the actual probability of harm occurring); the inability to see this difference is probably the single biggest difficulty non-specialists have in deciding whether a science-related development is good or bad. Science, in any case, cannot provide absolute answers: such certainties are ruled out by the scientific method, without which we would still believe that the sun went round the earth.

Journalists will also have to learn these inescapable truths. I find it immensely ironic that after amplifying all the self-righteous guff from GM food campaigners concerning the so-called precautionary principle, the media were immensely frustrated by Bill Stewart's report on the safety of mobile phones. He and his committee refused absolutely to proscribe the use of mobile phones for children but instead pointed out that there was an identifiable hazard to people whose nervous systems were still developing and that more research should be carried out to determine the risk. It might be messy but the universe is like that.

However, the major task facing society in respect of public understanding of science is the problem of science education in schools. Ideally we should educate children to understand that by and large science works - it produces reliable knowledge capable of proving, for example, that Halley's comet will reappear periodically or that certain patterns of DNA can only have come from a particular criminal suspect. More importantly, however, we should teach children how to weigh evidence and how to identify plausible but meaningless propositions (such as that evolution is "only" a theory). At the moment consideration of what science is, what it can do and the limits of its usefulness are crowded out of the school curriculum by an over-emphasis on facts.

Considering that only a small proportion of the population ever needs to use these facts, attempting to force them into the brains of unwilling recipients has caused wholesale rejection. Hence science education must be reformed so that by 16, our children have sufficient understanding of the way science works, the reliability of its findings and the relevance and applicability to our lives, so that they can make informed and sensible decisions about what they want.

Only those school students who have a particular scientific bent should be helped to acquire the detailed scientific knowledge needed prior to advanced study at universities. Unless we do this, we will have a population which is effectively disenfranchised due to a lack of adequate decision-making tools; worse, it will be open to be manipulated by sectional interests, whether of the religious right, the eco-fascists or the stockmarket wide boys.

Michael J Rennie is Symers professor of physiology at Dundee University.

Unless we do this, we will have a population which is effectively disenfranchised due to a lack of adequate decision-making tools; worse, it will be open to be manipulated by sectional interests, whether of the religious right, the eco-fascists or the stockmarket wide boys. Michael J Rennie is Symers professor of physiology at Dundee University. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The Northern Ireland police bill
fields.standfirst: Peter Mandelson is having a big day in the House of Commons. We explain why.
fields.trailText: 1. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is putting his police bill before parliament. The bill is supposed to implement the proposals of the Patten report, which recommended radical reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.
fields.body:
1. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is putting his police bill before parliament. The bill is supposed to implement the proposals of the Patten report, which recommended radical reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

2. Ulster Unionist MPs are expected to turn up in force to harangue Mandelson, who wants to transform the force into the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

3. The Ulster Unionist MPs, and their more raucous rivals in the Democratic Unionist Party, want to keep the royal name, and also the crown-and-harp badge.

4. Symbolism has always been a vital ingredient in the Ulster broth. Debate in the Northern Ireland Assembly, which resumed work yesterday after a four-month suspension, has been dominated by furious unionist demands for the Union flag to be flown over departments headed by Sinn Fein ministers.

5. The first secretary of Northern Ireland's executive, David Trimble, has come close to making retention of the RUC title a condition of continued power sharing.

6. But as Trimble savages the bill, the moderate nationalists of the Social Democratic and Labour party will also criticise any part of it they see as diluting the Patten proposals.

7. Sinn Fein MPs Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness will not be in parliament, because they refuse to take the oath of loyalty. But they, too, will fiercely condemn any perceived backsliding by Mandelson.

8. The Northern Ireland police ombudsman, Nuala O'Loan, is already pressing for amendments to the bill.

9. Police reform is an essential component of the Good Friday peace accord. The Irish government, and the US president, Bill Clinton, are pressing hard for speedy implementation of the Patten plan.

10. Another interest group praying for the success of police reform is the British army, which has manned the front line in the Northern Irish troubles for 31 years.

fields.headline: Bluetooth
fields.standfirst: Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications group, has announced the launch of its Bluetooth mobile phone - the first to allow customers to access their computers from their handset. Mark Tran looks at this latest technological breakthrough
fields.trailText: Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications group, has announced the launch of its Bluetooth mobile phone - the first to allow customers to access their computers from their handset. We look at this latest technological breakthrough
fields.body:
What is Bluetooth?
Bluetooth wireless technology enables mobile phones, computers and personal digital assistants (PDAs) to connect with each other using short-range radio waves, allowing them to "talk" to each other so they can be all coordinated. It's a bit like opening your car door with an electronic key by infrared, except at a more advanced level. It is also cheaper.

What is the advantage for mobile phone users?
The main selling point is that it does away with the jumble of wires and adaptors that encumber many mobile phone users. Ericsson will also offer the Bluetooth home base, which will automatically detect the presence of a mobile phone and connect it to a landline when the user is near or at home, saving on mobile phone bills and allowing the owner to have just one phone for all calls.

And after mobile phones?
Backers of Bluetooth technology say it will eventually be found in all sorts of devices, such as desktops, printers, fridges, VCRs and stereos. For example, when you'll get home, the door will automatically unlock for you, the hallway lights will come on, and the heat will adjust to your pre-set preferences.

How can Bluetooth be used in the office?
If you're giving a presentation, Bluetooth will allow you to send your presentation from your PDA to an electronic screen. If you record minutes from a meeting on your PDA, you'll be able to wirelessly transfer the data to colleagues before they leave the meeting.

How does Bluetooth work?
A low-cost transceiver chip is included in each device and transmits and receives in a previously unused frequency band which exists globally. In addition to data, up to three voice channels are available. The maximum range is 10 metres.

What is Ericsson's timeframe to introduce the new technology?
It will be bringing out the first mobile phones with the Bluetooth feature this year, allowing customers to access their computers from their handset. Ericsson began work on a short-distance radio system in 1994 and donated its research to the Bluetooth interest group.

Who is behind Bluetooth?
Five companies set up the Bluetooth special interest group in 1997 to come up with a common standard. The original group - Ericsson, IBM, Intel, Nokia and Toshiba - were joined earlier this year by Microsoft, 3COM, Lucent and Motorola. The group licences the technology to hardware and software manufacturers.

How popular is Bluetooth technology likely to be?
Merrill Lynch predicts that Bluetooth will be found in 1.7bn electronic devices around the world by 2005. Ericsson believes that up to 1bn Bluetooth devices will be sold annually by 2005 with prices falling as market penetration increases.

Where does the name Bluetooth come from?
From Harald Bluetooth, a Danish king from the 10th century famous for getting people to talk to each other.

Does Bluetooth have any connection with WAP phones and third-generation mobile technology?
No. They are entirely separate technologies.

fields.headline: Nail bomber 'felt nothing'
fields.trailText: The nail bomber who killed three people and injured dozens of others in a terrifying campaign last spring "did not feel anything" when his third bomb detonated at a busy gay bar in Soho, the Old Bailey was told today.
fields.body:
The nail bomber who killed three people and injured dozens of others in a terrifying campaign last spring "did not feel anything" when his third bomb detonated at a busy gay bar in Soho, the Old Bailey was told today.

David Copeland, 24, told police he hated homosexuals and believed they should be put to death. A man in a sex shop told him the Admiral Duncan was a gay pub and, to make sure, he went inside to find it was full of men hugging each other.

Nigel Sweeney, QC, prosecuting, said that Mr Copeland told police: "I saw the people I was going to maim and kill - I didn't feel joy or sad, I didn't feel anything."

Four-months-pregnant Andrea Dykes, 27, Nicholas Moore, 31, and John Light, 32, were killed in the attack on April 30 last year. 70 others were injured.

"There were 70 people in the pub that Friday night. The effect in that confined space was devastating," said Nigel Sweeney, QC, prosecuting.

Copeland brought forward his plan to bomb a gay pub in Soho by a day after his picture was released by police and published in the media. He built the lethal device in two central London hotels booked under a false name.

His work colleague, Paul Mifsud, recognised the bomber from the publicity and informed police at 5.30pm on the day of the Soho bomb.

"It was not his fault that by then Copeland was already in Soho with his bomb. Also, there was nothing police could have done to prevent the defendant carrying out his bombing," Mr Sweeney said.

Copeland was arrested at his home on May 1 where officers found Nazi flags on the wall.

"Yeah, they're down to me, I did them on my own," he told officers.

After his arrest Copeland said he felt sorry for Andrea Dykes because she had a baby. "I do feel sick about that. I just had to do it. It was my destiny," he told police. He said he also felt sorry about the 23-month-old boy who had a nail embedded in his skull after the Brixton bomb.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Tories tap into the teacher vote

fields.headline: Tories tap into the teacher vote
fields.standfirst: In dredging up the old stereotype of the "liberal elite" running the nation's education system, Conservative leader William Hague may have stumbled on a vote winner, writes education editor Will Woodward
fields.trailText: In dredging up the old stereotype of the "liberal elite" running the nation's education system, Conservative leader William Hague may have stumbled on a vote winner, writes education editor Will Woodward
fields.body:
It's an old political trick: define yourself by your enemies. William Hague has been doing this for some months now, and he's been buoyed by the response.

So, after asylum seekers and burglars (a response to the Tony Martin trial in Norfolk), comes a new assault on a regular Tory-devised caricature - the "liberal elite" that runs education.

During their 18 years in power, the Conservatives slung everything they could at this "elite" - including the introduction of grant-maintained schools as a way of shattering the unions - but apparently failed to smash the liberals.

Now, their leader is promising they "will not just turn the tide - we will defeat the liberal elite that has brought our education system to its knees."

But few outside the Tory party hierarchy - not even the Daily Mail - would argue that the current government is soft on liberals in education. Those liberals can't stop complaining about it: too much testing, too much direction, too much Ofsted.

Some of his criticisms smack of false iconoclasm: David Blunkett doesn't believe in setting quotas for state school students going to university, only that universities ought to do more to enlist from those in state schools who do get the grades. Mr Blunkett, too, wants to hand back more power over budgets to headteachers.

But Mr Hague may have discovered a rich seam of potential Tory support. The teacher vote, until recently, was mostly Conservative. Issues like pupil exclusion could be telling.

Mr Blunkett has set targets for reducing the number of exclusions by a third by 2002, and for all his protestations that this doesn't mean violent children should be allowed back into school, there is some strength in the argument that the target is artificial.

Issues like this unite teachers and parents, whereas the education battles of the Tory years over league tables, GM schools and suchlike have tended to divide them. Played right, this could be a clever political strategy.

fields.headline: Mandelson's balancing act
fields.standfirst: The watering-down of the Patten proposals has kept unionists on board but gives republicans a ready reason to abandon the peace process, says Ireland correspondent John Mullin
fields.trailText: The watering-down of the Patten proposals has kept unionists on board but gives republicans a ready reason to abandon the peace process, says Ireland correspondent John Mullin.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson is this afternoon expected to unveil concessions on RUC reform when he speaks at the second reading of the Policing Bill in the Commons. This time, his move is an attempt to keep nationalists and republicans happy.

EU commissioner Chris Patten's proposals last September to modernise the 78-year-old force have left Mr Mandelson playing a delicate game of see-saw. He is trying to maintain a balance, with the future of the power-sharing executive and other institutions of devolved government as much as stake as the police service.

Mr Mandelson's primary task last month was to appeal to Ulster Unionists as they considered whether to re-join the executive after it was suspended in February over the vexed issue of IRA decommissioning. He finally reassured them with pledges to include the RUC's name in the "title deeds" of the Policing Bill, while confirming the force's operational title would change.

David Trimble's party was convinced - just. It voted on May 27 to re-join government with Sinn Fein on the back of the IRA's unprecedented offer to put weapons beyond use, and powers were again devolved from Westminster on May 30.

But the nationalist SDLP, which had warmly welcomed the Patten proposals, listed 44 areas in which the Policing Bill diverged from them. It said it could not support the legislation as it stood.

Sinn Fein, which had rejected the Patten report as too little, changed its approach. It called for it to be reinstated, having exceeded the SDLP's count by spotting 75 differences between Mr Patten's recommendations and the Policing Bill.

There is an implicit threat at the heart of Sinn Fein's argument. It is warning that the IRA's offer on arms was made on the understanding the government would implement Patten in full, and the inference is the IRA may withdraw its initiative, collapsing devolution.

The legislation limits the powers of the proposed Police Board, ombudsman and commissioner, and departs from Patten's suggestion that local boards could raise up to 3p in the pound. The crucial symbolic issues of name, emblems and oath have also been muddied.

Mr Mandelson is expected to move closer to Patten, though many of the changes will come only when the legislation goes into its committee stage. That may be enough to pull the SDLP back on board, but republicans, if they choose, have their get-out excuse if they want to drag their feet on the decommissioning initiative.

webTitle: GM foods: The stuff royal rifts are made of

fields.headline: GM foods: The stuff royal rifts are made of
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist David McKie dissects the dispute over GM crops dividing the Windsors
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 1pm: Guardian columnist David McKie dissects the dispute over GM crops dividing the Windsors
fields.body:
The descendants of Richard Wagner, it emerges today, are engaged in a complex family feud as to who should manage the composer's artistic legacy. Top of the pile at present is Wolfgang, Richard's grandson, who, although 80, won't step down from his job as festival director at Bayreuth unless the job goes to his present wife; as opposed to two other determined candidates, his first wife's daughter Eva, and a rebellious niece.

Let nobody think that the British can't stage dynastic feuds of this vividness. It may not be quite as lurid, as suffused by the spirit of Götterdämmerung, but we have our own home-grown equivalent here in the form of the sudden dynastic dispute ravaging the House of Windsor.

Prince Charles, as everyone knows, is keen on organic farming and aghast at genetically modified foods. But this weekend, his sister the Princess Royal came out the other way round. In an interview with the Grocer, a publication to which royals don't usually talk, she gently but firmly disparaged organic farming and spoke in guarded favour of GM foods.

The Queen, in public at least, is neutral in these matters. But now the Duke of Edinburgh has dipped a characteristically insensitive toe into the great debate. He thinks (I paraphrase here, but only slightly) that the great GM agitation is a lot of boloney. Were these techniques, he demanded, so very different from breeding fast racehorses together to produce even faster racehorses? (The House of Windsor is famously fond of bloodstock metaphor.) Far greater threats, he told a meeting at Windsor Castle, had been introduced into the ecology over the years: grey squirrels, for instance.

Like other previous outbursts from this source, this one may not have been designed to reach the ears of the public. The duke was replying to a GM-sceptical lecture from the Chief Rabbi, Jonathan Sacks. But now that Charles is outnumbered two to one, it seems only right for other family members to enter the lists.

We have yet to hear the view of Prince Andrew, who perhaps believe that GM foods are what gets served in the Vauxhall canteen. Where does Fergie stand on these matters? Or Prince Edward? And will the Queen Mother speak out - perhaps at the celebrations, now only two months away, of her 100th birthday? Beyond them stand dukes and duchesses in serried ranks, their views still unplumbed by the media. Now the duke is involved, this story could run and run.

webTitle: Six hurt as Eurostar derails at 155mph

fields.headline: Six hurt as Eurostar derails at 155mph
fields.standfirst:
Transport in Britain: special report
Graphic: what happened?
fields.trailText: A Eurostar train travelling at around 155mph and carrying 501 passengers from Paris to London partially derailed in northern France yesterday, leaving six people hurt.
fields.body:
A Eurostar train travelling at around 155mph and carrying 501 passengers from Paris to London partially derailed in northern France yesterday, leaving six people hurt.

Neither the police nor the French rail authority SNCF had an immediate explanation for the accident, the first to involve a Eurostar train, which happened shortly before 6pm local time outside the village of Croisilles, near Arras, 110 miles north of Paris.

An SNCF spokeswoman said the wheels of the train's front three cars, which house the driver's cabin and the locomotive units, had left the tracks while the train was travelling at high speed. The train's 21 passenger carriages ground to a halt but remained upright and on the rails.

"Several people were shaken but no one was physically hurt," the spokeswoman said. "The passengers have been transferred by bus to Lille. Some are being picked up by Eurostars to complete their journey; others have chosen to return to Paris by train."

Emergency services in Arras said no one was seriously hurt but six passengers suffered minor bruising. A pregnant woman was taken to a nearby hospital as a precaution, a spokesman said. The line was closed for several hours.

Police and SNCF officials said nothing had been found on or near the tracks to suggest why the train, the 17.10 from Paris, had left the tracks. A full inquiry was underway, the spokeswoman said, adding that it is very rare for trains of the TGV design - the French high-speed design on which Eurostar is based - to derail.

Eurostar trains, which cross northern France on dedicated tracks at up to 186 mph, have had breakdowns in the past but have not derailed.

SNCF has always claimed that the TGV's low centre of gravity makes it more stable than traditional trains. Only two TGVs have derailed in the past seven years.

The accident came a day after the Vintimiglia-Calais express, not a TGV service, was derailed near Lyon in central France, killing two passengers and injuring 15.

A man of Algerian origin, known to have radical Islamic views and a history of psychiatric problems, yesterday confessed to derailing the train by placing iron rails on the track.

The train, carrying about 250 passengers to Calais, was derailed early on Sunday near Chasse-sur-Rhone station.

Nine of the train's passenger cars jumped the track, with the locomotive flipping over and landing on the first carriage. A Belgian passenger died of a heart attack, and one of the train's conductors was killed. Fifteen passengers were treated for slight injuries.

Good safety record, poor returns

Keith Harper

Eurostar has had an exemplary safety record since its first journey in November 1994, although it has been dogged by public relations problems.

They mainly occurred in the early stages of its operation. On the very first day Eurostar failed to leave Waterloo due to an electrical fault and it was several hours before a replacement set was produced.

Build up was slower than planned by British Rail, the French state railway (SNCF), and Belgium Railways. This reflected the delayed delivery of the trains and the time taken to deal with the problems revealed by commissioning and testing.

The worst setback was the Channel Tunnel fire in November 1996. All services were suspended for a month and full services were not restored until June 1997.

The official cause of the fire has never been given. It started on a shuttle train on the French side of the tunnel and is believed to have been deliberately caused by a dissident worker.

The incident last night in which a train was partially derailed in northern France leaving six people hurt was described by one expert as "a miraculous escape" for passengers. But investigators will want to know why Eurostar encountered problems after a stringent safety inspection.

Although the Eurostar service has increased the travel market between London and Paris, with a 60% market share over the airlines, the number of passengers has been well below expectations.

The original forecasts were wildly inaccurate, suggesting that Eurostar would be carrying up to 15m passengers a year by 2000. But the numbers are barely half that and Eurostar has yet to make a profit. It is losing around £70m a year.
