webTitle: Why Viv said no to a party and Nkala wrote to WCM

fields.headline: Why Viv said no to a party and Nkala wrote to WCM
fields.standfirst: Wisden.com's gossip column, which has already prompted follow-up stories in the newspapers, is going bi-weekly. In his first midweek edition, Charles de Lisle reports on the book do that wasn't, the latest Telegraph journalist named Martin-Jenkins, and Mluleki Nkala's first taste of fame
fields.trailText: Viv poops his own party
fields.body:
Viv poops his own party

Always one to play things his way, Viv Richards has just become one of the few authors to spurn a publisher's offer of a party to publicise their new book. It's as though he had ducked a Bob Willis bouncer instead of hooking it majestically for six.

The launch of Viv's "definitive" autobiography, Sir Vivian (Michael Joseph, £16.99), was pencilled in for the Cafe Royal in London's West End next Tuesday evening, but the party is now officially off. The reason? The laid-back Sir Viv couldn't be bothered - or didn't have time during his recent globetrotting - to produce a guest list.

It would have been quite a list, ranging from Mick Jagger and Eric Clapton to Ian Botham, many other great players, several press boxes' worth of cricket broadcasters and writers - and at least some of the current Windies side (though they would have had to plead a prior engagement: preparation for the first Test at Edgbaston). And the party wouldn't have cost Viv or his ghostwriter Bob Harris - who has also co-authored books with Kevin Keegan and Steve Coppell - a penny: in contrast to many publishing parties, the tab would have been picked up in full by the publishers, Michael Joseph.

Although Richards willingly agreed to a promotional lunch at Harrods (next week), as well as a number of book signings, a formal launch party seems to hold little allure for him. "Sadly, Viv's agent told us he couldn't be expected to supply a list," says a Michael Joseph source. "We're a little frustrated, but without full commitment from the author you cannot go ahead. We've not totally given up hope. Maybe there'll be a do towards the end of the season."

Nkala catches up with his "heroes"

Mluleki Nkala, Zimbabwe's debutant in the Trent Bridge Test, is a precocious figure. Not only has he reached the Test arena aged barely 19, and dismissed Sachin Tendulkar with his second ball in one-day internationals, but shortly before that, aged 15, he had a letter published in Wisden Cricket Monthly.

Nkala, who only left Falcon College, a private school near Bulawayo, late last year, wrote to the magazine drawing attention to the school's unrivalled contribution to Zimbabwe sides (only Prince Edward's, Harare, which produced Graeme Hick, comes close).

The letter, published in the January 1997 WCM, pointed out that the then Zimbabwe Test squad included seven Falcon alumni - Stephen Peall, Heath Streak, Craig Wishart, both Strangs and both Whittalls - while the side for the Lombard Under-15 World Challenge in England in 1996 had featured another seven (Brown, Croxford, Ewing, McCallum, Madondo, Munson and himself).

Nkala was then so unknown that WCM, unable to read his handwriting, called him Nhola. He rounded off his letter with some complimentary remarks about the magazine, explaining: "It helps me keep up with my world Test heroes".

Telegraph signs another Martin-Jenkins

It hasn't taken The Daily Telegraph long to reintroduce the name Martin-Jenkins to its sports pages. Only a year after its cricket correspondent Christopher Martin-Jenkins made his surprise move to The Times, the Telegraph has hit back by signing his son Robin.

The Sussex all-rounder's brief is to produce a column on the county scene every three weeks. In the next one, due out this week, Martin-Jenkins will have a good story to tell - taking 5 for 94 as Sussex rolled Glamorgan by ten wickets in the Championship last weekend. The first two columns were better than the average player effort: sharp, thoughtful, vivid and with the odd humorous touch - and he writes it all himself. "I think Dad finds it's quite amusing I'm writing for his old paper," says Robin. "He says my columns read OK."

CMJ would certainly approve of the plea for the introduction of regional cricket to be found in Robin's first effort, and one can imagine him nodding at the final line of his second: "Maybe we [in English cricket] need to lighten up a bit, take the pressure off ourselves a bit more and not worry so much about the outcome of each game."

RMJ, 24, was called up when the Telegraph, seeking a successor to Kent captain Matthew Fleming, spotted the column he has written for the Brighton Evening Argus for the past year, and thought it "pretty good". He also managed to sustain the weekly slot through an off season enlivened only by a knee operation and his marriage.

Robin hasn't given any serious thought to following his old man into the media centres, though he admits the Telegraph experience could prove handy. "Hopefully I'll play for another ten years," he says, "but you never know when your cricket career's going to end."

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com

For last Friday's Grapevine, featuring stories on Gloucestershire hitting drunks - and poverty - for six, the star players who will be partying during the Lord's Test, and Sky Sports drawing the short straw, click here

webTitle: PM taken hostage in Solomon Islands

fields.headline: PM taken hostage in Solomon Islands
fields.trailText: The prime minister of the Solomon Islands, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, was taken hostage at gunpoint yesterday in a coup attempt led by a prominent lawyer, Andrew Nori.
fields.body:
The prime minister of the Solomon Islands, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, was taken hostage at gunpoint yesterday in a coup attempt led by a prominent lawyer, Andrew Nori.

The Australian foreign minister, Alexander Downer, said Mr Nori, a key figure in politics in the islands and the head of the Malaita Eagle Force, was demanding that Mr Ulufa'alu resign for failing to curb escalating ethnic tensions.

"The leader of the Malaita Eagle Force, Andrew Nori, is simply insisting that the prime minister resign," Mr Downer said. The islands' broadcasting corporation said that Mr Nori, who outlined his demands yesterday during a news conference in the capital, Honiara, called himself a "mediator".

Mr Nori said his armed militia had taken control of the capital to prevent criminals from taking advantage of the situation. He said the prime minister was safe and would be released within days.

"Nori said the [resignation] demand was the result of failure by the government to positively address the current ethnic crisis," the radio said.

During the last 18 months, about 60 people have been killed in fighting between rival ethnic groups from the eastern island of Malaita and the main island of Guadalcanal, where Honiara is located.

The Guadalcanal islanders resent the Malaitans' dominance of Honiara politics and business. A local militia group, the Isatabu Freedom Movement, has forced up to 20,000 Malaitans to flee their homes.

Mr Nori, who comes from Malaita and has been the Eagle Force's lawyer, is a long-term political rival of Mr Ulufa'alu, who is also from Malaita but has been accused of not doing enough to protect the interests of islanders there.

Diplomatic sources described him as a fiery, outspoken character who used to be the president of the Solomon islands' bar association. He has been prominent in politics since 1984, acting as the leader of the opposition in the early 90s. He was finance minister from June 1993 to September 1994, when he resigned amid allegations about his personal finances.

webTitle: Tories would defeat 'liberal education elite' says Hague

fields.headline: Tories would defeat 'liberal education elite' says Hague
fields.standfirst: The full speech
fields.trailText: A Conservative government would give schools new freedom to raise standards of discipline and defeat the "liberal elite" which has brought the education system to its knees, William Hague pledged today.
fields.body:
A Conservative government would give schools new freedom to raise standards of discipline and defeat the "liberal elite" which has brought the education system to its knees, William Hague pledged today.

Laying out plans to make the enhancement of discipline a key plank in the Tories' education policy for the next general election, Mr Hague unveiled proposals to abolish what he branded the government's "artificial" targets for cutting the number of pupil expulsions.

In a counter attack on Labour's recent anti-elitism theme, Mr Hague told an audience at the Archbishop Tenison school in south London: "For decades we have had to put up with the classroom obsessions of the Labour party and the liberal elite. And we have paid the price in our schools with falling standards, poor discipline and children who can't spell the word Oxford let alone aspire to go there.

"The last Conservative government succeeded in turning the liberal tide with grant maintained schools, city technology colleges and the national curriculum. But we did not go far enough, and we were hampered in our efforts by left-wing local education authorities.

"The next Conservative government will not just turn the tide - we will defeat the liberal elite that has brought our education system to its knees."

Mr Hague was focusing his attention on discipline, undertaking to put the right of the many to a decent and ordered education before the rights of the disruptive and violent few.

Mr Hague accused education secretary David Blunkett of setting schools the "completely arbitrary and unacceptable target" of cutting the number of expulsions by a third over the next two years, and of imposing heavy financial penalties on schools who failed to meet the target.

"In short, 4,000 more young thugs are going to be allowed to hold our classrooms to ransom just to satisfy the politically-correct targets of this Labour Government," said Mr Hague. Mr Hague's plan for improving discipline includes:

 Abolishing the targets for cutting exclusions.
 Abolishing the "absurd" financial penalties designed to encourage schools to meet those targets.
 Abolishing on-site school 'sin bins', dismissed by Mr Hague as "gimmicky".
 Giving headteachers and governors "the complete freedom, within the law, to set the standards and rules of discipline in their classrooms.
 Helping disruptive pupils, drawing on the pioneering work of the Zaccheaus Centre in Birmingham as a model for 'Progress Centres', which would offer options varying from a week's special education for children at risk of being excluded, to full-time education for pupils who are permanently excluded.

But Mr Hague's approach drew a sharp response from the government.

A source close to education and employment Secretary David Blunkett said: "The Tories have failed to develop a coherent strategy for discipline and exclusions.

"When they were in power, exclusions rose threefold but there was no proper provision for those who were excluded, which meant that they ended up committing petty crimes and causing trouble for the wider community." Increased funding will mean that by 2002, excluded pupils would be getting 25 hours a week tuition at offsite units run by local education authorities, rather than the 10-12 hours they typically receive now.

fields.headline: 'Children can't even spell the word 'Oxford''
fields.standfirst: The full text of Conservative leader William Hague's speech on education
fields.trailText: "Today I have come to Archbishop Tenison's School, to see for myself what good teaching and excellent school leadership can do to bring excellence in education to pupils in one of the more deprived areas of our capital.
fields.body:
"Today I have come to Archbishop Tenison's School, to see for myself what good teaching and excellent school leadership can do to bring excellence in education to pupils in one of the more deprived areas of our capital.

"Archbishop Tenison's was for many years a monument to the absolute failure of a liberal establishment and its dogmatic ideas. A former grammar school and centre of excellence, it was forced to become a comprehensive under Harold Wilson's government. Its sixth form then withered away and, under the rule of the loony left in Lambeth, it became what some people would have described as an inner city sink school.

"Then, in 1993, under the leadership of headmaster Brian Jones, it opted out of local authority control and became grant-maintained. A couple of years later, it got back its sixth form. Since then it has gone from strength to strength. According to the HM Chief Inspector of Schools, it is one of the 29 most improved schools in the country. It is heavily over-subscribed, has earned much confidence within the local community and even has three ex-pupils playing in the Premier League. Last year, twenty four of its pupils gained places at university including one pupil who won a place at Cambridge university.

"Ignorant chancellors of the exchequer who lecture our best universities about elitism should come to inner city comprehensives like this one to find out what a liberal elite did to destroy standards in our schools. And they should learn from schools like Archbishop Tenison's about the dramatic improvements can happen when schools are freed from bureaucratic controls and left wing political interference.

"For the real enemy of good education in Britain is the elitism of a New Labour government increasingly in thrall to the obsessions of the liberal establishment.

"New Labour and its liberal elite have abolished the Assisted Places Scheme that helped children from less well off backgrounds go to some of the best schools in the country because of their ideological hatred of private education.

"New Labour and its liberal elite have scrapped grant maintained schools - the very mechanism that rescued schools like Archbishop Tenison's and hundreds of others from the clutches of politically motivated local education authorities.

"New Labour and its liberal elite have unleashed Labour party activists in a war against our excellent grammar schools, that only the good sense of parents has stopped becoming a national tragedy.

"Now New Labour and its liberal elite are trying to force feed our nation's school children with their politically correct nonsense by seeking to abolish important safeguards like Section 28. And the latest news is that they even want to ban musical chairs because it is unfair to the child without a chair when the music stops.

"For decades we have had to put up with the classroom obsessions of the Labour party and the liberal elite. And we have paid the price in our schools with falling standards, poor discipline and children who can't spell the word 'Oxford' let alone aspire to go there.

"Is it any wonder that the percentage of students at Oxford and Cambridge who went to state schools has dropped considerably since the liberal establishment got hold of our education policy in the 1960s?

"The last Conservative government succeeded in turning the liberal tide with grant maintained schools, city technology colleges and the national curriculum. But we did not go far enough, and we were hampered in our efforts by left-wing local education authorities.

"The next Conservative government will not just turn the tide - we will defeat the liberal elite that has brought our education system to its knees.

"In the next few weeks, I will be setting out our education policy in a whole range of areas. Today I want to start by telling you about how my party is going make discipline in our schools a key plank of our education policy for the next general election.

"I want to tell you about how we are going to give teachers the backing they deserve, and head-teachers the freedom they need, to deal with unruly pupils.

"I want to tell you about how the next Conservative government is going to put the right of the many to a decent and ordered education before the rights of the disruptive and violent few.

"Sadly, that is not the case today. For this government has put the interests of the small minority of children with behaviour problems first, and the interests of the great majority of teachers and parents and well-behaved pupils a distant second.

"David Blunkett has set schools the completely arbitrary and unacceptable target of cutting the number of expulsions or - to use the current jargon - the number of permanent exclusions by a third over the next two years. And to make sure his targets are met, the education secretary is fining schools up to £6,000 for every disruptive pupil beyond the targets set by civil servants in Whitehall.

"In short, four thousand more young thugs, are going to be allowed to hold our classrooms to ransom just to satisfy the politically correct targets of this Labour government.

"To education ministers who will no doubt say that this is not a very important issue in our schools, I say:

"Listen to the story of two London secondary schools which last month were forced to re-admit pupils they had permanently excluded for wielding knives and conducting gang-like vendettas. 'Now', say the headteachers, 'all the other pupils are desperately frightened' and the education of hundreds of children has been jeopardised for the sake of a tiny minority.

"Or listen to the story of Angeles Walford, a head-teacher seconded to a failing school, who said recently: 'I excluded a boy who hit a teacher but was forced to give him a second chance. He came back and hit another teacher'.

"Or listen to David Hart of the National Association of Head Teachers who spoke for all teachers when he said last week 'the fact is that in order to meet the government's target, more and more intolerable behaviour will have to be tolerated in schools... It seems to me that the interests of the violent, drug dealing and bullying few are increasingly given precedence over the interests of the quiet, law-abiding many'.

"The latest government gimmick that is supposed to be an answer these problems is the 'sin bin'. "Where this Labour government has failed, the next Conservative government will succeed. We offer a common sense approach that puts the rights of the many ahead of the problems of the few. This is what we will do:

"One, we will abolish Labour's artificial targets for school exclusions that are tying the hands of teachers, and forcing schools to keep disruptive or violent pupils.

"Two, we will abolish the absurd financial penalties that are used by the government to bully schools into meeting those targets. Schools will no longer face the stiff fines for excluding pupils. Good school discipline will no longer mean a heavy blow to school budgets.

"Three, we will give head-teachers and school governors the complete freedom, within the law, to set the standards and rules of discipline in their classrooms. That is what our Free Schools policy is all about - trusting teachers instead of issuing diktats from Whitehall.

"Today, the Conservative party is broadening its agenda and speaking up for the mainstream majority of the British people not just on tax and Europe and crime, but on pensions and now education too. We are coming forward with new ideas and challenging old orthodoxies.

"The contrast with the Labour government is clear. They are running out of ideas and running out of steam. Tomorrow we are told that Tony Blair is going to give another speech that tries to tell us all where his government is going. In other words, it is another relaunch from a prime minister who has had more relaunches than Cape Canaveral.

"It is time Tony Blair stopped trying to persuade parents and patients and pensioners that problems don't exist and start coming forward with answers to the problems that everyone sees in their local hospitals, schools and streets.

"After more than three years in office, people want to see more from Mr Blair than just yet another Downing Street summit and a new set of gimmicks. When is he actually going to deliver on all his promises?

"No doubt he will tomorrow reel out new telephone numbers that he claims to be spending on public services. So why is that people are waiting longer than ever for NHS treatment? webTitle: 6 June: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 6 June: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText:
In brief and the latest casting news

U-571 rattles Chris Smith's cage, David Puttnam retires from film, Jim Belushi goes net-crazy, Mel Smith directs, and on the casting couch Christina Ricci and Eminem
fields.body:
 The second world war submarine drama U-571 may be playing to packed houses on both sides of the Atlantic, but its cavalier approach to history continues to attract criticism. The latest sceptic to wade in against the movie is our very own culture secretary Chris Smith, who has damned the way the film credits Americans with a heroic mission that was actually undertaken by the British. "To have a film that purports to tell us that it was the Americans that did all of this is a little galling, I have to say," Smith told reporters. "One of the things we need to make clear to Hollywood is, yes, you are in the entertainment business, but people who see your movies are also going to come away thinking that it is information as well as entertainment."

 David Puttnam formally announced his retirement from film-making at the weekend and confirmed that his latest picture - My Life So Far - will be his last. Work commitments as a Labour Lord have made his continuing as a film producer untenable. "I tired for a year after the general election to juggle the jobs I'm doing with the government work and it was just impossible," he explained. Puttnam is responsible for producing 34 feature films, including Midnight Express and the Oscar-winning Chariots of Fire.

 Jim (brother of John) Belushi is the latest celebrity to dip a toe in the deep waters of the web. The comic will create 13 "webisodes" of an animated programme called The Greedy Show for Shockwave.com. The news is another coup for Shockwave, who have already signed up David Lynch and Tim Burton to produce original content for the website.

 Comedian turned film-maker Mel Smith is planning to direct a Thelma and Louise-style comedy called High Heels, Low Lives in London next month. The film follows the scatty misadventures of an actress and a hairdresser who conspire to rip off a gang of bank robbers. The film, which has yet to be cast, is tentatively budgeted at $10m.

Casting couch

 Christina Ricci is to star as the action heroine Adrenalynn in a Hollywood picture (called Adrenalin) based on the cult comic-book series by Tony Daniel. The Buffalo 66 star will play a mutant cyborg who works as an assassin in post-Apocalypse Russia. Warner Bros will back the picture, but a director has yet to be found.

 Lily-white Detroit rapper Eminem is to make his acting debut in a movie written by Scott Silver (director of Johns) about, erm, a lily-white rapper growing up in Detroit. As well as playing the lead character, Eminem will write the soundtrack for the as yet untitled project. In the meantime, the star has his hands full tackling charges brought against him following a brawl on Saturday night in the parking lot of the Hard Rock Café in suburban Detroit. Will that little incident make it through to the finished film, we wonder?

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Laurent describes his 'job' as a living statue on the Pont des Arts in Paris
fields.trailText: Laurent describes his 'job' as a living statue on the Pont des Arts in Paris
fields.body:
C'est vraiment dur comme boulot, mais il y a des moments agréables. J'arrive sur le pont tous les matins vers 10 heures - c'est le moment où commencent à venir les touristes et les promeneurs. Ça me prend un petit moment pour me préparer, surtout en hiver quand il faut que je mette plusieurs épaisseurs de vê tements sous mon costume. Pourtant le froid est moins dur à supporter que les grandes chaleurs de l'été.

Une fois que je prends ma position de pharaon, il me faut beaucoup de concentration pour ne plus bouger. Ce qui m'aide c'est de fixer le regard sur un détail comme une fenêtre, une feuille d'arbre. Mais parfois aussi, il me passe des millions de choses dans la tête. Je me pose plein de questions sur mon avenir. J'ai fait des études de danse classique mais je n'ai pas pu continuer à cause de problèmes de tune. En faisant la statue, je gagne assez pour vivre, mais c'est pas grand-chose. À côté, je fais de la figuration pour des films, j'ai déjà joué dans plusieurs courts-métrages. Mais mon rêve c'est de recommencer à danser.

C'est vrai qu'à Paris il y a beaucoup de gens qui font ce boulot, mais ça continue à étonner les passants. Heureusement, sinon j'aurais du mal à gagner ma vie. Parfois, les gens ont des réactions bizarres - ils vont te regarder pour essayer de te déconcentrer.

L'autre jour, une petite fille est passée avec ses parents. Elle s'est mise à pleurer en me voyant. Pour essayer de la calmer, je lui ai fait un clin d'oeil et un petit sourire discret, juste pour elle. C'était magique, elle s'est tout de suite arrêtée de pleurer. Je pense qu'on peut faire de vraies rencontres, même sans paroles.

Glossaire/Glossary

avenir (m) future
un boulot (coll) job
une grande chaleur great heat
clin d'oeil wink
un court-métrage a short film
une épaisseur layer
étonner to surprise, amaze
la figuration work as a film extra
la tune (coll) cash, money

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip mixed with milk, flour, and eggs and whipped into a batter
fields.trailText: Lazio vice-chairman Massimo Cragnotti will arrive in London today ready to bid £15m for Marc Overmars reports the Sun. The Italian club hope to tempt the Arsenal winger with a double-your-money offer.
fields.body:
Lazio vice-chairman Massimo Cragnotti will arrive in London today ready to bid £15m for Marc Overmars reports the Sun. The Italian club hope to tempt the Arsenal winger with a double-your-money offer.

Bryan Robson has offered £12m for out-of-favour Barcelona striker Dani, according to the Mirror, who say that the Middlesbrough manager is also in the market for at least four players - and could sell £3m-rated Hamilton Ricard to Lens.

The Mirror also claims that Martin O'Neill is ready to bid £2m for Stan Collymore. The rumour is fuelled by a Leicester insider who reveals: "It would be true to say that Martin loves Stan to bits. Apart from that business of the fire extinguisher being let off in La Manga, Martin never had a minute's trouble with him."

Liverpool striker Titi Camara has again expressed an interest in joining Celtic. "I know Martin O'Neill tried to sign me when he was at Leicester and he is clearly one of the best managers around," he tells Teamtalk. "I'd love to join up with him at Celtic because next season will be a very exciting one for the club."

Glenn Hoddle is a surprise contender for the vacant manager's job at Leicester according to the Express. But the Daily Mail say that Leicester have put Bolton boss Sam Allardyce at the top of their list of candidates to replace Martin O'Neill.

Teamtalk also reveal that Aston Villa's unsettled central defender Ugo Ehiogu is a potential target for Manchester City.

The Star reports that non-league Doncaster have offered 33 year-old Darlington striker Marco Gabbiadini a three-year deal that could earn him £500,000. And the paper also claims that Huddersfield have launched a cheeky 'pay-as-you play' offer to Andy Booth. Manager Steve Bruce is also chasing Barnsley's out-of-contract captain Nicky Eaden.

fields.headline: Unmoderne Bundeswehr
fields.standfirst: The German army has lost its way and is in need of modernisation. Young people discuss radical proposals with  Nicole Prestle
fields.trailText: The German army has lost its way and is in need of modernisation. Young people discuss radical proposals with Nicole Prestle
fields.body:
Die deutsche Bundeswehr ist "zu groß, falsch zusammengesetzt und zunehmend unmodern". Ganz neu sind Verteidigungsminister Rudolf Scharping diese Worte sicherlich nicht. Seit langem betont er, daß die Truppen der Bundesrepublik umstrukturiert, verkleinert, neu geordnet werden müßten. Vor einem Jahr setzte er deshalb eine "Kommission zur Reform der Bundeswehr" unter Leitung von Alt-Bundespräsident Richard von Weizsäcker ein.

Trotzdem: Das Papier, das die Arbeitsgruppe jetzt präsentierte, mag für einige doch Überrasc hungen bereitgehalten haben. Es schlägt vor, die Zahl der Wehrpflichtigen von derzeit 130.000 auf 30.000 herunterzuschrauben. Frauen sollen künftig unter gleichen Bedingungen wie männliche Bewerber zum Bund zugelassen werden. Die Ausrüstung der Truppen soll auf den modernsten Stand gebracht werden - auch, wenn dies momentan mehr Geld kostet, als die Einsparungen auf personeller Ebene bringen können.

"Zum ersten Mal in seiner Geschichte ist Deutschland ringsum von Bündnis- und Integrationspartnern umgeben und keiner äußeren Gefährdung seines Territoriums durch Nachbarn ausgesetzt. Diese neue Grundgegebenheit deutscher Sicherheit ist nicht vorübergehender Natur, sondern hat Bestandskraft für die Zukunft." Mit diesen beiden Sätzen begründet die Kommission ihre Vorschläge für die Bundeswehr der Zukunft. "Zu 80 Prozent" stimmt Rudolf Scharping nach eigenen Aussagen mit ihren Ergebnissen überein. Und dennoch: Er hat eigene Ideen, wie die Bundeswehr in den nächsten Jahren reformiert werden soll. Und die unterscheiden sich vor allem in Sachen Truppenstärke.

Von Weizsäckers Kommission schlägt eine Reduzierung der Wehrpflichtigen auf 30.000 vor. Ist dies Eurer Meinung nach gerechtfertigt oder wird die Wehrpflicht in Frage gestellt, wenn von den jungen Männern, die für den Wehrdienst in Frage kommen, immer weniger eingezogen werden?

Jürgen (21): Man könnte den Wehrdienst meinetwegen gleich ganz abschaffen. Ich habe keine Lust, für Deutschland in der Armee zu sein. Im Zuge eines vereinten Europa ist es an der Zeit, sich von diesem nationalen Denken zu lösen.

Anna (13): Ich bin grundsätzlich gegen die Wehrpflicht. Der Dienst an der Waffe hat für mich mit Gewalt zu tun, und ich bin gegen Gewalt. Wer sich freiwillig zum Bund melden will, soll das tun. Aber zwingen sollte man niemanden.

Johannes (18): Man sollte die Wehrpflicht beibehalten, sie aber verkürzen. Auf fünf Monate, das wäre doch gut. Ich selbst habe mich gerade erst für den Zivildienst entschieden. Aber nur deshalb, weil man in diesem Rahmen auch ins Ausland gehen kann.

Simone (17): Eine Reduzierung auf 80.000 Wehrpflichtige fände ich in Ordnung. Deutschland selbst ist nicht mehr in Kriege verwickelt, da reicht es aus, kleinere Truppen zu haben. Sie extrem zu kürzen, fände ich allerdings schlecht. Wenn dann doch einmal eine Krise käme, müßte man ja Soldaten haben.

Was können die Konsequenzen für die Verteidigung Deutschlands sein, wenn die Truppenstärke reduziert wird?

Jürgen: Über kurz oder lang wird man ein Europaheer aufstellen. Dort können Freiwillige aus allen Mitgliedsstaaten der EU dienen. In Zukunft werden die Aufgaben der Soldaten außerdem in anderen Bereichen liegen. Man sieht das ja schon jetzt: Der Einsatz außerhalb Deutschlands wird immer mehr zur Regel. Man denke nur an Kosovo.

Johannes: Eine Reduzierung macht da, glaube ich, noch nichts. Aber ganz auf ein Heer verzichten würde wohl keine Nation. Deshalb sollte man die Einsparungen auch nicht zu radikal ausfallen lassen.

Das Kommissions-Papier sieht vor, die Zahl der Soldaten, die im Ausland eingesetzt werden, um mehr als das Doppelte zu erhöhen. Was haltet Ihr davon? Wird es genügend Freiwillige geben?

Jürgen: Die Bundeswehr muß natürlich ihre Bedingungen verbessern. Zur Zeit ist es ja Pflicht, eine abgeschlossene Berufsausbildung zu haben, wenn man sich für längere Zeit verpflichten will. Solche Dinge müßten sich ändern. Aber dann würden sich bestimmt Interessenten finden. Schließlich ist kein Arbeitgeber so sicher wie die Bundeswehr.

Simone: Da die Bundeswehr in der letzten Zeit oft in Krisengebieten Hilfe geleistet hat, schadet es sicherlich nicht, die Zahl der Einsatzkräfte zu verdoppeln. Manche Länder stehen nach Konflikten da, wie wir nach dem zweiten Weltkrieg. Da waren wir auch froh, daß man uns geholfen hat.

Johannes: Mir hat neulich ein Soldat erzählt, daß die Bundeswehr nicht zu einem Einsatz ins Ausland fliegen konnte, weil ihre Flugzeuge zu alt waren. Meiner Ansicht nach ist es zunächst einmal wichtig, das Material der Bundeswehr zu modernisieren. Erst danach hat es Sinn, mehr Leute für den Auslandseinsatz bereitzustellen.

Sollten auch Frauen uneingeschränkt zum Bund zugelassen werden?

Simone: Nein. Frauen sind zu sensibel für den Dienst an der Waffe. Ich könnte im Kriegsfall nicht an einem verletzten Menschen vorbeigehen, auch wenn er von der anderen Seite wäre. Krieg, das ist immer noch Männersache.

Anna: Wenn Frauen zur Bundeswehr wollen, ok. Warum sollte man ihnen den Zutritt verwehren? Ich kann mir allerdings nicht vorstellen, daß so viele daran interessiert sind.

webTitle: Will Smith tipped for Kind Hearts and Coronets remake

fields.headline: Will Smith tipped for Kind Hearts and Coronets remake
fields.trailText: The Americanised remake of the classic Ealing comedy Kind Hearts and Coronets appears to be coming together. Following last month's news that Robin Williams had been lined up for the multiple roles played by Alec Guinness in the original come reports that the Dennis Price role is to be played by none other than Will Smith.
fields.body:
The Americanised remake of the classic Ealing comedy Kind Hearts and Coronets appears to be coming together. Following last month's news that Robin Williams had been lined up for the multiple roles played by Alec Guinness in the original come reports that the Dennis Price role is to be played by none other than Will Smith.

Smith's arrival inevitably changes the angle of the story. The 1949 original recounted the tale of a lowly member of the aristocratic D'Ascoyne clan (Price) who sets out to bump off those in the family standing between him and the inheritance (all played by Guinness).

Director Mike Nichols claims that his remake will focus on race, not class. Explaining his changes to Cinescape magazine, Nichols remarked that "the movie is about a large, rich family where this heiress marries a black man." If Nichols is able to lure Smith into the fold, the Men in Black star will play the disowned son of the heiress, who swears revenge on the family who made his mother an exile.

fields.headline: Dangerous medicines 'sold online'
fields.trailText: Potentially dangerous prescription medicines are being sold over the internet to people who might be damaged by them, an investigation by the Consumers' Association has found.
fields.body:
Potentially dangerous prescription medicines are being sold over the internet to people who might be damaged by them, an investigation by the Consumers' Association has found.

Researchers for the association's magazine Health Which? posed as internet customers who wanted medicines like Viagra, the anti-impotence drug, and Xenical, which is designed to help the obese lose weight. From details given of their health and other medicines they claimed to be on, they should have been refused the drugs, but in many cases they were not.

One researcher posed as a 45-year-old man suffering from impotence who was on nitrate therapy following a heart attack a year ago. It has widely been publicised that some men have died after taking Viagra on top of nitrates - both of which lower the blood pressure.

But one website - www.directresponsemarketing.co.uk - accepted the order and sent him the drug, even though its own online questionnaire states: "Viagra must never be taken in combination with nitrate-based drugs."

One of the GPs recruited by Health Which? commented that the attitude of the company was "totally inappropriate and dangerous". Another website, www.kwickmed.com, appeared to accept the order, but it did not arrive. Only one of the five sites approached, www.viagra.demon.co.uk, stated it would not send out the drug because of the medication the customer was on.

The other two sites refused Viagra, but one, www.drugs-express.com, gave no specific reason. The other, www.nethealthprescriptions, would not consider the order because the customer admitted he had not had a physical examination with blood tests within the past year.

A pharmacist asked to comment by Health Which? criticised both www.drugs-express.com and www.kwickmed.com for asking customers to indicate what drugs they were on, but offering a list of brand names instead of generics which are not always the same in Britain as they are in the US.

There were similar problems in attempts to buy Xenical, which is licensed for use in people with a body mass index over 30 in conjunction with a calorie controlled diet. Those with a BMI over 28 may have it if excess weight carries greater risks for them, such as if they have diabetes.

The researcher said that he had a BMI of 28, was healthy but ate a lot of takeaways and restaurant meals.

Health Which? advisers believe he should have been refused the drug, because he was not sufficiently overweight and his weight loss anyway should be calorie-controlled and monitored. Yet all five sites supplied him with Xenical.

fields.headline: Cops praise Douglas's vigilante antics
fields.trailText: The quick-thinking actions of Michael Douglas helped police officers foil a pair of car thieves during an urban chase in Cincinnatti, Ohio, last week. In showing the cops the alley where the two criminals had just disappeared into, the 55-year-old actor is being held directly responsible for their subsequent arrest.
fields.body:
The quick-thinking actions of Michael Douglas helped police officers foil a pair of car thieves during an urban chase in Cincinnatti, Ohio, last week. In showing the cops the alley where the two criminals had just disappeared into, the 55-year-old actor is being held directly responsible for their subsequent arrest.

Depending on which side of the crime line you fall, his antics can be regarded as impeccably civic-minded or the height of snitchery. Cincinnatti police lieutenant Steve Wilger is of the first persuasion and hopes to honour Douglas in a public service in the city later this summer.

The incident occurred while Douglas was on location filming his role as a drugs tsar in Steven (Out of Sight) Soderbergh's Cincinnatti-set thriller Traffic. The police had been chasing two suspected car-jackers (both aged 17), who crashed their vehicle yards away from where filming was taking place and escaped on foot down a nearby alley. Eagle-eyed Douglas clocked what was going on and pointed the way to the pursuing cops.

Douglas is the latest addition to a growing number of have-a-go-hero celebrities. While visiting London a few years ago, Tom Cruise was credited with foiling a mugger. Still more heroic were the actions of John Cleese, who reportedly once chased a burglar down a busy London street clad only in his bathrobe.

webTitle: Carrey lured by Phone Booth picture

fields.headline: Carrey lured by Phone Booth picture
fields.trailText: Jim Carrey is reported to be in final negotiations to star in Phone Booth, a Fox 2000 project that will be directed by Joel Schumacher. If talks are successful, the role will signal another dramatic change of direction for the $20m player, who in recent years has appeared determined to be regarded as an actor of genuine credibility.
fields.body:
Jim Carrey is reported to be in final negotiations to star in Phone Booth, a Fox 2000 project that will be directed by Joel Schumacher. If talks are successful, the role will signal another dramatic change of direction for the $20m player, who in recent years has appeared determined to be regarded as an actor of genuine credibility.

Phone Booth promises to be a classic Hitchcockian thriller about an innocent who gets in hot water. Variety reports that Carrey is tipped to play the role of a man who answers a ringing public phone only to be told by the voice on the other end of the line that he will be shot if he hangs up.

The film could hardly be more different from the glossy, populist packages that made Carrey's name. Phone Booth will be shot on a shoestring budget, in real time and around one solitary location (a public booth in a crowded Manhattan street). Actual filming time is not expected to extend beyond three weeks and there is even talk of streaming rehearsal footage on the internet as a guide to aspiring film-makers.

After breaking big in films like The Mask and Ace Ventura, Carrey won converts with his more serious work in The Truman Show and Man on the Moon, but Phone Booth looks to be shaping up as his first properly low-budget and experimental star vehicle. The film is due to begin production in August and be in the can by early September.

webTitle: Bill who? You know, the one who got impeached

fields.headline: Bill who? You know, the one who got impeached
fields.trailText: For what, say in 20 years' time, will Bill Clinton be remembered? When it comes to two-term Bubba, the country & western boy from downtown Hope, Arkansas, the quick answer may be Monica, impeachment, and nationally-televised grovelling as performance art. But would such a memorial be fair?
fields.body:
For what, say in 20 years' time, will Bill Clinton be remembered? Twenty years ago Ronald Reagan was on his way to the White House. Looking back, the old Californian cowboy cum thespian is the last cold war hero, indelibly associated with the collapse of the Soviet Union's "evil empire". Eight years ago, George Bush was heading for electoral humiliation. The Gulf war, still unfinished 10 years on, is his epitaph, plus a lethally broken promise of "no new taxes". When it comes to two-term Bubba, the country & western boy from downtown Hope, Arkansas, the quick answer may be Monica, impeachment, and nationally-televised grovelling as performance art. But would such a memorial be fair?

The coming months will bring many earnest, instant assessments of the "Clinton legacy". The president, spinning to the last, is already energetically weaving his own historical tapestry. And Bayeux-gorgeous it is, too. Northern Ireland: that's one in the pot, for sure. Forget George Mitchell and Mo Mowlam. Bill will claim this as all his own work. Kosovo? Strike two, for global leadership, smart politics, and smart bombs (the Chinese embassy apart). And don't forget that famous 1993 handshake between Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat. Who was the guy bear-hugging them together on the South Lawn? Yup, the very same fella who brought you the Dayton peace accords in Bosnia, Nato enlargement, Nafta, and the much-loved World Trade Organisation. If only that ornery Mr Assad in Damascus would seize the moment, it could be peace in our term from Golan to Galilee and another wing on the WJC presidential library. Mr Clinton was out legacy-hunting yesterday in Moscow and Kiev, with a grand, great man's speech to the Duma and some soulful words about Chernobyl (which happened on Reagan's watch, by the way). Pity about Vladimir Putin's awkward objection to star wars missiles. But don't think particulars; think posterity!

webTitle: Good news for female fans in the Caribbean

fields.headline: Good news for female fans in the Caribbean
fields.standfirst: Vaneisa Baksh has been repeatedly told she can't become a member of the all-male Queen's Park Cricket Club in Trinidad and Tobago. Now, at long last, there may be some hope for her and all other women in the West Indies
fields.trailText: The main stakeholders in West Indies cricket came out forcefully to condemn gender discrimination around the game at a recent regional conference in Barbados. Coaches, umpires, players, sponsors, writers, university academics and government representatives met for two days at a cricket conference held under the auspices of the Caribbean Community grouping (CARICOM) and the University of the West Indies (UWI), at the Cave Hill Campus of the UWI on June 1 and 2.
fields.body:
The main stakeholders in West Indies cricket came out forcefully to condemn gender discrimination around the game at a recent regional conference in Barbados. Coaches, umpires, players, sponsors, writers, university academics and government representatives met for two days at a cricket conference held under the auspices of the Caribbean Community grouping (CARICOM) and the University of the West Indies (UWI), at the Cave Hill Campus of the UWI on June 1 and 2.

The conference's first declaration was "that cricket is the principal expression of the people's cultural heritage and that all structures and relations responsible for its governance embrace this philosophy." At the end 15 resolutions were passed, including two which dealt with the relationship between women and cricket.

Resolution 7 was "that gender discrimination within the cricket Institutions of the region be immediately abolished and that all cricket clubs should implement a policy of encouraging female membership." Resolution 8 was "that the WICB (West Indies Cricket Board) and all other stakeholders provide technical and financial support for the development of women's cricket and the involvement of women in cricket at all levels."

The conference was the culmination of a series of consultations held in each of the islands. National committees made presentations and there were panel discussions which were linked throughout the Caribbean by television and radio. General Secretary of CARICOM, Edwin Carrington, said the resolutions will be presented at the CARICOM Heads of Government meeting in St. Vincent and the Grenadines from July 4-7, 2000.

UWI Pro Vice-Chancellor, Prof. Hilary Beckles, coordinator and principal consultant for the conference, drafted the resolutions, and when he spoke about the issue of gender discrimination at the cricket grounds he reminded West Indians that three of their most celebrated record-holders, Sir Garry Sobers, Brian Lara and Courtney Walsh had all been raised mainly by their mothers, and had credited them with the nurturing of their cricket abilities.

He spoke of the West Indies Women's Cricket Federation, which is currently hosting a regional tournament without any assistance from the West Indies Cricket Board. The women had approached the WICB seeking assistance to raise EC$30,000, but were turned down. At least this year they could approach the WICB; in years past they have been completely ignored by the regional administrative body.

For the old clubs like the Queen's Park Cricket Club in Trinidad, Kingston Cricket Club in Jamaica and Georgetown Cricket Club in Guyana, whose membership policies effectively discriminate against women, the news coming out of the conference will not be welcome.

Coaches, umpires, players, sponsors, writers, university academics and government representatives met for two days at a cricket conference held under the auspices of the Caribbean Community grouping (CARICOM) and the University of the West Indies (UWI), at the Cave Hill Campus of the UWI on June 1 and 2. At the end 15 resolutions were passed, including two which dealt with the relationship between women and cricket. Resolution 7 was "that gender discrimination within the cricket Institutions of the region be immediately abolished and that all cricket clubs should implement a policy of encouraging female membership." Resolution 8 was "that the WICB (West Indies Cricket Board) and all other stakeholders provide technical and financial support for the development of women's cricket and the involvement of women in cricket at all levels." fields.standfirst: We love Alan Shearer; football's Ron Perlman; the Itchy and Sepp show; Karel talks Manc
fields.trailText: We love Alan Shearer; football's Ron Perlman; the Itchy and Sepp show; Karel talks Manc.
fields.body:
A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

***********************************************************

EUROTALK

"Roger Lemerre's policy is that the best men play" - Zinedine Zidane blows France's chances by inadvertently revealing their secret plan. That's one less team for little Kev to worry about, then.

THE EURO-TORIAL

He sticks his arse out, he flails his elbows, he shrugs his shoulders and, above all else, he falls over: is there no end to Alan Shearer's talents? England's totem forward (in more ways than one) is the subject of several critical editorials today, and the object of more than a little in-pub abuse. But as far as the Euro is concerned, everyone should lay off the whinging, balding, cynical, flair-free forward.

It is, of course, traditional for the English to mock their best hope of scoring a goal on the eve of an international tournament. The washed-up Gary Lineker got it before Italia 90 (he went on to score four times, three of the goals proving crucial), and Shearer came in for the same treatment before Euro 96 (where five goals won him the golden boot). The argument always has something do with not scoring in friendlies, and questions over whether the player is really committed. As if we, perched on the edge of our bar stools, are in the perfect position to judge.

The fact of the matter is that Shearer's remorselessly dull professionalism is not about to let him ease up in what he himself has decided will be his final international tournament. He may spend the whole time trying to hold the ball up in seemingly innocuous positions - but that's where all England's goals have come from in recent games. He may also spend half the time criticising officials - but that's part and parcel of modern football. What he also has is a strike record at international level which will only be matched in Holland by Oliver Bierhoff and Hakan Sukur. So let's all get behind Alan Shearer - he might fall over and win us a free kick.

BREATHABLE FABRICS WITH ERIK MEIJER

Today, the Liverpool substitute, web enthusiast (http://www.sportprofile.co.uk/football/meijer/) and Ron Perlman lookalike reveals his outside tip for the tournament to be Italy. But surely that's nuts, Erik?

"Let me explain. The Italians' shirts are made of a special material which stretches, supposedly making it more comfortable for the players to wear. And if you are comfortable, you feel good. I know from experience that this is true." Wow.

Tomorrow: how peace can be achieved in Sierra Leone - if only they'd stop wearing acrylic.

***********************************************************

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

You'll get a wider view of the Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com. See how you score with fantasy share trading and you could win a 28" wide screen TV.

***********************************************************

EURONEWS

Fifa chief Sepp Blatter stuck his oar into the row over the venue for England's match with Germany yesterday, claiming the game should be moved from Charleroi. "Playing the game in another stadium should be considered," he said. "I am absolutely convinced that this is being thought about."

But Euro2000 organiser Alan Courtois hit straight back to insist: "The game goes ahead in Charleroi." Blatter then climbed onto a chair with a loudhailer to tell everyone that it's going to get moved cos a friend of his mate who works at the tournament told him. Courtois then descended into the room on a death slide and hit Blatter on the head with a frying pan.

George Best has given his verdict on the England team. "I have always believed it takes a genius in a team to win tournaments. England do not have one," said the former bar-fly. "It's obvious they haven't got the defence sorted out," he went on. "Keegan is not settled in his mind who he's going," he went on again, as his mates wondered whether they could get a word in. "Emile Heskey doesn't score enough goals to be world class. It's just a shame about Robbie Fowler," he went on some more as everybody else went home.

Knackered Maltese defender Darren Debono may sue Alan Shearer for breaking his nose. "I'll be talking to my manager to see if I can take any legal action against Shearer," he told the Daily Star. "My nose is in a terrible state." And your haircut isn't much to write home about either, mate.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Top o' the mornin' to ye, as I think they say in Manchester! Karel Poborsky here. You know, some people have told me that my shiny, beautiful locks were not the shiniest, most beautiful locks in the 1996 Czech Republic midfield. That's as maybe. But does Patrik Berger have his own transfer rumour service in an early-morning email? Well, does he?

I mean, does he tell you that Lazio are about to offer Arsenal £16m for Dutch winger Marc Overmars?

Or that Belgian striker Gilles De Bilde wants to quit relegated Sheffield Wednesday, claiming his ambitions "don't include playing in the First Division"?

Or that Middlesbrough are interested in Barcelona striker Dani, with Bryan Robson prepared to spend as much as £10m to land the Spanish international in the face of competition from Valencia and Fiorentina?

No he doesn't. All he does is wear an Alice band and kick the ball with his left foot. So whose hair is the most luxurious now?

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: Three Lions (10.45pm)
The first part of a documentary about the England football team. It's narrated by James Bolam, who will hopefully deliver the whole narration to the theme tune of When The Boat Comes In.

British Eurosport: Live International Football (7.30pm)
France play Morocco in a friendly, then make some excuses when they don't win by seven clear goals.

fields.headline: BCC attacks Straw 'licence to snoop'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Powers allowing Scotland Yard, MI5 and other state agencies to intercept all internet and email communications involve "a serious potential invasion of commercial privacy" and ought to be radically redrafted, the British Chambers of Commerce said yesterday .
fields.body:
Powers allowing Scotland Yard, MI5 and other state agencies to intercept all internet and email communications involve "a serious potential invasion of commercial privacy" and ought to be radically redrafted, the British Chambers of Commerce said yesterday .

Chris Humphries, the BCC director general, warned in a letter to the home secretary, Jack Straw, that the regulation of investigatory powers bill - now before parliament - could put British e-commerce at a competitive disadvantage that would "frustrate the government's ambition of making the UK the best place to trade electronically by 2002".

As drafted, the bill would require the police and security service to obtain just one warrant from a judge that would allow them to engage on potentially unlimited "fishing expeditions" in a company's electronic archive. In theory, four warrants would give them access to all electronic data held by Barclays, Lloyds TSB, NatWest and HSBC banks.

Home Office minister Charles Clarke said in March: "The bill will not be withdrawn." But he added that Mr Straw was prepared to listen to suggestions for improvement and was anxious to see keen parliamentary scrutiny.

Mr Humphries said the BCC had three main areas of concern, the first being that the cost burden on Britain's 10 big internet service providers of their having to provide links to the proposed MI5 monitoring centre had been underestimated.

Secondly, the BCC is alarmed by the orders that could be served requiring a company employee on pain of imprisonment to disclose passwords and code words and to remain silent about the fact that he or she had been so ordered. Quite apart from the civil liberties implications, the BCC said this could put the employee in a position of being forced to breach the trust of company directors.

Thirdly, the bill reverses the burden of proof in the cases of lost or missing passwords or codes, forcing employees to prove to a court that these were genuinely stolen or mislaid.

fields.headline: Royal rift over GM foods
fields.trailText: A royal rift developed today over the issue of GM crops, with the Duke of Edinburgh reportedly joining the Princess Royal in playing down concerns in remarks which appear to contradict the views of the Prince of Wales.
fields.body:
A royal rift developed today over the issue of GM crops, with the Duke of Edinburgh reportedly joining the Princess Royal in playing down concerns in remarks which appear to contradict the views of the Prince of Wales.

The duke's comments came just days after his daughter was criticised by environmental campaigners when she also spoke out in favour of genetically modified foods in the industry magazine, The Grocer.

Philip said: "Do not let us forget we have been genetically modifying animals and plants ever since people started selective breeding." The introduction of foreign pests, such as the grey squirrel, had done more damage to the environment than genetically modified crops would ever cause, he added.

"People are worried about genetically modified organisms getting into the environment.

"What people forget is that the introduction of exotic species - like, for instance, the introduction of the grey squirrel into this country - is going to or has done far more damage than a genetically modified piece of potato."

The duke's remarks, in response to a lecture at Windsor Castle by the Chief Rabbi, Dr Jonathan Sacks, were reported in The Times today.

Shadow agriculture minister Tim Yeo said he did not want to "get involved in a family row" but added: "I think he (the Duke) is slightly confused about this issue.

"Of course it is right that the introduction of some exotic animals into an island like Britain has done great damage, but that should make him more cautious, not less cautious, about the consequences of genetic modification.

"Genetic modification goes much further than selective plant breeding or gradually improving horses so that they can run faster. It does involve taking genes from one species such as a fish which is normally confined to the Arctic and sticking it in something like a tomato to make it more frost-resistant," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

At the weekend, environmental campaigners said the Princess Royal was "absolutely wrong" in some of the views she expressed - which opposed those frequently expressed by her brother, Charles.

But some food safety experts backed her view, saying that GM produce was just as safe as food produced by traditional farming methods.

The Princess said: "It is a huge over-simplification to say all farming ought to be organic or there should be no GM foods. I'm sorry, but life isn't that simple.

"Man has been tinkering with food production and plant development for such a long time that it's a bit cheeky to suddenly get nervous about it when, fundamentally, you are doing much the same thing."

fields.headline: Strong pound 'drifting away from euro'
fields.standfirst:
Former chancellors say Britain can carve out distinctive position within an enlarged EU

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The battle over British membership of the European Union's single currency flared again last night after two former chancellors of the exchequer endorsed claims that, far from converging, the UK and EU economies are drifting further apart.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Luxembourg and Michael White
fields.body:
The battle over British membership of the European Union's single currency flared again last night after two former chancellors of the exchequer endorsed claims that, far from converging, the UK and EU economies are drifting further apart.

The claim came as EU finance ministers (Ecofin) failed to break the deadlock over the controversial withholding tax on savings - guaranteeing renewed conflict between Britain and its allies at the Portugeuse summit in mid-June.

A paper published yesterday by the New Europe group, which includes Labour's Lord Healey and the Conservative Lord Lawson, said the UK economy was further than ever from meeting Gordon Brown's five economic tests for euro membership.

It said that in contrast to Britain's parlous position 25 years ago, the country is now "strong enough economically and politically to carve out a distinctive position firmly within the enlarged EU. But it requires self-confident leadership to do so".

The implications run counter to weekend advice from pro-euro campaigners that Tony Blair should start fighting to change public opinion now with a view to taking sterling into the eurozone as soon as the promised referendum has been won.

Mr Blair and Mr Brown insist on a "wait and see" policy and public opinion remains hostile. esterday's paper says Mr Brown's five tests have become harder to pass as UK inflation and unemployment falls and Europe's rates do less well.

Some ministers are getting restless that delay will damage national interests.

But the New Europe paper insists: "So far we detect no political or economic evidence which suggests that exclusion is harming British interests." Last night it attracted a counterblast from another weighty Tory ex-chancellor, Lord Howe, who said: "The euro-economies are already enjoying the benefit of currency stability in respect of 85% of their trade. But for British traders the pound, so far from being under our 'sovereign' control, will remain a punchball currency with its value at the mercy of euro-dollar exchange rate fluctuations."

Quite separately Brussels was quivering last night at the news that one of Britain's most combative diplomats has been appointed as the ambassador to the EU. Nigel Sheinwald, 47, the Foreign Office's director for the EU, has the reputation of being confident, assertive, and capable of driving through radical change.

Mr Sheinwald was spokesman for Robin Cook and Malcolm Rifkind before that. He replaces Sir Stephen Wall, returning to London in the summer to head the European secretariat in the Cabinet Office, which works closely with Downing Street.

In Luxembourg yesterday Britain again backed an exchange of information between national tax authorities, a measure countries like Luxembourg claim is incompatible with banking secrecy.

The two-year dispute over how to eliminate tax avoidance without introducing a tax that would damage the City will now have to be discussed again on the eve of the EU summit at Santa Maria de Feira in two weeks.

"I'm not so very optimistic about Feira," said the Finnish finance minister, Sauli Niinisto. "Britain is loading the boat to prevent an agreement," complained Didier Reynders, the Belgian finance minister.

If the issue is not resolved it is likely to cause even greater ructions during the French presidency of the EU, beginning on July 1.

But diplomats predicted that it would be extremely difficult to overcome objections by Luxembourg, the EU's smallest member, because of the perceived threat to its thriving international banking centre.

Austria and Belgium are also angry because Britain will only agree to exchange information on a reciprocal basis, and not with countries that opt for a withholding tax to preserve their banking secrecy.

Britain also faces opposition to its demand for the proposed EU directive to set a firm time limit on the retention of banking secrecy within the EU.

 Some encouragement for Mr Blair's long-term hope of euro entry came last night in a poll for ITN which showed that 50% of the British public think the UK should join the euro either as soon as possible or as soon as conditions are right.

Only 45% of those polled think joining the single currency should be ruled out for all time, or for the next few years.

fields.headline: Speaking up for the euro
fields.standfirst: Its vital signs look brighter, but... Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Will he or won't he? Pressure is building up on Tony Blair to lead from the front and embark on the herculean task of persuading a majority of British people to support adoption of Europe's single currency. It looks impossible since 70% of the public is against it.
fields.body:
Will he or won't he? Pressure is building up on Tony Blair to lead from the front and embark on the herculean task of persuading a majority of British people to support adoption of Europe's single currency. It looks impossible since 70% of the public is against it. But Bob Worcester, chairman of Mori, thinks it is possible to achieve what would be the biggest shift of public opinion since then war. What is needed, he says, is not focus groups but good old fashioned political leadership. Officially, the government says that the decision will be put to a referendum in the next parliament if the economy passes five tests. In reality these tests are neither a necessary nor sufficient reason for joining. Not sufficient because if all the tests were passed but public opinion overwhelmingly against it is unlikely that the government would push ahead. They aren't a necessary condition either because if they were not fulfilled but public opinion was overwhelmingly in favour the government would probably go ahead anyway.

They could, however, serve as a device to stifle debate in order to keep the issue from dominating the general election campaign and to camouflage Gordon Brown's more sceptical approach to monetary union. It is naive to presume that ministers will be able to stifle debate simply by pointing out that the British people will themselves decide the issue in a referendum. The Tories will lose no opportunity to exploit divisions between Number 10 and Number 11 and demand that Mr Blair says where he stands.

In theory, the economic tide is moving in favour of Mr Blair taking the initiative. The eurozone's economy, according to the OECD, will expand by 3.5% this year and account for the biggest fall in unemployment in the OECD area. In theory, since strong economies and strong currencies normally march side by side, this could provide a strong following wind for an upbeat Mr Blair. The trouble is that in practice currency movements are notoriously difficult to predict. It could be that higher interest rates in the US and Japan will siphon off global capital flows that would otherwise have buoyed up the euro. There are still good reasons to delay - look at the inflationary trouble building up in Ireland as it tries to adjust to eurozone interest rates. Yet the longer Mr Blair delays his campaign the more difficult it will be to turn a 70% negative vote into a positive majority. It is an unenviable dilemma.
fields.bodyText: Will he or won't he? webTitle: Blair must run the risk of a referendum - and win

fields.headline: Blair must run the risk of a referendum - and win
fields.standfirst:
Joining the euro can no longer be ignored. A critical mass is building

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Twenty-five years after the first British referendum on Europe, many people would prefer not to have another one.
fields.body:
Twenty-five years after the first British referendum on Europe, many people would prefer not to have another one. The identity of the opponents, however, has changed. The coming referendum on the euro was seen in 1996, when the Major government promised it over the fuming resistance of Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine, as a terrible defeat for those who favoured more integration. As in 1975, the fear and loathing were all on the pro-Europe side. Now, with 2002 as the likely date for another test, the scene is extraordinarily different.

Those who do not want a referendum are all on the Eurosceptic side. They do not, of course, oppose referendums in principle, though Michael Portillo lined up with Clarke and Heseltine in 1996. Nor have they moderated their hostility to the euro. If entry were contemplated without a referendum, they would choke on the foam of their own outrage. But they don't want this one to take place. Preventing it is a key part of their strategy. Just about their entire game-plan is so to magnify the certainty of their own victory as to intimidate the government from putting the question to the test.

This tactic has had some success. The referendum seems to have receded from the realm of fixed expectations. The pound-euro exchange rate could be said to make the issue academic. The domestic economy is doing well enough to suggest there are few costs in exclusion from the single cur rency, and public opinion evidently makes clear the risk any referendum would bring to the government that proposed it. Most of the media, as intimidators-in-chief, are complicit in the strategy, and have strong influence on making it work. In the perfect world of almost all anti-euro opinion, the referendum will be postponed for ever.

How can this be, when they're so convinced of their case that they should surely welcome popular proof that they have won it? Their reasons for hesitation, though seldom admitted, are revealing. One exposes a chink in their certainty. They know that a referendum, once called, could not be guaranteed to underwrite their claims about public opinion: ie, they're terrified of losing. They naturally prefer to keep that possibility locked and unexamined in the closet, a risk avoided not confronted.

Secondly, some are conscious of what the referendum could yield. They worry about winning almost as much as losing. For a "no" vote would have consequences beyond the euro. The campaign would, without a doubt, have been about Britain's entire European identity. The nation would have declared, in a strong sense, against further integration of any kind. Such a vote would be but the prelude to marginalisation of this country away from a central EU role. That would be an existential decision of the profoundest magnitude, bringing pleasure to the few people who honestly desire Britain to leave Europe, but consternation to the larger number of sceptics who, while willing this means of exit, would be horrified when confronted with the end they had recklessly brought about.

No wonder, therefore, that the parents of the referendum are now anxious to abort it. As it looms, they privately quail before the twin discomforts. But this doesn't mean the referendum has no friends. On the contrary, the pro-Europeans now want it very badly. Role-reversal is complete. Those who want a public consultation are all on the other side. The friends of the referendum are the friends of Europe. All they lack is the voice to shout about it - and the confidence they should take from this telling desire of their enemies to avoid the final battle.

Tony Blair is inexorably moving that way, after some interim wobbles. The economics must still stack up, he tells visitors. He can't be certain that they will. Obviously if the currency loses a member, all bets are off. Convergence between the pound and the euro needs to have proceeded for some time. But the bias towards entry has renewed its tilt, assisted by the visibly harsh consequences of the high pound for manufacturing jobs, and likely to be further assisted by manifest instability when the pound starts going down faster than the Bank and Treasury would ever want. Mr Blair is already preparing for the referendum which his side once regarded as anathema.

How he's going about it is a matter of debate. There are arguments about whether he should do more to make the case before the election. For my part, I think the statement of a desired timetable would do most to reassure markets and investors that the government was no longer uncertain of its purpose, while holding its hand on a final decision. Hanging over too large a portion of the scene is the shadow of the chancellor, who opposes such committing clarity, and appears to revel in the speculation caused by his apparent indecision. Is he a closet sceptic? Why does he disdain other finance ministers? What's his game? Even Number 10 asks the questions.

But the pressure from the other side is beginning to gather, with a new force. When ministers such as Stephen Byers, and especially Peter Mandelson, make a public case against the status quo, Mr Brown may be furious but Mr Blair is quietly pleased. They show the downside of being out of the euro. This is likely to go on, even if the prime minister himself chooses not to press the point. He has his proxies. Trade unions will soon start piling in. The figures on inward investment may go on looking rosy, but there are potent cases the other way, and anyway everyone knows this is a trend-line where the lags are long. A critical mass, composed of events and words, is building.

Whether the referendum is held depends now, in my opinion, on only one unknown: the size of Labour's majority at the election. Below a certain level, it may be unholdable. Above 80-100, the intimidatory power of those who want to stop the test being made will be swept aside. The parallels with 1975, when the government carried the yes vote home by 2-1, may not all be so apt as Bob Worcester makes them sound in his new pamphlet (How to win the Euro Referendum: lessons of 1975, Foreign Policy Centre). But his contention that the outcome depends on Blair's image as a credible leader more than on the minutiae of popular attitudes to the currency, or even sovereignty, will rightly encourage the leader to take the plunge.

In doing so, he will run a risk. But it has to be run. It means exposing those very existential questions that the eurosceptics fear to face. It would be a clarifying process. For better or worse, the referendum is a pledge - let it be for the better. Desired by one side, rejected or fended off or schemed against by the other, it will expose which is the side of democratic virtue. There are those so sure of their own case that they couldn't believe Mr Blair would dare hold it. If he wins biggish, prepare to watch their confidence fall, at last, incredulously apart.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Desert Bloom
(Eugene Corr, 1986) 6pm, FilmFour
Jon Voight runs a filling station in the middle of the Nevada desert, and discovers from the loose talk of army officers working in the area that there's going to be nuclear testing nearby. On top of this, he has to deal with latent alcoholism, his daughter (Annabel Gish) and his wife's divorcee sister (Ellen Barkin) adding pressure to the already spatially and financially stretched environment. Good performances from all of the leads, but an excess of issues finds the film unable to hold together all of its elements. (WH)

Bram Stoker's Dracula
(Francis Ford Coppola, 1992) 10pm, FilmFour
Coppola reads the great gothic tale as a grand amour: in the blood-weltered middle ages, Gary Oldman's grieving Dracula (pictured) condemns himself to the undead when his woman dies; he exists in torment for centuries until, in London, he discovers her living image in Winona Ryder. Anthony Hopkins plays Van Helsing, Keanu Reeves the foolish Jonathan Harker.

Play It Again Sam
(Herbert Ross, 1972) 12.10am, Sky Cinema
Woody Allen's hilarious homage to Casablanca, adapted from his stage play. He's his normal neurotic self and film buff, tapping into Bogart's legendary cool in a doomed attempt to seduce a woman, any woman, after his wife walks out. His efforts, as Rick would say, don't amount to a hill of beans, until he realises he's in love with best friend Tony Roberts' wife, Diane Keaton. Jerry Lacy does a good Bogart.

The Ice Storm
(Ang Lee, 1997) 1.05am, Sky Premier
A delicately crafted, beautifully acted study of suburban morality in 70s America: all self-consciously hip partner-swapping parties and inner torment. It focuses on the Hood family: student son, Paul (Tobey Maguire) is returning home for Christmas, finding parents Kevin Kline and Joan Allen's relationship in deep freeze: Dad's having an affair with a neighbour (Sigourney Weaver). Meanwhile Paul's sister Wendy (Christina Ricci) is exploring her sexuality, and there's a tragedy in the offing. (PH)

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
The Horror Of... Flatmates 8pm, BBC1
Mouldy pizza crusts and extremely dodgy toilets: Jo Brand exposes them all in this amusing look at the pitfalls of flatsharing. All extremes of flatsharing hell are covered, such as 24-year-old Tom who operates possibly the most disciplined flatshare in Britain. Cleaning rotas are organised with military precision. Phone bills are calculated to the nearest 100th of a penny and friends are charged to stay the night. "The secret of my success is organisation", beams Tom. "His rules can cause a bit of friction sometimes", says flatmate Scott diplomatically.

Can You Live Without... Your Wife? 8.30pm, Channel 4
In the second episode of this series, Julie leaves husband Cliff for two weeks to run the house. 39-year-old businessman Cliff has never ironed a shirt or cooked in his life and this film follows his predictably disastrous first attempts. Have we really just entered the new millennium?

Reputations 9pm, BBC2
Adored by women and idolised by his party, Anthony Eden is mostly remembered for his cataclysmic handling of the Suez crisis. "What counts is grit and judgement", says Barbara Castle. "And I believe Eden lacked in both." Reputations reassesses his political career and, predictably, explores his complex personal life. Interviews with his ex-wife and contemporaries like Lord Deedes provide an intriguing insight into one of the last upper-class British prime ministers.

Family Secrets 9pm, Channel 4
When it comes to committing sin in the eyes of the Roman Catholic church, love affairs with priests are pretty well up the list. The fourth programme in this series explores the particularly painful dilemmas of women who fall in love with priests and how the inevitable secrecy prevents the relationship from flourishing. "I detest the secrecy and deceit," says one woman. "It doesn't seem to bother him, which I find strange being that he's a priest".
