fields.headline: Pinochet opponents celebrate court ruling
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A Chilean court yesterday said it had "resolved that there are grounds to begin a case" against the former dictator General Augusto Pinochet after announcing the stripping of his immunity from prosecution, exposing him to a long legal battle over human rights abuses under his rule.
fields.body:
A Chilean court yesterday said it had "resolved that there are grounds to begin a case" against the former dictator General Augusto Pinochet after announcing the stripping of his immunity from prosecution, exposing him to a long legal battle over human rights abuses under his rule.

Opponents of the former dictator cheered and wept for joy, while Gen Pinochet's defence team announced plans to appeal against the ruling, the outlines of which had been leaked to the media two weeks earlier.

The Santiago court of appeal said yesterday it voted by 13 to nine on May 23 to remove Gen Pinochet's congressional immunity as a senator for life.

He faces 110 lawsuits filed on behalf of those killed or missing during his bloody 17-year rule, which began with a coup against the elected Marxist president Salvador Allende and ended in 1990.

In releasing the 55-page decision, the court president, Ruben Ballesteros, said the 22 members of the court "resolved that there are grounds to begin a case".

Gen Pinochet's opponents celebrated in the streets. "It's unbelievable what we've just heard, but we did it!" said Viviana Diaz, leader of a group representing the disappeared.

Gen Pinochet's lawyers have said they will appeal to the supreme court within the five days allowed. His attorney, Pablo Rodriguez, has said an appeal will be based on "Gen Pinochet's total innocence".

The defence is expected to portray the 84-year-old as mentally unfit to understand the charges or to consult with his lawyers.

webTitle: This time, Britain must get it right

fields.headline: This time, Britain must get it right
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The north-south divide is nothing new. Go back 150 or 200 years and Britain was split into distinct geographical and economic entities, just as it is now. The difference then was that the north was in the ascendancy, acting as the cradle of the industrial revolution. James Watt, George Stephenson, Richard Arkwright: these were not part of a London-based metropolitan elite, but from the north and Scotland.
fields.body:
The north-south divide is nothing new. Go back 150 or 200 years and Britain was split into distinct geographical and economic entities, just as it is now. The difference then was that the north was in the ascendancy, acting as the cradle of the industrial revolution. James Watt, George Stephenson, Richard Arkwright: these were not part of a London-based metropolitan elite, but from the north and Scotland.

Perhaps due to its supremacy in the age of coal and iron, Britain lagged behind in the second industrial revolution. British brains helped to develop many of the inventions of the modern age - the jet engine, radar, penicillin, the computer - but an inability to bring capital together with a skilled workforce meant a slow but relentless fall down the industrial league table.

A third industrial revolution is now under way, built around the half a dozen industries - from biotechnology to robotics - that are likely to shape the world over the next couple of generations. For all countries the age of the internet represents huge challenges, but for Britain more than most.

Get it right and Britain could end more than a century of relative decline and revive those regions still scarred by the decline of the sectors that powered the first industrial revolution. Get it wrong, and Britain could spend this century as it did the last, always a couple of steps behind the best and struggling to catch up.

All this presupposes that a third industrial revolution is under way. Constant technological change is a consistent theme of industrialised societies, but there is a school of thought which says that the global economy is marked by long cycles of around 60 years, each dominated by a prevailing industrial model that is invented, developed and finally becomes exhausted. Arguably, the transformation in the 19th century wrought by railways, the telegraph and electricity changed lives far more fundamentally than the internet ever will, but clearly something quite fundamental is changing the makeup of western economies.

The optimistic scenario is that the age of the internet plays to Britain's strengths. Just as the first industrial revolution was built around the ingenuity of self-taught men beavering away on their own, so the third industrial revolution prizes originality over organisation. Accordingly, the more flexible and fluid anglo-saxon countries have an advantage over those nations that are more reliant on order and traditional command and control structures.

The accepted wisdom is that the new economy will be reliant on plentiful supplies of top-grade human capital, something Britain's educational system is well-placed to provide.

A gloomier view is that Britain does well in software and has traditionally been good at providing services, but that the real money in the internet age will be made by companies providing physical products rather than ideas. Here, Britain's inability to translate pure research into mass production will cost it dear, as in the 20th century.

Policymakers will be unable to decide whether the right course of action is to let the market rule or to intervene vigorously, and the result will be the worst of both worlds.

The experience of previous technological paradigms suggests that government does matter, not so much through owning assets and directing investment but by creating the right social and political infrastructure in which new industries can flourish.

It may take decades before there is full flowering of the internet age, with the prizes going to those countries that adapt soonest, adapt best and adapt most comprehensively. The fact that the US has dominated the first phase of the third industrial revolution does not mean that it will continue to lead as the new technology enters a more mature phase, when the accent will be on incremental improvements to products rather than innovation.

In one sense, the advent of the dot.com era provides Britain with an opportunity to draw a line beneath its failures of the past century and start anew. Whether the opportunity will be taken, however, depends on whether the right lessons have been learned. Relying in the 20th century on the transport infrastructure, educational system, working practices and social attitudes of a bygone age cost the country dear. It is to be hoped history does not repeat itself.

All this presupposes that a third industrial revolution is under way. Constant technological change is a consistent theme of industrialised societies, but there is a school of thought which says that the global economy is marked by long cycles of around 60 years, each dominated by a prevailing industrial model that is invented, developed and finally becomes exhausted. Arguably, the transformation in the 19th century wrought by railways, the telegraph and electricity changed lives far more fundamentally than the internet ever will, but clearly something quite fundamental is changing the makeup of western economies. The optimistic scenario is that the age of the internet plays to Britain's strengths. Just as the first industrial revolution was built around the ingenuity of self-taught men beavering away on their own, so the third industrial revolution prizes originality over organisation. Accordingly, the more flexible and fluid anglo-saxon countries have an advantage over those nations that are more reliant on order and traditional command and control structures. The accepted wisdom is that the new economy will be reliant on plentiful supplies of top-grade human capital, something Britain's educational system is well-placed to provide. A gloomier view is that Britain does well in software and has traditionally been good at providing services, but that the real money in the internet age will be made by companies providing physical products rather than ideas. Here, Britain's inability to translate pure research into mass production will cost it dear, as in the 20th century. Policymakers will be unable to decide whether the right course of action is to let the market rule or to intervene vigorously, and the result will be the worst of both worlds. The experience of previous technological paradigms suggests that government does matter, not so much through owning assets and directing investment but by creating the right social and political infrastructure in which new industries can flourish. It may take decades before there is full flowering of the internet age, with the prizes going to those countries that adapt soonest, adapt best and adapt most comprehensively. The fact that the US has dominated the first phase of the third industrial revolution does not mean that it will continue to lead as the new technology enters a more mature phase, when the accent will be on incremental improvements to products rather than innovation. In one sense, the advent of the dot.com era provides Britain with an opportunity to draw a line beneath its failures of the past century and start anew. Whether the opportunity will be taken, however, depends on whether the right lessons have been learned. Relying in the 20th century on the transport infrastructure, educational system, working practices and social attitudes of a bygone age cost the country dear. It is to be hoped history does not repeat itself.

fields.headline: Beauty and the beasts
fields.trailText: The Natural World: Crater | Football Stories | A Question of Sport
fields.body:
In the Ngorongoro Crater in north Tanzania, there is the highest concentration of predators anywhere in the world. There must also be the highest concentration of film crews, seeing as nine out of ten nature documentaries seem to be made there. For those of us who have been watching these programmes since the 60s, the landscape of the Ngorongoro seems as familiar as Albert Square or Coronation Street. All the regular characters were on show in Owen Newman's The Natural World: Crater (BBC2), an elegant portrait of life in this ecological hothouse, where grass and water are in such plentiful supply that the huge herds of herbivores are willing to put up with the constant fear of attack.

There was nothing particularly new on show - but it was shown better, perhaps, than ever before. Two lionesses brought down a zebra in a nightmarish dance of death, the two huge cats clinging on to their victim and just waiting for it to die. Vultures dropped from the sky and thumped on to the ground all around the kill, while a serval, its giant ears twitching, stalked mice and rats among the herbiage. Newman's camera took us right to the heart of the action, whether watching a zebra licking its lips, the screen suddenly filled with black, white and pink, or dodging between the legs of lions and hyenas as they played out their daily squabbles over feeding rights.

These endless skirmishes suddenly made life in the Crater seem altogether less appealing, as each gang went out on cub-killing missions - anything to lessen the competition for meat. Pitched battles between the big strong lions and their smaller but more numerous rivals, the hyenas, had about them a certain sporting air, an impression reinforced by the hordes of tourists constantly observing the action from the safety of their jeeps, and by the apt description of the Ngorongoro as "Africa's superbowl".

And so, you see, there's nothing so unnatural about the implacable rivalry that exists between Scotland and England as portrayed in Football Stories (Channel 4). Filmed during the build-up to last year's Euro 2000 qualifiers, we were treated to the bar-room philosophy of fans from both sides of the border. Their grip on history was slight. "We beat them at the war games up around Hadrian's Wall", claimed one England fan, while his Scottish counterpart referred vaguely to "all the wars between England and Scotland". While the newspapers hammered out the headline "Battle of Britain", Kevin Keegan maintained an enviable sang-froid, and refused to be drawn into silly speculation. "I predict it will be a great game. May the best team win." Faced with such provocation as a Scotland fan pressing his hairy buttocks, bearing the legend "Keegan Can Kiss This", against a plate-glass screen, his impeccable facade was all the more impressive.

Deft use of long shots and a melancholy piano sound track played up the reflective nature of Richard Alwyn's film. There was a refreshing absence of pundits; most of the talk was left to the fans, who didn't beat about the bush. "We're dying to beat the English but that doesn't mean we hate them. It's only a game", said a Scottish cab-driver, but such equanimity was rare. For most of the interviewees, the England-Scotland game was a rare and welcome focus for all sorts of resentments, real and imagined. Happily for all concerned, the factions were kept apart, and only a few fans heard the result from the comfort of police cells.

Euro 2000 fever, for such it must be, was further inflamed on BBC1 with a special edition of A Question of Sport. It's a bit late to be whipping up England-Scotland rivalries, but that didn't stop team captains Ally McCoist and John Parrott from trading a few jovial insults. Sue Barker kept the peace with a twinkle in her eye, and McCoist came over eye-rollingly camp when she snapped "You're not too old to be spanked, Ally." Had this been They Think It's All Over, great mileage would have been made from an innocent line of commentary in one of the clips ("Gary Lineker is being pulled off by the England manager"), but such smut was confined to the dirty minds of armchair critics. A brief glimpse of David Baddiel and Frank Skinner on the terraces provided a grim reminder of what we're in for over the coming month.

webTitle: Getting personal with The Undertones' Damien O'Neill

fields.headline: Getting personal with The Undertones' Damien O'Neill
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym, and if so why? Yes - Tommy Tate And The Torpedoes (used on an Undertones B side....) Why? Not one of my better moments....

Have you ever lied about your age, and if so why? Yes,when I was 18 I was in California and I had a fake ID card made for me claiming I was 21 so I could get into the clubs.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Unavailable (my girlfriend made me write this!)

What was the last illegal thing you did? Mind your own business!

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Lending money to a friend in need.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Too many to mention really but I suppose it might have to be Kevin Shields(My Bloody Valentine/Primal Scream).

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? I love everyone!

Has a critic ever made you cry? With laughter maybe.

What would you advertise without a fee? I already have - I co-wrote a song called Mars Bars in 1978.

What would you never advertise? My body.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning? My nine-week-old daughter Rosa.

What takes you to a happy place? Seeing Rosa and her mum when I wake up in the morning.

 The Undertones are at The Mean Fiddler Harlesden on 9 June and at Fleadh 2000 on 10 June.

webTitle: Livingstone credit rating hits Tube funding row

fields.headline: Livingstone credit rating hits Tube funding row
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Plans to spend billions of pounds on modernising the Tube could cost more because of the "political risk" following Ken Livingstone's landslide victory in London's mayoral election, according to the world's leading credit rating agency, Standard & Poor's.
fields.body:
Plans to spend billions of pounds on modernising the Tube could cost more because of the "political risk" following Ken Livingstone's landslide victory in London's mayoral election, according to the world's leading credit rating agency, Standard & Poor's.

Yesterday Standard & Poor's awarded Transport for London - the new body which will succeed London Transport - a double-A rating, warning of the "uncertainties that influence credit quality at this point".

The lower the credit rating, the more expensive it is likely to be for TfL to borrow money, whether in the form of long-term private-finance contracts with infrastructure companies or in the form of debt issued to the market.

Although double-A is among the agency's highest ratings, it is lower than the government's own triple-A score. It could have been higher but for the tussle between Mr Livingstone and Downing Street over the best way to finance improvements to the capital's public transport in general and the Tube in particular, S&P said.

The government favours a partnership with private industry over a 30-year period to modernise the Tube's infrastructure.

Mr Livingstone and his supporters propose to sell bonds to investors to raise the billions of pounds needed.

S&P supplied the credit rating at the request of the Government Office for London and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

In theory, the rating is not affected by the method used to raise money for TfL, any more than an individual's credit rating is affected by the goods on which he spends his money.

However, S&P said yesterday that unanimity between central government and the mayor's office on the means of financing Tube improvements would have reduced the political risk and could have lifted TfL's rating.

S&P said that, as with all credit scores, the TfL rating would be kept under constant surveillance. TfL takes over responsibility for London buses, taxi licensing and the Docklands Light Railway next month; it also assumes responsibility for the Tube in 2001.

webTitle: Mersey beats faster to the hi-tech sound

fields.headline: Mersey beats faster to the hi-tech sound
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It is a strange statistic. It sounds spurious. But nevertheless it is trotted out locally with dead-pan confidence: 70% of Japanese computer games are designed within a 30 mile radius of Liverpool. Forget the wit and the tourists on their Magical Mystery tours. Liverpudlians now live and work in an e-port, churning out computer games, software and web designers at a rate that suggests the creative juices of the north-west are flowing as fast as they have for decades.
fields.body:
It is a strange statistic. It sounds spurious. But nevertheless it is trotted out locally with dead-pan confidence: 70% of Japanese computer games are designed within a 30 mile radius of Liverpool. Forget the wit and the tourists on their Magical Mystery tours. Liverpudlians now live and work in an e-port, churning out computer games, software and web designers at a rate that suggests the creative juices of the north-west are flowing as fast as they have for decades.

And just a glance at the new structures of steel and glass springing up around the old docks says this City has got a serious case of the new economies.

Further evidence of such can be found in the car park outside Psygnosis, a world-leading computer games developer which is based in Liverpool's Wavertree Technology Park.

There's a Porche Boxster, a dozen BMWs. various4WD's and a scattering of MX5 coupés. Most of the models are owned by the majority of twenty-something whizz kids who make up Psygnosis's 220 staff.

"Our staff are quite well paid compared to the average Joe out there," said John Bickley, general manager at Psygnosis. "They have a disposable income and we have helped play a small part in the rejuvenation of the Liverpool economy which is definitely on the up. It's almost literally every month now that new bars and restaurants are opening up, which to me is a significant sign of economic resurgence."

Life - one of the growing number of trendy bars and restaurants in Bold Street - is one of the popular haunts for both the "techies" and the stars of the local soaps, Brookside and Hollyoaks.

Meanwhile, penthouses are selling in the dockland renovated loft warehouses for £500,000. Unlike London, however, you can still buy a three bedroom semi for between £60,000 and £130,000. A £60m investment has also been announced for five 40-storey buildings along the city's river front.

"Obviously the new technology-related businesses are fast growing and a very important aspect of our regional economy," said John Burrows, the North-West Development Agency's business development director. The agency is now fielding 300 inquiries annually from large hi-tech firms, which are considering investing in the area and want to rationalise their European operations.

Sony saw the potential early and bought Psygnosis back in 1993 to support its Playstation business. The local firm's latest big project is updating the Formula One game for the Playstation2 which has already been released in Japan and is expected in the US and UK later this year.

Now a queue has formed to follow Sony's Liverpool lead. The French games giant Infogrames has also been drawn in to the hub of creativity and bought another gaming group, Ocean.

Another of Europe's largest games developers, Rage Software, is also based on Merseyside - but has remained independent, with a full listing on the London stock market.

The growth of hi-tech business has helped to offset the demise of manufacturing and port industries which drove unemployment in the region to almost 20% in the depths of the recession in the early 1990s. The latest figure is 9.5%. It has also lifted house prices, boosted new restaurants and bars - and left salesmen at glitzy car showrooms rubbing their hands with glee.

Almost £1bn in investment finance from the European Development Fund has contributed to Liverpool's economic revival and its increasing attractiveness to business.

But Pete Fulwell, who lectures at the Liverpool Institute of Performing Arts and acts as a digital industry adviser, warned that new funding needed to be spent wisely for the region's success. "It's the beginning of something really important in the next five years in this area and we've got to get the next round of European Development Funding right. That will see us continue to grow in the next 50 years," he said. "Otherwise we will carry on the old depression and fault lines."

While the north-west doesn't have London or Heathrow on its doorstop to lure the likes of Microsoft, the half-hour drive to Manchester's international airport is almost as adequate, says Burrows.

The argument of a better quality of life goes a long way with many of the companies which have decided to locate in Liverpool and the surrounding area. Housing is cheaper than in the south-east, commuting is easy and there is a thriving cultural scene. And of course Liverpool is one of the few British cities apart from London with what amounts to a world brand.

Amaze, an internet company that emerged from Liverpool University and which now employs 125 people, does not consider its location a disadvantage. Stuart Melhuish, chief executive of the web design and software company, admits Liverpool can be a difficult location for long-distance travel.

But he adds: "We are in the e-business, location isn't necessarily an issue. The reality is with our client handling skills we can work with customers remotely." It boasts clients such as pharmaceutical group Warner Lambert, Saatchi and Saatchi and Volkswagen.

Melhuish said a lot of Amaze's employees were graduates - and the company relied on the surrounding universities, which he listed as a major plus for the region. "Creativity is definitely one of the region's strengths," he said. "Finding a way to ensure that talent pool stays in the north-west is the difficult thing."

The region has to entice more government and venture capital funding into the area - and ensure that support is provided for local entrepreneurial flair.

One example of how the area can be bypassed was provided by BT. The initial roll-out of ADSL - the new technology that provides high-speed internet access using ordinary telephone lines - did not include Liverpool, even though it could be crucial to many local hi-tech firms.

But many of the e-businesses in the city are serving world markets, rather than just the UK, says Melhuish: "Liverpool has a much greater chance of success in Europe than it does within the UK ... there are a lot of cities like Liverpool across Europe that are trying to produce sustainable economies."

Even so, the area is still competing with centres like Cambridge and the south-east which have attracted large foreign investment and become powerful economic regions. The clusters of new businesses in Liverpool are small by comparison and need commitment and continued government backing to achieve anywhere near the growth of their counterparts in the south.

fields.headline: Trade-off  Sanctuary for Iron Maiden
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Members of the heavy metal band Iron Maiden have become stock market speculators by each taking hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of shares in Sanctuary Group, the entertainment company.
fields.body:
Members of the heavy metal band Iron Maiden have become stock market speculators by each taking hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of shares in Sanctuary Group, the entertainment company.

Lead singer Bruce Dickinson, bass player Steve "Arry" Harris and the rest of the group have been granted the shares in Sanctuary in exchange for their 50% stake in Iron Maiden's website, <A HREF="http://www.ironmaiden.com."

Sanctuary" TARGET="_NEW">www.ironmaiden.com.

Sanctuary already owns the other half of the site, which was launched last year and has quickly become one of Britain's five most popular internet destinations, notching up 9m page impressions last month.

Andy Taylor, chief executive of Sanctuary, said the deal was a rare venture into equities for the millionaire musicians.

"The boys usually keep all their money in bonds and insured investments. They don't generally speculate," he said.

Sanctuary's shares rose 1.75p to 61.25p on news of the deal, which was announced alongside a 33% increase in interim pre-tax profits to £1.33m.

Sanctuary Group wants full ownership of the Iron Maiden website so it can combine some elements of it with a more general heavy metal portal, Metal-is.com.

The company believes heavy metal merchandise is a highly promising area for e-commerce because the genre's fans tend to be very loyal, and many are interested in computers.

Mr Taylor said: "Heavy metal fans are often into hi-tech stuff - these things go hand in hand."

The official Iron Maiden site does a swift trade in selling T-shirts online. It also provides a chat community where fans and amateur bands can talk to each other.

Sanctuary benefited in the first half from the success of two of its other acts, Travis and Ricky Martin. Sanctuary's recording studios were used by Rod Stewart and Bill Wyman, while the group's Cloud 9 television arm gained from the popularity of its children's programme, The Tribe.

fields.headline: Straw's asylum admission
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, last night acknowledged that refugees seeking asylum in Britain were forced to break the law to escape the threat of persecution in their native country.
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, last night acknowledged that refugees seeking asylum in Britain were forced to break the law to escape the threat of persecution in their native country.

In a debate on the asylum system, sponsored by the Observer at Church House, central London, Mr Straw said that a fundamental ambiguity at the heart of the 1951 convention on refugees had led to an atmosphere of hostility against asylum seekers.

Under this convention "everyone has the right to make a claim, but there is no obligation on any country to admit them to make the claim." As a long-term strategy he would seek to reform it, working with other governments to remove the ambiguity. "There is a need for us to develop a new system in the world for how we entertain asylum seekers."

He told the audience: "I do not think the system is fully fair. Are we going to make it more fair? Yes, we are."

He added: "It has to be the most difficult issue in terms of ethical dilemmas I have had to deal with. I do not suggest we always get it right, but it is about getting a balance between fair and firm."

Mr Straw earlier clashed with the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, who described the system of processing asylum applications as "incompetent and chaotic". It was not fair to the person for whom it was designed to help, the refugee facing terrible persecution.

Britain was a target for fraudulent asylum claimants, she said. The Conservatives' proposed reforms, primarily the automatic detention of applicants in secure reception centres, would reduce non-genuine claims.

"I want to send a message that says that if you come to Great Britain you will be put in reception centres, you will be dealt with quickly, and if your claim is genuine you will be most welcome."

webTitle: Getting rich is vulgar, says developer with a dream

fields.headline: Getting rich is vulgar, says developer with a dream
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Chris Beech, a computer programmer seeking cash to develop his own business-to-business dot.com, is an interesting paradox.
fields.body:
Chris Beech, a computer programmer seeking cash to develop his own business-to-business dot.com, is an interesting paradox.

Unlike many of his peers scrambling to develop web sites and flaunting e-commerce strategies to catch the coat tails of the online gold rush, he says that he finds the whole money side of the dot.com boom vulgar.

"I do find the whole dot.com idea and getting rich vulgar," he offers earnestly.

But still Beech, 25, admits the explosion of the internet means there has never been a better time to turn a dream into reality. That dream is one of the reasons why the former maths student switched his university studies to science and technology.

And he says Liverpool is a great place to kick start his venture. What drives the net community is intellectual capital - and Beech lists Liverpool as a breeding ground for web designers and programmers - calling it a "little village where everybody knows each other".

As a Liverpudlian, Beech is determined to locate his internet venture in Liverpool. He looks at companies like Amaze and Psygnosis, which had their genesis as one- and two-man operations, and sees that success on the international stage "can be done here by local people".

He admits that the biggest challenge in the dot.com world is not being located in England's north-west, but that so many other eager individuals have been drawn to the web and its potential riches.

"It is trying to stand out from that crowd that is the big thing," he said. "Otherwise it's perfectly feasible to run a business from Liverpool."

Beech has proved this with his programming contracts both for clients in Britain and others further afield. He recently designed a database search system for a German gallery so that web users could find works by different artists online. The opportunities extend further with the prospect that the gallery may later need an e-commerce operation developed.

The other big challenge Beech outlines is the need for greater support by government and England's wider entrepreneurial community.

"We've got to learn to go with a good idea in this country."

Beech is reluctant to discuss the detail of the business concept for which he is negotiating funding. Almost the only detail he will give away is his expectation that it will employ about 30 people within 18 months of its conception.

Beech has spent the past six months fine tuning his business plan that has been presented to venture capitalists.

"There's no point in talking a lot about it unless I've got the funding," says Beech. There is also the concern of intellectual property, which can be hard to defend on the internet.

Beech's confidence in his idea, however, is leading him to arrange a business trip to silicon valley - even without venture capital backing in place. His programming work has paid for the ticket and covered the hotel bills.

The visit to California will also provide the opportunity to tap some potential customers, says Beech. He also intends to network and meet companies and individuals with the technical expertise in the US that would support his business. The one drawback of Liverpool he does concede is that it may not have the deep pool of technical staff his business will need.

Asked whether he might not consider pockets of south-east England sometimes referred to as budding silicon valleys, and you get a flash of Mersey wit. "It's rubbish. There's only one silicon valley. It's almost guilt by association."

webTitle: Green admits ITV let the BBC win internet initiative

fields.headline: Green admits ITV let the BBC win internet initiative
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications chairman Michael Green said yesterday that the ITV companies needed to extract further value from their collective brand name and develop the itv.co.uk website.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications chairman Michael Green said yesterday that the ITV companies needed to extract further value from their collective brand name and develop the itv.co.uk website.

He conceded that the BBC had stolen a lead in this area by developing a seamless transition between its free-to-air radio and television programming and its internet offering.

Mr Green said that the ITV website would gain much of its strength through closer relationships with the pay-television group ONdigital. At present, ONdigital - jointly owned by Carlton and Granada - provides e-mail only, but the launch of full internet access is imminent.

The other way of strengthening and capitalising on ITV.com as a "huge asset" would be through consolidation among the ITV franchises, Mr Green said at the Merill Lynch technology, media and telecoms conference in London.

Carlton is merging with United News & Media in a move that will streamline the ITV industry and also strengthen their clout in the fight for advertising revenue. The advertising revenues of both companies have suffered strong competition from cable, satellite, digital and internet media.

As part of the merger both companies are selling off a number of businesses. One of these is Technicolor - the leading video duplicator and ciné film processing business owned by Carlton, which has attracted strong interest. It is expected to fetch almost £2bn and at least 10 parties are said to be vying for it.

Granada has threatened to spoil the merger with a bid for one or other company but this depends on it gaining regulatory approval.

Mr Green refused to speculated on Granada's intentions.

"We believe in the consolidation of ITV," Mr Green said. "This is something that is going to help our industry. However, it would be inappropriate for me to comment on what Granada may or may not do."

He said Carlton was "still very confident that ONdigital will get a listing".

Analysts have put a value on ONdigital of almost £2bn following the release of figures which showed that it had signed up a total of 673,000 subscribers by the end of March.

In another conference presentation, Stuart Prebble, chief executive of ONdigital, said the pay-TV group would continue to fight fiercely to win the rights to Premier League Football.

"The rights market is now far more competitive and open to regulatory scrutiny," Mr Prebble said. "We completely understand what the value of those rights are to our business", and ONdigital was confident its subscribers would have access to Premier League football.

ONdigital is also expected to announce shortly the outcome of negotiations with BT on the introduction of ADSL.

This is the new technology that enables high-speed internet access using ordinary telephone cabling. It is now being rolled out by BT - but ONdigital will have to modify its set-top boxes to use the ADSL service rather than a standard analogue connection.

"We do an enormous amount of business with BT," Mr Prebble said. "We are discussing all the opportunities with BT and other players but we are not ready to make an announcement at the moment."

webTitle: Dowdy dowry turns heads at beauty show

fields.headline: Dowdy dowry turns heads at beauty show
fields.standfirst: European countries are divided on the way to allocate scarce mobile phone frequencies
fields.trailText: Ever gone to an auction, got caught up in the excitement of the whole process, bid feverishly for a top lot and then, when you got home, been gradually assailed by the feeling that perhaps you overpaid? Pity then (briefly) a cadre of top telecoms companies. They are locked in a series of competitions for third generation (UTMS) mobile phone network licences.
fields.body:
Ever gone to an auction, got caught up in the excitement of the whole process, bid feverishly for a top lot and then, when you got home, been gradually assailed by the feeling that perhaps you overpaid? Pity then (briefly) a cadre of top telecoms companies. They are locked in a series of competitions for third generation (UTMS) mobile phone network licences.

A few months ago the licences must have seemed, well, a licence to print money. Then Gordon Brown hit the jackpot by auctioning the licences for a staggering £22.5bn - more than anyone, the bidding companies included - expected. Spain, by contrast, only generated €2bn (£1.2bn) with a "beauty contest" in March, and Finland gave away its licences, arguing that it would spur innovation.

But Britain's windfall has seen continental governments reconsidering their plans. The choice: should they opt for so-called beauty competitions where business plans - how much a company will invest, the jobs it will create, the cost and range of services - matter more than the fee? Or should they look to maximise the amount of cash up front?

Some countries are clear in their approach. Norway will opt for a beauty parade, Germany for an auction. Italy is expected to go for something in between.

France will be the next country to decide. Finance minister Laurent Fabius will reveal this week how the new licences will be handed out. Before the British auction, France was heading for the beauty parade approach. Now it is expected to be a hybrid affair.

"Before the UK auction the situation was clear - it would be a beauty contest in France. Now the government's position has evolved," said one Paris-based observer.

A French attempt at compromise would be understandable. The beauty parade and auction approaches each have their advantages and their drawbacks.

Auctions are simple and transparent. If you have the money and win the bid , you get the licence - though Britain did keep one licence for a new entrant. The drawback is that the process forces the price up to a point where all but the biggest players are squeezed out. There are concerns that the entry cost will mean networks being rolled out more slowly and more expensively.

Worth noting is Vodafone's estimation that despite paying more than £5bn for its 3G British licence it is still expecting a very reasonable rate of return.

The government took the view that an auction would force the market to set the price for the licences rather than civil servants with little knowledge of the industry coming up with an arbitrary value. It was thought the latter risked short-changing the taxpayer and allowing the winners to make excessive profits.

"These are big, sophisticated companies. They are grown up, backed by big banks. They understand better than government what the licences are worth," said a DTI source.

But with France Télécom the country's only home grown telecoms heavyweight a beauty contest could allow the French government to head off the prospect of French companies losing to foreigners.

Martin Bouygues, head of the group which controls one of France's three mobile phone operators, Bouygues Télécom, has already attacked an auction process, saying the decision over whether or not to bid was "a choice between sudden death and slow death".

Beauty parades on the other hand are seen as too subjective, with the authorities free to pick and choose between competing companies. And there are those who argue that if companies do not have to put up large sums of cash up front they will be under less pressure to speed on with the network roll-out.

There are also those who wonder whether the mix of auctions and beauty parades across Europe allows some governments to subsidise local companies by opting for a beauty parade.

Britain was concerned about the risk of legal action from a beauty contest. It was thought that a misjudgment on the part of civil servants about who should win the licences would expose the government to lengthy legal proceedings which could tie up the process in red tape for several years, preventing rapid dissemination of the services that the new phones will offer.

While the authorities have underlined the cash generating potential of the aunction approach the revenue raised was a second order issue. The government's primary concern was to promote competition - hence the licence reserved for a new entrant.

The money flooding into the Treasury's already swelling coffers has, if anything, become a curse rather than a blessing, increasing the political pressure on the chancellor to be more generous in the current spending round than he believes is economically prudent.

Other national finance ministers may be equally embarrassed. Next generation licences are crucial to the operators. They cannot opt out, which ever way governments decide.

As one telecoms executive put it this week. "It's not a decision to be made. It has already been taken. We will go for it."

fields.headline: Friends' date with bomb disaster
fields.trailText: When Andrea Dykes was four months pregnant, she decided she wanted John Light to be godfather to her child.
fields.body:
When Andrea Dykes was four months pregnant, she decided she wanted John Light to be godfather to her child.

The 32-year-old had been her husband Julian's best man and the three friends, who had met when they were all working in Colchester, Essex, were extremely close.

Mr Light was so honoured and excited that he decided to treat the couple to an evening out in the West End of London. The Dykes wanted to make a day of "the special occasion", the court heard.

They booked time off work and travelled to London on Friday, April 30. They joined Mr Light and his partner Gary Partridge for lunch in Soho, spent the afternoon window-shopping, and agreed to meet at the Admiral Duncan pub, in Old Compton Street, for an early drink before going on to the theatre.

They were joined in the pub by Mr Light's former partner, Nick Moore, who went up to the bar to buy a drink. "The others stood close by," Nigel Sweeney QC, prosecuting, told the Old Bailey. "But unknown to them, the defendant had been into the pub and had planted a bomb inside a sports holdall. All five were standing close to the holdall."

Another customer spotted the bag and alerted the staff, the court heard.

"The manager was leaning over the bar to examine it when it exploded at 6.36pm," said Mr Sweeney.

"The effect of the explosion in such a confined space was devastating. Nick Moore and Andrea Dykes were killed at the scene. John Light died from his injuries the next day."

Mr Sweeney said the prosecution had refused to accept Copeland's pleas of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

He said Copeland had been to the doctor twice in 1998, complaining of memory loss, anxiety attacks and a feeling that he was "losing his mind".

But Mr Sweeney said Copeland had not been back to the doctors for six months before the first bomb was planted, and was facing a "mass of evidence".

"Your task is a narrow one," Mr Sweeney told the jury. "It is to decide whether this defendant is guilty of murder or is guilty of manslaughter, as he admits. We say that this is clearly a case of murder."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Weakness in the share prices of a handful of heavyweight drugs and telecoms names pushed the London market down yesterday, after the strong runs of recent sessions.
fields.body:
Weakness in the share prices of a handful of heavyweight drugs and telecoms names pushed the London market down yesterday, after the strong runs of recent sessions.

The FTSE 100 index ended down 79.7 points at 6,546.7 despite slightly more stocks showing increases than being hit by price cuts. Volume was a lightweight 1.1bn.

The decline was in large part caused by a dip in shares of Vodafone AirTouch, source of a large chunk of the FTSE's recent climb from 6,000 to 6,600, which succumbed to a bout of profit-taking to drop 10p to 325.25p.

Weakness in rival BT, which dropped 25p to £10.14, combined to account for 42 FTSE points lost to telecoms companies.

Nearly as influential, the FTSE 100's four pharmaceuticals names chomped through 35 points, with Glaxo Welcome (down 111p to £17.78) and merger partner Smith Kline (down 46p to 797p) dropping more than 5% to echo Friday's falls in US drug stocks.

"The strong rally we saw last week has probably run out of steam," said Steve Russell, UK equities strategist at HSBC Securities.

Prospects of higher US interest rates, dampened last week by weaker-than-expected jobs data, remained a threat to equity market valuations, Mr Russell warned.

"We will see the need for further interest rate rises and therefore more risk of a hard landing for the US economy and more chance of the FTSE backtracking to the low end of its range," he said.

A pause to the strong bounce in technology, media and telecoms shares left three recent FTSE 100 arrivals facing imminent demotion from the main index.

Friday's closing prices put e-security firm Baltimore Technologies, telecoms firms Thus and Kingston Communications in automatic FTSE demotion territory below 110th place, despite their recent recoveries.

None made the sort of move yesterday needed to ensure survival in the top flight, leaving just today's trading for them to scramble higher or face the chop at FTSE's quarterly review meeting tomorrow.

Even a last-gasp recovery might not help if Bookham Technology, Hanson and Ocean Group retain automatic promotion spots of 89th or above governed by market capitalisation.

Another risking ejection was palm-top computer maker Psion, up to 109th position and safety on Friday's close only to drop 22p to 625p yesterday.

Airports operator BAA saw its shares firm 16p to 498p on in-line profits, a share buyback plan and its pledge to focus on core activities after the end to European Union duty-free shopping.

Shares in British Land, the country's second biggest property group, shed23.25p to 426.25p after it bought a 29.9% stake in rival firm Liberty International, just short of the trigger for a full bid.

Investors ignored a denial by French defence and electronics group Thomson-CSF that it was gunning for British warship builder Vosper Thornycroft, driving the latter's price up 87.5p to £12.87.5.

fields.headline: Sober day for Spivvy.com
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Anyone hoping to make a stock market debut with SpivvyDeal.com buoyed by a recent bounce back in demand for technology stocks would have retreated back to the garden shed after more sober trading yesterday.
fields.body:
Anyone hoping to make a stock market debut with SpivvyDeal.com buoyed by a recent bounce back in demand for technology stocks would have retreated back to the garden shed after more sober trading yesterday.

Buyers were still out for key telecoms, media and technology companies but top firms such as palm top computer maker Psion and e-security group Baltimore Technologies saw their share prices fall. Psion was down 22p at 635 while Baltimore fell 16.5p to 565p.

Last week's rally culminated in an 8% jump in the Techmark 100 index on Friday and led to hopes of a sustained revival. But the index of top tech stocks ended last night at 3633.01 points, down slightly at 1.94.

Downward pressure was helped by profit-taking and this left traders disagreeing as to how the market was developing. Some claimed that yesterday's trading showed that higher values had been accepted and that the market had bottomed out.

Others said it signalled that many British stocks were still overvalued as compared with their counterparts across the Atlantic, and that there would have to be a further shake-out.

Whatever the future, European investors have made clear they will be more discerning than previously. Their appetite, even for new issues both here and abroad, has far from evaporated however as a stream of announcements yesterday made clear.

British internet software provider Orchestream Holdings and high speed internet service provider Chello Broadband both confirmed they were pushing ahead with early floats on the back of strong support.

Orchestream wants to raise about £54m when it moves down the slipway on June 28. Later this week Dutch-based Chello is aiming to raise a $400m in the US.

Similarly Hertforshire-based microprocessor designer ARC Cores said it would complete a $50m private placing later this week after being "overwhelmed" by support.

It is not just larger deals that are continuing to come forward. In London Online Travel Corporation, a net-based travel agent and tour operator, announced plans to raise £10m with the help of tech-heavy stockbroker Durlacher Corporation, whose shares had fallen 6% to 335p last night.

Confidence in the markets was helped by Comdirect, the internet broking arm of Germany's Commerzbank, when it floated at a 22% premium on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt.

This should not detract from the fact that plummeting values in the tech sector in recent months have left investor nerves frazzled and confidence dented. Top technology analysts now say that flotation is ruled out for anything other than those "with a very special story".

Miles Saltiel, technology analyst at West LB Panmure, believes many projects will have to wait till after the summer holidays to see whether investor optimism can return.

Whatever the future level of values, technology will continue to play a growing role in markets worldwide. They now account for 32% of the S&P 500 index of top stocks in the US compared with only 8% a decade ago, according to research from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

Mary Meeker, the technology guru there, says the last nine years of technology flotations had created $4.2 trillion by the end of January, 2000. But she points out that only 5% of the internet flotations created 68% of the total shareholder value appreciation in those new issues.

And while 27 net launches individually increased in value over 1,000%, the majority (65%) were trading in February at less than their first day's closing price.

Her conclusion is: "Given the narrow breadth of tech winners in the whole technology universe it is crucial to be selective when investing in technology stocks picking early leaders with strong fundamentals."

SpivvyDeal.com looks doomed ... for now anyway.

webTitle: Union snubs PM on Labour levy

fields.headline: Union snubs PM on Labour levy
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Members of one of Britain's biggest unions yesterday refused to increase funding of the Labour party in a direct snub to Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Members of one of Britain's biggest unions yesterday refused to increase funding of the Labour party in a direct snub to Tony Blair.

The 1,400 delegates to the Communication Workers Union's annual conference in Bournemouth voted overwhelmingly against a rise, reflecting growing anger within the union about a string of government policies including threats to sell off part of the post office.

Up to £200,000 more for Labour would have been raised by putting up the political levy from 10p to 12p a week, or from 45p to 55p a month.

But Pete Boswell, a Labour member and secretary of the union's Oxfordshire branch, said that would effectively endorse the 75p a week rise in pensions and £1,000 a year university tuition fees.

The conference also threatened to withdraw "financial and moral" support for Labour if the government privatised part or all of the post office.

A number of union leaders have privately warned the prime minister of a backlash in their ranks among traditional Labour supporters.

The CWU's leadership had recommended a levy increase and the decisive no vote followed a speech by Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, which was received politely.

Derek Hodgson, CWU general secretary, who sits on Labour's national executive committee, complained that delegates had earlier warmly welcomed Mr Byers.

"You gave him a round of applause and the minute he turns his back you say you don't believe him," said Mr Hodgson.

Mr Byers said: "We will seek consensus, but no vested interest can have a veto, or stand in the way of policies which are in the national interest.

"Our task, the historic responsibility of the Labour party, is to break down those barriers that deny opportunity and hold people back."

The Labour party declined to comment on the CWU vote.

fields.headline: First Choice buys Turkish agent
fields.trailText: First Choice is to buy a Turkish holiday company, Ten Tours, for up to £77m. Ten Tours, which specialises in trips to the eastern Mediterranean and north Africa, has operations serving French, German and Spanish holidaymakers.
fields.body:
First Choice is to buy a Turkish holiday company, Ten Tours, for up to £77m. Ten Tours, which specialises in trips to the eastern Mediterranean and north Africa, has operations serving French, German and Spanish holidaymakers.

First Choice's finance director David Howell said: "It's our first move into Europe and hopefully, it'll be the first of a number."

The company is initially paying £20m in cash and £20m in shares for Ten Tours, which is owned by three Turkish entrepreneurs. Another £37m could be due, depending on the business's performance.

Mr Howell said First Choice was keen to participate in the rapid consolidation of the travel industry.

A recent spate of deals has included the takeover of Thomson Travel by the German group Preussag, following a hostile bid battle with C&N. Companies are scrambling to build more volume, in order to get the upper hand in negotiating for hotel beds and airline seats.

Yesterday's deal will increase the number of passengers carried by First Choice each year by a quarter, to about 9m. The group will have particularly strong positions in holidays to Turkey, Tunisia, Egypt and Morocco.

Analysts said the acquisition made sense. One said: "Seasonally, it's a good time to buy - they'll get all Ten Tours' summer earnings."

To fund the acquisition, First Choice is using some of the proceeds of a £200m investment last month from Royal Caribbean, a US operator of cruise ships. The group will still have a war chest of about £120m to make further purchases.

First Choice's brands include Unijet, Eclipse and Sovereign, along with the airline Air 2000. Ten Tours also owns an airline, Honur Air, but this is not included in the acquisition because of rules preventing foreign takeovers.

Ten Tours has fared poorly recently - the company made profits of just £3.7m on sales of £188.5m last year. This was mainly due to a slump in bookings for trips to Turkey, blamed on the recent earthquake and continuing political instability.

However, analysts expect the deal to add profits of about £7m to First Choice this year. First Choice's shares rose 1p to 145p yesterday.

Consolidation in the tour industry has been prompted in part by an unwinding in the complicated ownership structure of Germany's leading operators, as well as a general realisation that there is over-capacity in the sector.

fields.headline: Trent buys UK Waste
fields.standfirst: £380m acquisition to be merged with Biffa
fields.trailText: Severn Trent yesterday moved to reduce its dependence on the British water industry by buying UK Waste, a collection and recycling business, from its American owners for £380m.
fields.body:
Severn Trent yesterday moved to reduce its dependence on the British water industry by buying UK Waste, a collection and recycling business, from its American owners for £380m.

Vic Cocker, Severn Trent's chief executive, said that UK Waste would be merged with Biffa, the group's waste management arm, to create a £500m a year business.

He said the purchase of UK Waste from Waste Management would redefine the shape of the British waste industry.

The merger of Biffa and UK Waste, which has yet to be cleared by the competition authorities, is expected to lead to job losses, though these are yet to be quantified.

Severn Trent said it was trying to buy WM Sellbergs, a Swedish company, from Waste Management but no agreement had been reached as "significant issues" were yet to be resolved. A deal would only be struck if it enhanced shareholder value.

The UK Waste deal was announced as Severn Trent, the country's third largest water company, announced that pre-tax profits for the year to March 31 fell from £350m to £274m.

The downturn was largely the result of exceptional restructuring costs of £56m, one off Y2K costs of £8.6m, and a 9% fall in Biffa's profits.

Although the group's overall profits were in the middle of analysts' forecasts, the group's shares ended the day off 15p at 577.5p.

As a result of last year's price review, Severn Trent must reduce the operating costs of its regulated water and sewerage businesses by 11% and 14% respectively.

Robert Walker, the group's deputy chief executive, said he expected operating costs to fall £60m by 2005, instead of the original £44m estimate.

He expected the acquisition of UK Waste would unlock about £15m a year in cost savings and efficiencies.

Mr Walker, who is to take over as chief executive when Mr Cocker retires in October, said the group was looking at securitisation of its assets but still had an open mind on the issue.

The industry regulator, Ian Byatt, has already indicated that such financial engineering raises serious regulatory issues.

David Arculus, group chairman, said the deal marked a high point in the transformation of the group which would become the market leader in waste management. It was already a leader in environmental laboratories in Britain and the United States.

"The annual run rate of turnover for our non-regulated operating arms is close to £1bn and is expected to account for over 50% of the group total over the next year," he said.

webTitle: Guillotine gives morris-dancing member the chop

fields.headline: Guillotine gives morris-dancing member the chop
fields.trailText: Arrogance!" shouted Michael Fabricant just before he left the chamber. For once Mickey was spot on. This is an arrogant government, though he may not be the best person to make the point, since I have in my possession a clipping from the Lichfield Mercury describing the annual Lichfield Bower, a sort of ancient fertility festival.
fields.body:
Arrogance!" shouted Michael Fabricant just before he left the chamber. For once Mickey was spot on. This is an arrogant government, though he may not be the best person to make the point, since I have in my possession a clipping from the Lichfield Mercury describing the annual Lichfield Bower, a sort of ancient fertility festival.

There is a colour picture of Mickey dressed as a morris dancer, with a scarlet sash and red and yellow ribbons on his hat, bizarrely carrying what appear to be two small trees, like a careful dog who doesn't want to be caught short.

Back in mufti, his heartfelt cry came as the Commons returned to the subject of the financial services and markets bill, one of the most complicated pieces of legislation I have ever set eyes on. It is 268 pages long, roughly the thickness of the phone book in a medium-sized African nation.

Earlier this session the Commons finished with the bill, and sent it off to the Lords, who have just returned it with 675 amendments spread over 91 pages.

Many of these are so-called "consequential" amendments, which tidy the bill up after a more substantial change. As a result, there is not an awful lot you can say about amendment no 669: ("Page 268, line 11, column 3, leave out from ('14,') to end of line 14 and insert ('subsections (2), (3), (5) and (6)')". Thrilling it may be to a handful of people, but it's not up there with the abolition of capital punishment as a blood-tingler.

Anyhow, the government had decided to guillotine debate on the whole lot. Its point was that that there might be 675 new amendments, but most of them were very minor, some had been suggested by the Tories in the first place, and the house had already spent, one way or another, some 200 hours on the bill - much of which is not really contentious in the first place.

So for 45 minutes they debated the guillotine motion, which was full of lines that could possibly be understood by Bill Gates, assisted by a Cray supercomputer: "(7) As soon as the House has agreed or disagreed with the Lords in any of their amendments, or disposed of an amendment relevant to a Lords amendment which has been disagreed to, the Speaker shall put forthwith a single question on any amendments moved by a minister of the crown relevant to the Lords amendment."

Fighting stuff, obviously, and it could make the basis of a stirring edition of The Moral Maze. Dr Starkey: " 'Forthwith', forsooth! Do you take us all for idiots, you idiot?"

The Tories had decided to be very angry indeed, and their awkward squad, Messrs Forth, Bercow, Swayne, and - briefly - the morris-dancing member, Mickey Fabb (as in: "pull the other one, it's got bells on"), were out in force. Unlike the Labour party, who managed to have a total of two back-benchers in the chamber.

John Bercow was furious, or so he claimed. There were no fewer than 35 groups of amendments, which once the guillotine motion passed would leave 12 minutes to debate each. (Since a vote takes a full quarter-hour, that would leave minus three minutes for each topic - a period of discussion that the government probably regards as ideal.)

The best intervention was by the Tory MP Richard Shepherd. Mr Shepherd makes a lovely speech, and he always ends with a catch in his throat and a tear in his eye. "This is no way to muzzle a parliament," he said mournfully. "This is a denial of the very function and purpose of this chamber" and the sluice-gates opened wide.

And of course the government won. It always does.

"This is no way to muzzle a parliament," he said mournfully. "This is a denial of the very function and purpose of this chamber" and the sluice-gates opened wide. And of course the government won. It always does.

fields.headline: Heartlands hit by jobs divide
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's heartland areas have been hardest hit by manufacturing job losses since Tony Blair became prime minister, according to a survey identifying a clear north-south divide in the labour market.
fields.body:
Labour's heartland areas have been hardest hit by manufacturing job losses since Tony Blair became prime minister, according to a survey identifying a clear north-south divide in the labour market.

Figures from the Labour Research Department show that eight out of 10 redundancies which could be linked to particular regions occurred in Scotland or the north of England.

The survey traced more than 170,000 redundancies since May 1997. The periods with the highest job losses were in January and March this year.

The findings, published yesterday by the trade union-backed research organisation, will add fuel to the claims of some northern Labour MPs that the government is failing to do enough to address the specific needs of heartland communities.

Mr Blair has always dismissed talk of a straightforward north-south divide, insisting that variations in unemployment and deprivation within regions were as great as those between them.

The survey comes less than two months after MPs on the Commons select committee on education and employment challenged the government's determination to play down the jobs gap.

Their report said: "The benefits of a strong economy have not been shared equally."

It concluded: "There is still a distinctive north-south pattern. Unemployment in southern regions, with the exception of London, is still substantially below the average regional level."

The unemployment rate in the north-east was almost three times the rate in the south-east, said the report entitled, Is there a jobs gap?

The committee chairman, Derek Foster, MP for Bishop Auckland, warned at the time: "In recent months there has been a tendency for ministers to take the view that there are plenty of jobs in all parts of the country.

"We have received a good deal of evidence which refutes that view. Our findings point to the continuing existence of slack labour markets in certain parts of the country ... A failure by the government to recognise this will result in a less sophisticated response to a problem which should concern us all."

The Labour Research survey, based on 578 redundancy announcements made by manufacturing industry in the past three years, found job losses from a wide range of firms, including new industries such as electronics and biotech com panies, as well as older ones such as steel and textiles.

The study concluded: "Of the 86,607 redundancies which could be allocated to a region (around half of the total), 80% were above the recognised north-south dividing line of the Severn to the Wash."

Scotland was the hardest-hit region, with 18,275 of the regional job losses, followed by the West Midlands.

Paul Convery, director of the Unemployment Unit, sounded a cautious note over the figures, saying that initial redundancy announcements frequently did not translate into real job losses.

But he said the Labour Research Department was "bang on" over the geographical divide in job losses. "Manufacturing industry is primarily in the north and in Scotland. Where the jobs are is where the job losses are going to be located."

The government needed to offer retraining more swiftly to those made jobless from manufacturing, he said. Ministers tended to "bounce into action" primarily in the case of big losses, such as those projected for the Ford plant at Dagenham.

A spokeswoman for the Department for Education and Employment stressed that the government was moving to tackle manufacturing changes with initiatives such as the rapid response fund and job creation efforts.

She said: "The government has never said there is not a north-south divide. We are interested at looking at the difference in the regions rather than the difference between the regions, as this is far more reflective of what is going on.

"Since the government came into power the number of job losses has gone down, and it is tackling unemployment."

webTitle: PM returns with call for change in NHS culture

fields.headline: PM returns with call for change in NHS culture
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday swept back to work after his informal paternity leave and set about dragging the NHS towards a modernisation agenda that will deliver better healthcare in return for the promised billions in extra funding.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday swept back to work after his informal paternity leave and set about dragging the NHS towards a modernisation agenda that will deliver better healthcare in return for the promised billions in extra funding.

He chaired a meeting of health ministers from Whitehall and the devolved assemblies - including Sinn Fein's Bairbre du Brun - to trade "best practice" ideas for a better NHS.

Ministers were quick to embrace a system of closer partnership between health and social service authorities for the better treatment of the elderly, which Northern Ireland has pioneered.

The prime minister also marked his return to Labour's increasingly election-oriented agenda by indicating that, although inefficiency and unjustified privilege in health and education will remain vital targets in the government's sights, ministers will use more conciliatory language.

Mr Blair will use a speech to a Women's Institute audience tomorrow to defend Labour's insistence, loudly trumpeted by Gordon Brown, that elite universities such as Oxford and Cambridge still have much to do to become true meritocracies for talent from all social groups. But he will also assure voters that "talk of class war is complete rubbish", according to his spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, marked the emollient tone when he declared yesterday that he had no quarrel with consultants, only with the poor practices of some. It came too late to prevent senior doctors complaining that they were being made whipping boys for wider NHS failures.

Back at No 10, Mr Blair chaired what was described as a successful, wide-ranging two-hour session with health ministers from Cardiff, Edinburgh and Belfast as well as Whitehall's own team and Downing Street experts.

Ministers are convinced that part of the battle they want to win within the NHS is to persuade most hospitals and GPs to adopt the habits of the best around the country. Last night officials singled out four areas for immediate cooperation:

Avoidable "bed-blocking" in hospitals to prevent inefficiency, patient distress and early readmission of elderly patients to hospital after they have been sent home too soon;

Better exchange of information during winter flu crises;

A drive to end wildly varying performances in different health areas;

Next month's promised national plan for health, which will foster Mr Milburn's "four Is" - more information, intervention where hospitals are failing, better inspection, and incentives for staff to do better.

The fruits of yesterday's talks should emerge quickly. Mr Milburn told the health summit that Britain was "under-doctored and under-nursed" and that progressive consultants supported efforts to raise the skills and status of nurses.

Today he will back plans to cut waiting times at accident and emergency departments by referring minor cases to new nurse-led injury clinics. Instead of waiting for hours while doctors handle critical cases, patients would get quick treatment.

Mr Milburn will publish the proposal at a conference in London where he will admit that the NHS has suffered years of undercapacity, underfunding and understaffing.

"But in many cases, variation in performance has little to do with lack of money and resources and everything to do with lack of modernisation," he will say. "For too long the Labour party thought that underfunding was the sole problem. It is radical ideas and radical reform that are needed."

That is a crucial admission: that medical habits must also be modernised.

"We need a cultural change to break through the old demarcation barriers between doctors, nurses and physiotherapists," Mr Milburn will say.

webTitle: New money meets old for an assault on races

fields.headline: New money meets old for an assault on races
fields.trailText: Chris Akers, a leading member of the new internet aristocracy, has teamed up with the decidedly "old money" Lord Zetland to launch a bid to acquire Redcar and other northern race courses.
fields.body:
Chris Akers, a leading member of the new internet aristocracy, has teamed up with the decidedly "old money" Lord Zetland to launch a bid to acquire Redcar and other northern race courses.

They want to spend anywhere up to £200m, partly through a stock market listing to turn Redcar from a middle-ranking race course into a recreational centre with theme park, hotels and restaurants.

But they are also keen to acquire some of the other nearby courses, such as York, Catterick and Doncaster. Their new venture, the Seahorse Group, wants to create a racing brand that would exploit the internet and find economies of scale by combining Redcar with other physical racing facilities.

They are aware that future competitors such as Arena Leisure have become hot stocks by successfully combining race course ownership with net-based betting services. Akers made his money through the Sports Internet Group and used to be chairman of Leeds United FC. Zetland is the second largest shareholder in Redcar Racecourse Ltd.

The two men are working with Tarek Kassem, a banking adviser with strong Middle East contacts and Akers's sidekick Rodger Sargent, who is on the board of a number of technology companies.

Seahorse wants to buy and sell Redcar, near Middlesbrough, and then acquire from Zetland a 537- acre site two miles south of the town. Money would be raised by floating Seahorse on the AIM.

Redcar offers 18 race meetings a year between April and November with its most celebrated event being an event for two-year-olds in September with a prize worth up to £160,000. Zetland says running one-off events in this way is common in racing but makes it difficult to make money as staff have got to be hired specially and then released.

He explains: "We want to provide entertainment 365 days a year and make it a day out for all the family in the way Americans organise their baseball games."

The organisers are aware that some people might be sceptical about creating a super racecourse close to a traditional northern town. "But the north of England has always been a centre of racing and road networks are excellent here. Research shows that people will drive two hours - which would take in places such as Liverpool - to have a family day out," says Zetland.

fields.headline: Farewell coal picker, hello DTP
fields.trailText: Thirty-two years after the last steam train was retired by British Rail, the government's number crunchers have finally deleted coal pickers from their list of the jobs people do.
fields.body:
Thirty-two years after the last steam train was retired by British Rail, the government's number crunchers have finally deleted coal pickers from their list of the jobs people do.

In a sign of the changing face of the workplace, the task of tidying up train sidings has been replaced by new jobs such as aerobics instructor, aromatherapist, and call centre operator.

Other jobs that have been officially declared defunct include buttermen ( the porters who unloaded butter from the ships), trouncers (men who travelled on the drays which delivered beer and rolled the barrels into the cellars) and tirrers (the quarry workers who removed topsoil by pick and shovel).

The changes are contained in the 10-yearly update of the standard occupational classifications released yesterday by the office for national statistics.

While some of the jobs removed from the SOC disappeared a long time ago from the workplace, the ONS said it was very careful not to delete jobs too soon, as the information is used to record people's occupations on death certificates.

Another job which has disappeared is described in the old occupational list as a company keeper. The ONS description says company keepers "accompanied and assisted a day wage worker such as a pumpman who worked alone in isolated places in an underground metal working mine".

The new jobs which the ONS has added show the growing importance of information technology. New jobs include desk-top publisher, software architect, and web designer.

Among the new SOC job titles are some humbler jobs, including theme park attendant and kissogram.

And the statisticians have woken up to the fact that Britain no longer has an empire. Colonial service officer has disappeared as a category because the ONS notes, the term was found not to be in current use.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Shops see more sales
Retailers recorded a healthy rise in sales last month, despite rain deterring shoppers in the final week. Sales were up 3.2% in May, according to the British Retail Consortium. Separate figures showed that the service sector as a whole enjoyed its 15th consecutive month of growth in May, although the pace has slackened, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply. Despite evidence from the institute's monthly snapshot that prices in the sector are rising, economists think the Bank of England is unlikely to change borrowing rates at its monthly interest rate meeting which begins today.

Microsoft wins small changes
The US government made some minor amendments to its proposal to break Microsoft into two separate companies yesterday in response to some of the company's objections.

Despite evidence from the institute's monthly snapshot that prices in the sector are rising, economists think the Bank of England is unlikely to change borrowing rates at its monthly interest rate meeting which begins today.

Microsoft wins small changes
The US government made some minor amendments to its proposal to break Microsoft into two separate companies yesterday in response to some of the company's objections.

In its latest filing to the US court overseeing the anti-monopoly case, the US justice department agreed to tinker with the language of its hard-hitting proposals.

However, it rejected all of Microsoft's fundamental objections and made few concessions to a plea for more time to work on a restructuring.

Microsoft has until tomorrow to respond to the filing before Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson rules as early as the end of this week on what remedy should be imposed to counter its anti-competitive abuses.

Textile trade to be helped
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers will today outline plans to assist the textile industry. The industry has complained that the government offered millions of pounds to aid the Rover group last year and a £530m package to help BAE Systems and other companies build a new European super-jumbo plane but nothing for textiles, following the decision by Marks & Spencer to expand its cheaper overseas clothing supply chain at the expense of British producers.

Shell pays for energy charity
Shell yesterday started a charity, backed by £20m, to fund renewable energy and social investment projects around the world. Shell, which already commits around £60m a year to charitable causes, has suffered a series of publicity disasters. The charity initiative is designed to persuade the public that the Brent Spar oil rig debacle, and the dispute with the Ogoni tribe in Nigeria over the management of its oilfields in the region, are part of the company's past.

Virgin joins power race
Virgin is to enter the energy market in an internet-based venture in partnership with London Electricity, it was announced yesterday.
