fields.headline: Honda cuts local sourcing
fields.standfirst: Strong pound forces Swindon car plant to buy continental parts
fields.trailText: Honda yesterday said it planned to slash local sourcing of components for its Swindon car plant in an attempt to offset the impact of the strong pound.
fields.body:
Honda yesterday said it planned to slash local sourcing of components for its Swindon car plant in an attempt to offset the impact of the strong pound.

The news will be a further blow for British suppliers who have already seen companies such as Ford and Rover turn to more competitive component firms in mainland Europe.

The likelihood of further job cuts in the industry will also disappoint government ministers desperate to protect what remains of British car production.

Honda's Swindon plant, which makes the Civic and Ac cord models, already imports about 25% of its components. But this will rise to 35% when the new Civic model starts production later this year and be even higher when new models are introduced.

Minoru Harada, the head of Honda's European operations, said the ideal balance would be a 50-50 split between British and continental European suppliers.

Honda is asking its British suppliers to absorb the extra costs caused by the pound's 15% appreciation against the euro over the past two years. About 100 of the group's 190 European suppliers are based in Britain. Mr Harada said British suppliers were best because of their location but a fluctuating exchange rate against the euro meant many were not competitive. He said Honda would be willing to work with British suppliers to help them reduce costs.

Honda last month blamed exchange rate fluctuations against the yen for the 14% decline in its net profits for the year to March 21 ,2000. But its European operations moved into the red, partly because of the pound-euro rate.

Honda's European chief joins a string of leading manufacturers who have called on the government to join the euro as soon as possible in order to eliminate foreign exchange risks.

Honda is seeking to offset the impact of the strong yen by making more vehicles in plants outside. It announced in April that it was expanding its Swindon plant at a cost of £130m to make its CR-V four wheel drive vehicle. The move is expected to create an extra 1,000 jobs by 2002.

Mr Harada said yesterday that the Swindon plant, which up to now has just made vehicles for the European market, would also export cars to other markets, including the US. Honda is aiming to sell 350,000 cars a year in Europe by 2004, with imports from Japan being reduced.

Mr Harada said a new manufacturing system being installed at Swindon will enable the plant to produce up to seven different models with only minimal investment.

The plant would be able to build 250,000 cars a year by 2004 and any investment to increase capacity further would depend upon "local market demand", he said.

Honda executives were confident that the group's European operations would return to profitability late in 2002. The company is counting on the introduction of its new manufacturing system at its plants around the world to cut annual costs by ¥100bn (£611m) by 2004.

 Rover yesterday said it was cutting the list price of its cars, including the MGF and the Mini, by 10% to reposition itself as a "value brand". The new management team said that previous owners BMW had been wrong to position Rover as a premium marque. The latest price cuts replace special discounts of up to £2,000 on Rover models in April and May.

fields.trailText: Dame Vera sees flotilla home
fields.body:
Dame Vera sees flotilla home

Dame Vera Lynn yesterday led emotional celebrations as a 70-strong flotilla of Little Ships arrived in Ramsgate, Kent, after a cross-channel voyage to mark the 60th anniversary of Dunkirk. Earlier, Dame Vera, 81, was guest of honour at a lunch where she was joined by more than 100 war veterans.

A wife too far for Henry VIII

Henry VIII had seven wives, not six, according to a Lake District guide which invites tourists to visit Kendal Castle - home to his "seventh and final wife" Katherine Parr. A spokesman said: "The document was checked by five to six people so no single person is to blame for the error."

£1 pays for sun protection

Sunglasses costing only £1 may offer as much protection as £89 designer shades as long as they carry the British Standard mark, according to research by Health Which? magazine. It also warned that the darkness of sunglasses is no indication of the protection level.

Streak helmet fetches £2,400

A police helmet used to cover the first streaker in British sport has raised £2,400 for charity at auction. PC Bruce Perry used his helmet after Michael O'Brien ran naked at Twickenham during the 1974 England v France rugby international.

Lib Dem MP to retire

Ronnie Fearn, 68, the Liberal Democrat MP for Southport, is to retire at the next general election. He recaptured the seat at the last election with a 6,160 majority after losing to the Tories in 1992.

fields.headline: BAA in£400m share buyback
fields.trailText: The airports operator BAA revealed yesterday that it has had to initiate an emergency buyback of shares worth £400m to placate shareholders anxious at the sharp decline in profits following the abolition of EU duty-free sales.
fields.body:
The airports operator BAA revealed yesterday that it has had to initiate an emergency buyback of shares worth £400m to placate shareholders anxious at the sharp decline in profits following the abolition of EU duty-free sales.

The abolition has cost the company, which operates seven British airports, £67m. It could be up to 18 months before the full effects of the loss of that business wear off.

Pre-tax profits - after £117m of exceptional charges - fell to £377m from £516m in the year up to the end of March. Sales were £2.19bn against £2bn the year before. The final dividend is 16.35p, an increase of 9% on last year.

The share buyback will be funded from disposals - ranging from retail property in Bond Street to selective stakes in its McArthur Glen joint venture discount stores.

This is the first time BAA has had to initiate a buyback - but analysts received some indication from Mike Hodgkinson, BAA's chief executive, that there could be further returns next year. He said that BAA might sell its underperform ing US duty free arm, World Duty Free America. It is priced at £290m and last November the company wrote off £147m from the business.

Mr Hodgkinson said that BAA would continue trying to improve WDFA before any disposal talks. He made clear that it was not part of BAA's core business - but declared that it was "not a distress sale".

He conceded that the loss of duty free shopping was a setback. It meant that the company was beginning the financial year "with a slightly lower earnings base," although the outlook was good.

Passengers are begining to spend again. When EU duty-free was withdrawn spending per passenger fell from £4.33 to £2.99 . By March the figure had risen again to £3.79.

Mr Hodgkinson said that the company was making progress and promised a return to profit growth next year.

The strong pound and dis count airlines increased passenger numbers to 117.8m against 112.5 m a year earlier. A further increase of 5% is expected next year. BAA's next major project is likely to be at Boston airport, where it is bidding to handle the retailing.

The first full year of the Heathrow Express has been a success. The business earned an operating profit of £4.1m, compared with a loss of £1.8m in 1998-99.

The service was disrupted by the Paddington rail disaster, but still carried 4.4m passengers. This year the number of passengers is expected to exceed 6m.

webTitle: Favourite to succeed Wigley launches bid

fields.headline: Favourite to succeed Wigley launches bid
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Ieuan Wyn Jones, the odds on favourite to succeed Dafydd Wigley as leader of Plaid Cymru, yesterday declared his hand.
fields.body:
Ieuan Wyn Jones, the odds on favourite to succeed Dafydd Wigley as leader of Plaid Cymru, yesterday declared his hand.

At his campaign launch in Cardiff Bay Mr Jones, the MP and Assembly Member for Ynys Mon (Anglesey), said Plaid Cymru, which stunned Labour by capturing the Rhondda and Islwyn in last year's assembly election, must reach out to new supporters in urban and city areas and "build on the support from non-Welsh speakers".

He would be putting forward a "positive programme" outlining how to achieve Plaid's immediate objective of full law making powers for the national assembly while maintaining a belief in eventual "full national status" within the EU. Mr Wigley announced last week that he is to stand down as head of the party on medical grounds after almost a decade as president. Mr Jones, 51, who will relinquish his Westminster seat at the general election, favours splitting the roles of president of the party and assembly leader but is putting his name forward for both so the party as a whole can decide who the leader in the assembly should be.

Two other potential candidates for the leadership, the MEP Jill Evans, and Helen Mary Jones, who chairs the Plaid Cymru group in the assembly, are expected to make their intentions known later this week. Nominations close on June 30 and voting will take place on a one member one vote basis at branch meetings in July.

fields.headline: RSPCA pre-empts hunting inquiry
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The RSPCA will today pre-empt the government's independent inquiry into hunting by saying that the evidence presented to it strengthens the case for a ban.
fields.body:
The RSPCA will today pre-empt the government's independent inquiry into hunting by saying that the evidence presented to it strengthens the case for a ban.

A report published by the charity and commissioned from veterinary experts says the evidence given to the inquiry chaired by Lord Burns shows that the case for a ban is stronger than ever.

The findings are certain to conflict with Lord Burns, who is not expected to recommend a total ban when his report comes out this week.

Bill Swann, the veterinary surgeon who carried out the inquiry for the RSPCA, the League Against Cruel Sports, and the International Fund for Animal Welfare, said: "Our team have now examined all the evidence from both sides of the argument and we believe it gives a green light for a complete ban on hunting with dogs.

"The most compelling evidence is in relation to cruelty. We have independent evidence, commissoned by the inquiry team itself, which shows that foxes suffer multiple severe injuries before being killed by hounds. The level of unnecessary suffering simply cannot be allowed to continue. The case for a ban is stronger than ever."

The key evidence that has swayed the vets is a series of independent postmortems on foxes which show that many are disembowelled before they are killed. All the postmortems showed that foxes died as a result of injuries to the stomach, chest and hindquarters rather than a "quick nip to the neck".

Foxes killed by terriers below ground were also found to have sustained serious injuries before they died. From the evidence on shooting foxes, night shooting appears to be particularly effective. It indicated that a fox receiving a fatal shot wound becomes insensible quickly and does not suffer from being chased by hounds.

It also concluded that flushing out foxes from cover with a gun pack was more effective in upland areas than hunting with dogs.

webTitle: Revealed: how war in Kosovo exposed weaknesses in Britain's armed forces

fields.headline: Revealed: how war in Kosovo exposed weaknesses in Britain's armed forces
fields.standfirst:
MoD failed with resources and hid cost of conflict, says watchdog

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence conceded yesterday that the Kosovo conflict led to "excessive" demands on Britain's armed forces and had exposed the failure of the European allies to mount a sustained military operation without the United States.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence conceded yesterday that the Kosovo conflict led to "excessive" demands on Britain's armed forces and had exposed the failure of the European allies to mount a sustained military operation without the United States.

However, its long-awaited report on lessons learned from the crisis, while praising the "outstanding" role of British forces, avoids many of the most controversial aspects of the bombing campaign and is short on detail compared to a hard-hitting report by the National Audit Office, also released yesterday.

More than half of the missiles carried by the Royal Navy's Harriers were unserviceable within just two months because of heat and vibration problems, and nearly half of the Harriers depended on spares "robbed" from other aircraft, the audit office says.

A quarter of all "precision bombing" missions by British aircraft had to be aborted due to bad weather. And, had the weather been better, there would have been a "real risk" of running out of smart bombs, the watchdog says. There was also a critical shortage of skilled airmen, with the Royal Signals 23% under strength, and too few medical staff and logistics experts.

The army's communications system was so insecure that it was regularly monitored by the Serbs, the Kosovo Liberation Army, and the media. "At times the only functioning communications were civilian bearer systems and the [4th Armoured Brigade] had to compete with others for their use," the audit office says.

During heightened media interest, it could be impossible to get "on the air." By failing to buy readily available commercial, secure radio systems, the army had to rely on "cumbersome paper-based codes", the audit office adds in its report, a draft of which was partially leaked earlier this year.

There was a shortage, too, of portable lavatories, with only one for the use of 50 British soldiers in Kosovo.

David Davis, Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said yesterday that the MoD's failure to manage a £113m contract to provide hard-walled units left British troops in tents through the cold Balkan winter. "And they wasted £228,000 on a hospital project which they approved but then cancelled."

The audit office also chided the MoD for failing to disclose the true, complete cost of the Kosovo conflict. It says that the additional cost to the taxpayer of operations in Kosovo is estimated to total £866m over five years.

In its report, the MoD says the cost of the first year of the operation has been estimated at £342m.

This figure, however, does not include the cost of replacing ammunition or the 12 unmanned reconnaissance drone aircraft that crashed or were shot down.

The MoD points to an authoritative Human Rights Watch report, which estimates that between 488 and 527 Yugoslav civilians were killed during Nato's bombing campaign.

It says that from a total of about 10,500 Nato strike sorties, which unleashed 23,600 bombs, less than 1% of all the missions led to unintended fatalities.

"It is not possible to avoid some collateral damage in any significant armed conflict. This fact is recognised by international law," the MoD says in its report.

However, Amnesty International yesterday accused Nato forces of violating the laws of war. "The April 23, 1999, bombing of the headquarters of Serbian state radio and television, which left 16 civilians dead, was a deliberate attack on a civilian object and as such constitutes a war crime," the organisation said.

The human rights group also pointed to a number of other attacks, including that on the Grdelica railway bridge, of April 12, on the road bridge in Luzane on May 1, and on the Varvarin bridge on May 30, when Nato forces failed to suspend bombing after it was clear that they had struck civilians.

The MoD defends the use of cluster bombs, though it concedes that they have a failure rate officially estimated at 5%. Unexploded cluster bombs, which contain hundreds of small "bomblets", have maimed or killed civilians in Kosovo, and an unknown number of them remain on the ground.

The MoD defends the use of depleted uranium bombs by US aircraft, saying health risks from exposure to them are low. "No satisfactory alternative material exists to achieve the levels of penetration necessary to defeat modern tanks."

It points to Nato estimates of "validated strikes" on 93 tanks, 153 armoured personnel carriers, 389 artillery pieces and mortars, and 339 military vehicles. But MoD officials acknowledged it was impossible to say how many items had actually been destroyed.

Slip-ups and shortages

 More than half of the missiles carried by royal navy Harriers were unserviceable from heat and vibration during take-off and landing.

 Nearly half of the navy's Harriers relied on spares "robbed" from other aircraft.

 A quarter of all "precision bombing" missions by British aircraft had to be aborted due to bad weather.

 Critical shortage of skilled airmen. The Royal Signals were 23% under strength. Also there were too few medical and logistics staff.

 The army's communications system was so insecure it was regularly monitored by the Serbs, the Kosovo Liberation Army, and the media.

 MoD bought 11,000 camp beds, at £24 each, after commanders on the ground said they would be a "key morale raiser". Of these, 2,000 broke, and many soldiers complained they were too short.

 £228,000 was wasted on a hospital project approved but then cancelled.

 Mobile showers and laundry units did not function in Kosovo. And there was a shortage of portable toilets.

 Additional cost to taxpayers of operations in Kosovo is estimated to total £866m over five years.

webTitle: British troops stay on for training

fields.headline: British troops stay on for training
fields.standfirst:
300 soldiers are to be sent to Sierra Leone to pass on skills for an offensive against the rebels that has seen unruly armed militias proliferate

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The British government yesterday sought to play down its commitment to maintain a military presence in Sierra Leone despite its decision to keep troops there longer than it had previously stated.
fields.body:
The British government yesterday sought to play down its commitment to maintain a military presence in Sierra Leone despite its decision to keep troops there longer than it had previously stated.

In response to pleas from the Sierra Leone president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, Britain has agreed to deploy 300 soldiers in the west African country after the withdrawal of 600 marines, who are due to leave at the middle of the month.

The issue was raised in the Commons by the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, who urged the government to deny categorically that any deployment of 300 soldiers of the Royal Anglian regiment to "substitute" for the marines was being considered.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said: "We remain absolutely committed to the timetable of withdrawing the bulk of UK forces by the middle of June. But we have always made clear to the government of Sierra Leone our commitment to training in that country. Ultimately we anticipate that a training team will consist of around 90 people, with the UK providing some half of its total.

"As a means of ensuring that training team gets effectively under way, we are considering deploying a team from the UK for about six weeks from the middle of June. But they will not in any way be substituting for the marines. They will be there to provide training."

UN officials in Freetown said that 10 UN peacekeepers were surrounded in the rebels' main jungle base in eastern Sierra Leone, joining more than 200 colleagues already besieged by rebels.

The 10 Indian peacekeepers were taking part in a resupply mission on Saturday to bring food to some 224 Indian peacekeepers and 10 international observers who have been surrounded by the rebels for nearly one month in Kailahun.

A UN spokesman, David Wimhurst, said fighters at a rebel checkpoint allowed the 10 to enter the town, but did not permit them to leave. Another 50 UN peacekeepers involved in the mission were turned back at the checkpoint and forced to return to Daru, 30 miles to the south-west.

Twenty-three peacekeepers have for weeks been encircled by rebels in nearby Kuiva. The Kuiva and Kailahun groups have been allowed to keep their weapons.

The UN mission is expected to be boosted to 13,000 troops by the end of June. In recent days, Indian blue-helmets have advanced from Freetown to Rogberi Junction, a key crossroads not far from the frontline. UN officials have said the force was prepared for a "more robust response" against the rebels, who trade attacks with pro-government troops in the area.

webTitle: US backs quest for brightest children

fields.headline: US backs quest for brightest children
fields.standfirst:
British scheme to find gifted youngsters with 'world-class' tests supported by Washington as universities gear up to copy aptitude exams

Education Unlimited
Try some of the test questions
fields.trailText: Britain's development of tests to identify the brightest youngsters in the world moved a step forward yesterday after the US government gave the proposal its backing.
fields.body:
Britain's development of tests to identify the brightest youngsters in the world moved a step forward yesterday after the US government gave the proposal its backing.

The tests, devised as part of a Labour programme to locate gifted children in urban areas, are set to be introduced at the start of the 2001 academic year.

Pupils aged nine and 13 will tackle questions in maths and problem-solving which will be pitched at the brightest 15% of children in the world. Teachers and parents will be encouraged to put suitably bright youngsters forward for the tests, which aim to stretch them to their full potential.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, has so far invited the US, Australia and Singapore to become partners in the tests, which are to be piloted shortly in 50 schools in England.

Yesterday the US secretary of state, Richard Riley, had detailed discussions with British ministers and officials about the tests, and a trans-Atlantic collaboration was announced to enable both countries to learn from each others' experiences of turning round failing schools.

Mr Riley said: "I'm very interested in the fact that [the tests] are being done here. As a first step we will have to see if larger urban school districts will want to take part".

In a separate move, outstanding headteachers who have raised standards in British schools will be invited to attend the first bilateral conference on school improvement, which will be held in Washington in October.

Britain has already borrowed many education ideas from the US, most recently plans for so-called city academies which are based on the American charter schools.

But yesterday Mr Riley, who is the longest-serving minister in Bill Clinton's cabinet, made it clear that he already thought there was scope to transfer many British initiatives to US schools in the drive to raise standards, including the numeracy strategy introduced under the Blair government as well as the proposed new "world class tests".

Yesterday Mr Riley visited a north London primary school, where he sat in on a class of 11-year-olds being tested on their mental arithmetic during their daily maths lesson.

Later he expressed his serious concern about the "downward slide" in standards of maths among American youngsters, which had worrying long-term implications for jobs and the economy.

Estelle Morris, the schools minister, yesterday welcomed Mr Riley's interest in British schools and his backing for the world class tests. "We are determined to learn from the experience of other countries as well as our own about the task of raising school standards. This includes raising the performance of schools in challenging circumstances. We want to establish a dialogue and share good practice at school level."

Progress on the world class tests will disappoint those who believe that pupils in Britain are already among the most tested in the world.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers, said: "These tests will quite quickly become mandatory. The tests, devised as part of a Labour programme to locate gifted children in urban areas, are set to be introduced at the start of the 2001 academic year. Pupils aged nine and 13 will tackle questions in maths and problem-solving which will be pitched at the brightest 15% of children in the world. Teachers and parents will be encouraged to put suitably bright youngsters forward for the tests, which aim to stretch them to their full potential. The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, has so far invited the US, Australia and Singapore to become partners in the tests, which are to be piloted shortly in 50 schools in England. fields.headline: Blair's apology to Guildford four
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Twenty-five years after four young people were wrongfully convicted of the Guildford pub bombings in 1974, Tony Blair has become the first person in authority to apologise for the miscarriage of justice.
fields.body:
Twenty-five years after four young people were wrongfully convicted of the Guildford pub bombings in 1974, Tony Blair has become the first person in authority to apologise for the miscarriage of justice.

In a letter to Courtney Kennedy Hill, the American wife of Paul Hill, one of the Guildford four, he said he was "very sorry" they were wrongly imprisoned.

Details of the apology were revealed in a special two-part edition of BBC Northern Ireland's Spotlight programme last night which told Mr Hill's story.

Mr Hill, Gerry Conlon, Patrick Armstrong and Carole Richardson were given life sentences for bombing public houses in Guildford, Surrey. Each spent 15 years in prison before their convictions were overturned by the court of appeal in 1989.

Mr Hill and Mr Armstrong were also wrongfully convicted of a bomb attack in Woolwich, south-east London. A total of seven people died in both bombings.

Gerry Conlon told the Guardian last night that he was delighted with the news but he expressed anger at the belated timing of the apology and the fact that he and his family had never received one.

"We should have had an apology a long time ago, as well as proper compensation," he said. "It's been driving me mad that there has not been an apology so this thing can be put to bed. My mother in particular should have had one. I'm still going through a terrible time, getting dreadful flashbacks.

"My psychiatrist tells me he has never experienced a worst case of post-traumatic stress syndrome, worse even than those soldiers in the Falklands war."

Mrs Hill is the daughter of the assassinated American attorney general, Robert Kennedy, and niece of the murdered president, John F Kennedy.

The programme says the prime minister wrote: "I believe that it is an indictment of our system of justice and a matter for the greatest regret when anyone suffers punishment as a result of a miscarriage of justice.

"There were miscarriages of justice in your husband's case, and the cases of those convicted with him. I am very sorry indeed that this should have happened."

It is understood that Mr Hill, 45, has received £200,000 as interim compensation for the time he spent in prison and is still awaiting a final settlement.

He told the programme: "No one knows the monetary value you can put on 15 years. I don't think there is anybody alive who can come out of that experience and not be scarred.

"Those who would begrudge me my compensation - their minds are smaller than peas. To those who say, 'Oh, he's living well,' you have no idea."

He said he was numbed by his conviction. "I stood in the court. I was numb. I had no feelings whatsoever. I wasn't sad; I was not depressed; I was cold and numb.

"And I think the most poignant thing was that the judge expressed regret that the death penalty was not an option."

fields.headline: Iran defector claims Lockerbie link
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: US and Turkish investigators were questioning an Iranian defector yesterday who told a US television programme that he was a senior intelligence official who had coordinated the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie and a string of other international terrorist attacks.
fields.body:
US and Turkish investigators were questioning an Iranian defector yesterday who told a US television programme that he was a senior intelligence official who had coordinated the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie and a string of other international terrorist attacks.

US intelligence sources confirmed that the defector, Ahmad Behbahani, was an Iranian agent, but said they were not yet convinced he was as senior as he claimed. They said it was possible he was exaggerating his importance in order to negotiate favourable asylum terms in the US.

If Mr Behbahani's claims are confirmed, they could have a dramatic impact on the continuing trial in the Netherlands of two Libyan agents, Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fahima, accused of carrying out the Lockerbie bombing which killed 270 people in 1988.

Mr Behbahani told the CBS investigative programme, 60 minutes, that in his role as head of Iran's state-sponsored terrorist operations abroad, he masterminded the attack as revenge for the accidental downing of an Iranian passenger aircraft by the US warship, Vincennes, five months earlier, at a cost of 290 lives.

He claimed that Ahmed Jibril, a Palestinian militant leader based in Damascus, helped Iranian intelligence to prepare the attack, and that a group of Libyans was given 90 days training at a camp in Iran to help them build the bomb that downed flight 103.

An Iranian-born CBS producer, Roya Hakakian, who slipped into the refugee camp to speak to Mr Behbahani, said: "He was very proud to... mention that the bomb was so very sophisticated that it required this kind of intensive training."

Mr Behbahani also claimed that Iranian intelligence arranged the bombing of the Khobar Towers US barracks in Saudi Arabia in June 1996, and an attack on a Jewish community centre in Buenos Aires in July 1994. He claimed to have been ousted in a power struggle inside Iranian intelligence, and to have escaped from Tehran's Evin prison four months ago. CBS interviewed him at a heavily guarded refugee camp in Turkey. He claimed he had documentary evidence to back up his claims, but he was seized by Turkish security forces before he handed it over.

The Turkish secret service issued a statement yesterday, saying Mr Behbahani had arrived illegally in Turkey on March 7 and had sought asylum in the US. "Behbahani, who was seen as suspicious, has been interviewed by our agency," the statement said. "The person claims that Iran organised some terrorist actions in the past."

US officials yesterday confirmed that Washington had dispatched agents to question Mr Behbahani and assess his claims. And a US intelligence analyst said yesterday: "It's not clear yet that this guy is who he says he is. He is certainly in Iranian intelligence, probably a hitman eliminating dissidents which the Iranians view as an internal matter, but not a coordinator for all terrorism directed at foreign countries.

"It is unlikely he was a coordinator for all terrorist operations. But its quite possible that these people gossip and he would have heard things in the corridors and then filled in the gaps," the analyst said.

Many western intelligence officials have long believed that Iran was the original instigator of the Lockerbie attack. Lawyers for the two Libyan suspects on trial at a special Scottish court at Camp Zeist, have argued that the bombing was carried out by a Palestinian militant, Mohammed Abu Talb, who is in a Swedish prison for an unrelated bomb attack.

In Iran yesterday, a newspaper aligned with Islamic hardliners denounced Mr Behbahani as a member of a anti-government terrorist group, the Mujihadeen Khalq.

fields.headline: No thanks, Camilla
fields.standfirst:
The Queen meets her eldest son's mistress at a barbecue. It is hardly the stuff of true romance

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: One glimpse at the newspapers is enough to tell us that the royal soap is being revived for another season. Most papers made front page news of Camilla Parker Bowles's weekend meeting with the Queen, while the tabloids also devoted several pages to speculation over whether the Prince of Wales will now marry Camilla. For the Sun this casual encounter over a barbecue was "the royal story of the year" and for the Express and Mirror, "a historic meeting". Even the Times led with "Camilla and Carey hold secret talks", making it as significant as negotiations to scrap the nuclear arsenal.
fields.body:
One glimpse at the newspapers is enough to tell us that the royal soap is being revived for another season. Most papers made front page news of Camilla Parker Bowles's weekend meeting with the Queen, while the tabloids also devoted several pages to speculation over whether the Prince of Wales will now marry Camilla. For the Sun this casual encounter over a barbecue was "the royal story of the year" and for the Express and Mirror, "a historic meeting". Even the Times led with "Camilla and Carey hold secret talks", making it as significant as negotiations to scrap the nuclear arsenal.

The portentousness of the language stands as a warning. The media is threatening an orgy of speculation, both personal and constitutional. There will be plenty of opportunities this summer. Will Camilla go for her holiday at Balmoral, as some papers are claiming? Will she accept the invitation to watch the parade of old nags and camels for the Queen Mother's 100th birthday? And what will these decisions tell us about the likelihood of her marrying Charles, becoming queen or winning public acceptance? The Sun and the Mirror's telephone lines are already open, voting on these issues.

This blanket coverage is not just tedious. It's maddening. Since Princess Diana's death, royal coverage has been relatively muted. Uncertainty about just how far public distaste for the whole royal family had gone has kept this stuff off the front page. Now the signs are the press is heading back - no holds barred - to royal fantasy land. Typically, the Express commemorated the weekend's historic barbecue with an outbreak of prose worthy of the late Barbara Cartland: "For a few moments they stood face to face smiling awkwardly, not knowing quite what to say. For a second or two, there was a silence. Camilla, for so long not even recognised by the royal family, curtseyed deeply out of respect for her sovereign."

It is not just the style of this language that belongs to fiction. So does the content. None of us know what the Queen or Camilla were actually thinking during this encounter, or whether Charles is in fact an incorrigible philanderer settling with Camilla as the least publicly damaging option available. But it is not difficult to recognise the cliche now being promoted: a true and honourable, if thwarted, love affair. This is the culmination of the "28-year, on-off romance" (the Sun). The prince who "wanted above anything else recognition from the Queen for Mrs Parker Bowles", is now "relaxed and happy" (the Mirror), "delighted and grateful" (the Sun) or "very happy and very relaxed" (the Times).

This is the same story promoted by Charles's aides, so it is tempting to imagine a coincidence of interest between the tabloids and the palace. When the papers ask if the public is now ready to accept Camilla, do they really mean: is the public ready to stomach a return to previous levels of interest in the royals? They must hope the answer is yes, since nothing sold papers like Diana's personal life.

They may be seriously disappointed however.

Forelock-tugging accounts of royal life are tricky at the best of times, with their details of endless royal holidays, sumptuous banquets (this time "barbecued steaks, lobster and king prawns prepared by Anton Mossiman"), and their party lists of double-barrelled toffs.

They are especially incongruous at the moment beside the full-blooded discussion of elitism currently raging in all papers. Besides, there may be a miscalculation about "public acceptance". Many people accept Charles's relationship with Camilla as inevitable, but have totally lost their appetite for royal gossip. Diana's fate left many feeling they had colluded in a judgmental voyeurism about her life that was somehow implicated in her death.

Nor has the charm offensive changed the impression of Charles which many formed at the time of Diana's death. Most think he is a bungler who should have married Camilla in the first place and spared everyone the grief. Having created such havoc, he should repair the damage now by retiring. He could become a gentleman farmer, live off the proceeds of his "royal" biscuits and do whatever he wishes with Camilla in the flowerbeds of Highgrove without any public attention at all.

Getting Versace to dress Camilla won't turn her into Diana; the terms silk purse and sow's ear come to mind. Nor will Charles's cranky preoccupations with his bowels and his tweedy life ever enthral us as Diana's hospital visits and dresses did. Icons require a degree of charisma and a life which resonates with a wider public.

It is hard to imagine Camilla's life ever resonating with anyone outside the hunting set. Editors might be rubbing their hands with glee at the prospect of the next episodes in the royal soap - family reconciliation, engagement, marriage - but the tedious saga of this odd couple is more likely to be a total ratings disaster.

webTitle: Boarding schools no longer 'preserve of the elite'

fields.headline: Boarding schools no longer 'preserve of the elite'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A survey released by boarding schools today purports to show they are no longer the "playground of the elite ruling class".
fields.body:
A survey released by boarding schools today purports to show they are no longer the "playground of the elite ruling class".

Of those pupils surveyed, about 30% were first generation boarders. Twenty-eight per cent came from households earning less that £50,000 a year, although 37% were from those earning more than £100,000.

"The type of families who are choosing the boarding option and the reason they are choosing it are changing.

webTitle: Ex-IRA man to be mayor of Derry

fields.headline: Ex-IRA man to be mayor of Derry
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A former IRA prisoner was last night poised to be elected mayor of Londonderry, the only republican to become first citizen of any Irish city since partition of the island almost 80 years ago.
fields.body:
A former IRA prisoner was last night poised to be elected mayor of Londonderry, the only republican to become first citizen of any Irish city since partition of the island almost 80 years ago.

Cathal Crumley, 41, one of the first IRA men to turn to politics with Sinn Fein, was expected to win with the support of the nationalist SDLP. He was promising to serve all sections, but unionists said his election would damage community relations.

His anticipated victory eased Sinn Fein's disappointment last week when it narrowly lost out on the top post in Belfast to the Democratic Unionist party.

There has never before been a Sinn Fein mayor in Northern Ireland, and Mr Crumley is the first republican mayor of any Irish city since Terence MacSwiney in Cork in 1920. He died at Brixton prison after 74 days on hunger-strike.

Mr Crumley said yesterday: "Change is coming and people have to embrace that change. But I want to extend the hand of friendship to the Protestant and unionist community in this city."

Mr Crumley was jailed in 1976 and served four years for IRA membership. He was re-arrested in 1982 on the evidence of IRA supergrasses. After two years on remand, he was convicted on charges including conspiracy to murder. He was given nine life sentences, but the convictions were overturned at the court of appeal in 1986.

Sinn Fein first won a council seat in Derry in 1985. It now has eight councillors. The SDLP, the largest party with 14 seats, said it was fulfilling a pledge it made to Sinn Fein to back a republican mayor if the IRA ceasefire held.

Gregory Campbell, a Democratic Unionist councillor and an assembly member, said: "Community relations are already poor, but this will make them plumb the depths."

webTitle: Help brides forced to wed, study urges

fields.headline: Help brides forced to wed, study urges
fields.standfirst: Practice should be treated 'like rape and child abuse'
fields.trailText: Every police force in Britain should have to put in place new emergency procedures to help women who report being forced into marriage by their parents, according to a report to be published this month.
fields.body:
Every police force in Britain should have to put in place new emergency procedures to help women who report being forced into marriage by their parents, according to a report to be published this month.

The study, the first national examination of the practice said to involve at least 1,000 British Asian women a year, will argue that forced marriage should be put on the same footing as domestic violence and child abuse, stressing that it contravenes women's human rights.

However, it will not propose changes in the law, concluding that existing offences such as kidnap, rape and assault are sufficient to curb the practice, provided that police are more aware of its nature.

The working party on the issue, chaired by two Labour peers, will recommend a "trigger mechanism" for police forces, so that complaints from young people who fear their family is trying to compel them to marry against their will, often in ceremonies abroad, will automatically bring help from social services, the victim's school or college and, where necessary, consular services overseas.

At present, according to one working party source, police treatment of the issue, which mainly affects women whose families come from Pakistan, Bangladesh and India, but also others from some African and Middle Eastern countries, is "very scant and inconsistent".

The Metropolitan police has established a working group in its racial and violent crime task force, but is now considering creating a separate reporting category for forced marriages to understand the extent of the problem better.

The report will also call revision of the procedure for issuing visas for entry to Britain, amid government concern that the vast majority of forced marriage victims end up sponsoring applications for their spouses to settle in the UK.

It will propose that the problem of young people being too scared to make formal complaints about such coercion should be addressed. Ministers are concerned that many victims tell entry clearance officers that they have been forced into marriage, with some threatening to kill themselves if the visa is granted, but are unwilling to put anything in writing.

The government announced this year that teachers are to be encouraged to go direct to police or social services if they suspect that a female pupil is being forced into marriage - a move endorsed by the report.

Teenage magazines, TV soap operas and pop radio stations are urged to carry stories that show Asian girls that a forced marriage is wrong and that they have a right to resist it.

The working party, chaired by the Asian peers Baroness Uddin and Lord Ahmed, was set up eight months ago following a high court ruling that parents who took their daughters abroad to marry against their will were guilty of child abduction.

It also followed the conviction of a mother and brother for murdering a young Muslim woman who became pregnant from an affair while the man she had been forced to marry was abroad.

Ann Cryer, Labour MP for Keighley, raised concerns with home office ministers after Asian women in her West Yorkshire constituency privately called on her to act.

Working party members are divided over how far the solution can be left to ethnic minority communities to resolve.

Baronness Uddin warned against alienating community leaders, saying: "We have got to carry the communities with us, or the whole problem will simply go underground."

But Pragna Patel, of the women's pressure group Southall Black Sisters, said community leaders did not necessarily represent the concerns of women and children. "Enough is enough - we look to the state to uphold women's rights."

webTitle: Chernobyl to close 14 years after disaster

fields.headline: Chernobyl to close 14 years after disaster
fields.standfirst:
US pledges aid to clean up scene of world's worst nuclear accident

The president's trip to Europe
fields.trailText: Ukraine pledged yesterday that the stricken Chernobyl nuclear power station, where the world's worst nuclear disaster erupted 14 years ago, would be closed down forever by the end of the year.
fields.body:
Ukraine pledged yesterday that the stricken Chernobyl nuclear power station, where the world's worst nuclear disaster erupted 14 years ago, would be closed down forever by the end of the year.

The announcement by President Leonid Kuchma in Kiev in the presence of Bill Clinton crowned the US president's week-long valedictory tour of Europe and concluded seven years of wrangling over the fate of the power station, which spewed clouds of radioactive debris across Europe when its fourth reactor exploded in April 1986.

"We will switch Chernobyl off permanently by December 15 this year," said Mr Kuchma after the two presidents had toasted the decision with champagne.

Mr Clinton said Washington would provide $80m (£50m) to Ukraine to help with the effort to render the disaster site safe and for investment in the moribund Ukrainian energy industry.

Most of the money will be spent on repairing or renewing the creaking concrete and steel "sarcophagus" which has entombed the stricken reactor since the disaster.

Describing the Ukrainian decision as "a historic announcement", Mr Clinton said: "The final reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant will be shut down and the entire plant closed on December 15. This is a hopeful moment. It is also a moment when we remember those who suffered as a result of the accident there."

An epidemic of thyroid cancer among thousands of children in Ukraine and in neighbouring Belarus is currently one of the most troubling legacies of the nuclear explosion.

Greenpeace said the announcement was long overdue. "Fourteen years after the worst nuclear catastrophe in history, the Chernobyl timebomb is finally being defused," said a spokesman.

Of the four reactors at Chernobyl, one - unit three - is still operational and has been generating electricity this year. Unit one was closed down many years ago and unit two after a fire two years ago.

Ukraine is immersed in a deep energy crisis, with power cuts a daily routine. However, the country's economy is contracting and Chernobyl is no longer seen as vital to its energy needs. As long ago as 1995, Kiev promised to close down the stricken station within five years if the west provided credits to finance alternative energy sources.

The G7 group of industrialised countries agreed to fund the closure and the western pro-nuclear lobby argued for funds to complete two mothballed Soviet-era nuclear power plants, at Rivne and Khmelnitsky.

But these plans ran into trouble, not least in Germany where the anti-nuclear Greens form part of the coalition government. Berlin is under pressure to boycott the nuclear funding scheme in favour of developing gas-fired stations in Ukraine.

In 1993 the Ukrainian parliament voted to keep the Chernobyl plant operating, triggering western protests and ultimately the G7 response.

But despite the Ukrainian closure pledge, Kiev repeatedly backtracked on its commitment, complaining that the west was reneging on its end of the bargain.

Earlier this year, Mr Kuchma backed a national commission ruling that Chernobyl should be closed this year and on the eve of Mr Clinton's arrival on Sunday he said that Chernobyl "has to be stopped from all points of view, above all from the point of view of safety".

He added, however, that Ukraine could not afford to deal with the problem alone. The cost of completing the two replacement nuclear power stations is estimated at around £800,000.

The favoured option was to complete the two nuclear plants at Rivne and Khmelnitsky but the EU governments' European bank of reconstruction and development fell out over the details. The stations have been lying incomplete since the end of the communist era. The bank was supposed to plump for the "least cost option" but figures making nuclear energy appear the cheapest were doctored, critics alleged.

On May 23, this year Germany, Sweden and Austria said the EU could only finance the building of non-nuclear stations in Ukraine.

No decision on replacing the remaining operational Chernobyl reactor, which is plagued with technical problems, has yet been reached. The question of how to replace it for when Ukraine's economy eventually expands again has yet to be resolved.

fields.headline: Blunkett tightens benefit rules
fields.trailText: Partners of unemployed claimants receiving the jobseeker's allowance are to be forced to sign on under the government's latest plans to get them into employment.
fields.body:
Partners of unemployed claimants receiving the jobseeker's allowance are to be forced to sign on under the government's latest plans to get them into employment.

Husbands, wives, boyfriends and girlfriends entitled to JSA support as a dependent will be requested to visit their local jobcentre every fortnight.

The move will be unveiled tomorrow by David Blunkett as the latest step in his drive to create a "new welfare state" requiring claimants to seek work in return for benefits.

The education and employment secretary will also outline proposals to make it easier for JSA claimants to take temporary jobs lasting up to 12 weeks.

Benefits will be suspended rather than ended, enabling claimants to take a temporary post without having to fill in more forms when it is over. Nearly 30,000 dependents a year will need to sign on under the new rules and will be channelled into interviews, training and the New Deal pro gramme. Officials in Mr Blunkett's department said it was "illogical" that dependents were financially backed without seeking work during the 12 months an out-of-work breadwinner is entitled to the JSA.

Mr Blunkett is to tell an Institute for Public Policy Research seminar that he and the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, are considering further changes.

"We want to make sure JSA is truly an allowance for jobseekers, not a punishment for job losers," Mr Blunkett is expected to say.

Grants of up to £100 to help tide over those who find work between the end of benefits and their first pay packet will be introduced in April next year.

The signing on reforms could be extended to people on income support if they prove successful.

Unemployment is at a 20-year low of 1.1m under the claimant count but ministers believe it could be even lower if the 360,000 jobcentre vacancies - a third of those in the economy - are filled.

webTitle: Carla's goat rewrites farmyard history by giving birth to 'lamb'

fields.headline: Carla's goat rewrites farmyard history by giving birth to 'lamb'
fields.standfirst: TV writer Carla Lane yesterday gave the world an animal tale which, if true, will ignite a scientific sensation; a goat on her sanctuary has given birth to a lamb.
fields.trailText: TV writer Carla Lane yesterday gave the world an animal tale which, if true, will ignite a scientific sensation; a goat on her sanctuary has given birth to a lamb
fields.body:
TV writer Carla Lane yesterday gave the world an animal tale which, if true, will ignite a scientific sensation; a goat on her sanctuary has given birth to a lamb.

Molly, an 18-year-old nanny goat, became the proud mother of Cilla three weeks ago, Ms Lane said.

It happened after Molly was kept in a paddock on the animal campaigner's West Sussex sanctuary, where rams were the only virile male company. Ms Lane, 61, writer of The Liver Birds and Bread, said: "We were dumbfounded. We looked to see if there was anything about it that was a goat, but it is a lamb. It has got the waggly tail, the tight curly coat, the little lamb's face, and the lamb's bleat. The vet came to see her and just shook his head and said: 'That is a lamb'."

Ms Lane added: "We suspect our Sussex ram because he is a big, tough guy."

Expert opinion yesterday suggested that a goat-sheep hybrid was unheard of, but not beyond the bounds of possibility. David Noakes, professor of veterinary obstetrics at London University, said: "It is well known that if you cross goats and sheep you will get fertilisation and the development of an embryo, but invariably the embryo does not survive."

Agnes Winter, of Liverpool University veterinary school, said it was "physiologically impossible" for a goat to give birth to a lamb.

webTitle: Chirac urges five-year term for president

fields.headline: Chirac urges five-year term for president
fields.standfirst:
A constitutional change could end 'cohabitation'

The French Constitution
fields.trailText: Launching France's biggest constitutional reform for four decades, President Jacques Chirac was due yesterday to propose cutting the seven-year presidential term to five years - a move that not only avoids future power-sharing between right and left, but also improves his chances of winning the next election.
fields.body:
Launching France's biggest constitutional reform for four decades, President Jacques Chirac was due yesterday to propose cutting the seven-year presidential term to five years - a move that not only avoids future power-sharing between right and left, but also improves his chances of winning the next election.

In an interview with the two biggest television stations, to be broadcast last night, Mr Chirac was expected to back down from his longstanding opposition to a shorter presidential term and announce an amendment to the constitution that could be put to a referendum as early as October and implemented in 2002.

The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has long favoured the idea of bringing the presidential and parliamentary terms into line, believing that this would increase the chances of one political grouping - left or right - holding sway in both the parliament and the president's Elysée palace.

Three times in the last 14 years, including since Mr Chirac's disastrous early election call in 1997, the prime minister and the president have come from opposing sides of the political spectrum, an uncomfortable situation, known as "cohabitation", that many French politicians feel weakens the effectiveness of the government.

The Gaullist Mr Chirac, a supporter of the strong but relatively hands-off "imperial presidency" envisaged by de Gaulle when he laid the foundations of the Fifth Republic in 1958, said a year ago that a five-year term would be "a mistake", which he would never support.

He has now plainly changed his mind - partly because Mr Jospin has said that if necessary he would bypass the president and use parliament to launch the reform himself, and partly because the president, who is 67, realises that he stands a better chance of being re-elected for five years rather than seven in the next election in 2002.

Both men were stung into action by a former rightwing president, Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, who last month announced that he would put the reform before parliament if no one else did. Opinion polls have shown that nearly 75% of French voters approve of the plan.

While the move is almost certain to obtain the two-thirds majority it needs in both houses of parliament before being put to the public vote, it by no means enjoys the full support of all politicians.

Some on the left fear that it will increase the power of the president, who at present has very little influence on domestic policy unless he belongs to the prime minister's party. Many on the right, however, fear that it will reduce the head of state to a ceremonial figurehead.

"In proposing a five-year term, we are turning our backs on the foundation of the Fifth Republic and we are betraying de Gaulle," said Jacques Baumel, a deputy from Mr Chirac's RPR party. Charles Pasqua, a former Gaullist interior minister who has set up a breakaway rightwing party, said he would "do everything in his power" to block the amendment.

The innocuous looking amendment to article six of the constitution - in future it will read: "The president of the republic is elected by universal suffrage for a term of five years" - also hides a furious debate over the consequences for French politics.

"Either we're heading for a Sixth Republic without saying it, or we're moving towards a spectacular but vain patch-up job," commented the left-leaning Libération. "The constitution has many failings. This is a minimalist reform that changes as little as possible so that, as usual, nothing really changes."

Many constitutionalists refused even to speculate on what the future might hold. But one, Stephane Baumont of Toulouse University, said it would "lead to a complete change of regime. We will be in a Sixth Republic, a presidential regime resembling the American system".

Mr Baumont said he was not sure that a five-year term would avoid future "cohabitations", arguing that having discovered power-sharing, the French public rather liked the idea of balancing the power of the president against that of parliament.

In an interview with the two biggest television stations, to be broadcast last night, Mr Chirac was expected to back down from his longstanding opposition to a shorter presidential term and announce an amendment to the constitution that could be put to a referendum as early as October and implemented in 2002. The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has long favoured the idea of bringing the presidential and parliamentary terms into line, believing that this would increase the chances of one political grouping - left or right - holding sway in both the parliament and the president's Elysée palace. He has now plainly changed his mind - partly because Mr Jospin has said that if necessary he would bypass the president and use parliament to launch the reform himself, and partly because the president, who is 67, realises that he stands a better chance of being re-elected for five years rather than seven in the next election in 2002. Both men were stung into action by a former rightwing president, Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, who last month announced that he would put the reform before parliament if no one else did. Charles Pasqua, a former Gaullist interior minister who has set up a breakaway rightwing party, said he would "do everything in his power" to block the amendment. "Either we're heading for a Sixth Republic without saying it, or we're moving towards a spectacular but vain patch-up job," commented the left-leaning Libération. "The constitution has many failings. webTitle: Kidnappers free UN captives in Georgia

fields.headline: Kidnappers free UN captives in Georgia
fields.trailText: Kidnappers who had been holding four hostages, including two United Nations observers, in a remote gorge in Georgia released them yesterday without any conditions, a Georgian official said.
fields.body:
Kidnappers who had been holding four hostages, including two United Nations observers, in a remote gorge in Georgia released them yesterday without any conditions, a Georgian official said.

The four, who were seized last Thursday in the former Soviet satellite, included two Danish UN officers, a Briton who works for the Halo Trust landmine-clearance charity and a local aide. Their names were not disclosed. Another local aide, Ismet Zade, was freed last Saturday.

"No ransom was paid. There was no deal involved here. There were negotiations and the hostages were freed without any ransom," said Kakha Imnadze, a spokesman for Georgia's president, Eduard Shevardnadze.

He told the Russian NTV television channel that he had no explanation for the motives of the kidnappers.

Mr Zade said the abductors were wearing masks and carrying pistols and sub-machine guns. They had swooped down on the UN group when it ventured beyond a military checkpoint to mark out a minefield.

"They fired several rounds into the air and then herded us [away]," he said of the ambush in the remote Kodori valley, in the conflict zone between Georgia and separatist Abkhazia. Abkhazia province has been outside government control since 1993, but has no international recognition.

The UN monitors a truce between Georgian and Abkhazian forces agreed after a war that killed 10,000 people in 1992-93. The Kodori valley lies within the administrative borders of Abkhazia but is populated by ethnic Georgians.

fields.headline: Wagner war earns an encore
fields.trailText: A meeting to decide the long-term future of Germany's renowned Bayreuth music festival was aborted yesterday as a vitriolic slanging match between members of the composer Richard Wagner's family reached new heights.
fields.body:
A meeting to decide the long-term future of Germany's renowned Bayreuth music festival was aborted yesterday as a vitriolic slanging match between members of the composer Richard Wagner's family reached new heights.

The meeting, in Bayreuth, to elect a new festival director ended without result after an announcement by the event's current supremo, Wolfgang Wagner, 80, that he would refuse to step down unless the job was given to his wife.

Wolfgang, the grandson of the controversial composer, has run the festival for nearly half a century. He said he would veto any decision by the event's 24-member governing committee that did not lead to his 56-year-old second wife, Gudrun, succeeding him as director.

"If the committee opts for my daughter Eva or my niece Nike then I will simply invoke my powers of veto and sit the matter out like Helmut Kohl," he said in a reference to the former German chancellor's reputation for riding difficult situations.

The festival committee said in a statement after the two and a half hour meeting that it would attempt to clarify the question of Wolfgang's successor later this year. "Negotiations over a leadership change will continue," it said.

The committee's failure to elect a new leader means that Wolfgang could carry on indefinitely - his contract is for life and can only be terminated with his consent.

Such a development would disappoint the German and Bavarian governments, which help fund the event. They have been pressing for change.

His statement left the committee in an embarrassing predicament: last month it declared that its preferred candidate was Wolfgang's 55-year-old daughter by his first marriage, Eva Wagner-Pasquier.

But the choice infuriated Mr Wagner, who retaliated with his veto announcement - thus intensifying a dynastic feud that has dogged the Bayreuth festival for more than 35 years, drawing comparisons with a TV soap opera script.

The three members of the clan battling to take over are Wolfgang's wife Gudrun, his daughter by his first marriage, Eva Wagner-Pasquier, and his rebellious niece, Nike Wagner, who once claimed that her uncle was guilty of suppressing the Wagner family's notorious links with the Nazis.

Last week Nike, an established music critic, committed further sacrilege by calling for a complete revamp of the annual festival that currently has a seven-year waiting list for its 50,000 tickets and rates as one of the most prestigious musical events among the German cultural elite.

In an article in the Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper, she charged that her uncle's work showed signs of "ageing" and called for the commissioning of new works that could be included in the festival's repertoire.

"The festival risks becoming repetitive. It is always resorting to its old-fashioned roots," she wrote.

But her uncle angrily dismissed her calls as "contrary to the Bayreuth festival idea". "Apart from that they are both unrealistic and unrealisable," he said, adding that he was being subjected to "mobbing" over the directorship question.

Wolfgang's insistence on his wife Gudrun becoming his successor is seen as an attempt to help her realise her ambition to take over the festival with her 22-year-old daughter Katharina.

Inside the clan, Gudrun is suspected of taking sides against Ms Wagner-Pasquier because she is Wolfgang's daughter from a previous marriage. Yet on paper she is the most eligible candidate, having worked as a consultant at Covent Garden, the Houston opera house and the Bastille opera in Paris.

But her father has written off her candidacy: "In all these jobs she was hardly an independent decision-maker," he said.

Wolfgang's son Gottfried is theoretically direct in line to succeed his father, but he disgraced himself years ago by publishing details of Richard Wagner's anti-semitism and the admiration of Wolfgang's mother Winfried for the Nazis.

He claimed that his father once told him that the Nazi extermination of the Jews was Hitler's "only mistake". Since then father and son have refused to speak to each other.

Gudrun insisted yesterday that there was no hurry to choose a new festival director. Her husband's reluctance to give up the job is, after all, in keeping with Wagner family tradition. Cosima Wagner, the composer's widow who fostered the Wagner cult, worked until her death aged 93.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: An article headed Portuguese hero to face terrorism charges, December 13 1999, may have confused some readers. The term "justice ministry" did not refer to the Minister of Justice in Portugal. The Ministério Público has judicial functions and "justice ministry" seemed an appropriate translation. We wish to make it clear that there was no interference in the trial of Otelo by the Minister of Justice and apologise if the article caused any misunderstanding.
fields.body:
An article headed Portuguese hero to face terrorism charges, December 13 1999, may have confused some readers. The term "justice ministry" did not refer to the Minister of Justice in Portugal. The Ministério Público has judicial functions and "justice ministry" seemed an appropriate translation. We wish to make it clear that there was no interference in the trial of Otelo by the Minister of Justice and apologise if the article caused any misunderstanding.

In a piece headed The scent of the maggot, page S3 Science, June 1, we said that in the 1660s a Dutch scientist tried to figure out how maggots, with no discernible nose, managed to smell, adding - prophetically - "His perception is still thought to be astounding more than 400 years later."

The bee in a picture on page 3, May 17, illustrating an article headed: Beekeepers seek GM halt after honey contaminated, was not a honeybee.

The Brueghel family of painters spelt their name like that and not Breughel as it appeared all the way through our review of the paperback edition of Michael Frayn's book, Headlong, page 11, Saturday Review, June 3.

We have slipped again with the American expression shoo-in, this time, appropriately perhaps, in a column called The Loafer, page 8, Saturday Review, June 3, where we asked, "Is Zadie 'White Teeth' Smith the shoe-in for the Orange Prize..." Collins definition: "Shoo-in, a person or thing that is certain to win or succeed." It has nothing to do with feet or feet in doors.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Mind the elitism gap
fields.trailText: Raymond Plant (Letters, June 5) identifies the nub of the Oxbridge problem: too many applicants for too few places. Well-qualified young people apply preferentially to Oxford and Cambridge because those universities are much better resourced than others in the UK.
fields.body:
Raymond Plant (Letters, June 5) identifies the nub of the Oxbridge problem: too many applicants for too few places. Well-qualified young people apply preferentially to Oxford and Cambridge because those universities are much better resourced than others in the UK.

Gordon Brown and Tony Blair have recently widened this gap by their arbitrary decisions in two cases which illustrate the general problem.

In November last year, Gordon Brown awarded £68m to fund a Cambridge-MIT collaborative venture. In anybody's language this is a vast amount of money, yet the process under which it was awarded was not open to any form of competitive bidding or scrutiny. Earlier this year, Tony Blair over-ruled his trade secretary to force the new £550m Diamond synchrotron to be situated on Oxford's doorstep near Abingdon. This was done in spite of the fact that the existing UK synchrotron lab, at Daresbury near Warrington, in partnership with the northern universities, virtually invented the synchrotron radiation studies.

Both cases show that Messrs Brown and Blair, far from extending equality of opportunity, are plundering the public purse to further entrench elitism. Is it any wonder that some of our brightest sixth-formers choose to go to the US to study, rather than accept offers to study at non-Oxbridge universities here ?
Prof Hugh McCann
University of Manchester Institute of Technology
h.mccann@umist.ac.uk

webTitle: Putting our railways back on our rails

fields.headline: Putting our railways back on our rails
fields.trailText: In his transport manifesto (Charting a course to a greener future, June 5), Keith Harper says Labour "should commit itself to considering renationalisation of Railtrack if it fails to provide sufficient investment and relies increasingly on the government to prop it up".
fields.body:
In his transport manifesto (Charting a course to a greener future, June 5), Keith Harper says Labour "should commit itself to considering renationalisation of Railtrack if it fails to provide sufficient investment and relies increasingly on the government to prop it up".

In reality there is no hope of the necessary upgrading without substantial input of publicly backed investment. But there is a practical course that would have widespread support. All public money that is put into our railways should be treated as publicly owned equity in Railtrack. Thus government, on behalf of taxpayers, would in due course become a major shareholder.
Dick Drew
Bristol
dickdrew@aol.com

 Reintegrating the rail network within the public sector would not only be the popular and responsible thing to do, it is also eminently "do-able". There are many ways in which it could be done at no significant cost to the Treasury. For example, when the franchises to operate passenger services come to an end they automatically return to the public sector unless the government chooses to extend contracts.

The public never wanted the railways split up and sold off. After Paddington they are even more convinced that this key public service should be back where it belongs. Now all we need is some politicians with the courage of their pre-election convictions to accept the "settled will" of the public and bring the railways home.
Jonathan Bray
Save our Railways

 How can Keith Harper mention Labour's transport manifesto and not use the words "pedestrian", "cyclist", "school", "HomeZone"?

The "big is beautiful" approach failed in the past and will fail again, simply creating longer journeys at greater cost. A quarter of all car trips are under two miles. We need investment to make non-motorised trips to shops, schools and stations as safe and attractive as possible. This would also be child-friendly and address coal exclusion issues.

According to the last National Travel Survey, the average person makes more journeys by bicycle each year than by rail and London Underground combined. Let us see some real money spent on getting us back on our bikes.
Don Mathew
Lowestoft, Suffolk

fields.headline: On the box
fields.trailText: The article on the ITC's consultation on public service broadcasting (More Matthew, less Melvyn for ITV as public service role is questioned, June 1) presented a somewhat distorted version of the ITC's own position
fields.body:
The article on the ITC's consultation on public service broadcasting (More Matthew, less Melvyn for ITV as public service role is questioned, June 1) presented a somewhat distorted version of the ITC's own position.

The ITC is four square behind public service broadcasting and believes it should not only exist in the commercial marketplace before the total analogue-digital transition, but probably for a good time afterwards as well.

We would welcome views from all parties on the consultation paper, which can be accessed at www.itc.org.uk. Copies are also available from the ITC, 33 Foley Street, London W1P 7LB.
Richard Peel
Independent Television Commission

fields.headline: Decorative effects
fields.trailText: In your front page photograph (June 5) of Prince Charles at Dunkirk, a megaphone obscures most of his face but not his chest. He seems to have as many medals as the celebrated veterans. Where did he win them all?
fields.body:
In your front page photograph (June 5) of Prince Charles at Dunkirk, a megaphone obscures most of his face but not his chest. He seems to have as many medals as the celebrated veterans. Where did he win them all?
Brian P Moss
Tamworth, Staffs
BrianMoss@NorthWarks. gov.uk

 Presumably once he'd finished inspecting the Dunkirk fleet with his megaphone, the Prince of Wales then addressed them all through his binoculars? Clever chaps, these Windsors!
Richard Ellam
Edinburgh
richard.ellam@virgin.net

 The claim by an anonymous royal source (Time was right for Queen to meet Camilla, says palace, June 5) that on Prince Charles's recent tour of Scotland "the general assembly of the Church of Scotland was welcoming to the fact that the Prince of Wales was there with Mrs Parker Bowles" is grossly misleading. Mrs Parker Bowles was not at the general assembly, and as a member of that body I can testify that it made no reference whatsoever to her presence in Edinburgh with the Prince.
Hugh Davidson
Edinburgh

 That we get men of the experience of Simon Hoggart (June 3) and Francis Wheen (May 31) complaining about the removal of Andy Kershaw from Radio 1 seems to be vindication enough for the decision. Let's face it, they're hardly the target audience.
Mark Taylor
London
markt@ops.nsf.org.uk

 I note your report (In brief, June 5) of a successor to Titanic being built. You do not report how many lifeboats it will have, or how high the watertight bulkheads will go. According to the films I've seen, the iceberg always wins.
Rev Tony Bell
Chesterfield
tonybell@glapwell.f9.co.uk

As usual, politically correct rhetoric defies logic.

To Balkanise is defined as the splitting up of a region by outside powers into a maze of statelets - precisely what the west has been doing in the former Yugoslavia since 1991. As usual, politically correct rhetoric defies logic. Misha Simic Bedford

fields.headline: Keir Hardie, Tony and me
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley (Endpiece, June 5) charges me with an excess of loyalty for saying that "the values that motivated Keir Hardie are the same ones that motivate Tony Blair". The problem comes if we confuse values such as social justice with policies such as "common ownership of land and capital".
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley (Endpiece, June 5) charges me with an excess of loyalty for saying that "the values that motivated Keir Hardie are the same ones that motivate Tony Blair". The problem comes if we confuse values such as social justice with policies such as "common ownership of land and capital". When Labour's pioneers demanded "common ownership", it was not an end in itself. It was to achieve a fairer society and a more productive economy.

In 1988, Roy and Neil Kinnock explained in Democratic Socialist Aims and Values that Labour's true aim was not public ownership but a society of "real freedom with real choices and real chances". When our new Clause Four talks about "power, wealth and opportunity in the hands of the many not the few", we are true to the same values Labour's pioneers espoused. What we are doing is to put those traditional values in a modern setting.

Keir Hardie and Labour's founders demanded work for all, equal access to education, child maintenance, and better health care - economic prosperity combined with social justice. These were taken forward by the Attlee, Wilson and Callaghan governments. But the calls for a minimum wage, devolution and Lords reform were all delivered by this Labour government under Tony Blair.

Labour's fundamental values remain intact. Leaders and their deputies may come and go, but values such as "opportunity for all" and "responsibility for all" are bigger than the lot of us.
John Prescott MP
Deputy prime minister

 Roy Hattersley rightly points out that Tony Blair's policies have little in common with Keir Hardie's socialism. He fails to add that Lord Hattersley's practice has little in common with the same Hardie. He put principles into everyday living, never took more than a modest income, and was scornful of those who went to the Lords.
Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow
BOB@holman24.fsnet.co.uk
