fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: What a relief that Mr Tony Blair has returned from paternity leave with a magisterial promise to save the NHS. It's particularly good of him to make the effort when he himself is so palpably blameless for the calamitous state of the system
fields.body:
What a relief that Mr Tony Blair has returned from paternity leave with a magisterial promise to save the NHS. It's particularly good of him to make the effort when he himself is so palpably blameless for the calamitous state of the system - the thousands who have died since the election for the want of £12,000 dialysis machines, for instance, while the government has creamed off billions for pre-election bribery. It can't be him, after all, because he's only the prime minister. Anyway, there appears to be even less time for Mr T to lose than we thought, judging by Alan Milburn's imbecilic survey that went out last week. Each of the 12m forms has a reply-paid posting address on the tear-off bit, but the blurb inside still advises that "if you use a stamp you will help NHS money go further". Marvellous, so now the health service is reduced to the level of charities like Oxfam, and openly solicits patients for donations. Would anyone with old meat cleavers they no longer use be good enough to send them in to their local hospital's orthopaedic registrar?

In the Staines and Ashford News, I am pleased by a headline which reads: "Wilshire in line to win Stupidest MP 2000 title". The paper reports that David Wilshire, the Tory MP for Spelthorne who once likened the Guardian's cod fax to the Third Reich, is trying to force Harold Trace, a cancer-stricken Labour agent who accused him of scaremongering over a local hospital, into a public apology. For once in his life David is "unavailable for comment", but if he really wishes to challenge heavyweights such as David Winnick, he'll have to get talking again soon.

Meanwhile, a new contender steps forward. Diana Organ, Labour member for the Forest of Dean, sits on the culture select committee so self- effacingly chaired by my friend Gerald Kaufman, and when yesterday it met to consider the Elgin marbles Diana made her mark. Haranguing Jules Dassin, Melina Mercouri's widower and the head of her foundation, Diana said if the marbles were returned to their rightful place at the Acropolis, they'd be seen by millions fewer than now. What a clever forensic device, reducing so troublesome a moral issue to a matter of attendances - and how cruel of Mr Dassin to respond by remarking that if it was just about numbers, "then let's send them to China".

In the education war, it is a bit surprising to find the Sun lining up behind weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown, especially since Rupert Murdoch went to Oxford. Perhaps it is worth noting that the paper's current editor David Yelland has an economics degree from Lanchester Polytechnic (as it then was; it is now Coventry University). We hope to discuss his academic history, focusing particularly on any rejections he may have suffered, when the alopecian editor returns from holiday.

In California, a winner has emerged in a competition to find the state's most creative expenses claim. Scott Adams, sole judge and creator of the cartoon Dilbert, has chosen an employee of a Bay Area software firm. According to the San Francisco Examiner, Dan Wolff claimed $70 for the cost of two voodoo dolls to be used against an industry analyst antagonistic to the company and his PR minder, plus $1 for two sets of coffin nails. The claim was made with the blessing of Mr Wolff's boss, and was processed successfully, but the dolls themselves were never sent. Rumours that Mr Wolff has been offered a senior position in several Labour-run Scottish councils remain unconfirmed.

There is no news yet of the campaign to have Professor Stanley Unwin installed as Guardian of the Dictionaries on the Channel 4 gameshow Countdown. A message has been left at Yorkshire TV asking Richard Whiteley to call, but he has failed to do so. Still, it's early days.

fields.headline: Facing up to consultants
fields.standfirst:
The risk is it could endanger real reforms

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Depending on who you talk to, Labour has either struck on a winning strategy or it has lost the plot. It has either discovered that the secret of clever politics is a smart choice of enemy, or it has stupidly alienated the very people it needs if it is to keep power and change Britain. Whichever view you hold, yesterday's Downing Street "summit" on NHS reform seemed to provide fresh evidence.
fields.body:
Depending on who you talk to, Labour has either struck on a winning strategy or it has lost the plot. It has either discovered that the secret of clever politics is a smart choice of enemy, or it has stupidly alienated the very people it needs if it is to keep power and change Britain. Whichever view you hold, yesterday's Downing Street "summit" on NHS reform seemed to provide fresh evidence.

The event was trailed with a direct attack by the health secretary on the country's most senior doctors. Alan Milburn seized on the case of Rodney Ledward, the Ashford gynaecologist who was struck off last week after botching operations for 16 years. Mr Milburn said the "consultant is king" culture which allowed that to happen had to change. From now on it should be the consumer who rules. At a stroke, consultants became the latest addition to that rollcall of elitist dishonour inaugurated by Gordon Brown's attack on Oxbridge - "forces of conservatism" holding Britain back. Whether this was part of some planned, methodical strategy by Labour or a seat-of-the-pants attempt to sustain an ad-libbed theme begun by the chancellor, it is hard to tell. Especially when there are government sources who will happily confirm both, conflicting views.

A more substantial question is whether this is a sound move. There are certainly risks. For one thing, doctors are a powerful lobby. One government official explains how Mr Milburn's job differs from that of the education secretary. "If Blunkett goes on the Today programme and attacks a teacher, then the listeners side with Blunkett. But if Milburn attacks a doctor, people side with the doctor every time." If that calculation is right, then picking a fight with consultants may not be such a good idea. Moreover, as politicians' wars on teachers have proved, demonising a profession can trigger the opposite of the intended effect: slowing down reform. The risk here is that consultants will feel besieged and resist modernisation. A final danger is that a headline-seeking attack on senior doctors might detract from the serious proposals for reform the government's current rethink on health are producing. Voters could dismiss this as just another instance of politicians shooting their mouths off, rather than producing constructive new ideas.

That would be a shame. Because, on the slim evidence so far available, the current health review is generating some worthwhile new approaches. The abolition of waiting lists through specialised centres - "hip replacement factories" and the like - is an imaginative idea. Specifically, the working practices of consultants do need a rethink. If extra money could lure senior doctors from the work they do on the side in the private sector, that could help to unblock bottlenecks (depending on how many of their private patients return to the NHS). The state could even "buy out" consultants' time completely. If they could be persuaded to accept a less wide-ranging brief - and specialise in certain procedures - that might increase "throughput" of patients and make a dent in waiting lists. And perhaps our clinical schools could start to train a new kind of middle-ranking doctor, a consultant-minus, who would be qualified in a specific procedure, if not the full range of today's top flight medics. Ideally these changes should be introduced with the co-operation of the medical profession. But doctors have shown a stubborn resistance to change for more than half a century. If confrontation is the only way to win progress, then the government is right to take them on.

webTitle: Hunters put their faith in spirit world

fields.headline: Hunters put their faith in spirit world
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Packed with singing young men, the old Leyland lorry lurched through the gates, girded by water containers, and with bags of rice strapped on top of the driver's cabin.
fields.body:
Packed with singing young men, the old Leyland lorry lurched through the gates, girded by water containers, and with bags of rice strapped on top of the driver's cabin.

A contingent of the Kamajors, the militia which fights alongside Sierra Leone's small army, was off to the front. The singing could be heard streets away as the lorry slowly climbed the road leading to Masiaka, the base for the government attack on the rebel Revolutionary United Front.

Kamajors, which means "hunters" in the Mende language, has come to describe the volunteer self-defence units formed in the southern region during the early years of the war in Sierra Leone. The units used the bush skills and local knowledge of forest youngsters to combat the RUF, which drew on similar assets among its own fighters.

As the war continued, additional "civil defence forces", as the government calls them, were formed across the country. The units were useful to a government that needed every fighter it could get and did not wish to depend wholly on an army prone to coups.

The Kamajors worked with the South African mercenaries who, for a time, assured the security of the diamond zones. Later, some moved to the capital, Freetown, often bringing along wives and children.

But the growth of the Kamajors - who have been accused of recruiting children and killing prisoners - was also part of the dangerous proliferation of armed groups in Sierra Leone.

Frank Tabor Bassie, a commander just back from the fighting at Lunsar, 70 miles north-east of Freetown, said that child soldiers with the RUF were often taken prisoner, but that the older rebels resisted to the end. In any case: "They can't be trusted. The few we have taken say they will reform, but I do not believe they will ever change."

The young men at Brookfields, a former hotel which acts as the Kamajor base camp in Freetown, did not live up to their fearsome reputation, however. Most were wearing jeans or slacks, with a few in combat fatigues. Baseball caps sent their usual confused messages - Miami Beach, Marlboro, Man United - and all the men had amulets or lucky charms.

Sam Hinga Norman, a twinkle-eyed man in his 60s, was prominent in raising some of the first civil defence units when he was a provincial administrator in the early 1990s. He has come to be regarded as the national leader of the Kamajors. He is also the deputy defence minister and was once a professional soldier.

Chairing a meeting of what might be called the Kamajor general staff, he ticked off lists of groups on their way to the front, debriefed a returning commander, and pursued the question of getting enough pots and pans to the fighters.

Afterwards we crunched through the once pleasant grounds, now metallic with discarded sardine cans, past cooking fires, laundry tubs and a tethered white goat, to examine the supplies.

There were stacks of pans, rice, cassava and enamel bowls stencilled with roses. It was all domestic in scale, important in a war conducted in rushes and dashes by relatively small groups of men, and heavily influenced by whether or not stew and rice are available at the end of the day.

But the Kamajors take more than rice and ammunition to the battlefield. Famously, they take magical protection against the bullets of the enemy.

Momoka Mara, 27, from Pujehun in the east, is one of the corps of "initiators" and "immunisers" who maintain this magic armour. Baseball capped and T-shirted, swinging his legs over the edge of a table, he did not look like a medicine man. But he explained that when he was younger, he fell in a river and should have drowned, but emerged with special powers. His main tools, he said, were "herbs, the Koran, and the Holy Bible".

"You see", Mr Hinga Norman said in his mellifluous English, "You call them medicine men, but you have your own armour in western armies and sometimes it does not work, which is the same with us. Sometimes we get hurt and sometimes we get killed, but that doesn't mean it doesn't work."

On one level the initiators carry on social and religious customs that mark the transition to adulthood in rural Sierra Leone in peacetime. On another their function is not dissimilar to that of chaplains in western armies. But they also illustrate that, to Sierra Leoneans, reality includes a spirit world that influences individual and collective life.

The outsider has to wonder whether herbs, the Koran, and the Holy Bible are going to be enough. In response, Mr Hinga Norman said simply: that they were "the three most important things in life" - and the Kamajor general staff exploded in approval.

fields.headline: Consultants under fire
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's attack on medical consultants (Blair gets tough with doctors, June 5) is cynical opportunism, riding on the back of the unspeakable gynecologist, Ledwood.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's attack on medical consultants (Blair gets tough with doctors, June 5) is cynical opportunism, riding on the back of the unspeakable gynecologist, Ledwood.

His behaviour is almost bizarre, as he colludes with the last Tory government, whose 18 years of relative neglect of our NHS led to the present parlous state. His focus on consultants diverts attention away from the core solution - the need to spend the average of what other developed nations spend on health, which of course requires an increase in direct income tax, the fairest and most efficient way forward.
Prof Colin Pritchard
School of Medicine, University of Southampton
cp1@soton.ac.uk

 I had to smile when I read Mac Armstrong's article (We're not all butchers, June 3) especially his claim that "god-like consultants" no longer exist. I had a hysterectomy eight months ago; within 24 hours I was back in theatre with an internal haemorrhage. I have now had five operations and am still in constant pain. The consultant was an autocratic woman who never gave me a satisfactory explanation of what had gone wrong. Her staff were obviously in fear of her, her registrar was unable to make a decision about my future care while she was on holiday. She tried to blame my continuing problems on my neurological condition and refused to listen to my 15 years experience of its effects. I have not been able to find out whether I was just unfortunate or whether others have been affected. Patients should have the right to this information.

In the last year I have seen four other consultants; two were caring and empathic and treated me with dignity and respect as they obviously do their staff teams. One was so arrogant he was like a caricature of the god-like surgeon. The fourth consultant I saw last week. He did not introduce himself or the other three people present but fired a series of questions at me. The door was left open and during the interview he was asked to sign a number of prescriptions and then took a telephone call all whilst discussing my neurological future.

I agree that it is vital that patients have confidence in doctors' ability to help them, but all the time they continue to behave in arrogant and insensitive ways we cannot.
Name and address supplied

 The governance of good practice of the medical profession is definitely not working for the public. Is is definitely not working for doctors either. My colleagues are exhausted from constant threat of complaint.

There are at least six organisations in Britain who will consider complaints and the litigious aggrieved patient can access them all in term. Hospital consultants suffer as much as their general practice colleagues. They are increasingly suspended from practice in hospitals by nameless managers for nameless offences.

In the general scheme qualification for legal aid is particularly destructive, with massive quantities of public money working up minimal or clearly hopeless cases. In spite of this legal and financial settlement is patchy, lacks justice, is lengthy and follows antagonistic defence arguments. In general the weight of the system only takes effects when problems become severe.

There is a great need for the system to monitor, compliment and intervene as a routine. No-blame medical compensation needs to be considered. The former is found in many of the government's current proposals and patients and doctors need these to be implemented as soon as possible.
Dr David Fish
Chair, Coventry East primary care group
DavidFishCF@email.msn.com

webTitle: PM rejects Greek push for marbles

fields.headline: PM rejects Greek push for marbles
fields.standfirst:
Elgin marbles: special report

Campaign for the return of the Parthenon marbles
fields.trailText: A Greek charm offensive to persuade Britain to return the Elgin marbles foundered last night when Tony Blair ruled out the idea and Tory MPs boycotted a Commons hearing for the country's foreign minister to make his case.
fields.body:
A Greek charm offensive to persuade Britain to return the Elgin marbles foundered last night when Tony Blair ruled out the idea and Tory MPs boycotted a Commons hearing for the country's foreign minister to make his case.

Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs gave George Papandreou a sympathetic hearing when he appeared before the culture, media and sport committee to propose a partnership deal to return the marbles to the Acropolis in time for the 2004 Olympics.

The hearing was marred by peremptory comments from Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's secretary, at the Downing Street lobby briefing, announcing that Britain had no intention of returning the treasures which are displayed in the British Museum, in central London.

Conservatives MPs boycotted the hearing with Julie Kirkbride, MP for Bromsgrove, claiming that Mr Papandreou's visit was "superfluous and unnecessary" since the committee had already been briefed by the Greek foreign ministry when they went to Athens to view the site.

She claimed that the culture committee was being used by Pasok (the Greek socialist party) which wanted to be seen fulfilling an election pledge to re-open a dialogue on the marbles.

Ms Kirkbride also indicated that she would oppose any move by the select committee to suggest Greece had a moral case for their return.

"As far as I am concerned the marbles were acquired legitimately and the committee has far more important issues to discuss.

"I see no reason why ... the Conservative party which opposed their return for 18 years should change their mind. "

At the hearing Mr Papandreou told the MPs the issue of the 2,500-year-old marbles was "a very sensitive one and a very important one" to the people of Greece.

"We are talking about the Parthenon," he said. "We are talking about the greatest national symbol of Greece. It symbolises the Greek contribution to the cultural heritage of humankind.

"What we are saying is that this masterpiece must be reunified and its integrity restored."

Mr Papandreou said he did not want to "rake over" the events of 200 years ago when Britain had an empire and Greece was a "subject" nation. But he told Gerald Kaufman, the Labour chairman of the committee, that one part of his case was that the marbles had been acquired illicitly.

Asked about sharing ownership between the countries, he said Greece would be "very glad to look at all the possibilities" provided the marbles were reunited with the rest of the monument.

Later, on Westminster's College Green, Mr Papandreou said: "This is something we want to move from controversy to building a partnership, conceptualising this problem as a win-win situation for both Greece and Britain.

"I think we can both do something which is very important for world culture, around the time of the Olympic Games, and this would be high visibility for Britain and high visibility for British culture."

webTitle: Speight: Fiji village boy with a big mouth and ambitions

fields.headline: Speight: Fiji village boy with a big mouth and ambitions
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: The sleepy village of Naivicula seems a million miles from the highly charged atmosphere of the hostage drama that ground to a tense stalemate yesterday in the parliament compound of Suva.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Naivicula, Tailevu province
fields.body:
The sleepy village of Naivicula seems a million miles from the highly charged atmosphere of the hostage drama that ground to a tense stalemate yesterday in the parliament compound of Suva.

But it is here, among the banana plantations and dairy herds in a verdant valley 40 miles east of the Fijian capital, that the rebel leader, George Speight, grew up and developed a nationalist ardour that has brought the country to its knees.

"George was a very ambitious boy," said Livai Tabua Tikoinasau, who describes himself as Mr Speight's "uncle" but is actually his first cousin once removed.

"He played a lot, was good at school and was very ambitious. But he didn't bully a lot because he was religious. He was brought up a Seventh-Day Adventist by his mother."

George's father, Sam, known as Savenaca Tokaonavo, is half Fijian and half European and one of the richest people in the village, thanks to the dairy farm he owns a mile beyond the last of the tin shacks and corrugated iron roofs.

It was this wealth that gave George his start in life, paying for a trip overseas to study and work. "We knew he was going to be successful because he was very good at talking, but we thought it would be as a businessman, not as a political leader," said Mr Tikoinasau. He has a photograph of a much younger and slimmer George posing with his father displayed prominently in his home.

For a time, however, George was a success as neither. The now deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, recently dismissed him as chairman of the Fiji Hardwood Corporation board, and he faces several court charges over allegations of financial abuse.

In Fijian politics he was an unknown until, with two dozen supporters, he seized 37 parliamentarians on May 19 in the name of defending the rights of indigenous Fijians against the perceived creeping social and political supremacy of the ethnic Indian minority.

Last night as the military, which seized executive authority last Monday to fill the power vacuum, broke off negotiations with Mr Speight, it became apparent that the rebel leader was being squeezed into a corner.

Under pressure from foreign powers, particularly the European Union which is threatening to ban Fijian sugar imports, the military commander, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, hardened his position significantly. He said the only concession he would make to Mr Speight would be to grant him amnesty if he released the remaining 31 hostages and surrendered his weapons.

Cmdr Bainimarama said there was no question of Mr Speight or any of his followers being included in the interim government that would pave the way for a general election, as the rebels had insisted.

He added he would not talk any further with Mr Speight until the rebels were willing to negotiate on his terms.

Mr Speight responded with his now all-too-familiar loquacious belligerence. He accused Cmdr Bainimarama of tearing up an agreement reached on Sunday night, saying that it was "a complete manifestation of the lack of commitment to what I thought were commitments made earlier".

He denied that the military could isolate him and the hostages in the parliamentary compound and continue running the country, because his supporters would automatically stage a rebellion.

"I do not have to [order an uprising]," Mr Speight said. "The people know what to do and they will make this decision themselves."

Most analysts believe that while Mr Speight commands enormous tacit support among indigenous Fijians for his vehement defence of their rights to the land, there will never be an uprising against a military-led interim government.

But in Naivicula all the adults say they support Mr Speight - who is regarded as a minor chief -"100%".

"We're willing to fight for him and die for him, our country and our future," said Waisake Ravasua, one of the village teachers.

"He is the only person who is prepared to stand up for indigenous Fijians' rights. If we let happen what Chaudhry has done then it would be like the aborigines in Australia or the Maoris in New Zealand; they haven't got any rights at all."

fields.headline: Maurice Richard
fields.standfirst: Ice hockey 'Rocket' who helped define French-Canadian identity
fields.trailText: Maurice Richard, who has died aged 78, was a record-setting goal scorer for the Montreal Canadiens' ice-hockey team. He was called "the Rocket" because of his speed, but it was the fire in his eyes, dubbed "the Rocket's red glare", that instilled fear in opposing goaltenders.
fields.body:
Maurice Richard, who has died aged 78, was a record-setting goal scorer for the Montreal Canadiens' ice-hockey team. He was called "the Rocket" because of his speed, but it was the fire in his eyes, dubbed "the Rocket's red glare", that instilled fear in opposing goaltenders.

Richard's impact went far beyond the rink. Canada's prime minister, Jean Chrétien, said that he "defined and transcended the game". As a boy, listening to Canadiens' games in far-off Connecticut, I visualised the Rocket as the most soaring of the "flying Frenchmen" whose names rang with exotic glamour. To English Canadians, he personified the French-Canadian character, defined in terms of Gallic flair, unpredictability and dangerous emotionality (which echo British analysis of French rugby).

In Quebec, however, Richard's place was unequalled. His impact peaked on March 17 1955. The infamous "Richard riot" was triggered when National Hockey League commissioner Clarence Campbell showed up at the Montreal Forum the day after suspending Richard for the remainder of the season, including the Stanley Cup playoffs, for his part in a stick-swinging incident, in which he also punched an official.

Campbell's escort of three women was not enough to protect him from slaps, tomatoes and a tear-gas bomb thrown from the crowd. When he stopped the match and awarded a forfeit to Detroit, it triggered seven hours of looting and burning over three miles of Sainte Catherine Street. After 60 arrests, only Richard's radio appeal stopped the violence.

The riot is still regarded by many as the start of the Quebec independence movement. Yet despite his iconic status to nationalists, in later life Richard accepted the Order of Canada, and served on the Queen's private council.

Born in the roughest part of Montreal's East End, Richard starred in local junior hockey before making his debut with the Canadiens' war-depleted squad in 1942 at 21. He overcame an early reputation as easily injured to register the NHL's first 50-goal season in 1943-44, a feat accomplished in only 50 games. His play was enhanced by his linemates, centre Elmer Lach and left-wing Hector "Toe" Blake.

But his greatest success followed the riots, in what should have been the twilight of his career. Without Richard, Montreal lost the cup to Detroit. The Rocket promised it would return to Quebec. The club replaced coach Dick Irvin, who could not control Richard, with Blake, who named him captain. They proceeded to win five consecutive Stanley Cups, a feat unprecedented and unequalled since. Following the fifth win, at age 39, Richard retired. He had scored a record 544 goals, and another 82 in cup play. His 18 game-winners in the cup, six in sudden-death overtime, remain records.

He died after a long fight against stomach cancer and Parkinson's disease. His wife, Lucille, died in 1994. He is survived by his seven children. In the words of the dean of hockey writers, Red Fisher, of the Montreal Gazette: "He was the most intense athlete this game, this city, this country has ever seen."

Joseph Henri Maurice Richard, ice-hockey player, born August 4 1921; died May 27 2000

fields.headline: Petur Mladenov
fields.standfirst: Short-lived hero of Bulgaria's reformist revolution
fields.trailText: In the course of a swift palace revolution the day after the Berlin wall was breached in November 1989, Petur Mladenov, the Bulgarian politician who has died aged 63, brought to an end the 35-year reign of his country's communist-era strongman Todor Zhivkov.
fields.body:
In the course of a swift palace revolution the day after the Berlin wall was breached in November 1989, Petur Mladenov, the Bulgarian politician who has died aged 63, brought to an end the 35-year reign of his country's communist-era strongman Todor Zhivkov.

Mladenov did not have long to enjoy the fruits of power. Within 12 weeks he stepped down as leader of the still dominant Bulgarian Communist party (BCP); five months later, he resigned as head of state after it emerged that he had suggested using force against pro-democracy demonstrators.

Yet as a caretaker leader, he helped oversee the transition from one of the most rigid one-party regimes in eastern Europe to a pluralist system based on free elections. He also restored minority rights to Bulgaria's sizeable ethnic Turkish community. He neither foresaw nor desired the extent of the transformation that was to envelop Bulgaria, but as the leadership was carried away by the pace of events, he did not resist the demand for radical change.

Mladenov was born into a family of farmers in the village of Toshevtsi, in north-west Bulgaria. His father was a wartime partisan who was killed in action in 1944. His education followed the conventional pattern of the children of reliable party activists; he went to military school in Shumen, attended the University of Sofia and graduated from the Institute for International Relations in Moscow.

After an early career in the communist youth movement and the BCP apparatus of his local Vidin region, Mladenov shot to prominence in 1971 when he was appointed foreign minister following his predecessor's death in a skiing accident. At 35, he was Europe's youngest foreign minister, although his influence had more to do with his membership, after 1974, of the BCP politburo than with his government post.

Mladenov served as foreign minister for 18 years. His task of presenting a favourable image of his country to the world was not always easy. He had to defend the Sofia leadership against accusations of ordering the elimination of Georgi Markov, the émigré Bulgarian journalist killed in London in 1978. Later, Bulgaria was attacked over the forcible assimilation of its nearly 1m-strong ethnic Turkish minority, a process which led in 1989 to the exodus of more than 300,000 Turks.

As the Zhivkov regime became increasingly isolated - shunned by the west and a growing embarrassment to Mikhail Gorbachev's reformist leadership in Moscow - Mladenov decided to act. At the end of October 1989, he issued a devastating indictment of the Zhivkov leadership and offered to resign from all his posts. Zhivkov was no longer strong enough to fend off the challenge. Mladenov stayed on in his job, and two weeks later used his new-found credibility to oust Zhivkov as BCP general secretary. Within days, he also replaced Zhivkov as head of state.

Mladenov was to deny reports that his coup had been co-ordinated with the Kremlin. But there was no doubt about Gorbachev's approval of the changes in Sofia, which seemed to reflect his own approach of extensive, but controlled, reforms.

Initially, Mladenov followed the same path. But within weeks, public pressure for a radical transformation overtook the limits the post-Zhivkov leadership sought to impose. Demonstrators surrounded parliament to demand that the constitutional clause stipulating the BCP's leading role in society should be scrapped. After it was removed, multi-party elections were held in June, and the BCP (by then renamed the Socialist party) swept back to power.

But taped remarks Mladenov had made during the December 1989 demonstrations - to the effect that "We'd better have the tanks come here" - continued to haunt him when they were used in the opposition's election broadcasts six months later. Mladenov claimed the tape was a fake, but after an official commission pronounced the recording to be genuine, he changed his story and said his remarks had been taken out of context. The public outcry and the loss of support among his party colleagues combined to force him to resign the presidency in July 1990.

He is survived by his wife, Galia, and his daughter, Tania.

Petur Mladenov, politician, born August 2 1936; died May 31 2000

fields.headline: General Iko Carreira
fields.standfirst: Key figure in  Angola's struggle to maintain its independence
fields.trailText: General Iko Carreira, who has died aged 66, was Angola's minister of defence, its army commander-in-chief and a member of the political bureau during the years of apartheid South Africa's undeclared war against his country in the late 1970s and early 1980s. He was a key figure in making Angola's struggle to maintain its independence - against enormous US pressure - a common cause for most of the third world for more than a decade.
fields.body:
General Iko Carreira, who has died aged 66, was Angola's minister of defence, its army commander-in-chief and a member of the political bureau during the years of apartheid South Africa's undeclared war against his country in the late 1970s and early 1980s. He was a key figure in making Angola's struggle to maintain its independence - against enormous US pressure - a common cause for most of the third world for more than a decade.

An Angolan of Portuguese and Italian parentage, Carreira became an officer in the Portuguese army, but deserted to join the guerrilla war for Angolan independence. His formative years were spent fighting in the bush alongside Agostinho Neto, the founder of the Popular Movement for the Independence of Angola (MPLA) and the country's first president after independence in 1975. That year, Carreira became minister of defence and the architect of the modern army built at speed to repel military threats on the new country's northern, southern and eastern borders.

He was brave, assured, multi-lingual, worldly and utterly without illusion about the cost Angolans would pay for their choices. "[Jonas] Savimbi, we can beat him; the South Africans, we can beat them; but the CIA and the Americans, that's the unknown quantity for us," he told me once in 1984.

In the early 1980s, Carreira went to Moscow for military training, the first African to take the Soviet Union's advanced officer course. Returning home two years later, he became air force commander and the technical specialist to whom the Soviet leadership related when supplying Angola with their most advanced fighter planes. The security of the capital, Luanda, while the south suffered repeated bombing from South Africa's illegal bases in Namibia, rested on the skills of his young pilots. These were years when Savimbi, leader of the Unita movement, and backed by a massive CIA and South African propaganda machine, was being groomed to take over in Angola.

Carreira was also close to the Cuban generals in Angola during the difficult years of high casualties and high stakes for the Cuban regime. By the end of the 1970s, Cuba had 30,000 men in Angola supporting the government.

Carreira's life phases were a mirror of the MPLA's historical fortunes. When the years which started with Agostinho Neto's self-sacrifice and idealism gave way to a new pragmatism in the mid-1980s, he was among the key leadership figures ousted at a landmark party congress in 1985. Under US pressure, socialism was being exchanged for social democracy and multi-party politics, the ANC's military training camps in Angola were closed down, the Cubans were asked to leave and negotiations began with Savimbi. Carreira was given an appointment far away - as ambassador to Algeria.

fields.bodyText: General Iko Carreira, who has died aged 66, was Angola's minister of defence, its army commander-in-chief and a member of the political bureau during the years of apartheid South Africa's undeclared war against his country in the late 1970s and early 1980s. He was a key figure in making Angola's struggle to maintain its independence - against enormous US pressure - a common cause for most of the third world for more than a decade. An Angolan of Portuguese and Italian parentage, Carreira became an officer in the Portuguese army, but deserted to join the guerrilla war for Angolan independence. His formative years were spent fighting in the bush alongside Agostinho Neto, the founder of the Popular Movement for the Independence of Angola (MPLA) and the country's first president after independence in 1975. That year, Carreira became minister of defence and the architect of the modern army built at speed to repel military threats on the new country's northern, southern and eastern borders. He was brave, assured, multi-lingual, worldly and utterly without illusion about the cost Angolans would pay for their choices. "[Jonas] Savimbi, we can beat him; the South Africans, we can beat them; but the CIA and the Americans, that's the unknown quantity for us," he told me once in 1984. In the early 1980s, Carreira went to Moscow for military training, the first African to take the Soviet Union's advanced officer course. Returning home two years later, he became air force commander and the technical specialist to whom the Soviet leadership related when supplying Angola with their most advanced fighter planes. The security of the capital, Luanda, while the south suffered repeated bombing from South Africa's illegal bases in Namibia, rested on the skills of his young pilots. These were years when Savimbi, leader of the Unita movement, and backed by a massive CIA and South African propaganda machine, was being groomed to take over in Angola. Carreira was also close to the Cuban generals in Angola during the difficult years of high casualties and high stakes for the Cuban regime. By the end of the 1970s, Cuba had 30,000 men in Angola supporting the government. Carreira's life phases were a mirror of the MPLA's historical fortunes. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Once again Auntie is scrabbling through our dustbins with grim disapproval. After last week's blast from Alex Kirby in Costing The Earth, our waste disposal habits now get it in the neck from Julian O'Halloran in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). It's all because we discard too much and the country is running out of places to bury the stuff. The easiest alternative is an incinerator - but that poses the worse risk of scattering dioxins and other horrible pollutants.

The first time I ever learned an official secret, no one would believe me (an early lesson for an aspiring journalist). A red-eyed soldier at the local railway station told me, aged seven, that the British army was quit ting France. He obviously knew, since he had just arrived from Dunkirk but, to my chagrin, my sceptical mother was told nothing on the wireless. Michael Aspel recalls the desperate atmosphere of The Summer Of 1940 (9.0pm, Radio 2).

webTitle: Women face same old foes in UN

fields.headline: Women face same old foes in UN
fields.trailText: Five years after the UN adopted an ambitious plan to achieve equality for women, this year's agenda may reverse some of the gains made, human rights and women's groups warned as delegates from 188 countries met yesterday to assess the progress they had made.
fields.body:
Five years after the UN adopted an ambitious plan to achieve equality for women, this year's agenda may reverse some of the gains made, human rights and women's groups warned as delegates from 188 countries met yesterday to assess the progress they had made.

Prior to the special session of the UN general assembly, the battle lines were looking very similar to those drawn in Beijing in 1995: women's activists and many democracies versus the Vatican and a handful of Islamic countries.

Mary Robinson, the high commissioner for human rights, said she was worried that the current review might weaken 1995's agenda. "This review is... worrying, because we're having difficulty holding on to the platform of Beijing, never mind moving much, much further as we need to.

"I think the few [states] that don't want progress are very effective, and that's a problem," Ms Robinson, the former Irish president, said before speaking to about 1,000 women at a human rights symposium at Columbia University on Sunday.

Amnesty International's secretary general, Pierre Sane, listed Algeria, Libya, Iran, Pakistan and the Vatican as the recalcitrant countries playing "a very destructive role" in negotiations on a final forward-looking document. Other delegates said Sudan should also be included on that list.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, last night expressed hope that this conference "will put the world on notice that not only do women belong on this planet, but that the future of this planet depends on women". He said that "much remains to be done" to achieve gender equality.

At Beijing, governments committed themselves to the promotion of women's inheritance rights, calling on governments to provide equal education and employment, and demanding that business and government put women in top decision-making posts.

More than 200 speeches will be made at this week's assembly. Parallel sessions for thousands of representatives of grassroots groups will cover topics ranging from the effects of globalisation on women to the role of men and boys in ending gender-based violence.

But the most important work will be going on behind closed doors, where negotiators will try to reach consensus on the final document. Ms Robinson said she would like that document to ensure that there is "no dilution" of the Beijing agenda, and to send a message that "national, cultural, religious and historical considerations... can never be allowed to be used as justifications for the infringement of women's human rights".

fields.headline: Together forever
fields.standfirst: When The Odd Couple arrived in 1968, they invented a new strand of TV - flatshare drama. But why has the concept remained so popular over the years? Because it makes such great television, as  Mathew Baylis explains
fields.trailText: When The Odd Couple arrived in 1968, they invented a new strand of TV - flatshare drama. But why has the concept remained so popular over the years? Because it makes such great television, as Mathew Baylis explains
fields.body:
What must it have been like to share digs with Nick Ross? Did he call Crimestoppers if he caught you drunk at midnight, with your mouth full of his muesli? Were the flatmates of Changing Rooms guru Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen afraid to go out in case he revamped their bedrooms with the contents of a nearby skip? BBC1's The Horror Of... Flatmates tonight neglects to answer these questions - in spite of anecdotes from the aforementioned celebs - but it raises one. Why are we so interested?

Maybe the screen obsession with flatsharing began in 1968, when Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau starred in The Odd Couple. The plot can be summarised thus: anal retentive divorcee Felix (Lemmon) moves in with low-living batchelor Oscar (Matthau). Hilarious consequences ensue - least hilarious of all being a spin-off sit-com.

Five years later, Thames Television introduced the flatsharing sit-com to the UK, in the shape of Man About The House. This dealt with the misadventures of randy bohemian Robin Tripp, his beautiful flatmates Chrissy and Jo, and downstairs landlords George and Mildred. The gags and drama came from two sources. First, Robin trying and failing to convert either or both of his flat-mates into bed-mates. Second, twitchy old-school landlord George trying to score points over his long-haired, "modern" nemesis Robin. As far as formats go, this was faultless. The tensions between men and women, the old and the new were built-in, and it was, by virtue of the upstairs/downstairs setting, cheap to make.

Ever since, communal living has provided rich pickings for TV. For a start, it's an experience common to anyone who ever harboured ambitions to write. No TV station is going to read your scripts if you're living in your Mum's house in Wigan. A move to Shepherd's Bush (or similar) is de rigueur, and unless you're equipped with a trust fund, you're likely to end up sharing lodgings. In this sense, writers are no different to the population at large, which has marched in cohorts away from the towns and towards the cities. Seventies sitcoms like Rising Damp and The Liver Birds not only reflect the experiences of writers, but of young people, as the traditional model of living at home until marriage was eroded. As BBC1 shows tonight, few people under 40 lack some anecdote about flock wallpaper and flatmates who constituted a threat to public health.

The concept of sharing one's private space with others also lends itself to the demands of drama and comedy. For both to work, you need tensions, for these turn a "scene" into an "event", something we see, into something we watch. Man in armchair alone - boring. Man in armchair alone, plus flat-mate and noisy hoover - tension. If you ever thought the most watchable episodes of Hancock's Half Hour were those co-starring Sid James, now you know why. Sharing space with loved ones has its own tensions - amply exploited in shows like Home To Roost and The Royle Family - but the relationship between people who are merely friends or strangers is more exciting. Families, boringly, tolerate one another's faults, but friends can fall out forever, just as landlords evict lodgers. This everlasting potential is one reason why the flatshare format has endured, yet undergone so many permutations. Porridge was an early attempt to twist the underlying struc ture: Godber and Fletch, competing for space, but united in opposition to "landlord", Mr MacKay. In Father Ted, three differing personalities were lumped together against their will, but could co-operate under threat from visiting Bishops.

In soapland, too, flatsharing is on a steady increase. Originally, the lodger-landlord model was preferred. Coronation Street mined hours of bitter-sweet fun from the prickly relationship between fussy pensioner Percy Sugden and his ever-martyred landlady Emily Bishop (not to mention Randy, Percy's budgerigar). EastEnders countered with its own odd couple, Dot and Ethel (and for perfect symmetry, Ethel's Pekinese, Little Willy). But it was Brookside where multi-person flatsharing came into its own in 1986, when nurses Sandra and Kate shacked up with hospital porter Pat - and, later on, a knife-wielding psychopath who held them hostage, but that's Brookie for you.

Like sit-coms, soaps profit from depicting this lifestyle, but for different reasons. Soaps need maximum viewers, and thus need maximum variety in their characters. Flatshares provide the perfect accommodation for younger characters and - not least because this means employing young actors, unestablished in their careers - they are a suitably transient setting to test new talent. If they flounder, they can be decamped with little more than a farewell pint in the Queen Vic. Flatshares also provide an on-site bolthole when couples split - it was thanks to the EastEnders squat that Tiffany and Ricky could leave their partners, but remain visible and thus keep the drama going. In real life, you return to Wigan and the story ends.

Our voyeuristic delight in flatsharing, however, is continually evolving. What is Castaway 2000 if not a communal living experiment on a scale larger but no bleaker than a flatshare in Shepherd's Bush?

 The Horror of Flatmates, 8pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Inside Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle  continues his trek through the highlights of the world's biggest modern art museum  This week: Lightning with Stag in its Glare by Joseph Beuys
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle continues his trek through the highlights of the world's biggest modern art museum This week: Lightning with Stag in its Glare by Joseph Beuys
fields.body:
The room devoted to the work of Joseph Beuys is one of the best at Tate Modern. The double-height proportions, with a rank of the building's original vertical windows along one side, is a perfect setting for his work. There is an undeniable hint of a fascist aesthetic at work in Gilbert Scott's power station, an aesthetic to which Beuys was inexorably related. His green politics and interest in paganism might also have struck a chord with the barbarous culture from which he arose.

There is too much Beuysabilia here, but even all this echoes the ramshackle attic of Beuys's mind, with its mishmash of shamanism and animalism, Rudolf Steiner anthropomorphism, felt-hatted utopianism and postwar German guilt.

One must always remember that his was ultimately an art of reconciliation and healing. Lightning with Stag in its Glare - what a great title. The stag, for Beuys, was a recurring and mythically laden image, "appearing at times of distress... the accompanier of the soul". Is this big inverted lump, dangling from a girder set into the wall, the stag itself, hung by the feet in some hunting lodge, or is it the thunder itself?

This great mass sticks in the brain, like an after-image of a terrible storm. It is more frightening than satisfying. The orchestration and shape reminds us yet again what a wonderful draughtsman Beuys was. Everything he did was drawing, and drawing is about making connections, however painful they might be.

 The Joseph Beuys room, gallery one, Landscape/Matter/Environment, level three, Tate Modern.

fields.headline: The Americans in Paris
fields.standfirst: An exhibition depicts the New York Philharmonic's first European tour in 1930.  Martin Kettle  reports
fields.trailText: An exhibition depicts the New York Philharmonic's first European tour in 1930. Martin Kettle reports
fields.body:
The old photograph shows a group of well-dressed men and women on the deck of a ship on the ocean sometime during the Bertie Wooster era. Some look silly. A few are serious. With one exception, who somehow contrives to look both silly and serious, they are all now forgotten faces. But the exception makes the rest of the group important, for he is Arturo Toscanini.

"This is certainly the best- known photograph from the 1930 tour," explains Barbara Haws, the archivist of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, handling her celebrated print with reverence. Haws is in her busy office in New York's Lincoln Centre, where she is preparing the orchestra's prize exhibits for shipment to London where they are on display this week.

"Here is Toscanini, with the bow tie and the cap," she explains as she pores over the picture. "This is Bruno Labate, the oboist. You know that he talked back to the maestro? Not many people ever did that. But then he had real estate investments in Long Island, so he could afford it if he was fired."

The New York Philharmonic was founded in 1842, and is altogether more venerable than any arriviste British orchestra, most of which were 20th-century foundations. What's more, when those New Yorkers in the picture took that voyage to make that first European tour in 1930, they came with the man who was then universally regarded as the greatest conductor of that or any other era.

"Ravel came to the concert in Paris," says Haws, "though he thought Toscanini conducted Bolero twice too fast and refused to take a bow with the conductor. In Berlin, Erich Kleiber, Otto Klemperer and Bruno Walter were in the audience. In Turin, true to his anti-fascist principles, Toscanini and the orchestra defied Mussolini's edict by refusing to play the fascist anthem Giovinezza (a local brass band played it instead).

"And this," Haws says, scanning the group photo once more, "this is Harry Glantz, the trumpet player who took the home movie."

Harry Glantz's home movies of the tour in 1930 are some of the more unlikely gems of an exhibition that is being mounted at the Barbican Centre to coincide with the orchestra's visit this month. "It's a very typical home movie. We'll be showing about eight minutes of it, and it has a special quality all of its own. To see Toscanini and the orchestra in playful off-duty ways is a first for most people," Haws says.

Did any of the players in the photograph play for Mahler, I ask. "Benjamin Kohon certainly did," Haws replies, consulting her identification chart. "Born 1889. Played with the orchestra from 1908. That would be in Mahler's first season with us."

If there is one name that resonates across the entire 20th- century history of the NYPO it is not that of Toscanini, or even that of Bernstein, but Gustav Mahler, who spent three years with the orchestra before he returned to Austria to die in 1911."This orchestra today is a Mahler orchestra because they have a direct line back to Mahler himself as music director," Haws says proudly. "I just wish we had one of his batons to show."

What Haws does have, though, and what she now hands me to examine, is Mahler's very own score of his first symphony. On the first page there are two stamped imprints. One says "New York Philharmonic Orchestra". The other just says "Gustav Mahler, Wien".

This precious score is still the orchestra's library copy, so if a conductor wants to use it while working with the orchestra, they can. Not surprisingly, they do. This much handled score is a symphonic icon. It contains markings in the hands of Mahler himself, some made obviously with care at a desk, others so crude they could only have been made in rehearsal. Then there are another batch by his pupil Bruno Walter who conducted the orchestra in the 40s, and still others by Bernstein, greatest of all Mahler's late 20th-century champions.

When Bernstein died in 1990, his family bequeathed his 3,500 conducting scores. One that is coming to the Barbican is Bernstein's score of the Mahler's Symphony No 6, on whose opening page the conductor affixed a bumper sticker announcing MAHLER GROOVES. "You've got to love him, haven't you?" says Haws.

Listen to Haws talking about her orchestra and you soon realise that the most special place in her heart belongs not to any of the famous names who have made the New York Philharmonic what it is, but to the very first conductor long ago, the delightfully named Ureli Corelli Hill, a musicians' musician from Connecticut who conducted the orchestra long before Bernstein ever claimed to be the first American to get the job.

Haws hands me another ancient score. There is barely a mark on this one, befitting the Ureli Corelli Hill era, when the conductor simply kept the musicians together. But what a treasure this one is too.

"This is a first edition of the Beethoven fifth, published in Vienna, the first work we ever played in 1842," says Haws. "When I showed it to Masur he said, 'Ah, you know there is a famous misprint in the first edition.' I was so worried that Ureli Corelli might not have known about the misprint, but Masur looked and, yes, they had blocked it out. Oh I was so relieved about that. I was so proud of them. Isn't that a thing to be able to do, to hold a first edition of the Beethoven fifth? Now you see why I became an archivist."

 The New York Philharmonic plays at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 4141), on Saturday and Sunday. Items from the orchestra archive will be on display till Sunday.

"Benjamin Kohon certainly did," Haws replies, consulting her identification chart. "Born 1889. Played with the orchestra from 1908. That would be in Mahler's first season with us." If there is one name that resonates across the entire 20th- century history of the NYPO it is not that of Toscanini, or even that of Bernstein, but Gustav Mahler, who spent three years with the orchestra before he returned to Austria to die in 1911."This orchestra today is a Mahler orchestra because they have a direct line back to Mahler himself as music director," Haws says proudly. "I just wish we had one of his batons to show." What Haws does have, though, and what she now hands me to examine, is Mahler's very own score of his first symphony. On the first page there are two stamped imprints. One says "New York Philharmonic Orchestra". The other just says "Gustav Mahler, Wien". This precious score is still the orchestra's library copy, so if a conductor wants to use it while working with the orchestra, they can. Not surprisingly, they do. This much handled score is a symphonic icon. It contains markings in the hands of Mahler himself, some made obviously with care at a desk, others so crude they could only have been made in rehearsal. Then there are another batch by his pupil Bruno Walter who conducted the orchestra in the 40s, and still others by Bernstein, greatest of all Mahler's late 20th-century champions. When Bernstein died in 1990, his family bequeathed his 3,500 conducting scores. One that is coming to the Barbican is Bernstein's score of the Mahler's Symphony No 6, on whose opening page the conductor affixed a bumper sticker announcing MAHLER GROOVES. "You've got to love him, haven't you?" says Haws. Listen to Haws talking about her orchestra and you soon realise that the most special place in her heart belongs not to any of the famous names who have made the New York Philharmonic what it is, but to the very first conductor long ago, the delightfully named Ureli Corelli Hill, a musicians' musician from Connecticut who conducted the orchestra long before Bernstein ever claimed to be the first American to get the job. Haws hands me another ancient score. There is barely a mark on this one, befitting the Ureli Corelli Hill era, when the conductor simply kept the musicians together. But what a treasure this one is too. "This is a first edition of the Beethoven fifth, published in Vienna, the first work we ever played in 1842," says Haws. "When I showed it to Masur he said, 'Ah, you know there is a famous misprint in the first edition.' I was so worried that Ureli Corelli might not have known about the misprint, but Masur looked and, yes, they had blocked it out. Oh I was so relieved about that. I was so proud of them. Isn't that a thing to be able to do, to hold a first edition of the Beethoven fifth? Now you see why I became an archivist."  The New York Philharmonic plays at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 4141), on Saturday and Sunday. Items from the orchestra archive will be on display till Sunday.

fields.headline: Rail travel 'not value for money'
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Railway companies are today given a harsh reminder that they are still performing badly, with official figures showing that only 41% of passengers feel their journeys offer value for money.
fields.body:
Railway companies are today given a harsh reminder that they are still performing badly, with official figures showing that only 41% of passengers feel their journeys offer value for money.

The performance of 13 of the 25 train operating companies worsened in the six months up to last March, compared with the same period a year earlier.

Dissatisfaction levels were highest for two of the London commuter companies, Connex South Central and Silverlink. Ten train companies improved their performance and two showed no change.

The survey, by the shadow strategic rail authority, comes when passenger usage is at its highest since 1946 and the number of trains has risen by 400 in a year. Passenger usage has increased by 30% in five years and is rising.

Satisfaction levels are much lower in London and the south-east, where there is considerable congestion and overcrowding. Some commuters think that their season tickets are too expensive for the poor service they receive.

Mike Grant, the SSRA's chief executive, blames lack of investment for the poor figures. He admitted that they would not necessarily improve in the next six months, even though more new rolling stock was being introduced.

As more people were using the network and more trains were running, network congestion was a "major cause of unreliability". He conceded that any significant improvement would require additional line capacity and rolling stock.

Mr Grant singled out Virgin Trains, one of the companies with a poor performance record, for improving its services. Chris Green, Virgin Trains' chief executive, said: "By paying attention to details, we have raised our game and we have also seen a dramatic decrease in the number of complaints we receive."

He said that 8% more trains were arriving within 10 minutes of their published time and 80% of customers were satisfied with their journey.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Casting clouts | Ice cream wars
fields.body:
Cast ne'er a clout 'til May is out, as my nan used to say. Only six days into June and already it would seem that we're casting clouts (that's an item of clothing, southerner) right, left and middle. Witness Sex And The City starlet Sarah Jessica Parker, who changed her outfit five times at the recent MTV film awards. One outfit was actually a towel, which arguably doesn't count as a clout but it's best to give the frock-frenzied the benefit of the doubt. Dresses are, after all, a seasonal trauma - all that air down below, exposed corns and virulent femininity.

 Sidelines, in an attempt to reconnect with the pink half of our psyche, had been practising a dream of skipping through sun-drenched meadows in floaty florals, kitten in hand, lolly in gob. But politics, dear reader, enters even this most pastoral of pursuits. Let the ice cream wars begin: a plague on the creators of the latest Magnum advert. In the offending ad, a tousle-haired, satin-clad lovely teasingly unzips the ice cream wrapper and chomps away erotically as though her mind were on another matter altogether, before lingering alarmingly on the wooden stick bit. Why not go all out and include the strapline: buy a Magnum, you may find eating one reminds you of giving head, but it's far less sticky. Enough. Sex is sex. A lolly is a lolly. Now where's my kitten, I must adjust its blinkers.

 Avid readers of Sidelines (yes, there are) will recall our concern over the poor woman in the lobby of the Vogue offices, captured on their internet vogue.cam, which keeps a 24-hour eye on the doings at their front desk. We're relieved to report that she has now left the lobby, where she'd been standing for over a week. But the waiting horror goes on. Now there is another woman, waiting plaintively for the lift. At the time of going to press, she'd been standing there for four hours. And her bag looks very heavy.

webTitle: All this, and free sweets too

fields.headline: All this, and free sweets too
fields.standfirst: Felix Gonzalez-Torres had the strangest way of dealing with sex and sickness and death, writes  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Felix Gonzalez-Torres had the strangest way of dealing with sex and sickness and death, writes Adrian Searle
fields.body:
Strings of ordinary lightbulbs on white plastic flex, hung like flowers on dangling vines and festooned from the ceiling, in celebration of nothing at all. A low and vacant plinth, waiting for something to happen, with more lightbulbs glowing around its edge, a tawdry halo of expectancy. A lone and distant bird in a high white sky, a huge distance caught in the camera's eye. Blue curtains sifting blue light on to a blue mirror, veiling the world outside and spilling over the silver cellophane wrappers of thousands of sweets. Walk through a blue and white bead curtain, and think for a moment that it could almost be rain (it is called Water). This is the work of Felix Gonzalez-Torres, currently at the Serpentine and on billboards around London (a single unexplained image - two dented pillows side by side, rumpled sheets, the aftermath of sleep or sex).

There are more works, discretely displayed in the Print Room at the V&A, and in the studios of the Royal College of Art across the way. More lightbulbs, too, strung out on Finchley Road near Camden Arts Centre, competing with north London streetlights and traffic lights, headlights and noise.

Whenever one reads about him, one is told that a spirit of generosity pervades Gonzalez-Torres's work, and that his work is of seminal importance. Julia Peyton-Jones, director of the Serpentine, goes so far as to claim that he was one of the most important artists of the 20th century. Lightbulbs, beads and sheer blue curtains, a number of newspaper-cutting jigsaws in plastic bags, a few photos, an endless supply of sweets (courtesy of Marks and Spencer), and some stacks of posters you can take away - the claim, surely, is going it a bit.

Something is missing. Gonzalez-Torres, born in Cuba in 1957, raised in Spain and Puerto Rico, spent his working life in the US, where he died in 1996: a career and a life cut short by Aids. Justifying the "generosity" of Gonzalez-Torres's work, or its continuing significance, requires a little more than trust in the artist's intentions, or in the critical and curatorial affidavits filed in his name. Does his generosity go further than offering sweets to strangers? You can fill your pockets with them, and take any number of posters from the perfectly aligned stacks on the floor. For once no one will stop you, and however minimal and pure these arrangements of things might look, you won't make a dent in the heaps and piles and stacks. What you get with Gonzalez-Torres is a kind of deceptive minimalism, re-done in the wrong materials. Whatever you take will be replaced. And what exactly have you got, rolled-up in your hand, or soft on your tongue?

"Without the public these works are nothing," he said. "I need the public to complete the work. I ask the public to help me, to take responsibility, to become part of my work, to join in." He said the sweets were a kind of gift - perhaps even a kind of profane communion wafer. Eating them becomes an act of transubstantiation. "You put it in your mouth and you suck on someone else's body, and in this way my work becomes part of so many other people's bodies. For just a few seconds, I have put something sweet in someone's mouth, and that is very sexy."

Sexy maybe, but also kind of deathly - the pile of endlessly replenished green sweets in a sugar candy corner between the walls and floor weighs in at 75lbs, the weight of the artist's lover, sick with Aids. The silver carpet of sweets on the gallery floor weighs a ton, and is called Placebo. Nothing is got for nothing. Like the public "Carrying" performances of the late Pepe Espaliu, in which the artist was passed along the street by a procession of friends and supporters, Gonzalez-Torres's sexy gifts can be understood in terms of disease and its transmission, as well as savoured in terms of an immediate pleasure, a sugar-rush. Illness is not a metaphor, but art always is, as it deals in the slippery language of things and images, stories and presences, things that are never quite themselves. Gonzalez-Torres understood this. His work was autobiographical, poetic and, however much grounded in the severities of theory, always open to the exigencies of real life and lived experience.

One might think of his work in terms of a lightness of materials, and light-handedness in their use and display. The things he used were commonplace and ephemeral but like those planets where a thimble-full of matter weighs thousands of kilos, his work also had an unrelieving density of meaning. This is the point at which Gonzalez-Torres begins to reveal himself, and earns our respect. He makes many of his peers and followers look obvious and banal, even when he himself worked with things that seemed more banal than most. His work was allusive, deceptive, tactful.

Gonzalez-Torres makes repeated reference to homoerotic desire: two identical, untitled metal rings on the wall; two dented pillows on a rumpled bed; two identical clocks placed side by side, set to precisely the same time, in perfect synchronicity. Two the same, together. The metaphor could not be plainer, or so understated. Two rings, two clocks, two nests of lightbulbs, two mirrors - Gonzales-Torres entertained the notion that these simple forms, at once resonant of the reserve and simplicity of the post-minimal gesture, could also be taken as deeply sexualised images, but ones that apoplectic congressmen could not condemn, unlike, say, images of two men having sex.

Gonzalez-Torres was all for the multiplicity of readings his art still provokes. He knew that context slanted reason, that the narratives the audience bought to his works completed them. One needs to speak of his body of work as though it were an actual body. And of its place alongside other works, other artists and intentions, as among other bodies, other consciences.

Part of his strength lay in what I can only call his disguise of passivity, the fluidity of his approach. His work makes me think of a man threading his way through a crowd, at once anonymous and particular. For a while he worked as a waiter and would come home and surf the TV channels. "Everything," he said, "boiled down to the same level of meaninglessness... the most horrific news next to the most glamorous gold ring next to the most glamorous celebrity next to cooking oil."

He began to make word-portraits and lists, charting the flow of global news events alongside personal milestones and memories. These text pieces were too resonant and elegiac to be mere footnotes. As well as a number of texts set out on shiny black photostat paper (the screen is empty, but the news rolls on), one text runs around the inner lip of the Serpentine's cupola. "Watercolors 1964. Blue Lake 1986. Our Own Apt. 1976. Ross 1983. Black Monday 1987. The World I Knew Is Gone 1991." He marks the fall of the Berlin wall, the foundation of the UN, vivid personal moments, deaths, places. Somewhere among the rolling news headlines we find equivalents to Citizen Kane's Rosebud, Proust's soggy madeleine.

The vacant plinth stands directly below this text. Hang around long enough and that empty dias with its corona of footlights will eventually be occupied, by a man in gold lamé trunks, go-go dancing to music only he can hear on his personal stereo. The performance lasts just five minutes, at an unappointed time, every single day. You might catch it, you might miss it. You are here anyway. Is this a good place to be? In the next room two stacks of posters, waist-high, stand together, the sheaves replenished every day. One poster says, "Nowhere better than this place". The other, "Somewhere better than this place". Some things you can take with you.

 At the Serpentine Gallery, London W2 (020 7402 6075), till July 16.

fields.headline: Like a virgin?
fields.standfirst: Yours for £7.5m. That's what Britney Spears has been offered to have sex for the first time.  Polly Vernon considers the price still put on maidenhood
fields.trailText: Yours for £7.5m. That's what Britney Spears has been offered to have sex for the first time.  Polly Vernon considers the price still put on maidenhood
fields.body:
Where was Lynda Lee-Potter when her readers needed her? Yesterday may not have been her allotted day to spout bile from the bowels of the Daily Mail, but how else were her legion fans to make it through without her pronouncement on the Britney Spears virginity bid farrago?

For those among you who weren't entirely wrapped up in yesterday's showbiz news, the story goes something like this. Late last week, a mystery businessman contacted Britney's record company and offered £7.5m to relieve the pneumatic teen of her virginity. Gossip suggests adenoidal radio anarchist Howard Stern was involved.

Britney has reacted with predictable crossness. "It's a disgusting offer," she told one newspaper. "He should go and have a cold shower and leave me alone. It's outrageous how a man like that can offer something which is totally unacceptable."

Now, as odd as the very format of the request is (why did the man approach her record company? Is that etiquette for this type of thing? And why did the record company tell Britney? Did they think she might say yes? And how did the story leak out? Surely it wasn't a cynical marketing ploy?), it does, for once, say as much about the unwitting object of the offer as it does about the strange condition of the male psyche. Britney Spears swirls her virginity about like a tasselled nipple. She doesn't believe in sex before marriage. She goes out with boys, but they only kiss. She fully intends to Wait. Her sexual inexperience is infinitely more titillating than the manicured, PR-generated excuse for sluttiness that she totes about in her videos. Or rather, it's the clash between her protested sexual inexperience, her God-fearing, clean-livin', ex-Disney Club-presenting public persona and the other, school uniform-wearing, Rolling Stone cover-posing pop persona that teases, inflames, thrills.

"I'm not that innocent," sings a pink rubber catsuited Britney in her latest video. Yet real-life Britney distances herself from this manipulating minx in assorted interviews. Can you adopt an entirely different sexual MO in a pop song? Is that pop protocol? Maybe not, but Britney does it anyway.

Which explains why so many are having problems forming a line on Britney. Is she a surgically enhanced, cock-teasing hussy? Or is she a solid, moral, Christian role model, a vast improvement on the Spice Girls, the anti-Madonna, if you like? The Daily Mail is at a loss.

Of course, the truly vile part of Britney's uniquely confused and confusing sexuality is that men find it so utterly intoxicating. For Britney's reconstructed virginity is indeed pressing men's buttons. More so than her just-above-average prettiness and her fresh-faced, collagen plump youth might lead you to expect. Why else offer £7.5m to take it?

Is a woman's virginity still so prized - in these most modern of modern times? Even now, days after the nation's most notorious fictional 13-year-old, Coronation Street's Sarah Louise Platt, gave birth to a girl and named her, most inappropriately, after Britney herself? Didn't we move on from this? Or was sexual liberation merely, as a French (male) friend once informed me, a phase women went through in the 60s?

Never mind last decade's sad little flirtation with female sexual bravado. Never mind the proverbial ladettes parading round Ibiza's most debauched nooks and crannies, steeped in distinctly non-virginal sexual promise, downing pints before roughly pleasuring pretty groupies against the side of their rented white-washed fincas . That's over now. What a 21st-century boy wants, apparently, is an old-fashioned gal. He wants the eternal prom queen who will never quite put out.

The infinite marketability of Britney Spears' virginity is what elevates her above teen queen sensation pretenders Christina Aguilera, Jessica Simpson and Billie Piper. It's what makes her videos so exciting - she doesn't really know what she's doing, or singing, or how she's thrilling her boy fans with her customised school uniform. She is that innocent.

All of which might explain why Britney really rebuffed this most ungallant of businessmen. Intact, her virginity is worth millions more than the paltry seven and a half on offer, both to her and to her record company. It's her USP. Without it, she's just another blonde piece. Although there's an outside possibility she's serious about marrying Prince William.
