"I'm not that innocent," sings a pink rubber catsuited Britney in her latest video. Yet real-life Britney distances herself from this manipulating minx in assorted interviews. Can you adopt an entirely different sexual MO in a pop song? Is that pop protocol? Maybe not, but Britney does it anyway. Which explains why so many are having problems forming a line on Britney. Is she a surgically enhanced, cock-teasing hussy? Or is she a solid, moral, Christian role model, a vast improvement on the Spice Girls, the anti-Madonna, if you like? The Daily Mail is at a loss. Of course, the truly vile part of Britney's uniquely confused and confusing sexuality is that men find it so utterly intoxicating. For Britney's reconstructed virginity is indeed pressing men's buttons. More so than her just-above-average prettiness and her fresh-faced, collagen plump youth might lead you to expect. Why else offer £7.5m to take it? Is a woman's virginity still so prized - in these most modern of modern times? Even now, days after the nation's most notorious fictional 13-year-old, Coronation Street's Sarah Louise Platt, gave birth to a girl and named her, most inappropriately, after Britney herself? Didn't we move on from this? Or was sexual liberation merely, as a French (male) friend once informed me, a phase women went through in the 60s? Never mind last decade's sad little flirtation with female sexual bravado. Never mind the proverbial ladettes parading round Ibiza's most debauched nooks and crannies, steeped in distinctly non-virginal sexual promise, downing pints before roughly pleasuring pretty groupies against the side of their rented white-washed fincas . That's over now. What a 21st-century boy wants, apparently, is an old-fashioned gal. He wants the eternal prom queen who will never quite put out. The infinite marketability of Britney Spears' virginity is what elevates her above teen queen sensation pretenders Christina Aguilera, Jessica Simpson and Billie Piper. It's what makes her videos so exciting - she doesn't really know what she's doing, or singing, or how she's thrilling her boy fans with her customised school uniform. She is that innocent. All of which might explain why Britney really rebuffed this most ungallant of businessmen. Intact, her virginity is worth millions more than the paltry seven and a half on offer, both to her and to her record company. It's her USP. Without it, she's just another blonde piece. Although there's an outside possibility she's serious about marrying Prince William.

fields.headline: Sold... or sold out?
fields.standfirst: A room - but not of her own.  Maggie O'Farrell on the feminist leap of faith that is buying a house with a man
fields.trailText: A room - but not of her own.  Maggie O'Farrell on the feminist leap of faith that is buying a house with a man
fields.body:
I can pinpoint the moment it all started - two weeks ago, early afternoon. I was leaning over a desk, writing a cheque, made out to my boyfriend, for my entire life savings. It was for my share of the deposit on a house we were buying together. This money is what I have always privately referred to as My Running Away Fund, an economic safety net should my current domestic or emotional set-up require me to make a sharp exit. And here I was suddenly handing it over to... a man.

This was the final stage in a decision I'd obviously reached over a long period of time; buying a house is not something even the most organised people can effect in a few days. So did I proceed in a mature and thoughtful fashion? Did I accompany him nicely to the bank? Did I start happily choosing blinds and flooring for our love nest? No. My own personal Ms Hyde took up residence and I treated him to the entire repertoire - furious ranting on irrelevant matters, petulant fight-picking, seething silence or irritable monosyllables, aggressive housework. In short, I metamorphosed into the harridan from hell.

It took me a while to work out the reason for my unpleasant behaviour. It wasn't the idea of cohabiting that was bothering me - we have, after all, been living together for a year. It wasn't that I didn't like the house. It wasn't even that estate agents seemed to be incapable of getting their heads around the fact that I don't have the same surname as him. (If I'd been given a tenner for the number of times I answered the phone and had to say, no, they couldn't speak to my husband because I didn't have one, I could have bought the whole street.) And it certainly wasn't any form of what people coyly refer to as cold feet. This wasn't a seizure of doubt about him. It was, I realised one night after a particularly striking display of sour-lemon temperament, an ideological crisis, feminist vertigo.

Feminism has been a cause close to my heart since I was nine, when I wanted to know why boys got to do cycling proficiency classes while we were forced to embroider Xs on to bits of gingham. What had turned me into a snarling monster was a sudden fear that I was not only abandoning the cause but ignoring its lessons.

Women since before Virginia Woolf have been telling us that shacking up with a man is Wrong. The money I handed over to my boyfriend is the economic representation of my whole life, right from money given at my christening, to savings from teenage waitressing jobs, to whatever slices of various salaries I could afford to put by, to the advance for my first novel. In turning all this over to him and committing myself to a shared space, I was, these eminent thinkers assured me, relinquishing my autonomy, my independence. I'd set myself full-tilt on a very slippery slope, at the bottom of which was me, chained to the dishwasher, manacled to the cooker, condemned to ironing his socks into Sisyphean eternity. I'd have no time for my own work. Forget the pram: this was the man in the hallway and he was a far more sinister figure.

Or was he? When I'd steeled myself for a confrontation, I went to look for my boyfriend. What I found didn't exactly match up with the terrible Brocken Spectre of misogyny I'd conjured up in my fevered imagination: he was standing in the kitchen cooking our dinner. While I delivered my speech, he listened, simultaneously clearing the table, getting out plates, dishing up the food and laying out cutlery. When I'd finished, he looked both surprised and relieved. "I wondered what was wrong with you," he said, dishtowel in hand.

But this is not a happy ending to a story of paranoid stupidity. I've realised that my confused tantrums point to a strange hole in current feminist thought. The message of contemporary gender politics - post-feminism, post-laddism, girl power, call it what you will - is that you can do whatever you want. The age of empowerment has given us that right. It's OK, we are told, to wear make-up, have a job, have sex. But what happens if you do all those things but just prefer your sex with the one man - and buy a house together to do it in? Is this really that antithetical to the lipstick-toting feminism of today?

There are no role models offered, no theories posited on how to handle this. From Elizabeth Wurtzel, a woman who poses nude for her books in what we are told is the spirit of irony, we get Bitch Rules on how to rationalise having a cleaner and not helping our fellow females to wash up after a dinner party, while Professor Greer incites a wide debate on the wearing (or not) of pants.

It seems to me that somewhere along the line, theory has been dislodged from reality. What feminism needs to catch up with and adjust to is the generation of men that have been brought up within its strictures. My boyfriend and others like him have been raised by liberated, emancipated women with their own careers and their own lives. This is not to say that all blokes whose birth certificates postdate 1970 are OK, so our struggle is at an end. Far from it. But we need to face the fact that there is a whole group of men out there who have grown up with gender equality as not just an idea but a reality as pervasive and integral as the air they breathe.

My point is that the feminists of the 60s and 70s did their job and did it well, in the process moulding not only their daughters but also their sons into something new. We should surely be recognising and rejoicing in that not inconsiderable success, not continuing to penalise and punish these men for the sins of their fathers. Aren't we otherwise clinging on principle to what can often seem outmoded prejudices? Generational inheritance is feminism's strongest constituency. If we oust this select group of men from the environment in which they grew up, purely on the basis of their gender, we're getting on to the dangerous ground of replicating misogyny in reverse. Perhaps we should think about allowing them back into the rooms of our own for short visits every once in a while.

fields.headline: No:1650: Jaid Barrymore
fields.trailText: Oh dear, another Barrymore tale of drugs, drink and general excess. Not quite. Now it's Drew's mother, Jaid, complaining that her daughter hasn't spoken to her for four years.
fields.body:
Oh dear, another Barrymore tale of drugs, drink and general excess. Not quite. Now it's Drew's mother, Jaid, complaining that her daughter hasn't spoken to her for four years.

Selfish child! Apparently, Drew was a little annoyed when Jaid auctioned her daughter's babyclothes over the internet. Posing for Playboy in 1995 - nine months after her daughter - caused some friction, and trying to steal Drew's boyfriends didn't go down too well either.

Quick biog, please. Born Ildiko Jaid in Munich, she worked her way across America in various nightclubs before meeting John Drew Barrymore, the son of a famous actor, in a club on Sunset Strip. She was manager to her daughter before the relationship took a downturn and the then 15-year-old Drew sued.

So how is Mrs Barrymore trying to reconcile with Drew? She has taken the touchingly maternal approach of publishing a book about her ungrateful daughter and useless husband.

And what is the title of this confidence-breaking autobiography? Um, In Confidential.

I seem to remember having read something else by Jaid Barrymore... Ah yes, that would have been Secrets of World Class Lovers: Erotic Tips & Sensual Stories for a Lifetime of Sexual Fulfilment.

Did she learn these tips from Drew's father? Unlikely. His (apparently successful) chat-up line to Jaid was: "You are the brood mare I have spent my entire life looking for."

Charming. The beginning of a long and happy relationship, then. Not quite. The romantic pair split up before Drew was born, and John Drew has been enjoying the hospitality of various rehab centres for the past 10 years.

But surely Jaid is proud of her successful offspring? Her comment, "I was going to be the star, not her! Drew got all the attention... It was so disgusting," would suggest not.

Drew's response? "You don't want guys like these to be your mom and dad."

Don't say: "You must be so proud of Drew, Mrs Barrymore."

webTitle: Parker's pieces: Cambridge library to go public

fields.headline: Parker's pieces: Cambridge library to go public
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of the richest and least known medieval libraries, the Parker collection at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, will be rehoused and opened to the public for the first time in a £20m project announced yesterday.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
One of the richest and least known medieval libraries, the Parker collection at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, will be rehoused and opened to the public for the first time in a £20m project announced yesterday.

There is room in the present library for just four scholars a day, and the public is never admitted.

For book enthusiasts the best chance of seeing one of the greatest treasures is when a new Archbishop of Canterbury is enthroned. The 6th century gospel given by Pope Gregory to Saint Augustine to take with him to convert the heathen English is then sent for a day to Canterbury Cathedral.

The library's extraordinary books include an 8th century Northumberland gospel, the two volume 13th century history of the world made by Matthew Paris at St Albans, which includes his drawing of the first elephant in England at the Tower of London, and the oldest known manuscript of the Anglo-Saxon chronicles, including an eyewitness account of the Battle of Hastings in 1066.

The collection of 600 manuscripts and 20,000 printed books was made in the 1560s by Matthew Parker, co-founder of the Church of England, archbishop of Canterbury and former master of the college. He was shocked by the carelessness of college libraries, and left his books to Corpus Christi with strings: if it ever lost 16 little books, 12 big books or six very big books, it would lose the bequest.

Parker collected his books in the wake of the destruction of libraries during Henry VIII's dissolution of the monasteries. Parker entered folklore as Nosey Parker, when, with a warrant from Queen Elizabeth, he sent his agents scouring the country to collect books.

The £20m will pay for a three-storey library with exhibition space, a conservation centre, and for digitisation - the entire collection is to be put on the internet.

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: Riots in Nigeria after petrol rise
fields.body:
Riots in Nigeria after petrol rise

Anti-government riots erupted in cities in south-west Nigeria yesterday after a 50% rise in fuel prices as a result of a cut in subsidies, witnesses said.

Students and workers went on the rampage in the cities of Abeokuta and Ibadan, about 35 miles and 70 miles north of Lagos, respectively. Witnesses said police fired teargas. Nigerians say the fuel increase has pushed up the price of other goods and services.

Expo protests block rail line

Anti-capitalist opponents of Germany's Expo 2000 world fair threw grappling hooks on to overhead electricity cables on the Hamburg-Hanover high-speed rail link yesterday, blocking the line for three hours.

Border guards said the hooks caused a goods train to pull down a cable near the town of Garssen. A note bearing the slogan "Expo No" was found at the scene.

Stampede kills 14 in Ethiopia

Fourteen children died and 67 others were injured yesterday during a stampede at a memorial service for Ethiopian victims of their war against Eritrea.

The stampede broke out when rain started falling at the Addis Ababa amphitheatre, where thousands of students were watching a cultural show.

Stowaways die on plane

Two men were found dead in the undercarriage of a plane at Stockholm's Arlanda airport, police said yesterday. The Premiaer plane landed on Sunday after a trip to Greece. Documents suggested the men came from the Dominican Republic, where the plane touched down last Friday.

webTitle: Camilla holds secret talks with Carey

fields.headline: Camilla holds secret talks with Carey
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Camilla Parker Bowles has held secret talks with the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, to discuss her relationship with the Prince of Wales, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Camilla Parker Bowles has held secret talks with the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, to discuss her relationship with the Prince of Wales, it was revealed yesterday.

Officials at Lambeth Palace said Dr Carey did not discuss pastoral matters concerning individuals, but sources claimed there had been at least six meetings at his residence and in the west country. They were also understood to have discussed matters of faith but not the subject of marriage.

The revelations came on top of feverish speculation about the prospect of a royal wedding after the rapprochement between the Queen and Mrs Parker Bowles on Saturday.

The 10-minute meeting at Highgrove, the prince's Gloucestershire home, was seen as the first step in drawing his mistress into an official royal role, a move which opens up the prospect of a wedding and a future Queen Camilla.

News of the event prompted bookmakers to slash the odds for a royal marriage down from 3-1 to 6-4. Yet two opinion polls yesterday made it clear that while Britons are slowly growing to accept the idea of Mrs Parker Bowles as the Prince of Wales's future wife, the vast majority will never accept the divorcee on the British throne.

Nevertheless, she is now certain to be among the 500 family and friends invited to the Queen Mother's 100th birthday party at Windsor on June 21.

Schooled as she is in the intricacies of royal choreography, Mrs Parker Bowles is expected to "tactfully decline" for fear that her presence upstages the Queen Mother.

Instead the Queen and Mrs Parker Bowles will meet again briefly this summer while the royal family holidays at Balmoral, and further meetings are likely to follow.

While broadsheets were more concerned with the implications of a second marriage for the Prince of Wales's role as supreme governor of the Church of England and moves by the church to open the way for the prince, as a divorcee, to remarry, the tabloids were preoccupied with grassroots opinion.

The Mirror announced the results of a poll, under the headline Marry Her, which found 77% of those polled approved of Saturday's meeting, while 68% want the couple to marry. Prince Charles was advised, though, to take heed that 83% still insist that Mrs Parker Bowles should never become queen. But an Express telephone poll brought bleaker news with 70% opposed to them marrying.

Newspapers also differed on the question of when any marriage might take place. The Sun appeared keen for an early wedding, urging Prince Charles to "be honest with the people" as his "best path to the throne" and "gamble his place in history by marrying Camilla".

The Times predicted a wedding within five years, following expected moves by the Church of England to allow divorcees to remarry in church. But both the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph were more circumspect, the Mail urging caution and the Telegraph calling for a slower process of "acclimatisation".

The development of the royal relationship will be, the Telegraph's editorial pointed out, "not so much a moral matter as one of taste and tact".

webTitle: British theatre a hit on Broadway

fields.headline: British theatre a hit on Broadway
fields.trailText: Michael Blakemore, the Australian director who does most of his work in Britain, scored at the Tony awards for best director both of a play and of a musical, marking a first in the 54-year-old history of the competition.
fields.body:
Michael Blakemore, the Australian director who does most of his work in Britain, scored at the Tony awards for best director both of a play and of a musical, marking a first in the 54-year-old history of the competition.

British theatre triumphed on a wide stage, winning almost half the main Broadway theatre awards, including those for best play, revival, actor, and actress.

Tom Stoppard's The Real Thing took the prize for best revival, confirming a long-running Broadway love affair with the work, which won a Tony for best play in 1984.

Its stars, Stephen Dillane and Jennifer Ehle, were presented with the top acting prizes, also a reprise of the original, for which Jeremy Irons and Glenn Close were honoured.

Ehle's victory marked another first, mother and daughter competing for the actress award. "We never thought either of us was going to win," said 30-year-old Ehle, star of the BBC's version of Pride and Prejudice and daughter of Rosemary Harris, 69, who was nominated for Waiting In The Wings. "We thought we would just come and enjoy ourselves. We had no feeling we were in competition with each other."

Blakemore showed his appreciation saying that winning two prizes was "like having twins - you get it all over at once".

webTitle: Banker spends millions to win Senate nomination

fields.headline: Banker spends millions to win Senate nomination
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Jon Corzine is expected to spend more than $2m of his own money today running for a US Senate nomination, a figure that confirms the former Wall Street wizard as a political record-breaker.
fields.body:
Jon Corzine is expected to spend more than $2m of his own money today running for a US Senate nomination, a figure that confirms the former Wall Street wizard as a political record-breaker.

Mr Corzine has already spent more than $31m (£20m) in the run-up to today's vote in New Jersey, all but $3m of which has come from his own pocket.

Today's spending is set to trump the $1.9m raised by Jim Florio, his rival for the Democratic party nomination, at the last count. No other contestant in a US Senate primary has ever spent as much money.

The race, condemned by supporters of campaign finance reform, is also seen as a test of public opinion on Wall Street. Mr Corzine, a 25-year veteran with Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, had never held political office before deciding to stand for one of the highest posts in the land.

On the campaign trail a few days ago, Mr Corzine, 52, seemed disappointed by all the attention being paid to his finances. After telling a crowd of local union workers with an average annual wage of $25,000 that he would fight for a living wage, he was asked by a local reporter whether he was trying to buy votes.

The candidate said quietly: "It's not about buying an election, it's about making a difference." He started to talk about justice when he was asked whether he had paid for a slap-up banquet for 800 people the night before.

Peter Eisner, the managing director of the Centre for Public Integrity, has criticised the campaign for "showing that you've got to be a millionaire to run for Congress and above".

The money being spent by Mr Corzine may have handed a ready weapon to his opponent. Yet the most recent opinion polls suggest that the people of New Jersey do not care. A Quinnipiac College poll two weeks ago put Mr Corzine 26 percentage points ahead of Mr Florio in the race, with 56% of the vote.

Mr Florio, hampered as much as helped by his almost 30-year record as a local politician, has used Mr Corzine's record as a banker to hit at his opponent.

The problem for Mr Florio is two-fold. The first is that New Jersey, with its large commuting workforce, is probably more dependent on Wall Street than most states. The second is that Mr Corzine, to the left of Mr Florio on many issues, from gun control to healthcare, is more the embodiment of the American dream than an evil trader.

Although he ended up with a fortune estimated at more than $400m, Mr Corzine started life on an Illinois farm. He went to the state university after taking his first job at 13.

He started at Goldman in 1975 as a lowly trader and moved to New Jersey to live an apparently exemplary life with his wife and three children.

On Wall Street, few speak ill of the man, apart from the odd snide remark about his beard and his habit of wearing tank tops. His generosity is also renowned. He paid for a college education for a secretary's son and gave the widow of a friend $500,000.

Mr Corzine, who was ousted in a boardroom coup last year, was credited with making sure that the riches resulting from the eventual stock market listing of Goldman Sachs filtered down to as many of its employees as possible.

His standard line about his spending is that he needs to raise his profile against a well-known candidate, and that at least he will be independent of the "special interests" which plague US politics. Asked whether politics or finance was the dirtier game, he said that neither was "fundamentally dirty".

If Mr Corzine wins today's primary vote, he will go on to fight the Republican candidate in November. "And they usually outspend Democrats by five to one," he pointed out.

webTitle: Earthquake kills at least 58 in Sumatra

fields.headline: Earthquake kills at least 58 in Sumatra
fields.standfirst:
World-Wide Earthquake Locator
USGS Earthquake Information
fields.trailText: At least 58 people died and hundreds were injured when a powerful earthquake and hundreds of strong aftershocks struck the Indonesian island of Sumatra late on Sunday night, officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
At least 58 people died and hundreds were injured when a powerful earthquake and hundreds of strong aftershocks struck the Indonesian island of Sumatra late on Sunday night, officials said yesterday.

Damage was reported in six provinces on the island, with thousands made homeless.

Widespread panic was reported in Bengkulu, a province of about 1.2m people, as rescuers dug through the rubble of ruined buildings in search of bodies and trapped survivors.

"Many houses have collapsed, and the walls on bigger buildings have been fractured. I helped save three of my neighbours who were trapped under rubble," said Edy, a resident of Bengkulu town, 60 miles east of the quake's epicentre.

Initial reports said Enggano island, about 125 miles south-east of Bengkulu town, the provincial capital, was also badly hit. "About 90% of the houses on the island were damaged," said Ali Muchtar, the head of Bengkulu's health department.

The Indonesian meteorological and geophysical service said the quake, measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale, struck at 11.29pm local time and lasted for several minutes. The US Geological Survey in Golden, Colorado, estimated its magnitude as 7.9.

Mr Muchtar said that 58 people were confirmed dead. Almost 500 people were reported injured, 255 of them seriously. With communications to many parts of the province cut, the death toll is expected to rise.

Doctors in Bengkulu town treated victims in a parking lot, fearing that aftershocks might bring down the state hospital, the official Antara news agency reported. Mr Muchtar said that the hospital had been badly damaged.

Electricity and water supplies were cut and many telephone lines were down in the town of about 250,000 people. Local authorities said that power would not be restored for at least a week.

A magnitude 6 aftershock hit 11 minutes after the quake, and more than 260 smaller tremors were recorded in the area yesterday, Indonesian seismologists said.

webTitle: Row over Bulger killers in secure unit

fields.headline: Row over Bulger killers in secure unit
fields.trailText: The confirmation yesterday that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of James Bulger, will remain in a local authority secure unit until they are at least 19, has been welcomed by penal reformers.
fields.body:
The confirmation yesterday that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of James Bulger, will remain in a local authority secure unit until they are at least 19, has been welcomed by penal reformers.

The National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders said that the prison system was far less able to provide treatment and therapy needed by serious young offenders and progress was often eroded when they were transferred to a prison.

But Denise Fergus, the murdered boy's mother, and police officers involved in the case, said changes were needed in the prison service if it could not deal with the youths.

Prison service sources confirmed that it is likely that Thompson and Venables, who were jailed for life in 1993, will stay in local authority care until they 19. They will then face transfer to a young offenders' institution run by the prison service if they have not completed the minimum sentence which is to be announced by the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, before they reach their 18th birthdays this August.

The youths would remain in the young offender institution until they are 21 when they would face transfer to an adult prison.

Norman Brennan, director of the Victims of Crime Trust, said that Mrs Fergus regarded the move as unwelcome. "Denise says that one would expect those convicted of the most heinous crime possible - murder - that there would be punishment as well as rehabilitation.

"All we have heard about is rehabilitation and it appears that Venables and Thompson haven't been punished. It sets the wrong precedent for other child criminals."

Former detective superintendent Albert Kirby said the decision did not take into account public feelings and the feelings of the Bulger family. "Why should they continue to bend the rules and set precedents? At the end of the day it's going to affect around 120 other young offenders."

Thompson's solicitor, Dominic Lloyd, said: "Anyone in their situation would be transferred somewhere between 18 and 19 years of age and not go to adult prison until they are 21. Both boys are aware of the situation and of what the future holds for them."

webTitle: Bush and Gore reach primary finishing line

fields.headline: Bush and Gore reach primary finishing line
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Only a handful of the faithful will bother to turn out. The media's big guns will not be there and will barely give it a mention. Nevertheless, today is a milestone for the US presidential contenders, Al Gore and George W Bush.
fields.body:
Only a handful of the faithful will bother to turn out. The media's big guns will not be there and will barely give it a mention. Nevertheless, today is a milestone for the US presidential contenders, Al Gore and George W Bush.

The Gore and Bush campaigns effectively wrapped up their party nominations on March 7, defeating challenges from Bill Bradley and John McCain in the "super Tuesday" primaries. But in the weeks since then, the two candidates have still had to criss-cross the US, rallying support in primaries which long ago became one-horse races.

That process reaches the finishing line today, with the season's last five primaries. In Alabama, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota, loyalists will cast their votes and complete the process which will be endorsed at party conventions in August.

The dynamics of the nomination race mean that only a minority of states held contests which had a true bearing on the result. Since March 7 the remaining states - and the candidates - have had to go through the motions.

Turnouts have slumped, even though voters in the primaries also have the chance to select Senate and state candidates for dozens of other posts.

"We could have had a very timely impact on the presidential race if this primary had been in February or early March. But once again we find ourselves behind the curve and out of the action," said Stephen Flance, a Bill Bradley supporter from New Mexico.

The calendar has been particularly cruel to Mr Bradley, whose home state of New Jersey brings up the rear. Ever since he pulled out of the race in March, he has stayed out of sight, declining interviews and refusing to endorse Mr Gore, who beat him to the Democratic nomination.

The Republican loser, John McCain, has been more in evidence, playing a prominent role back in the US Senate, leading a visit to Vietnam, and meeting Mr Bush in a bid to iron out their differences.

webTitle: Clinton's parting words leave Moscow cold

fields.headline: Clinton's parting words leave Moscow cold
fields.standfirst: The president's trip to Europe
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton said yesterday that as he neared the end of his eight years in the White House, he did not know whether Washington and Moscow would be friends or foes, making it plain that he was unsure where Russia was heading under Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton said yesterday that as he neared the end of his eight years in the White House, he did not know whether Washington and Moscow would be friends or foes, making it plain that he was unsure where Russia was heading under Vladimir Putin.

In a muted, slightly melancholy 44-minute speech to the duma, the Russian parliament, Mr Clinton reflected on the past decade of tumultuous upheaval in Russia, preached the gospel of globalisation to its suffering people and called on its new leadership to make the right choices to cement partnership with the west.

"We are not destined to be adversaries. But it is not guaranteed we will be allies," the president said at the end of a trip that included his first formal summit with Mr Putin and was noteworthy for the lack of warmth between the two men.

"All my life I have wanted the people of my country and the people of your country to be friends and allies, to lead the world away from war towards the dreams of children. I have done my best to do that."

It was Mr Clinton's fifth and final visit to Russia as president, and yesterday's speech was the first time a US president had addressed the duma. But the wistful, elegiac character of Mr Clinton's valedictory speech failed to elicit a sense of occasion from his audience.

Mr Putin did not attend, leaving for Italy and a meeting last night with the Pope. Dozens of seats in the parliament were vacant. No applause interrupted the speech, and only brief, half-hearted, clapping was heard at the end.

Nationalists and communists protested outside the duma in support of Saddam Hussein and Slobodan Milosevic, while inside, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the ultra-nationalist, heckled Mr Clinton.

Weightier figures such as Boris Gryzlov, a key lieutenant of Mr Putin in parliament, and Andrei Nikolayev, the head of the duma defence committee, were either angry or dismissive of the Clinton speech.

"We have to learn to identify and manage our disagreements because the relationship is profoundly important to the future," Mr Clinton advised. "Our interests are not identical and we will have our inevitable disagreements."

He urged the new Russian government to diversify its economy, establish new tax and property laws, and tackle crime and corruption, all to make Russia more attractive to foreign investors.

"The people of Russia do not yet have the Russia they were promised in 1991," he said, saying it was difficult to "weigh the gains of freedom against the pains of economic hardship, corruption and crime".

In a direct reference to Mr Putin's pledge to restore order and stability, Mr Clinton said: "The answer to law without order is not order without law."

Following the speech he briefly visited Boris Yeltsin at his country dacha outside Moscow, quipping that it was "just like old times".

In contrast to the bonhomie and backslapping of the Bill-and-Boris years, there was no first-name greetings between Mr Clinton and Mr Putin, who was described by one US official as a "cold fish".

Since the new year, Mr Putin has set his sights on bonding with Tony Blair, and Downing Street has hailed the instant rapport between the two leaders. But Mr Clinton appeared warier, while Mr Putin was polite but distant, clearly viewing Mr Clinton as a lame duck.

fields.headline: Rail crash driver 'was family man'
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The driver at the centre of the Paddington rail crash was a devoted family man whose criminal record was an embarrassment to him, his widow yesterday told the inquiry into the disaster.
fields.body:
The driver at the centre of the Paddington rail crash was a devoted family man whose criminal record was an embarrassment to him, his widow yesterday told the inquiry into the disaster.

Kerry Hodder, 29, who gave birth to the couple's third child, a girl, last month, said in a written statement that her husband, Michael, "idolised" his two sons.

Mr Hodder, 31, of Tilehurst, Berkshire, died after his Thames train passed a red signal and collided with a Great Western train at Ladbroke Grove last October. Its driver, Brian Cooper, 52, and 29 passengers also died.

Mr Hodder's conviction for common assault and affray, for which he received a conditional discharge, had been out of character, his widow said. In June 1998 he had been arrested over a fight after a girl had spat at his father on a train. "He was embarrassed ... because he was a law-abiding person ... not aggressive unless his family were threatened."

In a separate written statement, Mr Cooper's widow, Carole, of Hayes, west London, said he had been devoted to his three children and two grandchildren.

He had worked for British Rail since 1963. "He did become more concerned when the railways were privatised." He would say that whenever he brought a safety matter to someone's attention "it was always somebody else's job".

fields.headline: Sale of Mrs Simpson's jewels
fields.trailText: A gold powder compact and lipstick holder on which Wallis Simpson mapped her romance with Edward VIII is to be sold later this month.
fields.body:
A gold powder compact and lipstick holder on which Wallis Simpson mapped her romance with Edward VIII is to be sold later this month.

The American divorcee engraved the tiny gem-encrusted box with the routes of their continental holidays together during the summers of 1934, 1935 and 1936 when the then Prince of Wales wooed her.

Patricia Clarke, of Christie's, said the box was an "important and quite emotive historical artefact" which chronicled the development of the royal romance.

The vanity case - which originally went under the hammer during the sale of items from the Windsors' Paris home in 1987 - is expected to make £35,000.

Edward VIII later abdicated so that he could marry her after American newspapers reported how the as yet uncrowned king was travelling openly with his unchaperoned, twice-married mistress.

The British press had studiously ignored the romance as it blossomed over the previous two summers.

The skiing party the prince took to Kitzbühel in the Austrian Tyrol the previous winter, when Mrs Simpson was chaperoned by her Aunt Bessie, is also detailed on the compact and lipstick holder.

Her husband, Ernest Simpson, had been invited to join them on the slopes but declined - ostensibly because of business commitments back home in America.

fields.headline: Come to the fair
fields.standfirst: Town halls urged to foster centuries-old tradition
fields.trailText: Travelling fairs are fun and "immensely valuable in economic, social and historical terms", according to a committee of MPs.
fields.body:
Travelling fairs are fun and "immensely valuable in economic, social and historical terms", according to a committee of MPs.

In a report that is a ringing endorsement of a centuries-old tradition, the Commons environment and regional affairs committee urged local councils to preserve old sites and provide new ones for funfairs.

The MPs said: "It is a foolish local authority which does not do all it can to encourage travelling fairs."

There were some less favourable aspects: "Problems complained of include noise and light pollution; the nuisance of drunken youths urinating or vomiting in areas close to the fairground site; rowdyism; and a popular belief that fairs encourage crime."

Complaints were few compared with the number of fairs. Liverpool, which hosted 12 last year, received only five letters of complaint and eight phone calls.

A survey of chief constables produced no evidence of a rise in crime associated with fairs.

The committee praised Strasbourg, in France, which has provided an area for fairs. "It seemed particularly sad that so many English towns and cities have not followed this example, but have tried to banish fairs to out-of-the-way parts of the town in the expectation that they will fail and the town be rid of the problem," said the MPs.

"We are strongly in favour of an urban renaissance. No large community ought to be without a central focus for public entertainment ... Villages, towns and cities with such spaces ought to ensure they are designed to make holding funfairs easy, with good access to services such as water and electricity, while those which do not have such areas ought to be striving to get them."

The committee was concerned that the sites for showpeople to stay at during winter and stop overnight between fairs were disappearing. It urged the Showman's Guild, which was praised elsewhere for its efforts, to compile reports by region on this problem so the committee could return to the issue before the next general election.

fields.headline: Dolphin glides into ship canal
fields.trailText: It is definitely not the natural habitat of a dolphin - the murky water of the Manchester Ship Canal. But yesterday one of the creatures was spotted swimming there, apparently following a ship close to Runcorn docks, in Cheshire. It is the first time that a dolphin has been seen on the 36-mile stretch of water, and it has also been seen 20 miles away from the start of the canal at Latchford in Warrington.
fields.body:
It is definitely not the natural habitat of a dolphin - the murky water of the Manchester Ship Canal. But yesterday one of the creatures was spotted swimming there, apparently following a ship close to Runcorn docks, in Cheshire. It is the first time that a dolphin has been seen on the 36-mile stretch of water, and it has also been seen 20 miles away from the start of the canal at Latchford in Warrington.

A spokesman for the Manchester Ship Canal Company said the dolphin had probably followed a boat from the Irish Sea into the Mersey and then somehow found its way into the canal.

"One of the staff saw the dolphin playing in the dock area," he said. "We are all amazed and delighted to have it here. The first thing we did was to telephone the RSPCA to see if it would be OK in these waters, but they assured us it would be fine."

He said the appearance of the dolphin was a tribute to the money that had been spent cleaning up the waterway. "It has been around for about a week now and seems to be doing really well. Dolphins love to follow in the wake of ships, so I presume it followed one of the boats in and stayed around."

Mark Simmonds, director of science at the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, said it was probably a bottle nosed dolphin. "Historically, groups of bottle nosed dolphins used to live in estuaries," he said. "They very occasionally go up rivers but they cannot survive there indefinitely out of salt water."

fields.headline: Chat rooms
fields.trailText: Emma Haughton tells all about chat rooms, bulletin boards and electronic mailing lists
fields.body:
The first thing you need to know is the difference between chat rooms, bulletin boards and mailing lists. Chat rooms or online web conferences involve live discussion, and tend to attract more social chat. Bulletin boards are held on websites, and anyone can post comments or read past contributions. Mailing lists require registration; you will be emailed all the contributions sent to the list and can email in your own. Some lists are open to anyone, others grant membership to certain groups. Most keep archives of previous messages.

So what do these discussion forums offer? A chance to share practices, ideas and resources, says Debs Ayerst, education officer at Becta. "They help prevent everyone reinventing the wheel. If you're searching for books for a particular part of the literacy hour, for instance, you may find someone has already looked into it, which can cut out an awful lot of research."

According to Rachel Turner, administrator for the Early Language Learning Forum at the National Advisory Centre on Early Language Learning, which has more than 150 people registered, discussion forums are particularly useful for teachers living in remote areas.

To get started, focus on what you're most interested in, then sign up to a relevant list and lurk around, reading messages, while you decide whether it's for you. And when seeking advice, keep it succinct, advises Turner. "You've got to be quite pertinent otherwise you may get 20 replies that are not relevant."

So what's available? The Virtual Teachers Centre offers conferences covering subjects such as curriculum areas, senior managers, special educational needs, and over 50 mailing lists devoted to a wide range of educational issues. Becta, also offers various SEN and inclusion focused mailing lists.

Mailbase runs many electronic discussion lists for the UK higher education and research community. If it doesn't have a list that interests you, it will help you set one up.

Teachers.net is a US site with a healthy UK contingent.

Otherwise look on Liszt, which has a directory of worldwide mailing lists, including 112 covering education, and some more unusual areas like distance education and home-schooling.

fields.headline: The Holocaust
fields.trailText: The Holocaust doesn't make for easy reading, but it is both an absorbing and profoundly moving subject.
fields.body:
The Holocaust doesn't make for easy reading, but it is both an absorbing and profoundly moving subject. Books about this period in history tried to encapsulate both a factual account of the road to the "Final Solution" and the personal recollections of those who experienced the holocaust first hand.

Never Again: A History of the Holocaust by historian Martin Gilbert (Harper Collins, £19.99) has been published in association with the Imperial War Museum in London to coincide with the opening of their permanent Holocaust exhibition. Gilbert draws upon personal recollections, archive materials and maps to present a full and detailed testimony of the events leading up to and during the Holocaust. The juxtaposition of eye-witness accounts with a chronological explanation of what happened makes for a riveting and moving book. An ideal companion to an in-depth study of the period.

The Imperial War Museum education department have produced their own full colour student guide to the Holocaust exhibition. Called Torn Apart, it is a comprehensive resource pack that tells the story of the Holocaust through photographs, artefacts and personal stories. Designed to stimulate discussion of key issues and to encourage personal reflection, it aims to help young people begin to understand the experiences of those who suffered. (Museum publications: 01223 499345. £2.50 or £1.95 per copy for class sets of 25 or over).

The classic true-life story remains The Diary of a Young Girl by Anne Frank (Puffin, £4.99). In July 1942, Anne and her family, fleeing from the horrors of Nazi occupation, hid in the back of an Amsterdam warehouse. Anne was 13 when this happened, and for the next two years she chronicled the experiences of her family - the frustrations of living in such confined quarters, the constant threat of discovery, hunger and tiredness, and above all, the boredom. She and her family were discovered by the Nazis, and Anne was transported first to Auschwitz, and then Bergen-Belsen, where she died.

Anne Frank Beyond the Diary (Ruud van der Rol and Rian Verhoeven, Puffin, £6.99) provides a wider context for the life of this remarkable young woman. Excerpts from the diary are interwoven with commentary on the historical and political events surrounding her, photographs and the testimony of the people who last saw her and her sister Margot alive.

The foreword to Cirla's Story by Cirla Lewis (Minerva Press, £7.99) begins: "This true story is told so that my son and his generation will not forget the suffering and the courage of those people who lived through the Second World War." The writer uses her recollections to tell both the poignant story of the suffering of her own family in occupied Belgium and Holland, and to bear witness to the tremendous courage of those who were instrumental in saving her from the "clutches of Nazism". A moving, well written account for students from year 9 up.

Another memoir, which would be more appropriate to older teenage readers, is Night by Elie Wiesel (Penguin, £6.99). Born in a Hungarian ghetto in 1928, Wiesel was sent as a child to the Nazi death camps of Auschwitz and Buchenwald. When the camp was finally liberated by American troops, Wiesel remembers that "our first act as free men was to throw ourselves on to provisions. We thought only of that. Not of revenge, not of our families. Nothing but bread." Elie Wiesel was awarded the Noble Peace Prize in 1986.

fields.headline: Chemistry
fields.trailText: Roger Frost rounds up what's out there
fields.body:
Mechanism Movies
***
Aimed at: advanced chemistry (teachers or parents)

A dozen reaction mechanisms, animated as Quicktime movies that take a minute or so to download. This generous gesture from US publishers Jones & Bartlett show exactly who gets what in everyday hydrogenation, bromination and others.

Download.com
***
Aimed at: everyone

Free software! This really is the land of free when you can rummage an end-bin of demonstration and shareware software. Best finds from a search on "chemistry" found a chemical modelling program, a molecules simulator and a lab that does "virtual" experiments and makes apparatus diagrams. Don't expect the best in software, just value for money.

Webelements
**
Aimed at: everyone

If periodic table inventor Mendeleev is ever forgotten, Dr Mark Winter, inventor of its very established online equivalent, will probably take his place. More than just revered, Webelements is used for making element fact cards with Powerpoint and for fill-in the-table exercises on paper. To make life easier, track down Becta's Science Online book for a worksheet

Chemistry Video Consortium/Royal Society of Chemistry
**
Aimed at: teachers

An extraordinarily valuable service, this database helps source images and video tapes about all aspects of chemistry. Even if this does lack lustre, it is now much easier to track down lots of colourful resources, some free, some to buy or loan.

The Comic Book Periodic Table
***
Aimed at: everyone

Remember those fanciful comic book exclamations like, "arrrgh, molybedenum, you've poisoned me!"? Here's a different view of the periodic table of the elements as featured in the genre. Nostalgia and proof to the pupils, if needed, that chemistry teachers are human, or, as here, super-human. You will never think of the elements in the same way again.

Sheffield College Weblinks
****
Aimed at: teachers

Weblinks is a gateway that links to many others. Sheffield College's public-spirited effort categorises what is good for chemistry and adds comments to guide your mouse clicks. If that's not enough of a recommendation, this mostly post-16 site is also a winner of a Becta/ Guardian UK School and College Web Site Award.

International chemical safety cards
***
Aimed at: teachers

Having safety information on the web where it is easy to find and kept bang up to date must be an essential. This site is a great mine of data, not exciting unless read with the wrong intentions towards the autocrat that emptied my cupboard full of fun chemicals.

Ray's Software page
*
Aimed at: teachers

Chemistry teacher Ray Lecouteur has placed his tutorial programs, such as "Atoms, Symbols and Equations", ready for downloading and trialling before buying.

fields.headline: Trouble in paradise
fields.standfirst: As the military once again takes power in Fiji, the idyllic Pacific island faces crisis
fields.trailText: As the military once again takes power in Fiji, the idyllic Pacific island faces crisis
fields.body:
There is trouble in Fiji - a beautiful land of many volcanic and coral islands in the South Pacific. Its coat of arms includes two ferocious warriors and a dove of peace. But in Suva, the capital, there has been little peace recently.

Last week, an armed gang invaded the parliament building, taking the country's prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and 30 other politicians hostage. So far, the group's leader, George Speight, has had all his demands met while the army has used the opportunity to take over the country. Meanwhile, world governments are furious about what has happened and Fiji is at risk of becoming an outcast nation.

What lies behind the crisis?

Land and power. Fiji's present troubles date back to the 19th century, when thousands of Indians were shipped in to work on sugar plantations. To come, they had to agree to stay for at least 10 years and when their contracts ended they usually settled.

Many Indians built businesses while others continued to grow sugar on small parcels of land which they leased, paying rent to the Fijian owners. These arrangements meant that while Fijians had political power and kept their traditions and culture, they were left behind economically. In time the Indians (who make up over 40% of the population, which now totals 0.8m) began to press for greater political rights. When Fiji won its independence from Britain in 1970, Indians were finally allowed to take positions in the government.

All seemed well until 1987, when the Indian-dominated Alliance Party won an election. This was unacceptable to some Fijians and a military coup took place. It has taken Fiji 10 years to return to democracy. This is another reason for the international anger now at the overthrow of the government of Mahendra Chaudhry, who is an Indian.

What does George Speight want?

He does not want Fiji to have an Indian leader and dislikes the democratic political rules that allowed that to happen. He has asked for, and been granted, a pardon and wants the same for his supporters, many of whom have been involved in rioting and looting in the capital. He has also been insisting that some of his allies get jobs in the new pro-Fijian government that he hopes will emerge out of the crisis he has caused.

So who is in charge of Fiji?

Fiji's president is called Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. He has resigned and, before he went, he sacked the prime minister and his cabinet even as they were being held at gunpoint by Speight. Speight and his gang are squatting in the parliament compound. Outside, the country is under the control of a naval officer, Commodore Frank Bainimarama. Speight refuses to recognise Bainimarama's authority.

What sparked the current crisis?

Chaudhry was unpopular. He tried to rush through new laws that would have given Indians more control of the land they farm. Many leases in Fiji were arranged in the 1970s and are up for renewal now. Fijians are very defensive about losing their land and many wanted it back so that they could farm it for themselves.

Who is behind George Speight?

It looks as if the people behind Speight are nationalist Fijians and politicians who lost out with the return of democracy. Speight is a shadowy character, too - a failed businessman who was recently sacked as chairman of two timber companies. One of Fiji's most valuable resources is mahogany, a precious hardwood used in the production of fine furniture.

What will happen now?

The Fijian economy is just recovering from two years of drought, which devastated the sugar harvests. It does not need more instability.

Even if the hostages are released unharmed, they will not be getting their political powers back soon. This, and the rash of attacks on their businesses in Suva, may drive many Indians to leave the country.

Foreign ministers from eight Commonwealth countries are due to meet in London today to discuss the crisis. They may recommend that Fiji be expelled from the Commonwealth. This would leave Fiji politically isolated in the world. Overseas aid and trade links may also be cut. After the last coup, international airlines suspended flights to Fiji and if that were to happen it would be terrible for the tourist trade - the country's biggest industry. Fiji might also be stopped from taking part in international sporting competitions. This would be a great loss because most Fijians are rugby and football mad.

fields.headline: It's competition time
fields.standfirst: More, not less, competition is coming for colleges, says  Alan Blackwell
fields.trailText: More, not less, competition is coming for colleges, says Alan Blackwell
fields.body:
For some months now, the further education sector has been fed a torrent of news, rumours and rhetoric about the Learning and Skills Council.

We are told the changes will bring about greater harmony and collaboration, with local discussion of what communities actually need; unnecessary duplication or competition will be frowned upon.

Yes folks, this brave new world we are talking about is a sector with increasingly desperate colleges hanging on to market share. The big growth bubble has burst and new students are ever harder to find. Colleges remain underfunded. The new money David Blunkett has won for the sector? Anyone working on the ground will tell you the new funds are for extra projects; the underlying trend is for yet more efficiency gains.

So, what is this new panacea? A system with various regional partners. A desperate principal will sit next to a head, whose sixth form's survival will depend upon greater efficiency - codeword for bigger. I can't see principal and head getting on too well there. Next to them will be a local education authority representative, probably one who has clung on to a community education network since incorporation.

Wait until those Local Skills Council funding floodgates are opened. The local authority infrastructure is still there. Primary and secondary schools could earn nice extras for part-time evening vocational courses. Who needs the colleges? In fact, we may as well have the new Ufi stations in libraries and community centres to attract non-traditional learners. Traditional can go to college - well, the ones the local authority aren't going to pinch back. But the person really drooling is the private training provider with a hit list of safe courses he wants to expand into; and the other individual still dumbfounded over his luck is the large local employer who can finally cut out the middleman, ie the college, and get his hands directly on government training money.

These are the partners, then, who will not be acting in their own institutional interests, but for the common good. When all the rhetoric settles, how are these competing pressures going to be practically handled? What is frightening is that not only do we get no answers to this, but no one in authority is even asking the questions in public.

If this whole initiative is not to prove an unmitigated disaster, then the top down rhetoric has to be turned off temporarily and the people at the receiving end listened to. I don't mean via a consultative document that asks for views on 19 technical points. I mean asking the big question how this can work, if it can ever work? Excluding college representatives or minimising them from planning groups is not a good sign. When questioned about this, Department for Education and Employment officials tell us: "You are just a provider." "Just"? Are they joking?

Increased competition, which there will certainly be, will break many colleges. Many teeter on the edge of viability now. The sector, industry and the UK as a whole, needs a strong college network offering a broad range of upskilling, re-skilling and lifelong learning opportunities. Does the government really want a new system of competing institutions clamouring to provide the most lucrative courses whilst others go to the wall? Do they want to narrow the range of options?

In the short term, there may be a greater choice of providers, but in a few years there will be a narrower range of options for students. Ministers should recognise that there has to be an infrastructure to bring about lifelong learning and high quality education and training, and at its heart must be colleges.

They need to tap into that expertise on the ground now.

 Alan Blackwell, is principal of Craven College, Skipton

fields.headline: Beauty therapy
fields.trailText: Beauty therapy
fields.body:
Can you help me? I'll try.

I want to be gorgeous. Ah, right.

You are a beauty therapist, aren't you? Well um...

Nobody else wears those white nylon housecoats. OK. I admit it. I'm a beauty therapist.

Good. Well, I should like you to make me beautiful. It's just not as simple as that, sir.

Madam! Sorry, madam. I do beg your pardon. My lenses are playing up.

As I was saying, give me pulchritude. Oh dear, we can't dish out drugs. You'll have to see your GP.

Not drugs, girl. Pulchritude. Make me fair. Give me a face to launch a thousand ships. Oh dear.

What's the beef? It's what you do, isn't it? Beauty therapists are concerned with improving people's physical appearance and well-being. We're trained to offer a wide range of treatments for face and body, notably hands and feet.

Precisely. But they said nothing at college about ships.

It was just a quotation. Oo, lovely. Anyway, we provide a range of treatments, including facials, manicures and pedicures, hair removal and different kinds of body treatments using machinery or massage.

Ouch. Do you do anything less painful? Beauty therapists may also have to offer advice on exercise and slimming, take telephone calls, book appointments, handle money and order new supplies. The working environment has to be kept clean and tidy, hygiene is very important.

What personal qualities are needed? Sympathy and ability to put clients at ease. Some can be nervous and shy about the treatments. We've also got to be clean and well groomed and pay attention to personal hygiene. And we need stamina. The work involves a lot of standing, and massage in particular can be very tiring.

Anything else? An interest in science, particularly anatomy and physiology, and the way treatments affect the skin is important.

Do you all work in places like this? Most of us work in high street salons and in department stores. Some work in health and fitness clubs, hotels or on cruise ships. Self-employed therapists visit clients in their homes, or work from a room in their own house.

How do you get into it? Most people train for beauty therapy with a full-time course. There are NVQs and other beauty therapy qualifications awarded by City & Guilds, CIBTAC (Confederation of International Beauty Therapist), ITEC (International Therapy Examinations Council), IHBC (International Health and Beauty Council) and VTCT (Vocational Training Charitable Trust).

Where can you train? Usually at a further education college or private beauty school. College courses last one to two years. Private courses tend to be shorter and more intensive. There are some modern apprentice ships available and generally good opportunities for late entrants.

What do colleges ask for? No specific entry requirements, although some may ask for three GCSEs, including a science, plus good interpersonal skills.

So, what can you do for me? Well, madam, some dietary advice to start with. No more lunching a thousand chips.

 Hairdressing and Beauty Industry Authority (the national training organisation), 2nd floor, Fraser House, Netherhall Road, Doncaster DN1 2PH

 CIBTAC, Parabola House, Parabola Road, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire GL50 3AH

 ITEC, 10/11 Heathfield Terrace, Chiswick, London W4 4JE

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses

fields.headline: A knockout blow
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  puts his back into staff-student relations
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock puts his back into staff-student relations
fields.body:
I had a feeling that it would end in disaster. The signs were there, only I hadn't seen them. My half-hearted lunchtime workouts at the college's fitness suite were to be wasted.

My doubt was further compounded when I suffered a setback while bending over the waste bin in the staff room. Trying to despatch the sticky wrapper from my muesli bar, I felt something go in my back.

"All set for tonight then?" Colin asked, tossing a scotch egg confidently from palm to palm. Colin, also in a state of average physical fitness, had accepted the same challenge from a group of GNVQ Leisure and Tourism students. We were to take part in a "Fun Team It's A Knockout" competition. A series of events would test our stamina, team-work and give any student watching a cheap laugh at the expense of staff daft enough to get involved.

The thought of yearbook photographers and the presence of the local weekly newspaper were enough to remind me, once again, that I had made a mistake in succumbing to the persuasive charms of Rapinder.

"All the other lecturers are joining in," she smiled. "Well, only the ones we feel are strong enough to take part. And we're donating the entry fee to the student union's charity of the month."

"Lecturers' Benevolent Fund, is that, Rapinder?" I quipped.

"Polish pit donkeys, actually."

I have a soft spot for donkeys, so that was that. I was handing over £10 before I realised it. Later I found out that Rapinder had told Colin that she was raising money for extra staff parking places. And she had told Murray Whelk from administration that the money would be going towards replacement rubber plants in the foyer.

The first event involved bean bags, a length of rope and a space hopper. I had not heard the instructions clearly, so it all progressed in a confusing muddle around me. I remember stuffing bean bags inside my shorts and being shouted at to run faster.

My team got off to bad start. Arguing about who had trodden on whose inhaler did not help to raise morale. Colin got an adrenalin rush and started to make derogatory remarks about Murray's ball handling skills.

"Let's kick ass," rasped a pumped-up Colin, red faced and ready for what the next blast of Rapinder's whistle would demand from his vaguely athletic body. But it was the next event - The Dying Fly competition - that was to be my undoing.

On the command of "Die!" in a sibilant crackle from Rapinder over a malfunctioning microphone, we had to roll about on the floor and kick our legs in the air. We were accompanied by the convulsive laughter of students shooting off photographs like paparazzi on speed.

On the face of it this was an event for the stylist and not the pure athlete. I should have played my joker. However, the difficulty of getting up from the floor, having got stuck in the position of a paralysed fly, was too much. Once again, something nasty had happened somewhere inside my back.

I remember waiting for the doctor to arrive, having been rolled out of the way into a corner. The show had to go on, even if it meant suffering glancing blows from stray bean bags. I kept telling myself never to volunteer for anything like this again. They shoot donkeys don't they, I thought.

fields.headline: Winning further honours
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on the new awards for being there
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on the new awards for being there
fields.body:
Have you heard about Gary Rhodes, the telly chef, and Baroness Lockwood of Dewsbury? Or, for that matter, Jimmy Choo, the shoe designer, and Kay Mellor, the celebrated TV playwright? Or Richard Griffiths, who played creepy Uncle Monty in the film Withnail and I, and Marco Marenghi, lead animator for the BBC telly series Walking with Dinosaurs?

If by now you tingle with the juicy anticipation of something more usually found in the News of the Screws, you'll be disappointed.

Gary Rhodes and the Baroness, who happens to be deputy speaker of the House of Lords, do share something, but it isn't romps on the Woolsack. In fact all six have this common trait: they all went to a further education college and they're all about to be honoured for it.

Weather permitting, they'll all be basking on the Thames-side terrace at the House of Commons on Thursday, each the proud new possessor of a Gold Award.

It seems a bit weird in one sense to be dishing out, decades later, honours to people simply for having once gone to a further education college. But, as in so many cases where well-known and important people get gonged, the awarder expects to get as much, if not more, out of it as the recipient.

"We feel it is important to raise the profile of further education in as many ways as possible," says Alice Brown, of the Association of Colleges, who has organised the awards.

"The Gold Awards afford us the opportunity to celebrate the way in which these colleges have had a direct impact on these individuals, who have gone on to excel in their chosen field."

Five years ago, the association's predecessor ran a similar wheeze, but it fizzled out. Now it is being revived as the Gold Awards, and last October the call went out for colleges to bring out their famous and eminent former students. In fact only 32 out of about 450 institutions came up with the goods. It's disappointing, perhaps, but at least it means there will be plenty of untapped territory when the call goes out this autumn.

For the judges, members of the Association of Colleges charitable trust, it has not merely been a case of creaming off the six biggest names. They have deliberately spread the awards between industries and not, for instance, picked six from showbiz. The key factor for winners has been their acknowledgement to the importance in their lives of their colleges.

"All these candidates have said that further education had a bearing on their success," says Brown. Gary Rhodes, for example, says: "Thanet College was the base to my full catering career." He visits the college to give demonstrations and present awards.

Kay Mellor, best known for her television series "Band of Gold" and "Playing the Field", enrolled on a part-time childcare course as a teen mum and discovered her "thirst for education" at Park Lane college, Leeds. A string of O and A levels followed, before she won a place at drama school in her mid 20s.

"I have grabbed every opportunity to live life to the full since," she says.

Baroness Lockwood's early career in the Labour party led on from her secretarial studies course at Dewsbury College. Marco Marenghi did an HND Animation programme at Pontypridd College. Richard Griffiths studied O levels at Stockton and Billingham College after leaving secondary modern with no significant achievements. Jimmy Choo studied footwear design at Cordwainers College and, on leaving, opened a small shoemaking company in Hackney.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: I am a classroom assistant and am working with a new teacher who seems to be struggling with the delivery of the literacy and numeracy hours.
fields.body:
I am a classroom assistant and am working with a new teacher who seems to be struggling with the delivery of the literacy and numeracy hours. My dilemma is, should I speak to the head or a senior teacher, and run the risk of being seen to be questioning the professionalism of a staff member?

Jenni Railey is head of primary education at the London Institute of Education.

It is not a good idea for you to approach the headteacher, a senior teacher or indeed the class teacher yourself in this situation. As a classroom assistant, it probably wouldn't go down too well! However, you have every right to express your concerns, so I would suggest going to the head of year group or another class teacher whose discretion you can rely upon. They will then be able to decide what the best course of action is, and can guide and support the teacher in terms of how to effectively differentiate work for all abilities.

Margaret McGowan is an adviser at the Advisory Centre for Education. She provides advice here on how parents should approach their child's school.

Approaching the school if, for example, you feel your child is not getting sufficiently challenging work needs to be handled with diplomacy. While many parents/ carers believe their children to be little stars, they may not be quite as academically gifted as you believe. Moreover, by raising the issue of whether your child is being "stretched", you are challenging the teacher's professional judgement.

That said, the first point of call is the classroom/subject teacher him/herself. This might be at the annual parents evening, or you may arrange to see the teacher on a separate occasion. Before the meeting, think about what exactly your concerns are, and what you want to achieve.

Be prepared to listen to the teacher's point of view. Sometimes an able child will display behavioural problems because s/he is bored. The teacher may have missed this diagnosis and if the teacher is inexperienced, could feel attacked and go on the defensive. So take a bit of time before the meeting to talk to your child and find out what s/he would enjoy doing, so your contribution to the meeting can be positive.

Some schools may have a co-ordinator with responsibility for more able children, but this is often a grey area. Whilst there is a code of practice for those pupils with learning difficulties, there isn't one for gifted children, so good practice in this area can be variable. However, most teachers will be used to differentiating work, so should be able to provide your child with extension tasks.

In some cases, it may be appropriate for your child to work to the next key stage level. Investigate whether there are after-school or lunchtime clubs that your child could attend, which would extend their studies. I would advise all those who are considering private tuition for their child in any subject to discuss this with the school.

Be aware that the teacher may well have a different perception of your child's ability, based upon their time with him/her, their professional judgment and an informed idea of where your child is with regard to their age and year group. This doesn't mean your opinion is invalid, but try to be as tactful and co-operative as possible. Education is a partnership between parents/carers and schools, and a good relationship between with your child's teachers can only reap rewards for all concerned - especially your child.

The Advisory Centre for Education (ACE) Ltd is an independent national advice centre for parents, financed by funds raised from charitable trusts, local education authorities, the Department for Trade and Industry, and industry. ACE operates an advice line on 020-7354 8321. Parents can also e-mail questions to ace-ed@easynet.co.uk.

Next week's query

My child has begun to mention a certain school skiing trip that will be taking place next February. I know this is leading up to a plea to be allowed to go. My economic circumstances are such that I would find it hard to fund such a trip, but I allowed his elder brother to go on a French exchange two years ago. Are there any funds or sponsorships to help parents? Should I argue that a skiing trip, even a school one, is not educational and so my child cannot go? I want to be fair to both my children, but feel unsure of what to do for the best.
