In some cases, it may be appropriate for your child to work to the next key stage level. Investigate whether there are after-school or lunchtime clubs that your child could attend, which would extend their studies. I would advise all those who are considering private tuition for their child in any subject to discuss this with the school. Be aware that the teacher may well have a different perception of your child's ability, based upon their time with him/her, their professional judgment and an informed idea of where your child is with regard to their age and year group. This doesn't mean your opinion is invalid, but try to be as tactful and co-operative as possible. Education is a partnership between parents/carers and schools, and a good relationship between with your child's teachers can only reap rewards for all concerned - especially your child. The Advisory Centre for Education (ACE) Ltd is an independent national advice centre for parents, financed by funds raised from charitable trusts, local education authorities, the Department for Trade and Industry, and industry. ACE operates an advice line on 020-7354 8321. Parents can also e-mail questions to ace-ed@easynet.co.uk. Next week's query My child has begun to mention a certain school skiing trip that will be taking place next February. I know this is leading up to a plea to be allowed to go. My economic circumstances are such that I would find it hard to fund such a trip, but I allowed his elder brother to go on a French exchange two years ago. Are there any funds or sponsorships to help parents? Should I argue that a skiing trip, even a school one, is not educational and so my child cannot go? I want to be fair to both my children, but feel unsure of what to do for the best.

fields.headline: Land ahoy!
fields.standfirst: The new education bill has almost come to the end of its vogage.  Nick Tester reports on how the post-16 landscape will look for the next decade or two
fields.trailText: The new education bill has almost come to the end of its vogage. Nick Tester reports on how the post-16 landscape will look for the next decade or two
fields.body:
The talking stops today. OK, it still has to skip over just a few more parliamentary hurdles. And some of the fine-tuning has yet to be completed. But there's no doubt the Learning and Skills Bill, poised to leave its committee stage in the Commons today, is now firmly on course to receive Royal Assent next month.

Most education bills introduced over the past decade or so have had to endure a high profile parliamentary passage. But with this further education bill, the earth only really shook when discussions turned to sex (Section 28) and selection (grammar school ballots), potential tick-like amendments eventually brushed aside by the government.

Tory Tim Boswell, probably knows more than any other living MP about the likely implications of the bill. He characterised the gentle sparring over its contents by opening one debating session in the Commons declaring: "On a lovely late spring morning, we do not want to raise the temperature unduly."

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister responsible for piloting the bill through the Commons, has had a relatively easy time. Certainly he was spared the more robust exchanges that took place earlier this year in the Lords between Tory Baroness Blatch and the further education minister, Baroness Blackstone. It was in this "other place" that the bill first attracted accusations of centralisation and that Labour was behaving arrogantly, and had less time than the Tories for local government, in their drive to create a gigantic new quangoland run by cronies.

For students of politics, the bill has been a supreme example of how opposition peers and MPs, prompted principally by the Association of Colleges, have technically probed the nuts and bolts of important and complex new proposed laws. Refraining from throwing a spanner in the works, they've added a little oil, while attempting to tease out the government's thinking on the foreseen balance between centralisation and local determination.

Forget standards, per se; the question of whether the most effective learning and teaching is best run by Whitehall or town hall - or a combination of the two - remains the most crucial issue in the education world. Rather than resolving the matter, the Learning and Skills Bill makes it even more complicated. Local education authorities will remain in contention, but they're only holding on by their finger nails.

Ministers hope to establish a stable and predicable 10-year climate for the further education sector. The nitty gritty of how dramatically and successfully these changes will emerge is still being fashioned by a succession of detailed consultation papers.

There are two main reforms designed to simplify and make more apparent the way public money is spent in the vast post-16 education and training empire. They're mostly to do with funding - and checking how well the money has been spent. The emphasis will be on learning and learners, instead of provider processes and organisation.

Ministers continue to be wary of publicly undermining school sixth forms. Instead, they proceed by stealth, exposing the virtues of sixth-form colleges and upping their funding. This is not surprising, given that simple sums reveal that a further education A-level student costs a third less than one staying on at school.

For the first time some £6 billion worth of annual funding will cover all 16-18, community and adult education, embracing, as well, all business training and skills up-dating hitherto done by Training and Enterprise Councils (soon to be RIP). It will be dispersed by a new central agency - the Learning and Skills Council - via 47 local bodies bearing the same name and equipped with additional powers to vary (between 10 and 15%) how much and where they spend their money.

The government is giving itself unique powers to cap student fees at certain levels and for particular courses. Of course, there are always two sides to a coin. Opponents fear that central planners, with their eyes on spreadsheets and value for money, will override the local discretion of colleges and private trainers.

But ministers have also made adequately clear during the course of the bill that, for the first time, they intend to limit the fees training providers can charge, if they're also in receipt of Learning and Skills Council dosh. And, as these pages reported a few weeks ago, the bill will extend free post-16 tuition to some 250,000 teenagers currently doing part-time study.

This has been viewed as a triumph for the Association of Colleges, the government's biggest critical friend and responsible for exposing to public scrutiny some of the bill's most delicate nerves.

Nowhere is this more apparent than over the second major reform - inspection. Ofsted's remit is being extended to cover the entire 16-18 sector and further education colleges with sizeable A-level provision. A new Adult Learning Inspectorate will scrutinise the rest. There will be shared assessment arrangements, grading systems, report formats and intervention strategies.

Colleges continue to quibble over such issues as a lack of appeals procedure and a possible tension between setting challenging targets and measuring how much students have learned. If they're sure about the virtues of a five, rather than a seven, point grading system, the colleges fear that words like "adequate" will cause confusion. They also want the new inspection language to use phrases like "areas for development" rather than stark single words, such as "weakness". Above all, they're suspicious of entering a "name and shame" culture and, in the words of one MP, being "done over by somebody not fit to lick their boots".

The huge changes officially come on stream from next April and it will be a long time before anyone can make sensible comparisons with the present system and declare a success. But with a general election starting to loom, they probably will.

fields.headline: Figure it out
fields.standfirst: Will post-16 reforms deliver promised savings, asks  Julian Gravatt
fields.trailText: Will post-16 reforms deliver promised savings, asks Julian Gravatt
fields.body:
We've heard it so often, it's become a sort of leitmotif: the post-16 Learning and Skills reforms will save the country £50m.

Ministers made the promise last July and have reaffirmed it more than once when challenged by opposition MPs. This saving in running costs is one justification for the disruption and expense of the reforms, so the figures are worth a look.

The first rule in making comparisons is know your starting point. You cannot verify the £50 million saving without knowing the cost of the current arrangements. Reaching this figure is not easy, because much post-16 administration is covered by large departments whose activities cover a wider field.

The Department for Education and Employment, for instance, will spend £265m in 2000/1 on administration, but does not publish figures to work out how much is spent on individual areas: schools, universities etc. The same is true of Ofsted (2000/1 budget: £106m) and the government offices for the regions.

It's a complex picture. But there was some relief for number crunchers when Malcolm Wicks, the Lifelong Learning Minister, gave detailed estimates in the House of Commons in May. He reported that the current total spending on the national and local administration of post-16 education and training was £250-280m and that the £50m saving would bring this down to £200-230m.

Savings would come from reduced staffing in 10 regional government offices (£15m) and from having 47 Local Learning and Skills Councils in place of 82 TECs (another £35m). In other words, a 20% saving achieved by reducing the headcount, reorganising functions and minimising IT and office costs. Textbook rationalisation. Welcome if the £50m saved is put to good use.

In the short-term, the Learning and Skills reform results in increased expenditure. Malcolm Wicks also summarised this in May. £35m is needed this year to set up the Learning and Skills Council, including £10m for a new IT system. These short-term costs have their payback in the promised savings of £50m, but they may not be the only expenditure in the pipeline. The transfer of assets, liabilities and staff contracts on April 1, 2001 could throw up further transactions not currently anticipated. Assets will include money owed by providers who have missed their targets. Liabilities: commitments under existing contracts, plus redundancy payments for staff who lose their jobs.

DfEE civil servants have worked hard to anticipate every eventuality, but no plan is ever complete. A full account won't be available until after the event and, even then, it will be difficult to sort out cause and effect. For example, if reports that TEC staff have been leaving early are correct, then this will help keep the redundancy costs low in March 2001. We won't know the full story until 2002 and only then, if some body like the National Audit Office takes an interest and gathers some data. If not, we'll have to take it on trust.

A more important issue than the level of the saving is the effectiveness of the new spending. One change is the plan to have strong national systems, locally administered. Another is the planning and improvement role for the local councils. These will have their own impact on the administration costs of providers.

The costs - compliance costs - are often left out of the discussions about savings, but should not be. One of the legacies of the 1990s has been a growth in learning and training bureaucracy at all levels, including colleges and training providers. A simpler and more coherent rule book could help providers make their own administration savings, but only if the Learning and Skills Council makes this happen. And, even if it does, new initiatives could simply displace costs.

The initiatives with the most political support - education maintenance allowances and learning accounts - are often the ones which impose the biggest administrative burden on providers. Their responsiveness to individual circumstances is an advantage, but it is also expensive if the right systems are not in place.

So. This £50 million saving - will it really happen? The honest answer is that we'll never really know.

 Julian Gravatt is Registrar at Lewisham College.

fields.headline: No more machismo
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on the college defying government injunctions for a softer leadership style
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on the college defying government injunctions for a softer leadership style
fields.body:
The government's resolve to end "macho management" in colleges looks like being tested by one institution's threat to sack nearly 600 of its part-time lecturers and replace them with agency staff.

Woolwich and Greenwich community college has despatched letters to 597 lecturers informing them that if negotiations with Natfhe over their terms and conditions fail, they will be redundant.

Natfhe accuses the college of trying to dodge its obligations to honour part-timers' newly won rights, a crucial clutch of which come into play in July.

The union is concerned that part-timers re-employed through a third-party agency, such as Education Lecturing Services, will be denied their rights to paid holidays, sick leave and other benefits.

Union officials believe the college's strategy exemplifies the management style which the lifelong learning minister, Malcolm Wicks, says must end. It also makes nonsense of the union's joint agreement with the Association of Colleges on the employment of part-timers.

"The days of macho management are over. We cannot tolerate victimisation of Natfhe or other trade union activists," Wicks said in a speech warmly received by delegates at Natfhe's recent annual conference.

Senior Natfhe officers aimed to raise the Woolwich situation yesterday when they, together with delegations from the Assocation of Colleges and other further education unions, met Baroness Blackstone, the further education minister.

The college's assistant principal in charge of human resources, Andy Lightbown, said the reason for getting rid of all part-time employees was to avoid continuous challenges from Natfhe about their working arrangements. The use of a third-party agency was not its preferred option.

"We've only given it serious consideration because we have, so far, failed to reach an agreement with the union," he said.

He rejected accusations that management was simply seeking a way to subvert all the newly-won rights of part-time workers. Nor was it deliberately ignoring the two-month old joint agreement between Natfhe and the Association of Colleges that part-time employees should not be treated less favourably than full-time colleagues in, for instance, their holiday entitlements, pensions, and sick and maternity leave.

On the contrary, Lightbown said, the college had been trying to ensure that it fully complied with the regulations on holiday pay and the regulations coming into force on July 1.

"We've been in negotiation with Natfhe since March last year to try to achieve a more appropriate and higher rate of pay for part-time staff - currently £17.58 an hour."

Natfhe had pitched for an hourly rate "in excess of £28 an hour" which would cost the college £750,000, which it couldn't afford, he said.

Similarly it couldn't afford the £500,000 which Natfhe's modified claim for a top rate of £25 an hour would cost.

There was a glimmer of hope that settlement could still be reached, and part-time employees' jobs saved, in Natfhe's current call for £22.70 an hour.

"That's still too high, but the gap betweeen us is much smaller," he said.

Malcolm Wicks told the Natfhe conference that the government would be looking to the new local learning and skills councils to tackle the macho management culture of the past decade.

But Natfhe officials would prefer to see more immediate remedies. It would be easy for the government to tag something onto the legislation currently going through parliament which would close loopholes and firm up protection for part-timers, they reckon.

fields.headline: Economic forces
fields.standfirst: The next few weeks are crucial for the ESRC's new head, Gordon Marshall
fields.trailText: The next few weeks are crucial for the ESRC's new head, Gordon Marshall
fields.body:
Gordon Marshall's features suggest a mix of former US presidential aspirant John McCain and Professional Footballers' Association leader Gordon Taylor, but it is his voice that will matter over the next few weeks.

This is not because of its unmistakable reminder of Falkirk origins, but as a key advocate for academic research as the Comprehensive Spending Review reaches its conclusion. Marshall, 47, became chief executive of the Economic and Social Research Council only four months ago. He is newer to the job than any of his counterparts at the other research councils, and knows his own subject community will base its early judgments on spending review outcomes.

As Official Fellow in Sociology at Nuffield College, Oxford - an institution he describes as a "high-powered social science research institute masquerading as an Oxford college" - he has heavyweight academic credentials. His first job was in the formidable Essex sociology department, where he worked with his research council predecessor-but-one Howard Newby and David Rose (who must wonder when he will get his turn to run the ESRC) on social class and modern Britain. When appointed to a chair at Bath in 1990 he was Essex sociology's 25th professor in as many years.

Marshall brings a dryly humorous, self-deprecating eye to the idiosyncrasies of academic life. His contribution to last year's Nuffield research report computed that of 230 working days in an academic year, other calls on his time meant that only 60 were available to fulfil his contractual obligation to do sociological research. A couple of years earlier he reported his finding that "social class inequalities are still a prominent feature of advanced capitalism - this may or may not surprise colleagues."

But humour has always been a powerful weapon for any good advocate. While there is more to running the research council than advocacy - he points out that he has a staff of 95 and a research budget of more than £70m to manage - he is comfortable arguing for the value and virtues of the social sciences.

He says: "There is a great deal of high-quality good normal science, whose methods would be recognisable to any physicist or earth scientist, operating on the same logic of research and inference, and the same rules as evidence. But it isn't what gets noticed in television skits or jokey little newspaper articles."

While pointing out that there is no contradiction between doing good quality research and being able to explain it to a wider audience, he defends social scientists against the frequent charge of "jargon", saying: "Social scientists are dealing with issues people know about, but are often using complex models and concepts which have to be defined precisely."

Marshall also accepts that social science is afflicted by double jeopardy - damned for stating the obvious when its findings support conventional wisdom, condemned for being political when they do not. He has no doubt the current climate, with a vogue for "evidence-led policy" is more favourable than what went before. But he warns: "It is not up to social sciences to make the policy - that is the politician's job. And it is also very important that it should not be interpreted as whatever politicians want for their own purposes."

His research council can also be relied upon to go on supporting high quality "blue-skies" research in the face of pressures to be "relevant": "You can never tell what is going to be 'relevant'. John Goldthorpe's research on social class was pure blue-skies research, yet 30 years on it is now clear that his classifications are an incredibly useful tool for understanding our society."

National datasets like the British Household Panel Survey are, he said recently, "the social science equivalent of the Hubble telescope, Synchrotron radiation source or the 'Challenger' deep-sea exploration vessel. They are some of the most sophisticated resources available to policymakers anywhere in the world."

But he doesn't claim everything about British social science is perfect. One of his main concerns is a skills deficit in quantitative analysis: "We don't know why this is but it is an issue of great concern to many users. The ability to analyse complex datasets is immensely important. The problem may be out of the research council's control - there may be deeper reasons, possibly related to schools. But it is something we need to look into."

He believes one possible villain is the research assessment exercise: "Learning these skills does take time and when you are under constant pressure to do research and publish, your other options are limited."

This is just one item in a scathing indictment of the exercise: "I think it is increasingly clear that it is almost entirely counter-productive. People spend far too much time and energy chasing indicators. It has been a serious disincentive to long-term, deep research, instead generating a lot of rather ordinary papers. While it was intended to lead to centres of excellence generating innovations and spin-offs, its effect has been quite the opposite."

He argues that the research councils would make a far better job of research assessment than the funding councils: "To a far greater extent than the funding councils, we are focused, strategic and transparent."

Marshall is not prepared to defend uncritically every single piece of research ever funded by the council, but argues: "I am sure if you asked the chief executives of the other funding councils, they would have to say exactly the same of their projects."

A couple of years earlier he reported his finding that "social class inequalities are still a prominent feature of advanced capitalism - this may or may not surprise colleagues." But humour has always been a powerful weapon for any good advocate. While there is more to running the research council than advocacy - he points out that he has a staff of 95 and a research budget of more than £70m to manage - he is comfortable arguing for the value and virtues of the social sciences. He says: "There is a great deal of high-quality good normal science, whose methods would be recognisable to any physicist or earth scientist, operating on the same logic of research and inference, and the same rules as evidence. But it isn't what gets noticed in television skits or jokey little newspaper articles." While pointing out that there is no contradiction between doing good quality research and being able to explain it to a wider audience, he defends social scientists against the frequent charge of "jargon", saying: "Social scientists are dealing with issues people know about, but are often using complex models and concepts which have to be defined precisely." Marshall also accepts that social science is afflicted by double jeopardy - damned for stating the obvious when its findings support conventional wisdom, condemned for being political when they do not. He has no doubt the current climate, with a vogue for "evidence-led policy" is more favourable than what went before. But he warns: "It is not up to social sciences to make the policy - that is the politician's job. And it is also very important that it should not be interpreted as whatever politicians want for their own purposes." His research council can also be relied upon to go on supporting high quality "blue-skies" research in the face of pressures to be "relevant": "You can never tell what is going to be 'relevant'. John Goldthorpe's research on social class was pure blue-skies research, yet 30 years on it is now clear that his classifications are an incredibly useful tool for understanding our society." National datasets like the British Household Panel Survey are, he said recently, "the social science equivalent of the Hubble telescope, Synchrotron radiation source or the 'Challenger' deep-sea exploration vessel. They are some of the most sophisticated resources available to policymakers anywhere in the world." But he doesn't claim everything about British social science is perfect. One of his main concerns is a skills deficit in quantitative analysis: "We don't know why this is but it is an issue of great concern to many users. The ability to analyse complex datasets is immensely important. The problem may be out of the research council's control - there may be deeper reasons, possibly related to schools. But it is something we need to look into." He believes one possible villain is the research assessment exercise: "Learning these skills does take time and when you are under constant pressure to do research and publish, your other options are limited." This is just one item in a scathing indictment of the exercise: "I think it is increasingly clear that it is almost entirely counter-productive. People spend far too much time and energy chasing indicators. It has been a serious disincentive to long-term, deep research, instead generating a lot of rather ordinary papers. While it was intended to lead to centres of excellence generating innovations and spin-offs, its effect has been quite the opposite." He argues that the research councils would make a far better job of research assessment than the funding councils: "To a far greater extent than the funding councils, we are focused, strategic and transparent." Marshall is not prepared to defend uncritically every single piece of research ever funded by the council, but argues: "I am sure if you asked the chief executives of the other funding councils, they would have to say exactly the same of their projects."

fields.headline: A modern dark age
fields.standfirst: Amanda Roper previews the moving Holocaust exhibition at the Imperial War Museum
fields.trailText: Amanda Roper previews the moving Holocaust exhibition at the Imperial War Museum
fields.body:
In 1941, Kurt Gerstein joined the Schutzstaffel (SS). Gerstein was not enticed by the magnetism of Hitler - he joined the SS to find out if rumours about the murder of patients with physical and mental disabilities were true.

In the summer of 1942, he visited the death camps of Belzec and Treblinka, and witnessed the murder of thousands of Jews in the purpose-built gas chambers. This experience drove Gerstein in a personal mission to let the world know about the Nazis' crimes. His report, smuggled out to the Swedish and British governments, and the Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches in Berlin, was met with a wall of silence. In 1945, filled with despair, Kurt Gerstein took his own life.

But what Gerstein witnessed will not be forgotten, as it forms part of the Imperial War Museum's permanent Holocaust Exhibition in London, which the Queen formally opens today. Last Wednesday, pupils from the Notre Dame school in Lingfield, Sussex, visited the exhibition - Graham Smith, Pritesh Patel and Jonathan Gibbons in year 9, and Katy Turner and Heloise Brown in year 10. The boys have not yet studied the holocaust, but had a good general knowledge of what it was. The girls had already learnt of the holocaust through their history GCSE studies.

Asked why the Jews in particular were persecuted, Graham thought people were jealous of their wealth. Katy pointed to the belief in Germany that a worldwide Jewish conspiracy had led to defeat in the first world war and the humiliation of Versailles.

But, holocaust education co-ordinator Paul Salmons argued, these are reasons to look for a scapegoat, not why people hated the Jews. The students overlooked the religious dimension: that for centuries, the Christian church had erroneously laid the blame for Christ's death on the Jews.

Schools who visit the museum receive a video, "The way we were", which combines personal recollections with original film footage to give a sense of the lives of Jews before the rise of Hitler. It shows the strong sense of community in Poland, and the fact that Jews living in Germany, mainly wealthy professionals, considered themselves German first, Jewish second. For them, the holocaust was a double betrayal.

The exhibition features artefacts, with information presented on a striking backdrop of black or red tiled walls. Monitors relay authentic film footage - in one, Nazi propaganda minister Goebbels propounds his anti-Jewish rhetoric; in another, survivors weep when they recall the cruel separation of families.

The pupils were also given audio guides that provided a commentary to the exhibition. Katy found this use of a variety of media good, but Heloise pointed out that sometimes there was so much going on that it was difficult to follow. However, by walking through the various sections, she had a clear sense of how events took on a horrible momentum, culminating in the death camps. Pritesh thought the use of photographs from the time brought it home that these were real people. Jonathan found that the interactive computers that allow pupils to discover, country by country, how the Jews were treated, were extremely informative.

One of the most memorable images is of a stark, marble table. It was used for the "voluntary euthanasia" of "unproductives" - the physically and mentally disabled. Above the table, photographs of three such "unproductives" hang. They are naked and visibly distressed children no more than five years old. As Katy said, "it just all looked so controlled".

Auschwitz is represented by a white, scale model. Thousands of people are being herded off the cattle trucks, and divided into two lines: right for the camp barracks; or left to the imposing building at the end of the railway line, with the massive chimney - the gas chamber. Behind the model, a glass case contains some of the possessions that were left behind. Shoes, shaving brushes, combs, spectacles, all testify to a life lost.

Why did these young people feel that it is important for them to learn about the holocaust? Because history has a tendency to repeat itself, said Katy. To help us to resolve religious and other conflicts today, commented Graham.

But they all know that this has not been the case. Heloise reflected that looking around the exhibition, you had to remind yourself that this all happened not so very long ago. Katy agreed, and complained that events in the former Yugoslavia have almost been forgotten already.

Drawing parallels with today in terms of how our society treats refugees, Heloise said, "We haven't learnt from previous wars. We can look around this exhibition, and say how sad and terrible it all was, but we still don't help people now in the same situation, even though we could."

These young people, through their visit to the exhibition, are beginning to understand the dynamics that made the holocaust possible. It is a lesson that some of their elders have consistently failed to learn.

 The Holocaust Education Service has produced extensive materials for use in the classroom.

fields.headline: Worth £50,000?
fields.standfirst: Parents could soon be paying US-level fees for degrees
fields.trailText: Parents could soon be paying US-level fees for degrees
fields.body:
Students would pay up to £50,000 in tuition fees for top university degrees under proposals being presented to elite academic heads this week. Economists think cash-strapped universities in the UK must be freed from government controls and be allowed to set their own fees like US institutions to avert a financial crisis.

Under the scheme, middle-class students would lose all state support for degrees, with government teaching funds used only to generate scholarships for students from poorer backgrounds.

The new funding regime would be phased in over a number of years to give parents a chance to start saving. Eventually prestigious institutions such as Oxbridge would be able to charge fees for degree courses at a similar market rate to the top Ivy League institutions.

Annual fees for university tuition can be as much $25,000 in the US, about £17,000 a year. But poorer students benefit from an extensive system of scholarships and loans.

"My proposal is to suggest that the US model can work in the UK," said Professor David Blanchflower, head of economics at Dartmouth College in the US: "The rich can pay whatever the market price is. Those who cannot pay can be subsidised. Educational giving and saving should be made tax deductible - probably at the standard rate. Universities should be allowed to charge whatever price they like but be required to accept a diverse student body that reflects the characteristics of the population."

Blanchflower is part of the team of economists who have set out future funding options for universities in a report to the 19 Russell Group elite university heads. Earlier reports that the economists were considering proposals to charge fees of up to £7,000 a year have been completely denied by the vice-chancellors, most of whom only read the report for the first time this week.

Opinions also vary dramatically among the heads, who plan to issue a statement on the funding options. The study applies to all universities and will be submitted to a broader study being carried out by all the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals. But the case for fees is likely to gather momentum.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn is expected this week to continue the government's campaign against elitism in universities by proposing new incentives for medical schools to broaden their student intakes. And yet in private, universities have been told to expect further cuts in teaching budgets when the Whitehall spending review concludes next month.

A new study, meanwhile, suggests that by the far the most serious deterrent to students from poor backgrounds enrolling in elite institutions is not admissions policies but looming debts. A survey of Scottish university students by University of Glasgow researchers Dr Alisdair Forsyth and Professor Andy Furlong for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation has found that, since the withdrawal of student maintenance grants, applications to local institutions have increased.

"For many students from less advantaged families, the option to study away from home has been removed," say the preliminary conclusions. "Under these circumstances, any adjustment to admission policies will simply lead to more places in elite institutions for young people from relatively advantaged families who have been schooled in the state sector."

A report to be published by the Sutton Trust, meanwhile, is expected to expose under-representation of students from state schools and poor backgrounds not just at Oxbridge, but throughout the large research driven universities which make up the Russell Group.

fields.headline: Dash for cash?
fields.standfirst: Graham Wade assesses whether the government's new training salary for teachers has had any impact on recruitment of graduates into the profession
fields.trailText: Graham Wade assesses whether the government's new training salary for teachers has had any impact on recruitment of graduates into the profession
fields.body:
Last year's conference of the Secondary Heads Association warned that under-recruitment of students for postgraduate certificate in education (PGCE) courses was so severe that soon schools would be unable to teach the full national curriculum. Longstanding shortages of secondary teachers in areas such as maths and science were spreading rapidly to disciplines like modern languages and geography.

The government responded with a massive advertising campaign, and in March announced that all PGCE students would receive a minimum £6,000 training salary. This marked a distinct U-turn on its previous policy of abolishing maintenance grants which had caused a downturn in student numbers in the first place.

So far the reaction on the ground to the new money appears to be mixed. The Teacher Training Agency saw a significant increase in inquiries during the weeks following the original announcement. In science, for instance, calls were up from 180 to 315, and in design and technology from 103 to 172. However, the increase in applications to, and those accepted on, PGCE courses has been less dramatic, leaving the teacher-training institutions still in a worse position than they were at this stage last year.

At Newcastle University's education department, director of secondary education, Sally Taverner, expresses guarded optimism: "We have experienced a slight increase in the number of inquiries about courses, especially from mature students for whom finance is a key issue. In the shortage subject of maths, we have a target of 27 places to fill and so far we look like having allocated 14 of those."

Ms Taverner believes the only long-term solution to the recruitment crisis is to boost confidence in teaching and teachers: "There should be much more support from ministers and a much better press. Instead of being slammed by Ofsted, teachers should be praised."

At Warwick University's institute of education, Professor Chris Husbands welcomes the introduction of training salaries. "It will allow institutions to treat students as employees with rights and responsibilities." But he admits that Warwick's recruitment of maths PGCE students is still running below the level achieved at this point last year. So far, about a third of the 38 vacancies have been assigned, although he believes that, by the start of the course, some 25 students will have been found. In IT, not even half of the available places will be filled.

While training salaries may improve PGCE numbers by about 10 per cent this year, they are not a magic wand, says Professor Husbands: "It is going to be a long haul to get back to a healthy level of recruitment in secondary subjects.

Teacher Training Agency: Communication Centre, Freepost ANG2053, Chelmsford, Essex CM1 322, telephone 01245 454 454

fields.headline: Time to govern
fields.trailText: As the government replies to the Better Regulation Taskforce, questions about governors as volunteers will no doubt be raised.
fields.body:
As the government replies to the Better Regulation Taskforce, questions about governors as volunteers will no doubt be raised. Many governors feel that the time and expertise now required to do a proper job are beyond what can reasonably be expected and diligent heads find themselves spending more and more time supporting them. Current recommendations suggest scaling down responsibilities and reducing the role of governors. But what about making the current system more effective by supporting the volunteer principle on which it is based?

Volunteer governors need time to exercise their duties during the school day. Under employment law, they have the right to reasonable time off work for public duties in the same way as JPs and local councillors. However, until there is also an obligation on employers to grant paid time off, many governors won't have exercised this right. The mantra that governors need to meet outside the working day should be challenged.

The reasonable expenses of volunteer governors should also be met. Not surprisingly, governors have been their own worst enemy here, given the parlous state of many school budgets. Travel expenses, an attendance allowance and other reasonable expenses (except loss of earnings) can be claimed and each governing body should have a policy on this. This would help to encourage the widest possible voluntary participation, particularly in areas of socio-economic deprivation.

Most of all, volunteers need professional support and advice. The Code of Practice on LEA-school relations highlights the provision of "appropriate" training and information. But what is appropriate? A minimum entitlement could be induction training plus an annual refresher course on relevant legislation and educational developments. Add to this a training day each year focused on school improvement, professional clerking and training for chair, and the business of governance could be streamlined at a stroke.

 Jane Martin is an education officer with Dudley LEA with responsibility for school governance and development. She writes here in a personal capacity.

fields.headline: Fair and square
fields.standfirst: Pupils, staff and parents at Hampton junior school are in stitches over their novel maths project
fields.trailText: Pupils, staff and parents at Hampton junior school are in stitches over their novel maths project
fields.body:
The proud Norman, Bishop Odo, commissioned the Bayeux Tapestry to show the defeat of the Anglo-Saxons on a battlefield near Hastings. Except it wasn't a tapestry, it was an embroidery. Nearly 1,000 years later, the staff, pupils and parents of Hampton junior school in Middlesex have produced their own triumph of the art of needlework - a visual representation of the Maths 2000 "100" square. Except it isn't a tapestry either.

The square was the brainchild of maths co-ordinator, Jackie Stevens. The government drive to raise standards in numeracy places a strong emphasis on the number 100 to teach children about numbers. Stevens wanted to present this in a new, permanent way, as something that pupils would be able to see and use on a daily basis. She came up with the idea of producing a giant patchwork to represent this magical square. With the help of a £2,000 grant, the vision became a reality.

Stevens says: "I was aware of the need to produce something that would involve lots of parents and the school community as a whole. I used a computer to produce the templates, and then we worked as a team to cut out the material and prepare the patches. Just after Easter, myself, two other members of staff and 10 parents got together to sew all the patches together." Pupils in years 5 and 6 took a key role in helping to plan and calculate the total amount of fabric needed for the project.

The finished product is three metres square, and can be moved around the school thanks to the donation by Parkgate Timber, of Hampton Hill, of a specially made pole and brackets. It currently resides in the school hall. On the front of the patchwork, symbols are sewn onto the squares to show the special properties of certain numbers. For example, a circle to show a prime number, a triangle for a triangular number and a square for a square number.

Now that year 6 have finished their SATs, Stevens plans to utilise the imagination of her young mathematicians once again. "We'll use ICT lessons to get the pupils to come up with some ideas for activities and games that could be done with the square to learn about numbers."

Whether the Hampton maths patchwork will still be pored over in 1,000 years as the Bayeux Tapestry is now, has yet to be seen. But one thing's for certain - it all adds up to an enjoyable, interactive way for youngsters to learn their sums.

webTitle: 'I know I'm funny. I don't have to go out and prove it'

fields.headline: 'I know I'm funny. I don't have to go out and prove it'
fields.standfirst: David Duchovny tells  Emma Brockes  about life beyond The X-Files
fields.trailText: David Duchovny tells Emma Brockes about life beyond The X-Files
fields.body:
There is a scene near the beginning of David Duchovny's new movie in which the actor is seen applying a hairdryer to his trousers in the moments before an important ceremony. He is goofing about on one foot while his wife, played by Joely Richardson, looks on in an "isn't my husband adorable?" reverie and the dog huffs and puffs on the floor between them. For those whose knowledge of Duchovny derives solely from his role as agent Fox Mulder in the X-Files, a man to whom the concepts of romance and comedy are the most alien he'll ever encounter, it is an uncomfortable moment. The very act of smiling seems undignified on the lips of an actor whose emotional range has come to be characterised by various shades of the unamused.

Once over the initial shock, however, Return to Me is a surprisingly likeable film. Written and directed by Bonnie Hunt, it is the story of a woman who receives a heart transplant from the dead wife of the man she comes to fall in love with. Duchovny is the widower, Minnie Driver the post-op sweetheart and, if you can stomach the dodgy symbolism and the sentimental portrait of Chicago's ethnic communities, it is a witty and old-fashioned fairy tale that leaves you feeling well disposed towards them both. For Duchovny, it is a chance to prove that he has more expressions in his repertoire than scepticism, although he insists that's not why he did it. "I know I'm funny, I don't have to go out and prove it. I don't understand why I would have to prove that I'm funny. I do what I do and I'll do what's interesting to me. But the idea of proving anything to anyone is just weird to me. I don't give a shit."

This is delivered deadpan, like a well-buried joke, although he doesn't appear to be joking. While unfailingly courteous, his professional manner has the unfortunate effect of hanging somewhere between arrogance and conceit. When we return to the subject of him not having to prove himself, he mutters that it's "bullshit", as if it were a line he has grown weary of. He retains the faintly superior air of one whose inner life is beyond the reach of the people that surround him.

Duchovny, who is 40 this year, was born in New York to a Scottish, working-class mother and a father whose family originally came from Russia. He was as American as the next kid, he says, but unlike many of his friends, was able to perceive his culture with a certain amount of detached interest. "My mother was definitely an outsider and not shy about speaking about that. I felt like a New Yorker, but I knew there was another way of life."

It is a perspective he values. When Duchovny won a scholarship to a prestigious prep school, he didn't establish himself as the loud kid or the show-off. He had skill on the sports field and, up until the end of high school his ambition was to become a professional athlete. But he was happier in the role of observer and it' i something he worries that success is denying him. "As an actor and as a writer, I like to watch. But people become watchful when they come into contact with somebody famous. They don't act like themselves any more. It's sad. I can't complain about it, but I kind of miss... it is what it is."

His watchfulness did not translate into infatuation or groupie-dom or any of the props of teenage identity crisis. The portrait Duchovny paints of his teenage self is of a boy as measured in his emotions as he is now, self-possessed, straightforward, so that you wonder where his private self is or what it would take to shake him out of composure. "I kind of dreamed about being a famous athlete; not wanting to be famous but wanting to be good enough so that everybody knew who I was. But it wasn't fame for fame's sake. I didn't know what fame was really. I didn't know anyone famous; I didn't know any actors when I was growing up; I didn't understand what acting was. When I watched television I didn't think, I wonder what they do when they go home. I didn't want to read about them. I just watched TV. I never dreamed of shaking anyone's hand. Even with sports heroes, I liked watching them, I loved them from afar, but I didn't want to get to know them."

When the X-Files became popular, its creator, Chris Carter, wanted to be photographed alongside the stars. Duchovny advised against it. "I just said, you're so lucky, you're making money and you're creatively challenged, and you're doing what you want to do. Don't let go of your anonymity. People think that it's fun, but then there are repercussions."

When he left school, Duchovny won a place at Princeton, and later a place to study for a masters degree in English literature at Yale, where he was taught by Harold Bloom. ("I knew the work of Derrida and Paul de Man. It's like reading surgical text books. I know how to read them.") He was a short way into a PhD thesis on magic and technology in contemporary poetry and prose, when he began acting to help fund his studies. At a friend's suggestion, he auditioned for and won the lead role in an advert for Lowenbrau beer. An agent spotted him and his career began.

Writing is still a major interest. After years of making the X-Files, Duchovny was virtually on autopilot and revived his interest in the show by asking if he could have a go at writing an episode and if it was any good, directing it. To date, he has done two. His other passion, athletics, is something he still draws on as a metaphor for the challenges in his career. Of acting, he has said: "It is not thinking, it is feeling. It is athletic, in the sense that it is instinctual. You can lose your self-consciousness, you become like an animal without notions of the past or the future. And that feels good."

Minnie Driver is like a "good tennis partner", he says, always returning the ball. "She is real quick and funny and game and she's real respectful. We got on really well." Appearing on confrontational US talk shows is like revving up for a football game: "At first, when I did Letterman, it was like sports, it was terrifying and you'd come out of it and it was OK, it was a great achievement."

Like a professional sportsman, articulating his personality is not a great priority. Near the end of the interview, however, a flash of something more interesting appears, calculated as a reward. "My fear was that this could be a slushy movie," Duchovny says about Return to Me. "There was a lot of anxiety. Even though I believed in it, it doesn't mean anything. It could still have been a piece of shit. It wasn't like I knew all along that this was the right tone. There were days when I thought, oh my god, I don't know whether what I'm doing is right or wrong for this movie, and I just agonised." Then, just as quickly, he is gone.

 Return to Me is out on Friday.

fields.headline: Robert Dunbar
fields.standfirst: During a lifetime in film, he worked on masterpieces, founded a school and persuaded Orson Welles to appear in The Third Man
fields.trailText: The film producer and writer Robert Dunbar, who has died aged 85, was one of the last British links to the joint Anglo-German film productions of the early days of sound cinema.
fields.body:
The film producer and writer Robert Dunbar, who has died aged 85, was one of the last British links to the joint Anglo-German film productions of the early days of sound cinema.

His father, one of the founders of Odhams Press and creator of the Daily Herald, sent him to Bryanston school. Then, instead of taking a place at Christ Church, Oxford, he accepted an unpaid apprenticeship at Gaumont-British, and was sent to the Ufa studios in Babelsberg as a publicity writer and general assistant on the English version of a frothy operetta, Ich und die Kaiserin (The Only Girl), to be directed by Friedrich Hollaender, the composer for The Blue Angel and Congress Dances.

To lower production costs and ensure the film an international market, German, French and English versions were shot simultaneously on the same sets - German in the morning, French in the afternoon, English in the evening. Dunbar was put to work as a dialogue coach to Lilian Harvey, one of the German leads. His other tasks involved entertaining visitors, and guiding the actor Ernest Thesiger round Berlin's homosexual night clubs.

A month after the film opened in Germany, Hitler became chancellor and, along with other foreign film workers, Bob was expelled from the country. He returned to Gaumont-British and Gainsborough studios to take up modest duties as a scriptwriter, before becoming assistant director to the poet and film-maker Berthold Viertel on Little Friend. Dunbar was to co-write Viertel's next film, The Unchained Eagle, which depicted the poet Byron, not as a figure of sexual scandal but as a fighter for freedom. The studio head, Michael Balcon, concerned about the allusions to Hitler, consulted the Foreign Office and then rejected it.

Within a year, Bob had moved to Alexander Korda's London Films, primarily as a production manager, working with René Clair on The Ghost Goes West and William Cameron Menzies on HG Wells's Things To Come, where his primary role was to keep the interfering author off the set by taking him for long walks around Denham studios.

In 1937, with the near total collapse of British film production, Bob found it increasingly difficult to get work and, two years later, he took off for Hollywood, en route making a detour to Mexico, where he met his future wife, Tatiana, the daughter of elite Russian émigrés. When the second world war broke out, he registered at the British consulate and they married. He was soon seconded to the Ministry of Information, and later moved to the Foreign Office as deputy head of the inter-allied information office in Mexico and the Caribbean.

In November 1944, Bob was posted to Moscow in charge of press, public and cultural relations at the British embassy. He also edited a newspaper, British Ally. The film director Sergei Eisenstein would frequently dine at the Dunbars' rat-infested flat and, on one occasion, waited in the dark of the kitchen to catch a rodent, which he proudly presented on a covered dish.

When the family returned to England in 1947, Bob contacted Alexander Korda, then producing Graham Greene's The Third Man. Carol Reed, its director, sent him from Vienna to Rome to persuade Orson Welles to play Harry Lime. Welles asked Bob how a person of "such intellectual integrity could work for a fucking film company" - but finally agreed an arrangement, which included two silk suits. Later, Bob produced a series of documentaries for Associated Rediffusion, half of which were to be directed by Welles, although, in the event, he failed to turn up.

After a spell as production manager at Imperadio Pictures, Bob joined the founding father of British documentary films, John Grierson, as a producer at Group III, a film unit closely linked to the Association of Cinematographic Technicians (ACT), the then trade union of the industry. Michael Balcon, Group III's chairman, had sent Bob to invite Grierson to manage it. Group III took over a former Southall bus depot as a studio and produced some interesting projects, notably The Brave Don't Cry. But Group III quickly floundered. Bob considered that, in part, this was because Balcon, who was also head of Ealing Studios, forced scripts on it which Ealing had developed but not produced.

After a spell making comedies for Hammer Films, including Life With The Lyons, Bob produced one of his best and most successful films, The Man Upstairs (1958), which was directed by Don Chaffey and starred Richard Attenborough, Bernard Lee and Donald Houston.

With the industry in a continuous struggle for survival, he gradually moved towards teaching, first at a small art school in Brixton, south London, which he bought in 1957 and renamed the London School of Film Technique. Its success inspired the creation of numerous film schools throughout the country. In 1966, it became the London Film School, and still survives as the London International Film School.

Bob was able to call on many young film directors - including Nicolas Roeg, Clive Donner and Charles Crichton - to teach there. Bob and Tatiana, who became the school's secretary, wanted it to become the National Film School, but this was vigorously opposed by the ACT general secretary, George Elvin, who believed that a state-maintained organisation was essential.

In 1974, following Edward Heath's introduction of the three-day week, applications from abroad suddenly fell. Bob, who had never taken a salary, was forced out, and the school was taken over by a group that included many whom he had supported and helped over the years. Bob was not bitter, and maintained loyalty to friends and to the union.

He spent his retirement going to film festivals and landscaping gardens for his friends. He was devoted to Tatiana and their four children, Marina, John, Jennifer and Margaret. He and Tat- iana were also legal guardians to Nicholas, the son John had with Marianne Faithfull.

Robert Dunbar, film producer, writer, director and poet, born June 6 1914; died April 26 2000
